editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

A Methodicall Collection of Å¿uch Statutes and CuÅ¿tomes, with the CaÅ¿es, Opinions, Arguments and points of Learning in the LAVV, as doe properly concerne WOMEN. Together with a compendious Table, whereby the chiefe matters in this BOOKE contained, may be the more readily found.
LONDON; Printed by the aÅ¿Å¿ignes of IOHN MORE EÅ¿q and are to be Å¿old by IOHN GROVE, at his Shop neere the Rowles in Chancery-Lane, over againÅ¿t the Sixe-Clerkesâª Office. 1632.

div.head: A PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p: VArious are the Conceipts and Judgements of Men: Nature teacheth each to preferre his Owne; Hence it is, that the number of Bookes multiply, inÅ¿omuch, that, according to the WiÅ¿e-man; Thereof, is no end.

To expect new Matter, were to give the old Proverb the Lie; Nihil jam dictum, &c. It's enough, if what was before, be now Å¿o changed by Method
and Application, that it Å¿hewes as new, and becomes more ready for Æ²Å¿e. Habit and Apparell alter the Shape, Å¿ometimes the Conditions of Men. An old Theame in a new dreÅ¿Å¿e ingenuouÅ¿ly contrived makes the CompoÅ¿er an Author. Why then Å¿hould this Booke bluÅ¿h to Å¿hew it Å¿elfe? or doubt to bee Å¿ervant to the Printer, whoÅ¿e MaÅ¿ter nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e it is?

To give it as abÅ¿olute, or free from faults, were to make it more then the Worke of Man, whoÅ¿e incident is Error: Such as it hath, are rather accidentall then originall, and may bee fairly excuÅ¿ed; Not to inÅ¿iÅ¿t, That the Author's dead, That it was long Å¿ince collected, Alteration of Å¿ome CaÅ¿es by Moderne Statutes, Or this the firÅ¿t ImpreÅ¿sion. GoodneÅ¿Å¿e is the Parent of Confidence; The Act is crowned by
the End, which was this, A publique Advantage and peculiar Service to that Sexe generally beloved, and by the Author had in venerable eÅ¿timation. To implore their Patronage, and prevaile, were to guard this Booke beyond OppoÅ¿ition. The Å¿trong neither needs nor deÅ¿ires a Champion; Meeknes protects it Å¿elfe: What here you finde reall and perfect, therefore accept; It will Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t; Remit the reÅ¿t, the rather for that nor the Tract, nor This is peremptory, But onely propoÅ¿ed for your favorable Å¿enÅ¿e and Approbation.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
BY whom this following DISCOVRSE was CompoÅ¿ed I certainly know not, neither by what inducement the Authors paines therein was procured: But if for no other conÅ¿ideration then to make this Å¿cattered part of Learning, in the great Volumes of the Common-Law-Bookes, and there darkly deÅ¿cribed, to be one entyre body, and more ready, and clearer to the view of the Reader, his love deÅ¿erves thanks, and his endeavours
kinde acceptance. The VVorke hath beene carefully, and with much labour and diligence collected: The Theame, as the Å¿ubject, is, The Lawes ReÅ¿olutions of Womens Rights; which comprehends all our Lawes concerning VVomen, either Children in government or nurture of their Parents or Gardians, Mayds, VVives, and VVidowes, and their goods, inheritances, and other eÅ¿tates. It is profitable and uÅ¿efull Learning to be well knowne. I am Å¿ure it will pleaÅ¿e all them whoÅ¿e actions are guided virtutis amore, and offend none but thoÅ¿e ill manners, who can have no other antidote made them, then formidine poenae: for it Å¿ets forth Law, and IuÅ¿tice, things honeÅ¿t, and things convenient. I had Å¿uch a good conceit of the matter and frame of the
whole VVorke, that having a Copie there of lying by me Å¿omtimes, within the CompaÅ¿Å¿e of a Lent vacation, I pluckt my intentions from my own courÅ¿e of Studies, and caÅ¿t them upon this. And thoÅ¿e vitia Scriptoris, and Authoris, which I found, I amended, and haue added many reaÅ¿ons, opinions, CaÅ¿es and reÅ¿olutions of CaÅ¿es to the Authors Å¿tore: wherfore thoÅ¿e overÅ¿ights or neglects that thou maiÅ¿t impoÅ¿e upon the Printer or mee, (which I Å¿uppoÅ¿e wil be Å¿ome (if not many) thou Å¿halt have thanks to Å¿upply or amend, which is all I expected, and more then the Author, as I beleeve, had (or now being dead can receive:) and perhaps thou maiÅ¿t have a better reward; for the old Adage is true, pretium non vile laboris.

div.head: THE WOMANS LAWIER.
SECT. I.
div.p:
ALl Law, Å¿aith IuÅ¿tinian in his Imperiall inÅ¿titutions, belongeth to perÅ¿ons, to things, or to actions: which diviÅ¿ion I acknowledge to bee good: and Å¿o in his method of the Civil Law, doth a Doctor and very learned man, Conradus Lagus, yet the Å¿ame Lagus Å¿aith, it is too Å¿trait for his purpoÅ¿e, and therefore not fÃ©eling himÅ¿elfe at eaÅ¿e in Å¿o narrow a diÅ¿tribution, to drive the formes of Civill Law to certaine heads, according to their materiall varieties, hÃ©e confeÅ¿Å¿eth hÃ©e i â¢ compelled to conÅ¿titute a pluralitie of Law members more then the very Law Å¿etteth down as appeareth in the 2. Part of his Method the 2. Chapter, yet a curious Caviler (I perceive) might find in IuÅ¿tinians partition a very great red â¢â¢ dance rather then any defect, for Res is a tranÅ¿cendente, comprehending actions, perÅ¿ons, and what not. And actions in the wideÅ¿t Å¿ignification
Å¿Ã©eme alone to bÃ©e the theame and right Å¿ubject matter of Lawes and all Humane ConÅ¿titutions: as for perÅ¿ons they are Å¿o many, and Å¿o differing, that I thinke there is no uÅ¿e, CuÅ¿tome, Injunction or decrÃ©e, but it appertaineth to Å¿ome perÅ¿on, and that in Å¿ome peculiarity of difference, either in Å¿tate, age, Å¿ex, function, profeÅ¿Å¿ion, merit, or Å¿ome other like Å¿everall regard, Å¿o that in mine opinion, Law might bÃ©e diÅ¿perÅ¿ed into apt titles of this perÅ¿onall difference, in Å¿uch Å¿ort as both Students, might come to the eaÅ¿ier knowledge: the one of their learning generall, and the other of their particular duty. I though I bÃ©e farre unable to produce a perfect method of the Lawes of England, as Lagus following his owne artificial project hath framed an excellent Deliniation of the Lawes of Rome, and though I bÃ©e unworthy to have the MarÅ¿halling of the titles of Lawe to bring all matter cohering under them, yet I will make a little aÅ¿Å¿ay what I am able to doe if I were put to it in a popular kind of inÅ¿truction: following a frame by diÅ¿tinction of perÅ¿ons, chaÅ¿ing the primary diÅ¿tribution of them made before the World was Å¿even daies old, MaÅ¿culum & Foeminam fecit eo â¢ , of which diviÅ¿ion becauÅ¿e the part that wÃ©e Å¿ay hath leaÅ¿t judgement and diÅ¿cretion to bÃ©e a Law unto it Å¿elfe, (Women onelyâª Women) they have nothing to do in conÅ¿tituting Lawes, or conÅ¿enting to them, in interpreting of Lawes, or in hearing them interpreted at lectures, leets or charges, and yet they Å¿tand Å¿trictly tyed to mens eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hments; little or nothing excuÅ¿ed by ignorance, mÃ©e thinkes it were pitty and impiety any longer to hold from them Å¿uch CuÅ¿tomes, Lawes, and Statutes, as are in a maner, proper, or principally belonging unto them: Laying aÅ¿ide therefore theÅ¿e titles which include onely the maÅ¿culine, as BiÅ¿hop, Abbot, Prior, Monke, Deane and Chapter, ViÅ¿count, Coroner, together with thoÅ¿e which bÃ©e common to both kinds, as Hereticke, Traitour, Homicide, Felon, Laron, Paricide, CutpurÅ¿e, Rogue, with Feoffor, FeoffÃ©e, Donor, DonÃ©e, Vendor, VendÃ©e, RecogniÅ¿or,
RecogniÅ¿Ã©e, &c. I will in this Treaty with as little tediouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e as I can, handle that part of the EngliÅ¿h Lawe, which containeth the immunities, advantages, intereÅ¿ts, and duties of women, not regarding Å¿o much to Å¿atiÅ¿fie the dÃ©ep learned or Å¿earchers for Å¿ubtility, as woman kind, to whom I am a thankfull debter by nature.

div.head: SECT. II. The Creation of Man and Woman.
div.p: GOd the firÅ¿t day when hÃ©e created the World made the matter of it, Å¿eparating light from darkeneÅ¿Å¿e: the Å¿econd day hÃ©e placed the Firmament which hÃ©e called Heaven, betwixt the waters above the Firmament and the waters under the Firmament: the third day hÃ©e Å¿egregated the waters under the Firmament into one place, calling the waters Seas, and the dry land Earth, which hÃ©e commanded to bring forth â¢ ructifying herbes, plants and trees: the fourth day hÃ©e made the Sun, the Moone and the Stares in the Firmament, to bÃ©e for Signes, SeaÅ¿ons, Daies and Yeres, and to give light upon the earth: the fift day he made by his Word the FiÅ¿hes of the Sea, Whales and every fethered foule of the ayre, commanding them to increaÅ¿e: the Å¿ixt day he made Cattle, crÃ©eping things, the beaÅ¿ts of the Earth: and now having made all things that Å¿hould be nÃ©edfull for them, hÃ©e created Man, Male and Female made he them, Bidding them multiply and repleniÅ¿h the Earth, & take the joynt Å¿overaigntie over the FiÅ¿hes of the Sea, the Foules of the Ayre, and over all BeaÅ¿ts moving upon the Earth, GeneÅ¿is 1.

In the Å¿econd Chapter MoÅ¿es declareth and expreÅ¿Å¿eth the Creation of Women, which word in good Å¿enÅ¿e, Å¿ignifieth not the woe of Man as Å¿ome affirme, but with Man: For Å¿o in our haÅ¿ty pronouncing wÃ©e turne the prepoÅ¿ition with to woe, or wÃ©e, oftentimes: and Å¿o Å¿hÃ©e was ordained to bÃ©e with man as a helpe, & a companion, becauÅ¿e God Å¿aw it was not good that Man Å¿hould bÃ©e alone. Then when God brought Woman to Man to bÃ©e named by him, hÃ©e found Å¿traight way that Å¿hÃ©e was bone of his bones, fleÅ¿h of his fleÅ¿h, giving her a name, teÅ¿tifying Å¿hÃ©e was taken out of Man, and he pronounced that for her Å¿ake man Å¿hould leave Father and Mother and adhere to his Wife which Å¿hould be with him one.

div.head: Now Man and Woman are one.
div.p:
NOw becauÅ¿e Adam hath Å¿o pronounced that man and wife Å¿hall be but one fleÅ¿h, and our Law is that if a feofment bÃ©e made joyntly to Iohn at Stile and to Thom. Nokeâª and his wife, of thrÃ©e acres of land, that Thoâª and his wife get no more but one acre and a halfe, quia una perÅ¿ona, and a writ of conÅ¿piracy doth not lye againÅ¿t one onely, and that is the reaÅ¿on, Nat. br. â¢ o. 116. a writ of conÅ¿piracy doth not lie againÅ¿t baron & feme, for they are but one perÅ¿on, & by this a married Woman perhaps may either doubt whether Å¿hÃ©e bÃ©e either none or no more then halfe a perÅ¿on. But let her bÃ©e of good cheare, though for the nÃ©ere conjunction which is betwÃ©ene man and wife, and to tye them to a perfect love, agreement and adherence, they bÃ©e by intent and wiÅ¿e fiction of Law, one perÅ¿on, yet in nature & in Å¿ome other caÅ¿es by the Law of God and man, they remaine divers, for as Adams puniÅ¿hment was Å¿everall from Eves, Å¿o in criminall and other Å¿peciall cauÅ¿es our Law argues them Å¿everall perÅ¿ons, you Å¿hall finde that perÅ¿ona is an Individuum Å¿poken of any thing which hath reaÅ¿on, and therefore of nothing but Vel de Angelo, vel de homme, fol. 154. in Dyer, who citeth
no worÅ¿e authority for it then Callepinus owne Å¿elfe, Å¿Ã©eing therefore I liÅ¿t not to doubt with Plato, whether Women bÃ©e reaÅ¿onable or unreaÅ¿onable creatures, I may not doubt but every woman is a temporall perÅ¿on, though no woman can be a Å¿pirituall Vicar.

div.head: Of Hermaphrodites.
div.p:
OF Hermaphrodites I have Å¿ome kind of doubts, not whether they bÃ©e perÅ¿ons, but what perÅ¿ons they bÃ©e, If a man die Å¿eiÅ¿ed, leaving 3. children which bee all Hermaphrodites, whether the eldeÅ¿t Å¿hall have all his land, or that it bÃ©e partable as among coheires. AlÅ¿o if the eldeÅ¿t bÃ©e a Hermaphrodite, and the other 2. faire young Virgins which way jetteth the diÅ¿cent. Bracton in his firÅ¿t Booke, Cap. 7. Å¿aith, Hermaphroditus comparatur maÅ¿culo tantum, vel feminae tantum, Å¿ecundum praevaleÅ¿centiam Å¿exus i â¢
caleÅ¿centis, that is, it muÅ¿t bÃ©e dÃ©emed male or female, according to the predominance of the Å¿ex moÅ¿t inciting.

And as I remember I have read the like diviÅ¿ion,V â¢ . Britt. Cont. Å¿ol. 1678. Bracton in his firÅ¿t book the 30. Chapter fol. 438. where hee Å¿heweth that a man Å¿hall not be tenant by the courtiÅ¿ie Si partus declinaverit ad monÅ¿truÌ, & cum clamore emitteret deberet, emiÅ¿it rugituÌ, Å¿aith, it is not partus monÅ¿troÅ¿us, licet natura membra m â¢ nuerit, vel ampliaverit, ut Å¿i quis habeat digitos, aut articulos Å¿ex vel plures. Now then if theÅ¿e creatures bee no MonÅ¿ters, but are in conjunction to take on theÌ the kind which is moÅ¿t ruling in theÌ, this muÅ¿t nÃ©eds be underÅ¿tood in matrimony, and conÅ¿equently they may have heires, which being granted, why may they not be heires according to the prevaleÅ¿cence which Bracton Å¿peaketh of: if I were to furniÅ¿h my Å¿elfe a houÅ¿e, I would place no picture or Image in any parlour, dining or bed-chamber, but it Å¿hould be of good Å¿Ã©emely and natural proportion, Satyres and Centaures Å¿hould come no nearer then the poÅ¿t
at my doore. And at the threÅ¿hold of this my treatiÅ¿e, or as it were a little behind the doore: I will leave theÅ¿e deformed Children of Mercury, or Venus, Å¿uffering them to enter no further.

div.head: SECT. III. The puniÅ¿hment of Adams Å¿inne.
div.p: REturne a little to GeneÅ¿is, in the 3. Chap. whereof is declared our firÅ¿t parents tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion in eating the forbidden fruit: for which Adam, Eve, the Å¿erpent firÅ¿t, and laÅ¿tly, the earth it Å¿elfe is curÅ¿ed: and beÅ¿ides, the participation of Adams puniÅ¿hment, which was Å¿ubjection to mortality, exiled from the garden of Eden, injoyned to labor, Eve becauÅ¿e Å¿hÃ©e had helped to Å¿educe her huÅ¿band hath inflicted on her, an eÅ¿peciall bane. In Å¿orrow Å¿halt thou bring forth thy children, thy deÅ¿ires Å¿hall bee Å¿ubject to thy husband, and he Å¿hall rule over thee.

SÃ©e here the reaÅ¿on of that which I touched before, that Women have no voyÅ¿e in Parliament, They make no Lawes, they conÅ¿ent to none, they abrogate none. All of them are underÅ¿tood either married or to bÃ©e married and their deÅ¿ires or Å¿ubject to their huÅ¿band, I know no remedy though Å¿ome women can Å¿hift it well enough. The common Law here Å¿haketh hand with Divinitie, but becauÅ¿e I am come too Å¿oone to the title of Baron and feme, and Adam and Eve were the firÅ¿t and laÅ¿t that were maried Å¿o young, it is beÅ¿t that I runne backe againe to conÅ¿ider of the things (which I might Å¿eeme to have loÅ¿t by the way) that are fit to be knowne concerning women before they be fit for marriage.

div.head: SECT. IV. The Ages of a Woman.
div.p: THe learning is 35. Hen. 6. fol. 40. that a Woman hath divers Å¿peciall ages, at the 7. yeare of her age, her father Å¿hall have aide of his tenants to marry her. At 9. yeares age, Å¿hee is able to deÅ¿erve and have dowre. At 12. yeares to conÅ¿ent to marriage. At 14. to bee hors du guard: at 16. to be paÅ¿t the Lords tender of a husband. At 21. to be able to make a feoffement: And per Ingelton there in the end of the caÅ¿e, a woman married at 12. cannot diÅ¿agrÃ©e afterward, but if Å¿he be married younger, Å¿hee may diÅ¿Å¿ent till Å¿hee be 14.

The age of 7. yeares, when Bracton wrote this aide, for making the Å¿onne a Knight, or marrying the daughter, was due de gratia & non de Iure, and pro neceÅ¿Å¿itate & indigentia domini capitalis: meaÅ¿ured by the indigence of the Lord, and opulence of the tenants: But WeÅ¿t. 1. Cap. 35. in the third yeare of Edward 1. the Law was made certaine, the Lord Å¿hall have aide of his tenants, as Å¿oone as his daughter accompliÅ¿hed 7. yeares age-for the marriage of her. Viz. xx. s. of a whole knights fÃ©e, and xx. s. of xx. I. â¢ and in Å¿occage, and Å¿o forth, according to the rate more or leÅ¿Å¿e.

The King Å¿hall have this aide according to this proportion, by a Statute made 25. Ed. 3. and for this aide every Lord may either diÅ¿traine or bring his writ de auxilio habendo at his election, but tenant by grand Å¿erjeanty, or petit, Å¿hall not pay this aide. Mich. 21. He. 4. fol. 32. no more Å¿hall coppy-holders, as Å¿Ã©emeth by the writ, both in Fitzherbert and Bracton, for it is, Precipimus ut habere facias rationabile auxilium de Militibus, et liberetenentibus. Now if the Kings writ runne for it before the Statute, how is it that Bracton Å¿aith it was due, but de gratis, That perhaps
he meant but for the quantity, ipÅ¿e videri â¢ , if the father dye, the daughter being unmarried, Å¿hee Å¿hall recover Å¿o much as was gathered and not paied her at the hands of the executor or heire, but this aide is onely for the marriage of the eldeÅ¿t daughter, and not for no daughter, where many make but one heire: But Å¿Ã©e Bracton fol. 36. b. Where he Å¿aith, primae genitae filiae non dabitur auxilium tale, quia iÅ¿tud auxilium pertinet ad Cap. dom. Å¿icut pertineret Å¿i non eÅ¿Å¿et niÅ¿i unus haeres cum omnes Å¿unt quaÅ¿i unus h â¢ eres.

div.head: SECT. V. A Woman compellable to Å¿erve.
div.p: THe next age of a Woman is 9. yeares when Å¿hee is dowable, but wee will Å¿tay a while with the virgins, concerning whom, if they be in the power and governance of parents, maÅ¿ters, or prochein amies, or if they bee poore, the Law differeth little or not much from the common forme apperteyning unto males, unleÅ¿Å¿e it been in caÅ¿es of rape, which I reÅ¿erve to the end of my diÅ¿courÅ¿e, where the poore have leaÅ¿t need of Å¿ubÅ¿idie, onely this I obÅ¿erve here, By a Statute made 5. Eliz. ca. 4. Two IuÅ¿tices of peace in the Countrie, or the head officer and 2. BurgeÅ¿Å¿es in Cities, &c. may appoint any woman of the age of twelue yeares, and under 40. being unmaried, and out of Å¿ervice, to Å¿erve and bee retained by yeare, weeke, or day, in Å¿uch Å¿ort and for Å¿uch wages as they Å¿hall thinke mÃ©et, and if Å¿he refuÅ¿e, they may commit her to priÅ¿on, till Å¿he Å¿hall be bound to Å¿erve.

div.head: SECT. VI. Of Heires.
div.p:
BVt leaving this Å¿ort to the title of day laborers, come we to women wards in the cuÅ¿tody of their lords. And
take for the foundation here the Statute it Å¿elfe WeÅ¿t. 1. Cap. 22. This Statute expreÅ¿ly reciting the materiall point of the Statute of Merton, willeth it in every of them to be obÅ¿erved, Merton Cap. 6. and the Statute of Merton is this, WhoÅ¿oever lay perÅ¿on Å¿hall bee convicted bee hee parent or other, to have detained, abduced or married puerum aliquem, he Å¿hall yÃ©eld the value of the marriage and be impriÅ¿oned untill yee have both made amends to the partie damnified, if the ward bee married, and Å¿atisfaction to the King for the tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion hoc de haerede infra 14. &c. but if any heire of 14. yeares age, or upward till 21. Å¿hall marry himÅ¿elfe without grÃ©eing with his Lord to defraud him of the marriage, where the Lord offered him a convenient marriage, and without diÅ¿paragement, there it Å¿hall be lawfull to hold the inheritance untill and after the full age of 21. yeares, by Å¿o long time as Å¿hall Å¿uffice to reape and receive the double value of the marriage, Å¿ecundum eÅ¿t inationem legalium hominum et Å¿ecundum quod p â¢ oeodem maritagio prius fuerit oblatum, Å¿ine fraude & malitia, et Å¿ecundum quod probare poterit in Curia Dm. Regis. Let us Å¿peake of heires, and Å¿ee a litle in what caÅ¿es a woman Å¿hall inherit, It is knowne to all, that becauÅ¿e women loÅ¿e the name of their anceÅ¿tors, and by marriage uÅ¿ually they are tranÅ¿ferred in alienam familiam, they participate Å¿eldome in heireÅ¿hip with males, and therefore Bracton is bold to Å¿ay, Nunquam ad Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ionem vocatur femina quaÌ diu haeres Å¿uperfuerit ex maÅ¿culis, but to this rule he Å¿ubjoyneth exception and examples, the very Å¿ame which are in Littleton, To wit exception of right line, right bloud and maner of giving.

div.head: SECT. VII. Of the right Line.
div.p:
A Female may be preferred in Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion before a male by the time wherein Å¿he commeth: as a daughter or
daughters daughter in the right line is preferred before a brother in the tranÅ¿verÅ¿all line, and that aÅ¿well in the common generall taile, as in fee Å¿imple, for example, land is given to a man, and to the heires of his body, who dyeth having iÅ¿Å¿ue two Å¿onnes, of which the eldeÅ¿t dieth, leaving iÅ¿Å¿ue a daughter, this daughter Å¿hall inherit by the right of blood, alÅ¿o a woman Å¿hall bee preferred propter jus Å¿anguinis: Example, a man hath iÅ¿Å¿ue a Å¿onne and a daughter by one venter, and a Å¿onne by another venter, the firÅ¿t Å¿onne purchaÅ¿eth in fee, and dieth without iÅ¿Å¿ue, the Å¿iÅ¿ter Å¿hall inherit. So it is where a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed in fee hath iÅ¿Å¿ue, ut Å¿upra, and dieth, his eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne entereth and dieth without iÅ¿Å¿ue, &c. Bracton who hath both theÅ¿e caÅ¿es, diÅ¿puteth here as if he were Å¿eeking a knot in a bulruÅ¿h, and he findeth a difference where the inheritance is DiÅ¿cendens and PerquiÅ¿ita. But Littleton is plaine though the Å¿econd Å¿onne bee heire to the father in the laÅ¿t caÅ¿e, and therfore Å¿hould have had the land, had the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne neuer entered, yet the caÅ¿e being as it is: poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿io fratris de feodo Å¿implici facit Å¿ororem de integro Å¿anguine eÅ¿Å¿e heredem. & whether the fee was deÅ¿cended, or perquiÅ¿it what skils it, here it muÅ¿t needs be, if the brother was heire of the blood of the firÅ¿t purchaÅ¿or, that the Å¿iÅ¿ter of the whole blood is Å¿o too, yet there is a great difference betweene land purchaÅ¿ed by him that died Å¿eiÅ¿ed, and land diÅ¿cended unto him, for the firÅ¿t may goe to the heire on the fathers Å¿ide, & for default of Å¿uch to the heire of the mothers Å¿ide, but land diÅ¿cended muÅ¿t alwaies goe to heires of the blood of the firÅ¿t purchaÅ¿er, and the caÅ¿e may bee Å¿uch that a female Å¿hall cary away inheritance from a male, though there be no difference of right line, or in the integrity of blood, which Bracton calleth jus Å¿anguinis duplicatum: as where Iohn Stile purchaÅ¿eth in fee, & dieth without iÅ¿Å¿ue, an ant or ants, or uncles daughter on the father Å¿ide, Å¿hal inherite before an uncle, or uncles Å¿onne on the mothers Å¿ide, where they be both collaterall and the integrity or neernes of blood is alike. Put caÅ¿e, that the purchaÅ¿or died leaving
iÅ¿Å¿ue only Iohn the younger, and this Iohn married or unmarried dieth without iÅ¿Å¿ue, now cannot the land goe to the heires on the part only of the mother of young Iohn, and therefore ye muÅ¿t aÅ¿cend a Å¿tep higher to the marriage of the father and mother of the firÅ¿t purchaÅ¿or, if ye will finde who Å¿hall inherit, where if there be neither brother nor Å¿iÅ¿ter to the purchaÅ¿or, a daughter to the eldeÅ¿t uncle on the fathers Å¿ide may inherite before any of the mothers Å¿ide, yea and before a Å¿onne of the Å¿econd uncle on the part of the father, and this by the worthineÅ¿Å¿e of blood. I will not examine the crainkes of diÅ¿cent, but turne to the caÅ¿e, where poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the brother excludeth a brother and taketh in a Å¿iÅ¿ter: If a man hath iÅ¿Å¿ue a Å¿onne and daughter by one venter, and a Å¿onne by another, and give land to the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne in taile, now if the father die and the reverÅ¿ion in fÃ©e diÅ¿cend to the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne, who likewiÅ¿e dies without iÅ¿Å¿ue of his body, the Å¿econd Å¿onne Å¿hall have this land: For here was no poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, but an expectance of fÃ©e Å¿imple in the eldeÅ¿t. Per omnes IuÅ¿ticiarios de Communi Banco. 24âª E. 3. fol. 13. For it is poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿io fratris & non reverÅ¿io fratris, &c. Yet Thorpe IuÅ¿tice of the Kings Bench thought the land Å¿hould goe to the daughter, Brooke con. Brooke diÅ¿cent. 13. Againe, afine was levied to I. and A. his wife in taile, the remainder in fÃ©e to A. they had iÅ¿Å¿ue a Å¿onne, and the huÅ¿band died, the wife tooke another husband, by whom Å¿hee had iÅ¿Å¿ue another Å¿onne and died: the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne entered and died without iÅ¿Å¿ue, the collaterall heire to him entered as into the remainder in fÃ©e, and the youngeÅ¿t Å¿onne of the halfe blood, to execute the fÃ©e, brought a Scire facias, which was holden good, for though the eldeÅ¿t might have charged, for â¢ ited or given the fÃ©e Å¿imple by atteinder, yet it was not actually in him, and therefore the demi Å¿anke none impediment but the younger Å¿onne might have it, as heire to his mother, 24. E. 3. fol. 30. Which caÅ¿es prove, that the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of a brother to convey the fee to a collaterall heire, if it be not apprehendeth actively, the generall heire to the
common anceÅ¿tor may enter, Therefore where there is a Å¿on or daughter by one venter, and a puiÅ¿ne Å¿onne by an other venter, if the father die Å¿eiÅ¿ed of an advouÅ¿on or a rent, and the eldeÅ¿t Å¿on died before he preÅ¿ent or receive the rent, the daughter Å¿hall not inherit, and if the father die Å¿eiÅ¿ed of an uÅ¿e in fee, poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿io fratris facit Å¿ororem eÅ¿Å¿e haeredem: by taking the profits of the ground. 5. E. 4. 7. Where it is Å¿aid that if the father by teÅ¿tameÌt bequeath the profits for tearme of yeares, this letteth not the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the eldeÅ¿t brother: otherwiÅ¿e it is, if it had beene for tearme of life, and the like difference is (by this booke) if a leaÅ¿e be made for yeares or for life of lands not in uÅ¿e, &c.

div.head: SECT. VIII. Where the manner of gift altereth the diÅ¿cent.
div.p: BRactons firÅ¿t exception to his general rule, that a Woman Å¿hall not inherit, when there is an heire male, is, NiÅ¿i contrarium faciat modus donationis. His example is, A man giveth land to one in mariage with his daughter, to them two and to the heires of their bodies, they have iÅ¿Å¿ue a daughter, and the husband dying, the wife taking another husband, hath by him a Å¿onne and dieth, the daughter Å¿hall inherit per modum donationis, the caÅ¿e is plaine.

But Littleton hath a limitation, where modus donationis, doth cleane exclude Women from inheriting, That is, where lands are given to a man & the heires male of his body: now if he die having iÅ¿Å¿ue a Å¿onne and a daughter by one wife, and a Å¿econd Å¿onne by a Å¿econd wife, the daughter can never inherit, nay, if he die having iÅ¿Å¿ue a daughter onely, which daughter hath a Å¿onne, neither daughter nor Å¿on Å¿hall inherit, for whoÅ¿oeuer Å¿hall inherit by force of an intaile made to heires males, muÅ¿t (per modum donationis) be males & coÌvey his diÅ¿ceÌt to it per heirs males, which becauÅ¿e
the Å¿onne cannot doe here, the donor may reenter. But Littleton Å¿aith alÅ¿o (leÅ¿t women Å¿hould take the matter unkindly at his hand) that where land is given to a man, & to the heires females of his body, his iÅ¿Å¿ue female Å¿hal inherit per formaÌ doni & not the iÅ¿Å¿ue male: for the will of the giver muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erved. He hath another caÅ¿e which I may not omit: When lands are given a man, & to the heires males of his body, which have iÅ¿Å¿ue 2. Å¿onnes, & the eldeÅ¿t dyes having iÅ¿Å¿ue a daughter, if hÃ©e leaÅ¿e the land for tearme of yeares, the reverÅ¿ion deÅ¿cendeth to the Å¿onne: but if the leaÅ¿e bÃ©e for tearme of life of the leÅ¿Å¿Ã©e, the reverÅ¿ion and the fÃ©e Å¿imple deÅ¿cendeth to the daughter, the diÅ¿continuance is the cauÅ¿e, & here the daughter is in not in the per, but contra modum donationis by violating the will of the giver.

div.head: SECT. IX. Where a woman comming to lands Å¿hall retaine them, &c.
div.p:
NOw I will Å¿hew you where a female having gotten inheritance: per modum donationis, or otherwiÅ¿e, Å¿hall retaine it, and where not. Marke well this caÅ¿e, Iohn died Å¿eiÅ¿ed of fÃ©e, leaving iÅ¿Å¿ue Robert the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne, and Richard the puiÅ¿ne: Robert entred, tooke a wife and had iÅ¿Å¿ue Alice, which Alice died, hÃ©e tooke another, and leaving her great with childe hÃ©e died, the Lord Å¿eized the land and ward of Alice, and granted the cuÅ¿tody to one which indowed the wife of Robert, Å¿he was delivered of a Å¿onne William, The Lord Å¿eized William his ward which lived ten yeares, and died without iÅ¿Å¿ue, Henry the Å¿onne of Richard the Å¿econd Å¿onne of Iohn entereth, Alice entereth upon Henry, and hÃ©e brings an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e: now becauÅ¿e the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Lord was Å¿eiÅ¿in and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of William, to whom Alice was but
of the halfe blood, it was awarded that Henry Å¿hould recover. But by the opinion of the Court, the land which the wife held in dowre Å¿hould goe to Alice: for therein William hadBroke diÅ¿pent. pl. 19. no more but a reverÅ¿ion 8. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿a pl. 6. Againe, Henry Å¿eiÅ¿ed of tenements deviÅ¿eable in WincheÅ¿ter (where the CuÅ¿tome is, that hÃ©e which is Å¿eiÅ¿ed by deviÅ¿e may not with warranty or without warranty make alienation to barre the reverÅ¿ion or remainder (deviÅ¿eth them to his wife Alice for tearme of life, the remainder to Th. his Å¿onne for life, Å¿o that Th. Å¿hould make no alienation: quo minus tenementa devenirent propinquioribus haeredibus de Å¿anguine puerorum poÅ¿t mortem predicti Thom. Henry died having iÅ¿Å¿ue Steven an elder Å¿onne, and Maud a daughter, which had iÅ¿Å¿ue Eliz. Steven died without iÅ¿Å¿ue Alice, the wife entered and died Å¿eiÅ¿ed, Tho. entereth and alieneth in fÃ©e with warranty: Ma â¢ d dieth, Elizabeth maketh claime by taking the haÅ¿pe of the doore in her hand: Tho. dieth without iÅ¿Å¿ue, Eliz. entereth upon the alienee, he puteth her out Å¿hÃ©e, bringeth an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e.

It was holden that the heires of Henry had nothing in the fÃ©e Å¿imple by the limitation, which went not to his children, but to the next of blood to his children, excluding Å¿es infants demeÅ¿ne, And by Wilby, if B. make a leaÅ¿e to Alice for life, the remainder to the nÃ©ereÅ¿t of blood, if he die having iÅ¿Å¿ue 2. Å¿onnes, and the eldeÅ¿t dye having iÅ¿Å¿ue a Å¿onne (though this iÅ¿Å¿ue be heire to B,) the other Å¿onne after the death of Alice Å¿hall have the land as nÃ©ereÅ¿t of blood, and (by Greene and Seaton) if there had bÃ©ene Å¿everall iÅ¿Å¿ues, of divers Å¿onnes and daughters to the deviÅ¿or, when the remainder veÅ¿ted it Å¿hould have gone to them all. But here becauÅ¿e the daughter of him had iÅ¿Å¿ue a daughter when the tenant for life died, and there was not iÅ¿Å¿ue of any Å¿onne, at the inÅ¿tant to take from her, or with her, this Daughters Daughter Å¿hall have all, and though there came an after borne Å¿onne of any of the brethren, Å¿he may detaine all, &c. for a remainder veÅ¿ted is not like to fÃ©e Å¿imple diÅ¿cended
to a daughter, where a Å¿onne PoÅ¿thumus may enter. And if lands be letten for life, the remainder to the right heires of I. & if I. dye having iÅ¿Å¿ue a Å¿on, which entereth after the death of the tenaÌt for life, & then dieth, his Å¿on Å¿hal have nothing, becauÅ¿e he was not capax at the fal of the remainder, likewiÅ¿e where there is a brother & Å¿iÅ¿ter, & lands are let for life to an eÅ¿tranger the remainder to the right heires of the brother, if he and the tenant for life die, the Å¿iÅ¿ter may enter, and retaine the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion and fÃ©e, though the brothers wife bee afterward delivered of a Å¿onne: in like Å¿ort did the remainder reÅ¿t in the child of Ma â¢ d in Eliz. viz. which recovered by award, 30. AÅ¿Å¿i. p. 47. But where there is father and Å¿onne, which Å¿onne purchaÅ¿eth and dieth without iÅ¿Å¿ue, and an uncle entereth, if two yeares after the father hath a Å¿onne by the mother of the purchaÅ¿or, this Å¿onne may enter and put out the uncle, and the reaÅ¿on of Law is that hÃ©e that comes in by purchaÅ¿e muÅ¿t be capax, at the time when the purchaÅ¿e veÅ¿t in him, but in caÅ¿e of diÅ¿cent it is not Å¿o requiÅ¿ite. Perk. in his Chapter of deviÅ¿es Å¿aith, that if a deviÅ¿e bÃ©e made to a colledge, which is not a colledge at the time of the deviÅ¿e it is a void deviÅ¿e, although afterward it be made a colledge: & upon the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on, is Dier 13: Eliz. 303. of a deviÅ¿e to an infant in ventre Å¿a mere: And where a man dieth Å¿eiÅ¿ed and his daughter entereth, &c. a Å¿on borne afterward may enter, but it is not Å¿o in caÅ¿e of purchaÅ¿e, &c. for if a woman conÅ¿ent to a raviÅ¿hor, & her daughter and heire enter by the Å¿tatute, 6. R. 2. ca. 6. the Å¿on PoÅ¿thumus Å¿hall not put her out, no more Å¿hall he, where a daughter and heire entereth for condition broken, and where a daughter hath a villain by diÅ¿cent, which purchaÅ¿eth & Å¿he entereth into the perquiÅ¿its an after borne Å¿onne her brother Å¿hall have that which diÅ¿cended, viz. the villien but not the land: theÅ¿e caÅ¿es hath Brook DiÅ¿cents, 58. out of the Doct. and Student, 5. Ed. 4. fo. 58. in the caÅ¿e of Elizabeth Venor, agreeth concerning entry made by 6. Ri. 2. And Å¿o doth Hales and Mountague, in the caÅ¿e of WimbiÅ¿h and Talbois, yet Mountague Chiefe IuÅ¿tice taketh there a
learned difference if a man deviÅ¿e land for life, the remainder to the right heire male of the deviÅ¿or, & the heires of his body, &c. now if the deviÅ¿Ã©e for life die, and a woman which is heire generall to the deviÅ¿or entereth, and hath afterward a Å¿onne, the Å¿onne Å¿hall never out the mother in whom is veÅ¿ted the inheritance for want of other perÅ¿ons to take the falling remainder: per le melior opinion 9. H. 6: yet (he Å¿aith) the caÅ¿es of raviÅ¿hment poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of a brother, abatement of a baÅ¿tard, &c, are all to bee underÅ¿tood of fÃ©e Å¿imple: for where the entry gaineth but eÅ¿tate taile, one may beate the buÅ¿h and another take the bird, Å¿o if a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed by diÅ¿cent from his mother make a feofment with condition, &c. and die without iÅ¿Å¿ue, if a woman heire on the father Å¿ide enter for condition broken, an heire male or female on the mothers Å¿ide may ouÅ¿t her. Plow. &c. fo. 56. a. b. & 57. a.

div.head: WeÅ¿t. 1. ca. 22.
div.p: THen WeÅ¿t goeth on with heire females, that Å¿o Å¿oone as they come to the age of fourtÃ©ene yeares if the Lord for covetouÅ¿nes will not marry them, yet he Å¿hall not kÃ©epe their land above two yeares after they have accompliÅ¿hed 14âª within which two yeares if they be not married by their Lord, they may take action againÅ¿t him for their inheritance, to recover it without paying any thing for the cuÅ¿tody or for marriage. If Å¿o be that of their proper malice or through the miÅ¿chievous counÅ¿ell of others, Å¿uch women refuÅ¿e convenable marriage offered by their Lord, he may in this caÅ¿e retaine their land untill they be of 21. yeares, and longer untill he Å¿hall receive the value of their marriage.

div.head: Littletons words upon this Å¿tatute in his 2. booke cap. 4.
div.p:
BY Littleton if tennant by Å¿ervice of Chivalry die, his here female being 14. yeares old or moreâª the
Lord Å¿hall have cuÅ¿tody neither of the land nor body, for at that age a woman may have a huÅ¿band able to doe knights Å¿ervice, but if Å¿uch an heire be under 14. and unmaried at the time of her aunceÅ¿tors death, the Lord Å¿hall have ward in her land untill Å¿he be of 16. yeares age, WeÅ¿t. 1. cap. 22. which getteth the Lord 2. yeares to tender marriage without diÅ¿paragement, and if during theÅ¿e two yeares the Lord tender no Å¿uch marriage Å¿hee may enter and ouÅ¿t the Lord. If Å¿uch an heire female be married under the age of 14. in the life of her anceÅ¿tor, which anceÅ¿tor dieth before Å¿he accompliÅ¿heth 14. yeares, the Lord Å¿hall have no more but the wardÅ¿hip of her land till Å¿hee be 14. yeares old, and then her huÅ¿band with her may enter into her land and put the Lord out, for this is out of the Statute, becauÅ¿e the Lord may not tender marriage to her that is already married, for before the Statute of WeÅ¿t. Å¿uch an heire female that was under the age of 14. at the death of her anceÅ¿tor, and had atteined afterward to the age of 14. yeares, without any tender of marriage by her Lord made unto her, might well enter into her land, and put out the Lord, as appeareth by the rehearÅ¿all and very words of the Statute, which as it Å¿Ã©emeth (Å¿o Å¿aith Littleton) was made altogether for the advantage of the Lord.

div.head: A Å¿uÅ¿pition of Littletons error.
div.p:
NOw Å¿aving Mr. Littletons inÅ¿piration, I am greatly afraid that ye Å¿hal not finde by the text of the Statute, That an heire female, being under 14. at the death of her anceÅ¿tor, might by the common law before this Statute, enter and ouÅ¿t her Lord, as Å¿oone as Å¿he had accompliÅ¿hed 14. yeare of age without tender of marriage. The law perhaps was Å¿o, but this Statute proves it not: Againe, I doubt, Littleton was deceived, in taking this Statute to be all for the advantage of Lords, yet it is likewiÅ¿e Å¿aid by Davers
13. H. 7. 11. that this Statute was made for advantage of the Lords.

div.head: Glanvill ibro. 7. cap. 12.
div.p: HEare what Glanvill Å¿aith, women Å¿halbe in ward vntill they be of ful age & the Lord Å¿hal mary them being of ful age, euery one of theÌ, with their reaÅ¿onable portion, & thoughthey be of ful age they Å¿hal remaine notwithÅ¿tanding in their Lords cuÅ¿tody vntil they bÃ©e married by his aduiÅ¿e, for by the law of the land, no woman heire can be married, but by her Lords diÅ¿poÅ¿ing and aÅ¿Å¿ent. In Å¿o much, that whoÅ¿oever having a daughter or daughters heire or heires, Å¿hall in his life time without grÃ©e of his Lord marry any of them, he Å¿uffereth by the right and generall cuÅ¿tome of the Realme perpetuall diÅ¿inheriÅ¿on, without ever recovering any thing, but by the grace & mÃ©ere mercy of his Lord. If it be prooved that any woman holden in ward do forfit with her body, Å¿he Å¿halbe deprived of her heritage, & her portion Å¿hall goe and accrue to her parceners. And if they all offend, the whole heritage Å¿hall fall as eÅ¿cheate to the Lord. But after Å¿uch heires be once lawfully maried, though they become widdow afterwards they Å¿hall no more be holden in ward, nor then by their incontinency can they forfit any inheritance. But yet they may not remarry without their Lords aÅ¿Å¿ent. Thus far Glanvill.

div.head: Bracton his 2. Booke cap. 37.
div.p:
BRacton, who (as it may very well be gathered) wrote one halfe hundred yeares after Glanvil, and but very little before the making of WeÅ¿t. 1. In his 2. Booke and 37. Chap. finding it a queÅ¿tion, at what time an heire female Å¿hould bee out of ward, whether at 14. or 15. or at 21. acknowledgeth a greater capacity of deceipt, and maturity of
deÅ¿ire, to be in women then in men.

And that therefore, a woman might be out of ward at 14, and marry, becauÅ¿e, at that age Å¿he is able diÅ¿ponere domui Å¿uae et habere cone et key, et virum Å¿uÅ¿tinere, that is to order and diÅ¿poÅ¿e, a to have, the key clog at her girdle, and to be a jolly Å¿tay vnto a man. But this early emancipation of women heires he taketh to be onely of Å¿uch as inherit laÌd of Å¿ocage tenure: for drawing toward the end of the Chapter he falleth in with Glanvil, And Å¿aith of heires coparceners in Chivalry, Å¿i ab initio omnes maiores extiterunt nihil ominus in cuÅ¿todia dominorum â¢ rint donec per conÅ¿ilium et diÅ¿poÅ¿itionem eorum maritentur: quia Å¿ine ipÅ¿orum coÌÅ¿ilio et aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u, mulier haereditateÌ habens maritari non poteÅ¿t non etiam in vita anteceÅ¿Å¿orum, quod Å¿i olim feciÅ¿Å¿ent, hereditatem amitterent: Å¿ine Å¿pe recuperan â¢ i niÅ¿i Å¿olum per gratiam. Hodie tamen aliam paenam incurrent. And preÅ¿ently hee Å¿heweth the reaÅ¿on why they might not marry without their Lords aÅ¿Å¿ent viz. leÅ¿t the Lord might be conÅ¿trained to take homage of his capitall enemy, or of a man altogether vnfit or vnworthy.

div.head: SECT. X. How the law came to a certainty in the point of a womans being out of ward.
div.p:
CHooÅ¿e now whether ye will learne of Glanvil and Bracton, what the law was in their time, or of Mr. Littleton, that wrote many Å¿core yeares after the making of WeÅ¿tm. 1. In mine opinion, neither did this law bring any advantage to Lords, neither doth it Å¿hew that heires females, oftenants in Chivalry, might enter at 14. yeares, neither is there any clÃ©ere proofe that the law was clÃ©erely Å¿o taken. The letter of the Statute doth
not expreÅ¿ly give 2. yeares to tender mariage, but reÅ¿t raineth covetous Lords, that they Å¿hall not hold the land above 2. yeres after the 14. which Å¿Ã©emech plainly to import, as it is reaÅ¿onably taken both by Needh. & Billing 35. H. 6 that before the making of this law, the age of male and female in this point, tooke no difference. I may be asked, how it commeth then to paÅ¿Å¿e, that the law is Å¿o clÃ©ere in that which Littleton concludeth withall, viêªt. That the Lord Å¿hall not have two yeres to tender his woman ward marriage, Å¿ave onely where Å¿he is under 14. and unmaried at the death of her anceÅ¿tor: before the Statute, it was either out of doubt, that a daughter and heire, Å¿hould not be cleane out of ward. at 14. or at the leaÅ¿t it was doubted, whether Å¿he Å¿hould or no: and the words of the Statute whatÅ¿oever Mr. Littleton Å¿aith, maketh not the matter plaine enough. But we have the helpe of Reverend PriÅ¿ot, in the Booke above mentioned. 3. 5. Henrici 6. WeÅ¿tm. 1. (Å¿aith he) was made in the time of Edward the firÅ¿t, who purpoÅ¿ing to put all the law into certainty, and in writing, begun to makes Bookes thereof, by helpe of the moÅ¿t Å¿age men of the law in this Realme, Iudges and others. And he made a Booke two yeares after the making of this Statute in which all the Statute is reherÅ¿ed, which booke goeth on, and Å¿aith by expreÅ¿Å¿e words: that no woman Å¿halbe Å¿aid to be vnder age, thereby to be in ward after Å¿he is paÅ¿t the age of 14. Thus Å¿aith PriÅ¿ot. By him therefore and by other IuÅ¿tices in the EÅ¿chequer chamber it was ruled cleere, that where the Kings tenant in Chivalry died leaving his daughter and heire of the age of 15. yeare, Å¿he Å¿hould not be in ward. And Billing Å¿aith for law, that if betwÃ©ene the 14. and 16. yere, when an heire female is in ward another ward falleth which holdeth in Chivalry of the firÅ¿t, the Lord Å¿hall not have gard, per cauÅ¿e de garde, for the firÅ¿t ward is out of his power to all intents excepting onely tender of mariage. And another IuÅ¿tice Å¿aith, if a tenant hold ofone lord bypriority, & of another by poÅ¿teriority, the daughter heir vnder. 14. Å¿hal
be in cuÅ¿tody of the anteriour Lord till Å¿he be 16. but Å¿hÃ©e may enter vpon the land by poÅ¿teriority, as Å¿oone as Å¿hee commeth to 14. likewiÅ¿e if the Lord hath once maried this woman-ward, after the age of 14. Å¿he may preÅ¿ently, enter into her land: for now the Lord hath had all that, which to him belongeth, the marriage. And the courÅ¿e of the Chancery is to make livery, before: 14. cum exitibus, but after 14. livery tantum: vid. 4. Eliz. 213. Dyer. & Dyer. 20. Eliz. 362. 1. Hen. 720. on livery for then Å¿uch an heire is to have the profits by the law. To come to an end of this matter, I will not forget, that even in Mr. Littletons daies very nÃ©ere two hundred yeares after the making of WeÅ¿t. 1. by the laÅ¿t Statute, that ever Hen. 6. made in the yeare of his reigne. 39. ca. 2. it was eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed by Parliament that women being of the age of 14: yeares at the death of their anceÅ¿tors, without queÅ¿tion or difficulty Å¿hall have delivery of their lands and tenements diÅ¿cended to them: for Å¿o the Law of the land wils.

div.head: SECT. XI. A Å¿earch for the true reaÅ¿on, why a woman is hors du garde, at the age of 14. yeares.
div.p:
THe principall reaÅ¿on that mooved our law founders, Å¿o Å¿oone to Å¿et women out of ward is none other then hath bÃ©ene already declared, Å¿he is quickly able domui preeÅ¿Å¿e, viro Å¿ubeÅ¿Å¿e, and her huÅ¿band for her Å¿hall doe Knights Å¿ervice, or Å¿ome other for him, and in his Å¿tead, the caÅ¿es are therefore 26: H. 8. fo. 2: If the Kings tenant in chiefe, having feoffees to his uÅ¿e, marry his daughter, vnder age, to a man of full age, and dye, this daughter, being heire, is out of ward for her body though not for her land: for that Å¿halbe in ward in this caÅ¿e, an
the Kings poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion muÅ¿t bee voided by Å¿uite and livery. But had Å¿he bÃ©ene of full age of 14. yeares at her fathers death, no Å¿uch thing had nÃ©eded, neither Å¿hould Å¿he have bin in ward, nor the King have any primer Å¿eiÅ¿in: For that was not as yet Å¿eene into by the Statutes of H. 7. which had given ward, reliefe and herriots upon the death of him, which died inteÅ¿tate and Å¿eiÅ¿ed of onely a bare uÅ¿e: againe, if the King have a woman ward which he marrieth before Å¿he be 14, Å¿he Å¿halbe be to all intents out of ward at 14. and may immediatly Å¿ue her livery. 28. H. 8. for as a ward maÅ¿culine, married by his Lord vnder 21. Å¿halbe Å¿ui luris at 21. Å¿o Å¿hall a ward feminine being maried before 14. bee out of ward at 14. altogether. In the old Natura brevium in the writ de electione cuÅ¿todiae. it is Å¿aid, that where the tenant marieth his daughter being under age, to a man of ful age, & dieth, the daughter Å¿halbe out of ward. But if he mary his daughter, being of full age, to a man under age, and die, Å¿he Å¿hall be in ward. This Mr. Brooke taketh to be no law: even Å¿o doe I: his reaÅ¿on is, that no Lord can have the marriage of her that is already married, or compell any heire to be twice married. For if a tenant marry his Å¿on and die, and then the Å¿onnes wife dieth holden, the Lord Å¿hall not have his body in ward to marry him. Which is cleare: Å¿pecially if the Å¿onne were infra annos nubiles at the time of his fathers death. But certainely, if the Lord couple his ward to a wife which dieth, the ward is at full liberty for his body, and Å¿hall not be married by his Lord.

The reaÅ¿on why an heire female of full age married by her father to a man under age, Å¿hould not be out of ward, muÅ¿t be becauÅ¿e the Å¿uppoÅ¿ition of law faileth: her husband is not able arma portare & officiis fungi militaribus, vel pro iiÅ¿dem faciendis cum alio paciÅ¿ci. But this notwithÅ¿tanding, me thinketh a woman married, Å¿hould bee out of ward for all her huÅ¿bands nonage, thought the woman bee but twelve yeares old a boy knight Å¿hall be out of ward for his body: Å¿hall a woman innupta & matura viro be in kÃ©eping
of any but her huÅ¿band, Å¿hall Å¿hee at 14. yeares age bee ward becauÅ¿e Å¿he hath a huÅ¿band but 19. yeare olds, who Å¿hould not have bÃ©ene in ward had Å¿he had no huÅ¿band at al? non videtur. The huÅ¿bands ability to doe Å¿ouldiers Å¿ervice, is neither the onely nor the principall cauÅ¿e in mine opinion, why a woman is by law out of ward at 14. yeares age. But law going with the trace or tide of nature, that hath made women (as Bracton Å¿aith) fit to carry cey and key cloge betimes, Å¿uffereth them to mary very early: And it Å¿hould be a miÅ¿chievous, inconvenient, unjuÅ¿t, and unnatural law, that Å¿hould hold a woman from her huÅ¿band, or from her inheritance, which is without offence of law maried, & fully able to bring forth children, becauÅ¿e her huÅ¿band is not fully fit for all mannor of horÅ¿emanÅ¿hip. Be not therefore good woman abÅ¿terred from a young huÅ¿band, by old natura brevium.

div.head: SECT. XII. How a woman that hath beene in ward, Å¿hall come by her land.
div.p: A Woman paÅ¿t 14. yeares of age at her anceÅ¿tors death Å¿hall not be in ward: And where Å¿he is in ward till 16. Å¿he may have action at 16. againÅ¿t her Lord for her inheritance, according to the Statute. By Littleton, Å¿he may enter which Å¿tandeth with reaÅ¿on, for the Statute giving action to her affirmatiuely, doth not diÅ¿affirme the entrie which Å¿he might have had, by the auncient catholicke Common law: if Å¿hee cannot or dare not enter, Å¿he may have alone (if Å¿he be alone) or with her fellowes (if Å¿he be a coheire) a writ of mortdanceÅ¿ter, as well againÅ¿t her Lord as againÅ¿t any other abator. Marlbridg ca. 16.

But if Å¿hee be ward to the King, againÅ¿t whom a mortdancestor,
writ of Aile, BeÅ¿aile or CoÅ¿inage then it melts into petition, and Å¿he muÅ¿t Å¿ue for livery. And where the King hath a woman in ward with Å¿ome lands holden of other Lords in Å¿ocage, Å¿uch a ward Å¿hall not Å¿o Å¿oone as Å¿hee is 14. yeare old have livery of that Å¿ocage lands, but Å¿he muÅ¿t arry unleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿he be married, in the meane while till Å¿he be 16. becauÅ¿e livery muÅ¿t be at once parcell, & not by percels. Yet if 3. copartners be in ward to the King, Å¿he which firÅ¿t commeth to age, Å¿hall Å¿ue her livery, and have partition vpon it.

div.head: SECT. XIII. Of Parceners.
div.p: FOr, it muÅ¿t not be omitted there where a man dieth Å¿eiÅ¿ed of any manner of inheritance, having iÅ¿Å¿ue none but daughters, to whom Å¿uch inheritance deÅ¿cendeth, when they have entered by Litt. they are parceners, one heire to their common anceÅ¿tor, & Å¿o are the heires of females parceners and they ought to come in by deÅ¿cent, for if by purchaÅ¿e they are jointenants: & they are called partners (Å¿aith he) becauÅ¿e they are compellable by a writ de partitione facienda, to divide the inheritance amongÅ¿t them. Like, or the Å¿ame law is, where a man dying Å¿eiÅ¿ed having no iÅ¿Å¿ue, his land goeth to his Å¿iÅ¿ters, or aunts, that are partners, if one of them dye before partition made, her part Å¿hall deÅ¿cend to her iÅ¿Å¿ue, and for want of iÅ¿Å¿ue to her coheires, which Å¿halbe dÃ©emed and adjudged in, by diÅ¿cent and not by Å¿urvivour.

div.head: SECT. XIII. Difference betweene partners and jointenants.
div.p: FOr although partners have a conjoyned eÅ¿tate, yet law maketh a great diverÅ¿ity betwixt them and jointenants: Partners by the coÌmon law, are onely females or the heirs of females, which alÅ¿o muÅ¿t be in, by deÅ¿cents, for if Å¿iÅ¿ters makeajoint purchaÅ¿e they are jointnants, and not partners. Betwixt whom obÅ¿erve here the germaine & apparent difference: If two coparceners be of lands in fee Å¿imple, wherof one before partition made chargeth her part with a rent & dieth without iÅ¿Å¿ue, her coparcener taking as heire and by diÅ¿cent, Å¿hall hold the land charged. But it is otherwiÅ¿e betwixt jointenants.
AlÅ¿o partners may deviÅ¿e and give away their part by teÅ¿tament, Å¿o cannot jointenants.

div.head: SECT. XV. Difference betweene partners and tenants in common.
div.p:
ANd as in the caÅ¿es precedent, parteners are like tenants in common, Å¿o in that which followeth they are like jointenants. If two Å¿iÅ¿ters enter into their deceaÅ¿ed fathers lands, and every of them having iÅ¿Å¿ue a Å¿onne, dieth before partition, Å¿o that one moitie deÅ¿cendeth to one Å¿onne, and one moitie to another, which Å¿ons enter and occupy the lands in common, if they bee now disfeiÅ¿ed they Å¿hall have but one aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e and not Å¿everall aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿es. BecauÅ¿e although they come in here by divers diÅ¿cents, yet
Å¿till they are partners, and that not onely in regard of the Å¿eiÅ¿in & poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion which their mothers had, but rather in reÅ¿pect of the eÅ¿tate which deÅ¿cended to their mothers from the common anceÅ¿tors, the grandfather, to whom they are but one heire, Å¿o that of a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in before partition, they Å¿hal have but one aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e.

div.head: SECT. XVI. Difference of partners from both jointenants and tenants in Common.
div.p: BY Bryan, 10. Ed. 4 fo. 3. one copartner may in feoffe another copartner, for though their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion bee joint, yet their right and intereÅ¿t is Å¿evered, Å¿o that if one Å¿iÅ¿ter die, the other Å¿hall claime a moitie by diÅ¿cent from her, and not the intire inheritance from the Common aunceÅ¿tors.
Partners in this therefore are like tenants in Common, whoÅ¿e title and right are Å¿eparated, and therefore they may infeoffe one another.

But it is otherwiÅ¿e with jointenants, whoÅ¿e right is intire and goeth with the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion by Å¿urvivour. Againe, partners may releaÅ¿e the one unto the other, and in this they are like jointenants only, for if one tenant in Common releaÅ¿e to his fellow, his moitie paÅ¿Å¿eth not, becauÅ¿e that hee to whom the releaÅ¿e is made, hath in the franck tenemeÌt of this moitie no poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion. But partners whoÅ¿e right is from one roote have a more co ãâ¦ã ect poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion then tenants in common, and may releaÅ¿e one unto another.

To conclude this point, partners differ from both jointenants and tenants in common in this, that partners are and alwaies were compellable to make partition, Å¿o was neyther
of the other two before the Statute 31. H. 8. cap. 1. which ordaineth that jointenants & tenants in common of inheritance, which in England or Wales in the right of themÅ¿elves or their wives, Å¿halbe compellable by writ de participatione, to be deviÅ¿ed in Chancery to make partition: And that after partition, they and their heires Å¿hall have mutuall aid one of another, for the deraigning of a warranty peramount, to recover pro rata, as is uÅ¿ed betwixt partners at the common law.

Afterward. 32. H. 8. cap. 32 it is ordeined, that if any have equal eÅ¿tate with others or in common jointly for tearme of life or for yeares, or unequal eÅ¿tate, with Å¿uch as have an adhering inheritance, they Å¿hall likewiÅ¿e be coÌpellable to make partition: Provided, that this Å¿hall not bee prejudiciall to any perÅ¿on, other then the parties to it, their executors or aÅ¿Å¿ignes.

div.head: SECT. XVII. Of the Nuper obiit.
div.p: BVt ere wee goe any further in partition, let us Å¿Ã©e what actions may lie betwixt partners for their inheritance before they have divided it.

And firÅ¿t, of the Nuper obiit, This is a writ and commandement of the King to the Å¿heriffe to Å¿ummon a coheir to be before the Kings iuÅ¿tices at a day certaine, to Å¿hew why Å¿he or he (for it lieth betwixt parcenersin Gavell kind alÅ¿o) deforceth the plaintiffe coheire from her reaÅ¿onable part belonging to her, of the inheritance of I. S. their grandfather, father, uncle, brother, grandmother, aunt, Å¿iÅ¿ter, or couÅ¿in (as the caÅ¿e requireth) whoÅ¿e heires they be: & qui Nuper obiit, ut dicitur. This writ lieth for lands holden in fÃ©e Å¿imple, onely betwixt coheires, where one or more of
them deforceth or holdeth out his or their fellow coheire or coheire, &c. It muÅ¿t be brought in the name of all thoÅ¿e which be deforced though in verity there be but one that Å¿ueth. And this 1. may haue a writ of Å¿ummoneas ad Å¿equenduÌ againÅ¿t her negligent copartners, who if they appeare not, the Å¿ole plaintiffe Å¿hall be receiued to Å¿ue for her portion againÅ¿t the deforcer: If after the anceÅ¿tors death, a kinÅ¿man enter claiming by deÅ¿cent, the Nuper obiit lieth not againÅ¿t him, but after entry and ouÅ¿ter, an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e of novell diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in or a writ of right, for though coheires may haue AmordanceÅ¿ter againÅ¿t a Å¿tranger, yet can they not haue it againÅ¿t one of their owne parenteale, priuy in blood, and claiming by the Å¿ame deÅ¿cent, and where a writ of right Å¿ometimes is betwÃ©ene Å¿iÅ¿ters, as where one is infeoffed by dÃ©ed and another claimeth by diÅ¿cent, battaile lieth not, nor the grand aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e, but an inqueÅ¿t in licu thereof. Thus far, V. N. B.

The New. Na. Bre. not diÅ¿agrÃ©eing Å¿aith further. That if one Å¿iÅ¿ter deforce another of the land whereof her anceÅ¿tor died Å¿eiÅ¿ed in eÅ¿tate of fÃ©e taile, the remedy muÅ¿t bee by forme done, and not by Nuper obiit, a Nuper obiit may bÃ©e brought of the Å¿eiÅ¿in of the aile, beÅ¿aile or the treÅ¿aile, and if it be brought of the Å¿eiÅ¿in of the grandfather, Darreigne Å¿eiÅ¿in in the father is no good plea without Å¿hewing that hÃ©e died Å¿eiÅ¿ed.

This writ may be brought, by the aunt againÅ¿t her Å¿iÅ¿ter and niece, or by the aunt and niece, againÅ¿t another Å¿iÅ¿ter & niece, or by one Å¿iÅ¿ter againÅ¿t another, that is but of the halfe blood. But if the father giue part of his land in francke mariage to one daughter and dye Å¿eized, &c. the donÃ©e in francke mariage, Å¿hall not haue a Nuper obiit againÅ¿t her Å¿iÅ¿ter for her part in reÅ¿idue of her fathers fÃ©e Å¿imple laÌd, unles Å¿he put her land in hotch pot which was given in francke mariage. A nuper obiit muÅ¿t be brought by a coheire deforced, againÅ¿t all the other coparceners, though Å¿ome of them haue nothing to doe in the demand.

A villein and his wife, Å¿hal not haue a Nuper obiit againÅ¿t
the coparceners of his wife, for hee is not infranchiÅ¿ed by marriage with one of thoÅ¿e Å¿eignioreÅ¿Å¿es to whom hee was bound. If a coparcener be deforced by a coparcener and by aÅ¿tranger, the deforced may haue a Nuper obiit againÅ¿t her coparcener, and iointenancie abateth not the writ, no more Å¿hall non-tenure of parcell of the thing demanded, by rule of the regiÅ¿ter. If two coparceners enter after the anceÅ¿tors death, and deforcing a third parcener, doe afterward make partition, and then one of them alieneth her portion in fÃ©e, the deforced partner may by a Nuper obiit againÅ¿t her two coheires (notwithÅ¿tanding the alination) recouer a third part of that which is not aliened and a third part of that which is aliened by a mortdanceÅ¿ter or writ of Aile (as the caÅ¿e lieth) and in her owne name, and in the name of her two coparceners againÅ¿t the alien â¢â¢ .

If one coparcener infeoffe a Å¿tranger in fee, and take backe an eÅ¿tate in fee or for life, it Å¿eemeth a Nuper obiit is maintenable Å¿till againÅ¿t her Å¿o long as Å¿he diÅ¿claime not in the blood, &c. But 21. Ed. 3. and 45. Edw. 3. is contra. But Å¿everall tenancy, or non-tenure is no plea in a Nuper obiit for the priuity of blood. But a Å¿iÅ¿ter may claime by purchaÅ¿e, and diÅ¿claime in the blood, and this is a good plea. If one coparcener die leauing iÅ¿Å¿ue a Å¿onne, which Å¿onne infeoffeth a woman in all the land, &c. & then marrieth her, now cannot the other percener haue a Nuper obiit againÅ¿t the baron & feme. But Å¿he may haue a mordanceÅ¿tor in her owne name and in the name of the Å¿eiÅ¿ure which the father had the day of his death, for that amounteth to a dying Å¿eiÅ¿ed Å¿ee Novel nat. br. 197. &c.

div.head: SECT. XVII. Of the writ of right de rationabili parte.
div.p:
THere is alÅ¿o another Writ, called a writ de recto, de rationabili parte that neuer lieth but betwixt priuies in blÃ©ed as betwixt brothers in gavell kinde, or betwixt Å¿iÅ¿ters, nephewes, nieces, &c. It is alÅ¿o for lands in fÃ©e Å¿imple, as where the anceÅ¿tor leaÅ¿eth land for tearme of life, and dieth having two daughters, and after the death of tenant for life, one of the daughters entreth into the whole inheritance and deforceth her Å¿iÅ¿ter, the deforced may haue this Writ, it is maintenable by two or thrÃ©e Å¿iÅ¿ters againÅ¿t the fourth, or by an aunt, or niece againÅ¿t a Å¿iÅ¿ter that deforceth, and this writ lieth as wel where the anceÅ¿tor dyed Å¿eiÅ¿ed, as where he died not Å¿eiÅ¿ed. It is in nature a writ of droit patent, & muÅ¿t be directed to the Lord of whom the land is holden, from before whoÌ it is remoueable by a Tolt, as the Haught writ is, where the anceÅ¿tor dieth Å¿eiÅ¿ed, and one coheire deforceth another (whether it be in gauell kinde, or amongÅ¿t partners at the common law) the deforced hath election of this writ or of the nuper obiit. But when he died not Å¿eiÅ¿ed, and a coparcener afterward deforceth, the Nuper obiit lieth not: The forme of this writ is, Precipimu â¢
to the Lord, ut Å¿ine dilatione plenum rectum teneas A. de decem acris cum pertinentii â¢ , quas clamat eÅ¿Å¿e rationabilem parteÌ de libero tenemento quod fuit I. patris, vel &c. & tenere per liberum Å¿ervititum tertiae partis, &c. for it muÅ¿t be Å¿Ã©ene what rent and Å¿eruice the whole land yÃ©eldeth to the Lord, & according there to Å¿hall the plaintiffe be rated in his, or her writ. If after the death of their anceÅ¿tor two coparceners enter, and the one doe then deforce the other of Å¿omething appendant or appertenent to that which is holden in coparcenery, Å¿he may haue a writ de rationabili par â¢ e of this appendant or appertenent which Å¿hall Å¿ay, quod clamat tenere ad liberum tenementum.

If a man dying Å¿eiÅ¿ed of lands intailed haue two daughters whereof the one entereth and deforceth the other, the remedy is by formedon, and neither by Nuper obiit or Rationabili parte: If a Å¿iÅ¿ter, aunt, niece or couÅ¿in, claime from her anceÅ¿tor by feofment in fÃ©e, & one which Å¿hould haue bin coparcener (had the feofment not bin) deforceth her, Å¿he may haue a writ of Droit patent, and joine the miÅ¿e by battaile, or graund aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e, come Å¿emble, Å¿aith Fitzherbert, becauÅ¿e Å¿hÃ©e claimeth not as heire. But where there is no impediment, intaile, feoffement, or Å¿uch thing, & all the partners deforced bring a rationabili parte againÅ¿t all the copartners, terretenants (for Å¿o it muÅ¿t bÃ©e) and the heire of an heire may Å¿ue for part of the Å¿eiÅ¿in of the coÌmon anceÅ¿tor, there battail, or grand aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e, voucher or view lie not, neither is noÌtenure any plea, for the writ lieth only betwÃ©en privies in blood: finally, the demand in this writ muÅ¿t bÃ©e of a portion certaine as of x. acres, if xx. diÅ¿cend to two Å¿iÅ¿ters, and the demandant if Å¿he recouer, Å¿hall haue iudgement of Å¿o many to hold in Å¿eueralty.

div.head: SECT. XVIII. Of Partition.
div.p: NOw of Partition, it may be made in diuers maners, as firÅ¿t for example by agrÃ©ement amongÅ¿t two copartners or more which accord to diuide the inheritance into certaine parts of equall valew to bee holden in Å¿everalty, and alwaies the part which the elder hath is called Ini ia pars, though in this kinde of partition, there bee no prerogatiue of primer election giuen to the eldeÅ¿t.
Another manner of partition, is where they cauÅ¿e certaine friends to make the parts or diuiÅ¿ion; & here the eldeÅ¿t Å¿hall firÅ¿t chuÅ¿e, & then the next eldeÅ¿t, and Å¿o Å¿uccÃ©edingly.

If by their whole agrÃ©ement the eldeÅ¿t make the diuiÅ¿ion it is Å¿aid (Å¿aith M. Littleton) that Å¿he Å¿hall laÅ¿t make election, which is as much to Å¿ay (Å¿ay I) as Å¿he Å¿hall haue none election at all, Littleton hath another maner of alotment wherein after partition made of the lands euery part being written in a Å¿eroule, and lapped vp in a bale of wax, is put into a bonnet, which muÅ¿t be holden by Å¿ome indifferent body, and then (as wee uÅ¿e to chooÅ¿e Valintines euery partner pulleth out a part, the firÅ¿t borne firÅ¿t, the reÅ¿t after her in degrÃ©e of ancientry and euery one Å¿hal hold her to her chance.

AlÅ¿o partition may be made in Chancery, as when one copartner of full age, and another remaineth in ward to the King, &c. in Å¿uch caÅ¿e if Å¿he which reÅ¿teth in ward at full age haue not her full part, Å¿he may Å¿ue a writ of partition or Scire facias vpon the record returnable in Chancery, to Å¿hew why a new partition Å¿hall not be made, and partition may be of a reverÅ¿ion, or of an aduowÅ¿on.

Of a reuerÅ¿ion thus, that A. Å¿hall haue reuerÅ¿ion of Å¿uch Å¿uch lands, B. the reuerÅ¿ion of Å¿uch other laÌds, & of an aduowÅ¿on, that A. Å¿hall haue euery 2. 3. or 4. auoidance, &c. & this is good without deed, where partition is made of a mannor without mention of the aduowÅ¿on it remaineth in common Å¿Ã©e that caÅ¿e of aduowÅ¿on and partition of aduowÅ¿on, 2. Hen. 7. 5. a.

Partition by agrÃ©ement of parceners is good in law, aÅ¿well by paroll as by writing, and if vnto two copartners there doe deÅ¿cend two houÅ¿es, whereof the one is worth xx. s. and the other x. s. annually, the beÅ¿t houÅ¿e may bee allotted to one copartner, and Å¿he and her heires to pay to the other and her heires, (for owelty or equalities Å¿ake) v. s. rent iÅ¿Å¿uing out of her houÅ¿e, and all this is good without writing, Å¿o that the partner that Å¿hall haue this rent, and her heires may diÅ¿traine for the Å¿ame when it Å¿halbe arere, of common right in whoÅ¿e hands Å¿oeuer the houÅ¿e charged Å¿hall come, and this Å¿hall be a rent charge of Common right had and
receiued for equality of partition, Fitzherb. fol. 252. & Plow. 134.

Partition of lands, that one partner and her heires Å¿hall haue and hold them from EaÅ¿ter to the gule of AuguÅ¿t, alone and by her Å¿elfe; and the other and her heyres from AuguÅ¿t till EaÅ¿ter in the like manner, was awarded a good partition in the time of Ed. 2. and by Å¿imilitude of reaÅ¿on (Å¿aith Fitzherbert) it is a good partition, where two Mannors deÅ¿cend to two Copartners: that the one Å¿hall haue one Mannor by name, and the other the other for a yeare, to change poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion the next yeare, and Å¿o forth from yeare to yeare commutatiuely, betwixt them and their heyres for euer, No. na. br. 62. l. & m. Et auxi. partie. que lunâª auera le ter â¢ . in ta. & laut. le ter. in fee Å¿imple eÅ¿t bone partic. And partners may make partition for terme of life or for terme of yeares, and if one Co-partner leaÅ¿e her part to another Co-partner for terme of yeares, yet Å¿hÃ©e may Å¿ue a Writ of partition againÅ¿t her partner the LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e, though the terme be vnexpired. 33. Hen. 8. Dyer 52. is a quaere. If the one of two Co-partners leaÅ¿e for terme of yeares, that which to her belongeth, and after the other bringeth a Writ of partition againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿or, to whom in this partition there is alotted a leÅ¿Å¿e portion then the due, Å¿ome thinke (Å¿aith he) that the LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e without remedie muÅ¿t hold himÅ¿elfe contented, aÅ¿well as the partner which leaÅ¿ed; But if the partition had beene without writ, quaere.

div.head: SECT. XIX. Of partition by Writt.
div.p:
VVHen Copartners cannot all agree to make partition amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elues, the apteÅ¿t meane to compell them, is a Writ of partition. And if there be foure
Copartners, one may haue this writ againÅ¿t three, or two againÅ¿t two, or thrÃ©e againÅ¿t one.

The giÅ¿t of it by the old Na. bre. is where the one entereth kÃ©eping out the other, and refuÅ¿ing to make partition, but l â¢â¢ t. layeth it where they be all in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and Å¿o Å¿oundeth the Writt it Å¿elfe; for it is a commandement to the Sheriffe, Si A. fec â¢â¢ it te Å¿ecurum, &c. Å¿ummoneas B. that Å¿he come and Å¿hew why Å¿he refuÅ¿eth or permitteth not partition of a Mannor, or a wood, or Å¿uch like, the which with the appurtenances, the Å¿aid A. and B. doe hold together, vndiuided of the inheritance of â¢ . their father, Mother, or, &c. Fitzherbert in his Writt of partition, Å¿etteth downe the forme as a Carpenter Å¿hould Å¿et vp a frame of a Cottage, being both to Å¿hew on what Å¿oile it Å¿hould Å¿tand, for he Å¿heweth not the generall giÅ¿t of his Writ, and that his PreÅ¿ident might make plaine, which is not doubtfull, that when Partners are in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, one or more may haue a partitione faciunda, yet he toucheth not the queÅ¿tion, whether a Partner ouÅ¿ted, or not Å¿uffered to enter, may haue it.

40. Hen. 7. fo. 9. in a Writ of partition, Keble pleadeth for his Clyent, that the defendant was Å¿ole Å¿eiÅ¿ed, Å¿ans ceo, that he held pro indiuiÅ¿o, with the Plaintiffe: by VauiÅ¿our that is no good plea, for admit that Å¿hee bee Å¿ole Å¿eiÅ¿ed, yet partition lieth well enough, but by Brian Chiefe IuÅ¿tice, it is & hath been adiudged a good plea, in our books, for one Å¿hall not come to diuide that with another wherein he hath no part. And (Å¿aith Keble) in a Writ of waÅ¿te betwÃ©ene tenants in Common it is a good trauerÅ¿e, Non tenet inÅ¿imul & pro indiuiÅ¿o, likewiÅ¿e is it here where we haue trauerÅ¿ed the point, and Å¿uppoÅ¿all of your Writ, and the partie by nuper ob â¢ jt, may recouer in Å¿eueraltie, and partition Å¿hall be made, and it was Å¿aid that the Å¿eiÅ¿in of one parcener, is the Å¿eiÅ¿in of both, and Å¿o the reporter thinketh, if one enter, &c. Where Å¿he which entereth claimeth in the name of her Å¿elfe, and of her partner I can
well agrÃ©e, or if Å¿he enter not denying the right of her fellow: And if after the death of the common AnceÅ¿tor, A. which is one Coheyre enter Å¿ilent into the whole inheritance, B the other Coheyre may now perhaps (without other entry) in the name of her Å¿elfe and her Companion maintaine a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿orie action, againÅ¿t a Å¿tranger, but when a SiÅ¿ter entereth vindicating all to her Å¿elfe by purchaÅ¿e, or obiecting againÅ¿t her SiÅ¿ter, BaÅ¿tardie, or Attainder, and keeping her out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, this I trow is no entry of both, but Å¿uch a deforcing as the Writs de rationabili parte, and the nuper obijt, were made to redreÅ¿Å¿e: If euery Å¿eiÅ¿in of a partner muÅ¿t nÃ©eds be the Å¿eiÅ¿in of all thoÅ¿e that can claime as coheyres, then there is no deforcing or nÃ©ed at all of the forenamed writs.

But Å¿Ã©eing that law hath appointed them for lands in Å¿ee-Å¿imple, and a formedone for land in taile againÅ¿t deforcers of their coparceners, I Å¿ay, that Å¿eiÅ¿in of one of them is not Å¿eiÅ¿in to all of them, and hauing a chiefe IuÅ¿tice on my Å¿ide, I dare hold, that non tenet pro indiuiÅ¿o is a good plea in a Writt of partition, which if it be brought by her that is deforced and out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, it commeth prepoÅ¿terouÅ¿ly out of kind and Å¿eaÅ¿on, and out of the order that our Law-founders at the firÅ¿t ordained, See Brooke Coparceners per totum, ou entrie de vn eÅ¿t le entrie del auter vers eÅ¿trange pur lour advantage, mes nemie pur disaduantage 43. Ed. 3. 19. & lentrie d'un neÅ¿t l'entrie de ambideux entre eux meÅ¿mes. 40. E. 3. 8.

div.head: By whom, and how the Writt of partition muÅ¿t be brought at this day.
div.p:
COheyres in Gauell kinde, may compell one another to make partition by Writt, but then they muÅ¿t mention the cuÅ¿tome in their declaration, If one Coparcener dye hauing iÅ¿Å¿ue, &c. her huÅ¿band being tenant by the courteÅ¿ie is compellable to make partition, but he cannot
compell, &c. by the Common Law, for the Writt lieth naturally, for none but parceners. Fitzherbert, and the old na. bre. haue a note out of the RegiÅ¿ter, that in the 12. of King Ed. (they tell not which) there was Å¿ealed a Writ of partition at Barwicke betwÃ©ene Å¿trange perÅ¿ons, and there it was Å¿aid it might bee granted betweene any Coheyres or fellow tenants, without naming de heredit â¢â¢ e in the Writt, where it was likewiÅ¿e affirmed that Å¿uch a Writt before that time was neuer Å¿Ã©ene, aÅ¿well the other bookes of Law, as the Statutes of 31. H. 8. make it out of queÅ¿tion, that this Writt by the Common Law was onely betwixt Coheyres, as the two Writts which we haue paÅ¿Å¿ed, were by cuÅ¿tome in Å¿ome Å¿peciall places: ioynttenants, and tenants in Common might haue a Writt of partition, as Fitzherbert Å¿etteth downe: by the CuÅ¿tome of London, Writt of partition lyeth againÅ¿t tenant by the curteÅ¿ie Littleton 264. Dyer 1. M. 98. Brief de partit. at this day lye againÅ¿t the FeoffÃ©e of one Coparcener, but not for a FeoffÃ©e: mes. vide Dyer 3. M. 128.

LikewiÅ¿e before the Statutes, if a man were both tenant in Common, and tenant in Copartnerie, as hauing one third part by purchaÅ¿e from one SiÅ¿ter, and another in the right of his Wife, he and his wife might bring a Writt of partition, which Å¿ee Nat. br. fol. 61.

It hath bÃ©ene much doubted, whether partition by agrÃ©ement betwixt tenants in Common, or ioynt-tenants were good without dÃ©ed: But by the better opinion, 3. Ed. 4. â¢ . 9. & 10. Å¿uch a partition is good enough if it be vpon the ground: but Å¿ee the bookes of 2. Eliz. Dyer. 179. 18. Eliz. Dyer. 350. There is alÅ¿o a prety caÅ¿e of a mill parted betwÃ©en two brethren ioynt-tenants by an award of a third, that one Å¿hould repaire the mill on the one Å¿ide of a certaine poÅ¿te, and the other on the other Å¿ide imperpetuum, &c. which was awarded a good partition without any writing. 47. Ed. 3. 24. & â¢ 9. AÅ¿Å¿i. p. 1.

It hath bÃ©ene alÅ¿o much doubted whether iudgement may
be giuen to hold in Å¿euerall when in aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e of nouell diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, brought by one ioynt-tenant or tenant in common againÅ¿t another, it is found for the plaintiffe, as it is cleare it may be if the action were betwixt partners 7. aÅ¿Å¿i.. p. 10. Herle would not haue giuen iudgement to hold in Å¿eueraltie, had the parties beÃ©ne ioynt-tenants: But 10. AÅ¿Å¿i. p. 17. Å¿uch a iudgement is giuen and no bones made of it, yet 28. aÅ¿Å¿i. p. 35. R. Thorp in like caÅ¿e, would giue no iudgement but generally to hold a moity per my & per tont, though he were beÅ¿ought in the Country at the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿es, & at WeÅ¿t. again and again for Iudgement to hold Å¿euerally, 7. H. 6. fo. 4. WeÅ¿ton glanceth on Å¿uch a iudgement, and Strange denyeth that it may be, for it deÅ¿troyeth the Å¿uruiuor: But Chine Å¿aith, that it may be, and hath bÃ©en often: the reaÅ¿on why the Law was more Å¿crupulous in thoÅ¿e points betwÃ©ene tenants in Common, and ioynt-tenants, then betwÃ©en partners, was (as I gueÅ¿Å¿e) becauÅ¿e coheyres haue their eÅ¿tate by courÅ¿e of law, and the other are in either by the act of Å¿ome body which made the eÅ¿tate, or by their own doing, Å¿o that though for neceÅ¿Å¿ity they may alien that which belongeth to them, or charge it yet otherwiÅ¿e the Contract made by conÅ¿ent may not without manifeÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ent be vndone: Bract. Å¿aith, fo. 206. Å¿ufficit femel voluiÅ¿Å¿e, nec diÅ¿Å¿oluitur mutua voluntas niÅ¿i mutua voluntare contraria. It is perceiued how the law was before the Statutes, 31. & 32. H. 8. a Å¿ummarie of which is Å¿et downe already, now that it may the better in part be vnderÅ¿tood, how the law hath bÃ©ene taken Å¿ince thoÅ¿e Statutes, obÅ¿erue the cauÅ¿es following, out of my Lord Dyers Reports.

The puiÅ¿ne of thrÃ©e Coparceners of a reuerÅ¿ion vpon eÅ¿tate for life gauel-kind alieneth by a fine, the leÅ¿Å¿Ã©e dieth, the eldeÅ¿t parcener entreth into all his Inheritance, the middlemoÅ¿t, and the AlienÃ©e bring a ioynt Writt of partition vpon the Statute, the eldeÅ¿t pleadeth the generall iÅ¿Å¿ue, non tenent inÅ¿imul & pro indiviÅ¿o, the caÅ¿e appearing by the euidence, it was holden vpon a demurrer cleere, that the action was not maintainable,
for the one ought to haue her Writt by the Common Law, and the other by the Å¿tatute, but ioyne they could not, Quaere (Å¿aith Dier) if the entry of the eldeÅ¿t giue Å¿eiÅ¿in to the reÅ¿t, that it Å¿hould giue it to the Å¿tranger were hard 2. & 3. Phi. & Ma. fol. 12. 8.

One of three Coparceners alieneth that which to her belongeth, one of the other two bringeth a Writt of partition againÅ¿t her fellow parcener, and the alienÃ©e, vpon the Å¿tatute, becauÅ¿e in this caÅ¿e, Å¿he might haue had a Writ by the Common Law, this Writ vpon the Å¿tatute abated: But if the two Coparceners had ioyned againÅ¿t the alienÃ©e, and the one had beene at non-Å¿uite, Å¿he Å¿hould haue been Å¿ummoned and Å¿euered, and her part beene diuided as well as the others, quaere, by the RegiÅ¿ter, when the huÅ¿band vnto one of thrÃ©e partners purchaÅ¿eth one part, &c. he and his wife may haue a Å¿peciall Writt againÅ¿t the third, euen Å¿o it Å¿Ã©emeth if one of thrÃ©e Coparceners purchaÅ¿e a fellowes part, the purchaÅ¿er may haue a Å¿peciall writt againÅ¿t the third parcener, 7. ct 8. Eliz. 243. in Dyer, by Anthony Browne and Dyer ioint-tenants, cannot at this day make partition by paroll out of the countie where the land lieth, for 31. and 32. &c. change not the law in this point: But the partition muÅ¿t bee by Writt out of Chancery. Humfrey Browne and WeÅ¿ton: 2. Eliza. Dier. 179. a man deuiÅ¿ed Å¿ocage lands to his two daughters, and to the heyres of their two bodies loyally engendred, and died, the two daughters tooke huÅ¿bands, and at full age, &c. partition was made by paroll, one huÅ¿band had iÅ¿Å¿ue by his Wife, and Å¿hÃ©e dyed: By the opinion of the whole Court the other HuÅ¿band, and his wife Å¿hall haue the whole Land by Å¿uruiuor, for partition by word onely betwixt ioint-tenants or tenants in Common of eÅ¿tate of Inheritance is voyd: yet of a tearme peraduenture (Å¿aith Dier) Å¿uch a partition is good enough fo. 350. in Dier: If ye doubt now of any thing Å¿omthing more then you did before, yÃ©e are the better learned and warned to worke Å¿urely.

div.head: The manner of partition by Writ, &c.
div.p: THe Iudgment vpon a writ de partit. faciend. if: that diuiÅ¿ion be made betwÃ©ene the parties; and that the ViÅ¿count in proper perÅ¿on going to the lands and tenements by the oath of 12. loyall men of his Countie, make the partition, deliuering one part to the plaintiffe, or to one of the plaintiffes, and another part to another parcener, &c. making no mention in the iudgement more of the eldeÅ¿t then the youngeÅ¿t SiÅ¿ter, The Sheriffe muÅ¿t giue notice to the IuÅ¿tices of the partition which he hath made, aÅ¿well vnder the Å¿eale of the 12. men as vnder his owne Å¿eale, And in this partition there is no primer election giuen to any: but the Å¿econd may haue liuery before the eldeÅ¿t, or the younger before either of them euen as it pleaÅ¿eth the Sheriffe.

And this difference is betweene partition by Writ here, and the other partition which is by agreement: In the firÅ¿t the ViÅ¿count Å¿hall make to euery partner, her diÅ¿tinct Å¿hare, but in the other they may agrÃ©e, that one Å¿hall hold in Å¿eueraltie, and the reÅ¿t Å¿hall occupie that which remaineth in common. Thus farre Littleton.

div.head: Bractons partition.
div.p:
