THere is in Bracton a large diÅ¿courÅ¿e of partition, which I Å¿Ã©e not why, (for the forme) at this day Å¿hould not be good, if not of all other the beÅ¿t: And this partition is by commiÅ¿Å¿ion to men either choÅ¿en by the parties, or appointed by the King as IuÅ¿tices or extenders, with commandement to the Sheriffe to make them come before thoÅ¿e CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners or extenders tam milites quam alios legales homines nulla affinitate attingentes, per quos negotium melius expedire poterit. He hath alÅ¿o a precept to the Coroners where the Sheriffe is negligent: Tepidus & remiÅ¿Å¿us
in executione preceptorum domini Regis, with a rule for valuation of an aduowÅ¿an, viz. that a marke annuall to the parÅ¿on Å¿hall be rated a Å¿hilling to the parcener to whom the aduowÅ¿an Å¿hall be alotted.

And when the extent and diuiÅ¿ion is made, euery part being written by it Å¿elfe Å¿hould be deliuered to a Lay-man altogether vnlettered, which Å¿hould diÅ¿tribute to euery coheyre her part at aduenture, wherwith Å¿he Å¿hould Å¿tand contented: But this might be otherwiÅ¿e, by their agrÃ©ement amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elues, to elect according to the prerogatiue of their age. Bracton diÅ¿cendeth dÃ©eper into examination what things may be parted amongÅ¿t coheyres, exempting neither lands, tenements, homages, villinages, Å¿eruices, Å¿eruitudes, or anything belonging to lands and tenements from diuiÅ¿ion, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be Å¿eriantia (quae diuidi non debent, ne cogatur-Rex Å¿eruitium accipere per particulas) or a caÅ¿tle, or the head of Å¿ome Earldome or Barrony, quod propter ius gladij diuidinon debet Å¿it illud caÅ¿trum vel aliud edificium, & hoc ideo (Å¿aith he) ne Å¿ic caput perplures particulas diuidatur & plura iura comitatus & Baroniarum deueniunt ad per nihilum quod deficiat regnum quod ex comitatibus & Baronijs dicitur eÅ¿Å¿e conÅ¿titutum. Therfore Caput comitatus vel Baroniae reÅ¿teth indiuiÅ¿ible, and Å¿hall go to the eldeÅ¿t copartner, though where there are many chiefe and great ManÅ¿ionhouÅ¿es, euery one may haue one perhaps, and if there be but one, euery one may haue part thereof, where the frank-tenement is holden by Å¿eruice militarie, for if a frÃ©e Å¿oke-man die, whoÅ¿e heritage it is, ab antiquo partibilis, the eldeÅ¿t Å¿on (by Bracton) Å¿hall haue his houÅ¿e, and the reÅ¿t Å¿hall haue allowance: AmongÅ¿t other things, Bracton Å¿tandeth long vpon the bringing to a common heape (which we call Hotchpot) Lands giuen in marriage to a coheyre, Å¿hewing that though lands giuen in marriage (whether the Inheritance be diÅ¿cendens, or perquiÅ¿ita, and whether Å¿hee to whom the land is giuen, be at the time of the gift a maid or a widow) muÅ¿t needs fall into partition, when part of the other lands
is claimed (& hoc quamuis homagium interuenerit & poÅ¿t tertium haeredem:) yet for all that, Å¿he to whom there is giuen in marriage already more then an euen portion, may well retaine it, and is not compellable to any confuÅ¿ion vnleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿he demand a Å¿hare in that which remaineth, Å¿o that Å¿he to whom all is giuen, may likewiÅ¿e retaine all. And where a daughter was infeoffed pro homagio & Å¿eruitio, or where a Å¿tranger was infeoffed of part of the inheritance, which afterwards married a daughter, &c. they might be made parcell of the other lands, without any Hotch-pott: of theÅ¿e things ye may read more in Bract. li. 2. c. 33 and 34 with a Writt of habere facias Å¿eiÅ¿inam, for he Å¿aith, poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿io non pertinet ad haeredes niÅ¿i naturaliter fuerit apprehenÅ¿a animo et corpore proprio vel alieno: Å¿icut procreatorio prius ad ipÅ¿os non pertinebit, & vnde cum in curia Regis facta fuerit partitio Å¿tatim habean â¢ breue de Å¿eiÅ¿ma Å¿ua habenda.

div.head: SECT. XX. of Hotch pott, according to Littleton.
div.p:
FOr putting of lands in Hotch-pot, there is no where Å¿o full, and plaine learning, as in M. Littl. third booke c. z. If (Å¿aith he) a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed in fÃ©e-Å¿imple lands, hauing iÅ¿Å¿ue two daughters, of which the eldeÅ¿t is married, giue parcell of thoÅ¿e lands to his daughter and her huÅ¿band in frankemarriage, and die Å¿eiÅ¿ed of other lands, excÃ©eding in value thoÅ¿e which are giuen, &c. the huÅ¿band and wife Å¿hall haue no part of this remnant vnleÅ¿Å¿e they will put the land giuen vnto them in Hotch-pot: for example, If the father had 30. acres, and gaue 10. now after his deceaÅ¿e if the donÃ©es refuÅ¿e to make commixtion, the other daughter may enter and occupie the whole 20. and hold it to her Å¿elfe: But putting all in Hotch-pott, to finde the intire value, (for it is but an eÅ¿timation or valuation) finding the acres to bee of like goodneÅ¿Å¿e, the DonÃ©es in franke-marriage Å¿hall haue an n â¢ reaÅ¿ement of 5. acres to hold all 15. in Å¿eueraltie, Å¿o that
alwayes, the land giuen in frank marriage, muÅ¿t remaine to the donÃ©es and their heyres, for elÅ¿e (Å¿aith Littleton) Å¿hould follow a thing vnreaÅ¿onable and inconuenient, which alwayes the Law deteÅ¿teth, there is the Å¿ame Lawes betwixt the heyres of DonÃ©es in frank marriage, and the other partners, if the DonÃ©es themÅ¿elues die, before their anceÅ¿tor, or before partition.

This putting of Land in hotchpot is where the other lands deÅ¿cend from the Donor onely, and not from any other aunceÅ¿tor, for if they deÅ¿cend from the father or brother of the donour, from the mother of the DonÃ©e, that which is equallie Å¿o diÅ¿cended, Å¿hall be without Commixtion equally diuided: AlÅ¿o (by Littleton) if the land deÅ¿cended be of equall valew with the land giuen in franke Marriage, Hotchpot Å¿hould be then in vaine and to no purpoÅ¿e, and Å¿Ã©e Littl. Chapter of parceners more concerning Å¿uch Hotchpot.

div.head: How partition may be auoyded.
div.p: PArtition made betwixt two SiÅ¿ters tenants in fÃ©e Å¿imple, they both being of full age, is not defeÅ¿able, though there want oweltie, and equall valew in their parts.

But if the land were in fÃ©e-taile, the parties making the partition Å¿hould bee bound and concluded onely for their time, the iÅ¿Å¿ue of her which had the meaner value, might enter after her mothers death, into her Aunts part, and occupie with her in common, and Å¿he againe with her niece in the part alotted to her SiÅ¿ter: If two Coparceners in fÃ©e, both married, together with their huÅ¿bands make partition, it Å¿hall Å¿tand in force during the coverture, but after the death of a huÅ¿band, his wife hauing a meaner part, may enter and defeat the partition, not Å¿o if at the time of the alotment, the parts were both of equall annuall valew.

If two Coparceners, whereof the one is vnder 21. yeares
age, make partition Å¿o that a meaner valew is allotted to the puiÅ¿ne partner, Å¿he may enter and defeat the partition either in her minoritie, or when Å¿he is of full age: but let her take hÃ©ed when Å¿hÃ©e commeth once to full age, that Å¿hÃ©e take not the whole profit of that which to her Å¿elfe was alotted, for that is an agrÃ©ement to the partition, and maketh it indefeaÅ¿able, peraduenture a moietie of the profits Å¿he may take.

ThrÃ©e acres of land are giuen to one in taile, which hath other thrÃ©e in fÃ©e, and after his death, his two daughters make partition, Å¿o that one hath the land intailed, and another the land in fÃ©e, if Å¿hÃ©e which hath the fÃ©e-Å¿imple, alien her part and die, her iÅ¿Å¿ue may enter into the land tailed, and hold occupation in Common with her Aunt, whoÅ¿e folly was to make Å¿uch a partition, for Å¿ince Å¿hee is without remedie, againÅ¿t the alienÃ©e of her mother, and without recompence, for the lands intailed, whereunto Å¿he is an heyre, by deÅ¿cent from the firÅ¿t DonÃ©e, it is reaÅ¿on Å¿he may enter, Å¿pecially conÅ¿idering, that the Å¿tate taile is not diÅ¿continued, yet 20. Hen. 6. it is holden, that Å¿he is put to her Formedon.

A man Å¿eiÅ¿ed of two carues of land, one by iuÅ¿t title, another by diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in of an infant, dieth Å¿eiÅ¿ed hauing iÅ¿Å¿ue two daughters, they diuide Å¿o that one hath the carue gotten by diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, & the infant entereth vpon her poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, &c. Å¿he may enter into the other carue, and hold in parcenarie with her SiÅ¿ter: But if Å¿hee had aliened her part in fee before the entrie of the infant, this had beene a full diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ion of her Å¿elfe out of CopartnerÅ¿hip which Å¿he could not haue recontinued by entrie, as Å¿he might perhaps, had Å¿he made onely a leaÅ¿e for yeares, generally if after partition one part be euicted from her which hath it, by loyall entrie, Å¿he may enter into the other lands, and occupie with the other Coparceners, compelling them to a new diuiÅ¿ion: all this Å¿aith Littleton.

div.head: SECT. XXI. How Partition Å¿hall bee auoided when it is by Iudgement.
div.p:
MUch of that which Littl. hath taught for the auoyding of partition (as I collect) muÅ¿t bee vnderÅ¿tood of partition in pais, and by agrÃ©ement, for when it is made by Iudgement in a Writ of rationabile parte, nuper obijt, or aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e to hold in Å¿eueralty, or by liuery in the Chancery, or elÅ¿e by Writt, de partitione, in which caÅ¿es there is commiÅ¿Å¿ion or authority deriued from the Prince to extend and to make partes by the Oath of 12. men, &c. there is now no reaÅ¿on, that a matter of this Å¿ubÅ¿tance, circumÅ¿tance and Å¿olemnity, Å¿hould be all layd on the ground, by a bare entrie, yet that Å¿illy poore women altogether ignorant of the law, might not feare that that Partition which is made by the Law, that by law there were no meanes to reuerÅ¿e it, but that Å¿till it muÅ¿t Å¿tand impugnable, whatÅ¿oeuer iniquitie or inequality it had, Old Breton Å¿aith in the end of his 17. Chapter, Si aÅ¿cum â¢ ercener Å¿oit que Å¿e tient nient paie de cel partiÅ¿on Å¿i ferres nous vener le proceÅ¿Å¿, & le record deuant noÅ¿tre iuÅ¿tices de banke, &c. illonques Å¿oient les errors redreÅ¿Å¿e, &c. He concludeth Å¿omewhat like Bracton. Et apres le AÅ¿Å¿ignement des purparties fuit per Å¿ort ou per election: foit le Å¿eiÅ¿in per iudgement de noÅ¿tre court: But to the matter. There is occurring in many of the yeare bookes, remedies againÅ¿t partitions, as if iudgement be giuen in a nuper obijt, of purpartie, and Å¿eiÅ¿in granted to hold Å¿euerally, yet the partition may be anoyded by error in the firÅ¿t iudgement. If partition bee made in Chancerie, and a leÅ¿Å¿e value then is due alotted to a puiÅ¿ne SiÅ¿ter, which remaineth Å¿till in ward, Å¿he may haue remedy by Å¿cire facias when Å¿hee commeth to full age: So whether partition be of it Å¿elfe altogether
vniuÅ¿t, or in part inequall, through malice, ignorance, or negligence of the Sheriffe or extenders, there is remedie alwayes, Å¿o the parties be not hurtfull to themÅ¿elues.

And although partners of eÅ¿tate in fÃ©e, being all of full age, making purpart by agrÃ©ement, bind & conclude themÅ¿elues and their heyres for euer, yet when partition is compulÅ¿atorie, and the parts are deliuered by the Sheriffe, who with his extenders maketh diuiÅ¿ion (which may be without the preÅ¿ence of the heyres) I Å¿Ã©e no great reaÅ¿on here, why acceptance Å¿hould be a barre in the iÅ¿Å¿ue perpetuall, or to the parceners for terme of life, yet Littletons bien for garde is good counÅ¿ell, vide Dyer 33. H. 8. 52.

div.head: SECT. XXII. Of the coherence betweene Partners after diuiÅ¿ion.
div.p:
BUt admit now that partition is Å¿o made that there remaineth neither cauÅ¿e nor intention to vndoe it, yet the partners are in a kinde of confederacie and combination amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elues, by the very Law and cuÅ¿tome of this Realme, Et lou â¢ droit eÅ¿t cy connex nul de eux ne doit reÅ¿pondre Å¿ans le autre: pur le contribution. EtÅ¿i aÅ¿cun Å¿e face ceo ne Å¿erroit in preiudi â¢â¢ des auters partners. Britton cap. 73. Å¿o that if any of them will Å¿ue for any inheritance that was their Common AnceÅ¿tors, the Å¿uit muÅ¿t be in all their names Å¿till, and if any of them be Å¿ued, for any Å¿uch Land or inheritance, Å¿he may pray ayde of the other coheires, which may come with her to pleade a feoffment, fine or releaÅ¿e, or deraigne warrantie, and if in this Å¿ort Å¿he loÅ¿e Å¿ome or all her part, Å¿he Å¿hall recouer that which her partners hold her equall portion. But if a parcener put her Å¿elfe in defence, and will not pray ayde of her fellowes, which may
Å¿trengthen and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t her, Å¿he Å¿hall then recouer nothing againÅ¿t her coheyres, though Å¿he loÅ¿e all her purpart and liuelihood: They continue therefore Å¿till in a Å¿ort one heyre tyed together like bundles of rods, for their mutuall Å¿trength, and by Bracton and Britton, if one of them die without iÅ¿Å¿ue after partition, her part Å¿hall goe to the reÅ¿t, per ius accreÅ¿cendi, But is croÅ¿Å¿ed by Littleton aboue, which telleth you that their title Å¿hall be in this caÅ¿e by diÅ¿cent, though the dying be before partition, therefore if partition be betwixt two SiÅ¿ters of the halfe bloud, and one of them dyeth without iÅ¿Å¿ue, hauing an vncle of the whole blood to the Father, that Vncle by Bractons partition Å¿hall haue her Inheritance, &c.

div.head: SECT. XXIII. By what manner of acquiÅ¿ition the ouer-liuer taketh the part of a Co-heire when Å¿he dyeth.
div.p:
FOr your better inÅ¿truction in this point, marke this CaÅ¿e, a man hath iÅ¿Å¿ue thrÃ©e daughters, by one venter, and one daughter by another venter, and dyeth Å¿oiÅ¿ed, &c. they all enter, and two of the daughters by the firÅ¿t venter die, the third daughter by the Å¿ame venter Å¿hall be heyre alone to their two parts, and the fourth daughter of the halfe blood getteth therein nothing, 10. AÅ¿Å¿i. p. 27. yet 4. AÅ¿Å¿i. p. 10. if a man die Å¿eiÅ¿ed hauing iÅ¿Å¿ue two daughters by diuers venters, both vnder age, and a Å¿tranger abateth, and one of theÅ¿e daughters in their infancie, releaÅ¿eth all her right, and dyeth without iÅ¿Å¿ue, the other may haue a mortdanceÅ¿tor, and recouer the whole Inheritance, as heire to her Father, though Å¿he can by no meanes be heyre to her SiÅ¿ter: But if Å¿he which releaÅ¿ed, had beene of full age when Å¿hÃ©e releaÅ¿ed, Å¿he had giuen away her moitie. And if Å¿hÃ©e had entered
at full age, or vnder age, nothing had accrewed to her SiÅ¿ter: But not entring, the mortdanceÅ¿tor to which they were both intituled, goeth for all to the Å¿uruiuor. And this I thinke to be a good caÅ¿e, making nothing on Bractons Å¿ide, and not plaine any thing on Littletons.

div.head: SECT. XXIIII. Of Contribution
div.p: THat which Britton toucheth aboue, of Contribution, I vnderÅ¿tand to be in caÅ¿e, where one partner prayeth ayde of another, the Å¿equell whereof I haue Å¿hortly told you: There is another Contribution by Statute, Marlebridge, c. 9. which willeth, S â¢ haereditas al â¢ qua de qua vnica tantum Å¿ecta debeatur, ad plures par â¢ icipes eiuÅ¿dem haeredit. devoluatur, ille qui habet eineciam partem vnicam Å¿acier Å¿ectam, & participes pro portione Å¿ua contribuant. The writ for this Contribution, when the young copartners will not performe the ordinance, hath cum de communi conÅ¿ilio prouiÅ¿o, &c. reciting the Statute.

This Statute reacheth not to the King; at whoÅ¿e Court all the copartners Å¿hall giue their Å¿euerall attendance, Å¿uite; and Å¿eruice. And if any of the lands partable be holden in Capite euery Coheyre Å¿hall and muÅ¿t haue a part of that in her alotment, for the Kings profit, The Å¿tatute of Ireland which is a receipt of H â¢ n. 3; 14 of his reigne to Gerrard Fi â¢ zmorrice IuÅ¿tice, Å¿heweth that by thoÅ¿e dayes, the firÅ¿t borne partner did alwayes homage for her Å¿elfe and her fellowes to euery common Lord of the fÃ©e who tooke all his Å¿eruice, per man â¢ s primogeni â¢ ae, which primogenita, had in recompence; (Å¿aith the Statute) no homage, ward-Å¿hip, or Å¿ubiection of Copartners, nor any thing but the Capitall MeÅ¿Å¿uage, ratione eineciae: Glanuil (which writ before the Statute) Å¿aith, that homage and all other Å¿eruices, were done to the chiefe Lord by the hand of the eldeÅ¿t parcener for all the reÅ¿t, without guerdon from them or their heyres,
in the firÅ¿t or Å¿econd degrÃ©e: But (by him) their heyres in the third degrÃ©e were bound to doe homage, and pay reliefe to the heyres of the eldeÅ¿t daughter, &c. BecauÅ¿e forÅ¿ooth (as Bracton maketh the reaÅ¿on) iÅ¿Å¿ue being had and continued to the third and fourth degrÃ©e, the heyre of the eldeÅ¿t, might now take homage without feare of being excluded from inheriting that which was altogether vnlike to deÅ¿cend vnto them: But by Bracton the youngeÅ¿t SiÅ¿ter Å¿hould preÅ¿ently doe fealtie to the eldeÅ¿t, and by Britton (who wrote after Marlbridge) the matter reÅ¿ted mÃ©erely in the Lords election, (for thus Å¿aith he) Election le Seignior aprendre tiels Å¿eruices per vn mayne ou per les mains de toutes les parceners, Car autrement per droit les gardes & marriages des auters parceners pur les parols in le briefe de gard o â¢ le plaintiffe dit que launceÅ¿ter, l'infant Å¿oit Å¿on tenant & lui fiÅ¿t Å¿eruice de chiualer. eac. 68. fo. 175.

Now Å¿Ã©eing that Glanuile, the Statute of Ireland, Bract. Britton, and al do agrÃ©e, that euery Lord might take his Å¿eruices by the hands of the eldeÅ¿t partner, (the reaÅ¿on whereof was a deÅ¿ire which the Law had to conÅ¿erue Seignories in their intierties, & that Lords Å¿hould not take or diuide them into mynnomes, and Crotchets) what was it that cauÅ¿ed the making of this ninth Chapter of Marlebridge? It Å¿hould Å¿Ã©eme that Lords in thoÅ¿e dayes played vpon the aduantage, And though they were Å¿crupulous in taking of homage, by which they were Å¿hut from Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion, and yet willing enough to take intirely all other emoluments incident or annext to the tenure, from one paire of hands: yet Å¿uite of Court, which is burdenous or inconuenient to none but to the tenants, they would be and were content to diÅ¿Å¿ipate, and it Å¿hould Å¿Ã©eme alÅ¿o that in puiÅ¿ne SiÅ¿ters and Coheyres, though they were eaÅ¿ily intreated, that the eldeÅ¿t Å¿hould do all Å¿uit and Å¿eruice, yet they could be well content to giue them nothing for their paines, and therefore a Statute was needfull, for other things I will not accuÅ¿e old writers of error, they erred not perhaps if they take it
as it was taken by Lawyers then, though that taking Å¿taggered from Lawes conformitie.

This I Å¿ay, (to me) the Å¿tatute of Ireland is Å¿ufficient to proue that the eldeÅ¿t SiÅ¿ter Å¿hall haue no gard, marriage, or Å¿ubiection of the yongeÅ¿t, and neither homage nor fealty (by Littl.) can be taken otherwiÅ¿e, then a Å¿eruice incident to a tenure, for which it is lawfull to diÅ¿traine. As therefore when a Mannor deÅ¿cendeth to two partners, each one may haue parcell of the demeÅ¿ne, and parcell of the Å¿eruices, and Å¿o of one there may Å¿tep vp two Mannors: And if the diuiÅ¿ion be that one Å¿hall haue the demeÅ¿nes, and another the Å¿eruices, the Å¿uite is now in a very haut Å¿uÅ¿pention, and the Mannor for a time broken in pieces: but it Å¿hal be a Mannor againe, if Å¿he which had the Å¿eruices die without IÅ¿Å¿ue, (per Thiru. 12. H. 4. fo. 34. 35) So I doubt not but when a tenement, holden by Å¿eruice military, deÅ¿cendeth vnto two coparceners, and diviÅ¿ion is euenly made, each of them may pay rents and do Å¿eruice for her part to the Lord, who may take fealty and homage of either of them, if he will: And may be compellable to take homage of one of them at the leaÅ¿t, which for the warrantie Å¿hall be auailable to both.

div.head: SECT. XXV. What Å¿eruice belongeth only to the eldeÅ¿t parcener to doe.
div.p:
THere is Å¿ome thing beÅ¿ides Å¿uite of Court that Å¿hall lie only vpon the part, which by an Alcumized tearme we call einitia: Fitzherbert titulo partition. 18. hath this note, If the Earledome of CheÅ¿ter deÅ¿cend vnto two parceners, it Å¿hall be diuided betwixt them, As other lands vÅ¿e to be, and the eldeÅ¿t Å¿hall not haue the Seigniory or Earledome whole to her Å¿elfe, quod nota: adiudged, percotam curiam. 23. H. 3. But this notwithÅ¿tanding if law Å¿hould haue the courÅ¿e, which Å¿he had in her Å¿tate of innocencie, I thinke the capitall MeÅ¿Å¿uage of a Knights fee, and the head
of an Earldome or Baronie in partition ought euer to goe to the eldeÅ¿t. And if becauÅ¿e there is not elÅ¿e perhaps wherewith to make purparte to the youngeÅ¿t coheyre, or not any other thing, holden in Capite, to be diÅ¿tributed for the Kings aduantage and Å¿o for neceÅ¿Å¿ity, (quae nullis vinculis legum contine â¢ ur) the head of a Barony be diuided, yet the indiuiÅ¿ible Å¿eruice by which it is holden, is Å¿cutage and grand-Å¿erjeantie, I meane the very actuall Å¿eruice, falleth by right vpon the eldeÅ¿t parcener. Et vbi eÅ¿t commodum, ibi debet eÅ¿Å¿e onus, and Å¿o vbi eÅ¿t onus debet eÅ¿Å¿e commodum: whether the caÅ¿e following proue mine aÅ¿Å¿ertion or no, I will Å¿et it downe out of my Lord Dyer, and then prepare me to Å¿peake of another partnerÅ¿hip: Humfrey Bohune, Å¿ometime Earle of Hereford and EÅ¿Å¿ex, held the Mannors of Harefield, Newman and WhitenhurÅ¿t by Å¿eruice of ConÅ¿tableÅ¿hip of England (which is grandÅ¿erjantie) and dyed Å¿eiÅ¿ed, hauing iÅ¿Å¿ue onely two daughters, they entred, tooke huÅ¿bands, and the huÅ¿band of the youngeÅ¿t became King, then partition was made, in which the King and his wife did chooÅ¿e WhitenhurÅ¿t and Harefield, and Newman fell to the other partner: By the opinion of all the IuÅ¿tices of England, the reÅ¿eruation of the tenure at the firÅ¿t was good, the two daughters before marriage ererciÅ¿e this office by Å¿ufficient deputie, and after marriage the huÅ¿band of the eldeÅ¿t might execute alone, And per omnes iuÅ¿ticiarios, as when there are two daughters, and the Father dyeth Å¿eiÅ¿ed of lands holden of one of them, the whole Å¿eruice, if it be entire, (as homage) is reviued after partition: Å¿o here vnitie of parcell of the tenansie in the King, did not determine the office, but it continued in the other parcener, Å¿o that the King might exact the Å¿eruice, or refuÅ¿e it at his pleaÅ¿ure, as euery Lord may refuÅ¿e the homage of his tenant, if it be not anceÅ¿trell. Me â¢ pur ceo que le office fuit haut & dangerous, & auxi ver â¢â¢ chargeable al Roy in fees, le Roy voile declaimer de auer le Å¿eruice execute Dier 11. Eliz. fo. 285.

div.head: THE WOMANS LAWIER. The Å¿econd BOOKE.
div.p: NOw that I haue brought vp a Woman, and made her an Inheritrix, taken her out of Ward, helped her to make partition, &c. me thinks Å¿he Å¿hould long to be married: Foemina appetit virum, Å¿icut materia formam, And I did not meane when I begun, to produce any VeÅ¿tall Virgin, Nim â¢ e, or new Saint Bridge â¢ . Following therefore my firÅ¿t intention, I will begin to inÅ¿truct Women growneâª firÅ¿t Å¿uch as are, or Å¿hortly Å¿hall be Wiues, and then Widdowes.

div.head: SECT. I. Of Marriage, according to the Ciuill and Common Law.
div.p:
MArriage is defined to be a Coniunction of Man and Woman, containing an inÅ¿eparable connexion, and
vnion of life. But as there is nothing that is begotten and finiÅ¿hed at once, Å¿o this Contract of coupling man and woman together, hath an inception firÅ¿t, and then an orderly procÃ©eding. The firÅ¿t beginning of Marriage (as in reÅ¿pect of Contract, and that which Law taketh hold on) is when Wedlocke by words in the future tence is promiÅ¿ed and vow â¢ d, and this is but Å¿ponÅ¿ioâª or Å¿ponÅ¿alia. The full Contract of Matrimonie, is when it is made by words, de praeÅ¿enti, in a lawfull conÅ¿ent, and thus two be made man and wife exiÅ¿ting without lying together, yet Matrimonie is not accounted conÅ¿ummate, vntill there goe with the conÅ¿ent of mind and will Coniunction of body.

div.head: SECT. II. Of SponÅ¿ion or firÅ¿t promiÅ¿ing.
div.p: THe firÅ¿t promiÅ¿ing and inception of Marriage â¢ s in two parts, either it is plaine, Å¿imple and naked, or confirmed and borne by giuing of Å¿omething: the firÅ¿t is, when a man and woman binde themÅ¿elues Å¿imply by their word only to Contract Matrimonie hereafter: the Å¿econd, when there is an oath made, or Å¿omewhat taken as an earneÅ¿t or pledge betwixt them on both parts, or on one part, to be married hereafter. There is not here to be Å¿tood vpon, the age definitiuely Å¿et downe for making of marriage irreuocable, but all that are Å¿euen yÃ©eres old (betwixt whom Matrimony may conÅ¿iÅ¿t) may make Å¿ponÅ¿ion and promiÅ¿e. But if any that is vnder the age of Å¿euen, begin this vow and betrothing, it is eÅ¿tÃ©emed as a miÅ¿t, and vaniÅ¿heth to nothing.

div.head: SECT. III. Of publike SponÅ¿ion.
div.p: THis SponÅ¿ion (in which as it Å¿tands, is no full Contract of Matrimony, nor any more, Å¿aue onely an obligation, or being bound in a Å¿ort to marry hereafter) may be publique or Å¿ecret: publique, either by the parties themÅ¿elues, preÅ¿ent together, or by meÅ¿Å¿age or Letters when they be diÅ¿tant one from another: Neither is there herein any curious forme of paction or Å¿tipulation required, but onely by words, howÅ¿oeuer expreÅ¿Å¿ed, a plaine conÅ¿ent and agrÃ©ement of the parties, and by the Ciuill Law, (with which the ancient Canons concorded) of their parentsâª if the Contractors were Å¿ub poteÅ¿tate parentum: the like reaÅ¿on Å¿Ã©emeth to be for conÅ¿ent of tutors, &c. But it is now receiued a generall opinion that the good-will of parents is required, in regard of honeÅ¿tie, not of neceÅ¿Å¿itie, according to the Canons which exact neceÅ¿Å¿arily, none other conÅ¿ent but only of the parties themÅ¿elues, whoÅ¿e Coniunction is in hand, without which the concluÅ¿ion of parents is of none effect: note further, that Å¿ponÅ¿alia may be made pure or conditionall, and whatÅ¿oeuer is elÅ¿e adjected (as earneÅ¿t, pledge, or Å¿uch like) is but accidentall.

div.head: SECT. IIII. Of Å¿ecret SponÅ¿ion.
div.p:
THoÅ¿e SpouÅ¿als which are made when a man is without witneÅ¿Å¿e, Solus cum Å¿ola, are called Å¿ecret promiÅ¿ing or deÅ¿ponÅ¿ation, which though it be tolerated, when by liquid & plaine probation it may appeare to the Iudge, and there is not any lawfull impediment to hinder the Contract, yet it is Å¿o little eÅ¿tÃ©emed of, (vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be very
manifeÅ¿t) that another promiÅ¿e publique made after it, Å¿hall be preferred and preuaile againÅ¿t it. The cauÅ¿e why it is miÅ¿tiked, is the difficultie of proofe for auoyding of it, when for offence her iuÅ¿t cauÅ¿e of refuÅ¿all, the one or other partie might Å¿Ã©eke to goe looÅ¿e, and perhaps cannot, but muÅ¿t Å¿tand haltered from any other Marriage, and the Iudge in Å¿uÅ¿pence what to determine.

div.head: SECT. V. The validity of the DeÅ¿ponÅ¿ation.
div.p: THough this SponÅ¿alia be alwaies made with intent that Matrimony Å¿hould inÅ¿ue, yet the Contracter cannot therunto be compelled, vnleÅ¿Å¿e there were another thing ioyned to the Contract of SpouÅ¿als, neither are they compellable to marry, though an oath accompanied the promiÅ¿e, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it were made pure and without Condition, for in conditionall Å¿ponÅ¿ion of Marriage, the bond of performance is Å¿uÅ¿pended in the Condition, till that be performed, vnleÅ¿Å¿e there follow a relinquiÅ¿hment of the Condition, by copulation of bodies, or a new conÅ¿ent by word â¢ of the preÅ¿ent.

div.head: SECT. VI. The nature of the Condition.
div.p:
ANd here in the quality of Conditions it is obÅ¿erued, that if the Condition annexed to the promiÅ¿e be repugnant againÅ¿t the right of Matrimony, the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the whole SpouÅ¿als are void: As if a man promiÅ¿e a woman to marry her, if Å¿he poiÅ¿on the child which Å¿he conceiued, the promiÅ¿e is of none effect, as towards Marriage. But a
Condition, though it be otherwiÅ¿e vnhoneÅ¿t or impoÅ¿Å¿ible, corrupteth not promiÅ¿e of Marriage if it be not aduerÅ¿ant, and againÅ¿t the Law of wedlocke.

div.head: SECT. VII. How long the performance of promiÅ¿e is to bee excepted.
div.p: NOw it may bee demanded what time muÅ¿t be tarried and expected by the Law Ciuill and Common, for perimpliÅ¿hing of promiÅ¿es made of future Wedlocke: It is anÅ¿wered, that if the limits of time prefixed when the Å¿ponÅ¿ion was firÅ¿t made, be once paÅ¿Å¿ed and expired: if the vow were made without limitation of time, then (where there appeareth not any weighty cauÅ¿e of Å¿tay) if both the parties be reÅ¿iding in one Prouince, the woman quae non vult â¢ ua vo â¢ a diutius delud â¢ , may after two yeares marry to whom Å¿he liÅ¿teth, But if her SpouÅ¿e be commorant in another Prouince, then Å¿he muÅ¿t tarry thrÃ©e yeares, Though indÃ©ede theÅ¿e times of expectance, may be prolonged and lengthened, by a Iudge, as he Å¿hall finde cauÅ¿e iuÅ¿t and reaÅ¿onable.

div.head: SECT. VIII. In what caÅ¿e the betrothed may refuÅ¿e one another.
div.p:
IF after the SponÅ¿ion or firÅ¿t betrothing, and before Matrimony contracted, Å¿ome euill diÅ¿eaÅ¿e (as leproÅ¿ie, or Å¿ome violent cauÅ¿e or caÅ¿ualty) make one of the parties vnfit for generation, the other may repudiate and abandon him or her, which Å¿hall be Å¿o diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed or vnabled. SpouÅ¿als are alÅ¿o diÅ¿Å¿olued for fornication, Å¿pecially if it be committed
by either of the parties with their kindred: likewiÅ¿e SpouÅ¿als which are made a pupillis may be diÅ¿Å¿olued by a bare renuntiation, but by no meanes they are rightlier auoided, then by a diÅ¿Å¿ention of both the Contractors, from their firÅ¿t conÅ¿ent, for by Å¿uch diÅ¿Å¿ent alÅ¿o Å¿ociety is or may be broken in Å¿under. There are other cauÅ¿es for which the bond of deÅ¿ponÅ¿ation may be taken away, as devulgation of kindred vnknowne, and opportunity of nuptialls Å¿ought by deteÅ¿table meanes, for which cauÅ¿e not only SpouÅ¿als, but Marriage it Å¿elfe, when it is contracted, may be diÅ¿Å¿olued.

div.head: SECT. IX. By what authoritie SpouÅ¿als are to bee vndone.
div.p: TO all theÅ¿e cauÅ¿es of vndoing the firÅ¿t vowes of marriage, there muÅ¿t be added the authority of the BiÅ¿h which hath power to abÅ¿olue, yet the Canons doe without the authority of any BiÅ¿hops make frÃ©e from the Obligation of onely promiÅ¿ed marriage, all thoÅ¿e which abdicate themÅ¿elues to Religion. And HoÅ¿tienÅ¿is contendeth that without authority of any Iudge, SpouÅ¿als are vndone ipÅ¿o iure, by a poÅ¿t-marriage, made by words of the preÅ¿ent time, Å¿ed nemo Å¿ibi ipÅ¿i ius dicere debet, no man may bee his owne Iudge: And it is certaine, that eÅ¿pouÅ¿als ought neuer to be vndone, but by publike authority, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the cauÅ¿e for which wee will haue them vndone be Å¿o well knowne, that it nÃ©edeth neither proofe nor Å¿entence, Å¿uch as is fornication when it is notorious, and publike to all the world.

div.head: SECT. X. Of Matrimony contracted in the preÅ¿ent time, and who may contract.
div.p: THoÅ¿e which the Latines call puberes, that is, they which are come once to Å¿uch Å¿tate, habit and diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of body that they may be deemed able to procreate, may contract Matrimony by words of the time preÅ¿ent, for in contract of Wedlocke, pubertas, is not Å¿trictly eÅ¿tÃ©emed by number of yeares, as it is in wardÅ¿hip, but rather by the maturity, ripeneÅ¿Å¿e, and diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of body: There is further required in them which contract Matrimonie, a Å¿ound and whole minde to conÅ¿ent, for hee that is mad, without intermiÅ¿Å¿ion of â¢ ury, cannot marry: But hee that is deafe and dumbe, may contract Matrimony, quia non verbis tantum Å¿ed nutu & Å¿ignis Å¿enÅ¿a mentis exprimuntur, and as they which are impuberes, cannot for infirmity of age, make any firme knot of Wedlocke, Å¿o likewiÅ¿e they which by coldneÅ¿Å¿e of nature, or by inchantment, are impotent, be forbidden to contract.

The impediments EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, as vowes, Compaternitie and Å¿pirituall kindred, I will not meddle with: But come to kindred of bloud, which containeth a principall let and prohibition of Marriage.

div.head: SECT. XI. Impediment of Marriage by Kindred and ConÅ¿anguinitie.
div.p:
IN the worlds infancie men were inforced by neceÅ¿Å¿ity to marry with owne kindred, propter hominum pauci â¢ atem, But that neceÅ¿Å¿ity is taken away and long Å¿ince by the very voice of God, they which are in certaine degrÃ©es of
bloud are forbidden to marry, Leuiticus 18. And becauÅ¿e Marriage is an aboundant Å¿eminarie of charitie and loue, it is wiÅ¿ely and profitably ordeyned that it Å¿hould be diÅ¿perÅ¿ed into many families.

Therefore by Naturall, Ciuill, and Common Law, Marriage is cleane forbidden betwixt all thoÅ¿e, which are as Parents or Children one towards another in infinitum; and betwixt thoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons, which are of kindred in the tranÅ¿uerÅ¿e line, Marriage is forbidden till the fourth degrÃ©e bee paÅ¿t.

div.head: SECT. XII. The impediment of Marriage by Affinitie.
div.p:
THere is further a certaine nigh alliance called affinity, quaÅ¿i fines duarum cognationum coniungensâª this riÅ¿eth betwixt them which are married, and the kindred of one of them, as betwixt the huÅ¿band and the kindred of his wife: now affinity prohibiteth Marriage onely to the perÅ¿ons contracted, &c. for the CoÅ¿ins or ConÅ¿anguinity to my wife, are of affinitie onely to me, and not to my brothers or children by a former Wife; and my bloud and conÅ¿anguinity are kindred of affinitie onely to my Wife, and not to her brothers or former children: here is it that the Father and the Sonne may marry the Mother and the Daughter, and two Brethren may marry two SiÅ¿ters in another Family: for the ConÅ¿anguinity, of which one is of bloud to the huÅ¿band, and another to the wife, are betwixt themÅ¿elues in no bond of affinity: And obÅ¿erue that in what degree a man or woman is to one of them that are married, by ConÅ¿anguinity, they are accompted in the Å¿ame degree to the other in affinity: As the wiues brother, who is in primo gradu to his SiÅ¿ter, is in the Å¿ame degree to her huÅ¿band, and their children in the Å¿econd, &c.
And Å¿o forth their Childrens Children, which after the fourth degrÃ©e, are againe by all lawes permitted to marrie, contrahi â¢â¢â¢ & affinitas per illicitum co â¢â¢ um.

div.head: SECT. XIII. DiuerÅ¿itie of Religion.
div.p: AMongÅ¿t the hinderances of marriage, note this alÅ¿o, that by ConÅ¿titution of holy Church, marriage is forbidden betwixt perÅ¿ons of divers Religions, as Iewes and ChriÅ¿tians.

div.head: SECT. XIV. Of feare and conÅ¿traint.
div.p: ALÅ¿o Matrimonie holdeth not when it is extorted by force, or by Å¿uch a feare as may cadere in conÅ¿tantem virum; quia matrimonia debent eÅ¿Å¿e libera.

div.head: SECT. XV. Of Marriage deteÅ¿table made.
div.p: ALÅ¿o Marriage holdeth not, when it is Å¿ought or made with wickednes: And if a man promiÅ¿e to a woman which he hath adulterouÅ¿ly polluted that he will marry her when his wife dyeth, &c. Or if a man haue Å¿ought to abridge the dayes of his lawfull wife to marry another: TheÅ¿e villanies are Å¿uch perpetuall cankers in marriage, that they doe not onely hinder it to be made, but alÅ¿o rend it in Å¿under when it is made.

There are other crimes, quae diÅ¿trahunt Matrimonia contracta, as InceÅ¿t cum cognata, and rauiÅ¿hment, yet if any man rauiÅ¿h a Maide, or other vnmarried Woman, the Canons doe admit him to marry with her if Å¿he conÅ¿ent: But otherwiÅ¿e Å¿hee Å¿hall be rendered to her Father, vpon whoÅ¿e Å¿uite and accuÅ¿ation, the rauiÅ¿her is put to Capitall puniÅ¿hment.

There are by the Ciuill and Common Lawes many other impediments of Marriage, as Å¿uÅ¿ceptio propriae Å¿obolis, publica poenitentia, caedes Sacerdotis, interdictum EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticum, &c. which I will not trouble Women withall.

div.head: SECT. XVI. Marriage forbidden by publique ConÅ¿titution.
div.p: BY Ciuill ordinance alÅ¿o Marriage is Å¿ometime reÅ¿trained and forbidden, as betwixt him which adopteth, and her which is adopted: for Å¿Ã©eing that they which are adopted are in the place and Å¿tead of Children, there reÅ¿teth a League, as of kindred betwixt them and the bloud of him which adopteth, by the Ciuill Law and Canons both.

But this Ciuill kindred laÅ¿teth no longer then the adopted are in poteÅ¿tate adoptantis, Neither is it any obÅ¿tacle to a Marriage, Å¿aue onely betwixt the adopted and adoptant, and thoÅ¿e which are in his power. And as adoption hindereth Marriage by the Ciuill Law: Å¿o by the Å¿ame lawe, a man may not marry her whom hee tooke expoÅ¿ed, as a caÅ¿t-away or a foundling, and brought her vp as a Daughter. Marriage is alÅ¿o forbidden, Å¿ometime ratione publicae honeÅ¿tatis, as if a Man be diuorced
from his wife, and afterwards Å¿hÃ©e hath a Daughter by another man, this is no Daughter in Law to the huÅ¿band, yet hÃ©e Å¿hould doe impudently to marry her, ThoÅ¿e prohibitions of Marriage that were Å¿ometime betwixt a Tutor and Pupill, betwixt a PreÅ¿ident and a Woman in his Å¿ubiection, betwixt a Senator and a frÃ©ed bondwoman, betwixt a Senators Daughter and a frÃ©ed bondman, betwixt a woman Comedian or one whoÅ¿e parents vÅ¿ed Å¿ome laÅ¿ciuious or light Art, and a Senator: laÅ¿tly, betwixt frÃ©e and Å¿eruile, are all either by long publike CuÅ¿tome or by Common Law taken away.

div.head: SECT. XVII. Of Polygamie.
div.p:
THere are examples in Scripture of Poligamy (viz.) where men had more wiues then one at once, as Abraham, Iacob, Dauid, and Salomon had: And it Å¿eemeth 21. of Deuteromie 15. that it was Å¿ufferable by MoyÅ¿es his law, But it was Å¿aid at the firÅ¿t, man and wife Å¿hall be one fleÅ¿h, and the examples were rather permitted then lawfull. The Ciuill Law Canons, and all ChriÅ¿tian Common wealths doe vtterly condemne Polygamie, and Å¿o much did the wiÅ¿e Emperors of Rome deteÅ¿t all petulancie of Marriage, that they made and ordained Lawes, that Women which within the yeare of mourning for their huÅ¿bands betake them to wedlocke againe, Å¿hould be reputed infamous and defamed. But this alÅ¿o the Canons haue taken away, Contracts of Matrimony ought to be publike. Nuptials de preÅ¿en â¢ i ought alwaies to be made publike at the Church, or at the leaÅ¿t, in preÅ¿ence & Congregation, del bon g â¢ n â¢ s, yet is it not of neceÅ¿Å¿ity, that they which marry Å¿tipulate by theÌÅ¿elues, or be preÅ¿ent in perÅ¿on at the contract
making, but it may be well enough by Proctor, Å¿o that the Contractors themÅ¿elues be willing and witting, or that they ratifie it when it is done.

div.head: SECT. XVIII. What words are requiÅ¿ite.
div.p: THere nÃ©eds no Å¿tipulation or curious forme of Contract in Wedlocke making, but Å¿uch words as proue a mutuall conÅ¿ent are Å¿ufficient, and it may be made by Letters. If queÅ¿tion riÅ¿e about words, recurrendum eÅ¿t ad communem intellectum, & vÅ¿um loquendi, & indubio pro matrimonio iudicandum, for there is more doubtfulneÅ¿Å¿e in conÅ¿truing of words, vt res magis valeat quam pereat, &c.

div.head: SECT. XIX. The Accidents of Marriage.
div.p: THoÅ¿e things which are of Å¿olemnitie or beneuolence, as prouiÅ¿ion of Dower, earneÅ¿t, giuing pledges, nuptiall benediction, &c. are not of the eÅ¿Å¿ence of Matrimony which is made by conÅ¿ent: for though Dower cannot conÅ¿iÅ¿t without Marriage, yet Marriage may very well Å¿tand without dower: And Å¿o it is of all Donations propter nuptias: In onely one caÅ¿e written inÅ¿truments are required in making of Marriage, and that is where a man marrieth her whom he hath holden a long time as Concubine, here inÅ¿trumenta dotalia are behouefull, that the children had before Marriage, may be eÅ¿tÃ©emed Legitimate: But this holdeth not in England.

div.head: SECT. XX. Wherefore Marriage ought to be made.
div.p: THe cauÅ¿es of Matrimony principally are two: The firÅ¿t is Å¿uÅ¿ceptio Å¿obolis, increaÅ¿e of Children, for euen by Plato euery good man ought to deÅ¿ire that he may leaue behind him worÅ¿hippers of God, and propagators of piety: The Å¿econd cauÅ¿e is the euiting of fornication and vncleanneÅ¿Å¿e 1. ad Corinth. ca. 7 Saint Paul biddeth, that to auoid fornication euery man haue his owne wife, and euery woman her own huÅ¿band, and whoÅ¿oeuer marryeth for beautie, age, order, Å¿plendour of birth, or for riches, rather then for theÅ¿e two cauÅ¿es, doth very peruerÅ¿ly, though it be not expreÅ¿Å¿ly diÅ¿allowed, but Marriage may be for the other things alÅ¿o, and the ConÅ¿ent may be giuen for them.

div.head: SECT. XXI. The ConÅ¿ummation and indiuiduitie of Marriage.
div.p:
WHen to the ConÅ¿ent of minde, there is added Copulation of body, Matrimonie is conÅ¿ummate, the principall end whereof is propagation or procreation: But where the courÅ¿e after going is not obÅ¿erued, there riÅ¿eth no lawfull Off-Å¿pring, the Children which are had, are not in power and commandement of them which beget or beare them, neither are they taken by Law for any other, then vulgo que â¢ i â¢ i. OtherwiÅ¿e it is in lawfull Wedlocke, the knot whereof is Å¿o Å¿traight and indiÅ¿Å¿oluble, that they which are yoked therein, cannot the one without the conÅ¿ent of the other, (neither was it euer permitted) abdicate themÅ¿elues, or enter into Religion, for Saint Paul in the aboue titled EpiÅ¿tle and Chapter, Å¿aith plainely, that the
huÅ¿band hath not power of his owne body, &c. And there cannot chance any fedity or vncleanneÅ¿Å¿e of body Å¿o great, as that for it a man and wife ought perpetually to be Å¿egregated, yea Å¿o vnpartible be they, that law Å¿aith, they may not vtterly leaue coniugalem conÅ¿uetudinem, though one of them haue the very leproÅ¿ie it Å¿elfe.

And here is moued a queÅ¿tion not impertinent, That is, whether a woman be bound to follow her huÅ¿band wherÅ¿oeuer he goeth, if he require it, wherevnto it is anÅ¿wered by Bartall and by Å¿ome other, That if the wife before Å¿hee married knew the negotiations and occaÅ¿ions of her huÅ¿band, would be Å¿uch, that he muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity euer be trauelling, Å¿he is bounden, and i â¢ the Contract Å¿eemeth to haue conÅ¿ented to go with him at commandement, but if after the bargaine made he take vp a new tricke of circum â¢â¢ gar â¢ , Å¿he may let him goe when he liÅ¿t, and tarry at home when Å¿hÃ©e will.

div.head: SECT. XXII. Of Diuorce.
div.p: PActis poenarum cogi poteÅ¿t nemo ad Matrimonium contrahendum: And as no man can be compelled by any conuention of paine or penaltie to contract Matrimony, Å¿o is it impoÅ¿Å¿ible, when it is once lawfully and euidently contracted, to diÅ¿tract it by any partition, couenant, or humane traction, Quos Deus coniunxit, homo non Å¿eparet, yet there are CauÅ¿es, for which diuers are permitted: But Diuorce, that onely Å¿eparateth a conÅ¿uetudine coniugali, taketh not away the bond of Matrimony, and therefore Diuorces are Å¿ometimes perpetuall, as long as the parties liue, Å¿ometimes for a Å¿eaÅ¿on limited, and Å¿ometime, till reconcilement be had, and he that maketh Diuorce with his wife being only Å¿eparated a Toro, is forbidden to take another wife.

div.head: SECT. XXIII. CauÅ¿es of Diuorce.
div.p: THe Ciuill Law hath many cauÅ¿es of Diuorce, but by Diuine and Common Law, the onely Å¿ufficient cauÅ¿e is adultery and fornication, which by the Canons is carnall and Å¿pirituall: the Å¿pirituall is hereÅ¿ie and Idolatry: They diÅ¿Å¿olue Matrimony for Å¿pirituall fornication onely, where one of the parties is conuerted to ChriÅ¿tian faith, and the other for hatred of his religion will not cohabit, &c. And this is taken alÅ¿o from Saint Paul 1. ad Corinth. 7. where he Å¿aith, If the vnbelÃ©euing depart, let him depart, a Brother or SiÅ¿ter is not in Å¿ubiection.

div.head: SECT. XXIV. Impotencie or DiÅ¿abilitie of Procreation.
div.p: THere is admitted alÅ¿o, in diÅ¿Å¿olution of Marriage, the complaint of impotencie: And IuÅ¿tinian very diÅ¿crÃ©etly, willed that in that exploration or proofe of the defect there Å¿hould be expected thrÃ©e yeares: but the Canons ordeine that Matrimony is diÅ¿Å¿olued by probation of impotencie, without mention or limits of time. And this is more then a bare diuorce or Å¿eparation, a Toro, for it diÅ¿Å¿olueth Marriage, auoyding it as it had neuer bÃ©ene: Å¿o that he or Å¿hee whoÅ¿e fellow is conuicted of impotencie, may chooÅ¿e a new friend, and preÅ¿ently marry againe.
But this is to be vnderÅ¿tood of impotencie which was before the Marriage made: for indÃ©ede where the impediment was Å¿o precedent, there could not any Matrimony exiÅ¿t or haue being, &c.

OtherwiÅ¿e it is, when this diÅ¿ability betideth after Marriage perfected and conÅ¿ummate, for in that caÅ¿e, he or Å¿he
which remaineth potent, Å¿hall not leaue and depart from the impotent, but be compelled to beare the diÅ¿commodity, aÅ¿well as any other ill fortune. And that which is here taught of Coniugall impotencie, Å¿tretcheth to all impediments of Marriage which are perpetuall, vt per ea Matrimonium nunquam extitiÅ¿le iudicetur.

div.head: SECT. XXV. Marriages inter aÅ¿cendentes & deÅ¿cendentes.
div.p: THoÅ¿e Marriages that are made betweene aÅ¿cendentes and deÅ¿cendentes, are Å¿o deteÅ¿table, that by the Ciuill law they deÅ¿erue exile and confiÅ¿cation of goods. And there is a gloÅ¿Å¿e that would extend this to all vnlawfull Marriages: but by Bartell and others, it is to be inflicted only vpon thoÅ¿e, which are contra iura Å¿anguinis.

div.head: SECT. XXVI. Captiuitie or long abÅ¿ence of one which is married.
div.p: IT falleth out not Å¿eldome, the one of them which are married to be taken captiue, or otherwiÅ¿e Å¿o deteined, that it is vncertaine if he liue or no.

Therefore becauÅ¿e it is in Å¿ome Å¿ort dangerous to expect long the incertaine returne of an abÅ¿ent yoake-fellow, here the Ciuill Law did ordaine, that after a huÅ¿band had bÃ©ene gone fiue yeares, and nothing knowne whether he liued or no, the wife might marry againe, and Å¿o might the huÅ¿band, that had expected his wife, &c. But the Common Law commandeth Å¿imply to forbeare Marriage till the death of him or her that is miÅ¿Å¿ing be certainely knowne.

div.head: SECT. XXVII. That no crime diÅ¿Å¿olueth marriage.
div.p: OF old time, Å¿ome Crimes were numbred amongÅ¿t the CauÅ¿es of DiÅ¿Å¿oluing marriage: but IuÅ¿tinian changed the Law here in part, and the Canons vpon the Å¿aying of ChriÅ¿t, Quos Deus coniunxit, &c. will not by any meanes that Matrimony rightly made and conÅ¿ummate, can bee diÅ¿Å¿olued, quoad ad vinculum Matrimonij. though for fornication they Å¿uffer a parting, quoad Torum. So that nodus legitimi Matrimonij, is neuer diÅ¿Å¿olued but by death, and the wife as long as Å¿he liueth is Å¿ubiect to the law of her huÅ¿band by Saint Paul.

Yet Å¿aith Lagus, Å¿Ã©eing that in Contracts of Wedlock we regard as well what is decent and conuenient, as what is lawfull, I cannot tell why we be not bound in diÅ¿Å¿oluing of it to follow the like equitie: and for example, if a Wife cannot dwell with her huÅ¿band without manifeÅ¿t danger of death, becauÅ¿e he is cruell and bloudy, why may not Å¿hee be Å¿eparated iudicis ordinarij cognitione precedente.

div.head: SECT. XXVIII. The Authoritie of the ordinarie Iudge, &c.
div.p:
FOr if SpouÅ¿als of future Marriage cannot be diÅ¿Å¿olued without publike authority, it muÅ¿t nÃ©edes follow, that without like authoritie, there can bee no repudiation when Matrimony is fully contracted and conÅ¿ummate: But in purÅ¿uing of diuorce the Å¿trict order of Iudiciall proceedings is not alwayes Å¿euerely kept: for regularly production of witneÅ¿Å¿es before conteÅ¿tation of Å¿uite, non adiuuat producentem, yet if Cornelia Å¿ue a Diuorce againÅ¿t Sempronius, cauÅ¿a conÅ¿anguinitatis, and Sempronius being
cited will not appeare, if now Cornelia bring her witneÅ¿Å¿es, the Iudge may receiue them.

Marry this religious obÅ¿eruation the Canons giue him euer, when he commeth to point of Iudgement, That the danger is leÅ¿Å¿e, in leauing men contrary to the Statutes of men, then in Å¿eparating (contrary to the Statutes of God) thoÅ¿e which are lawfully conioyned.

Thus farre haue I run my Å¿elfe in debt to Doctorâª Conradus Lagus, of whom in the third part of his Method, ca. 22. may be further learned the difference betwixt Scortum, pellex and Concubina, Our EngliÅ¿h comprehendeth them all in one word, and I would they dwelt all in one HouÅ¿e, beyond Seas, Concubinatus Å¿peciem conjugijâhabet; Et ex Concubinae natis conceditur beneficium legitimationis. If maid, wife or widow, aÅ¿ke what I meane to tell them Å¿o much of Ciuill and Canon Law, Å¿Ã©eing they be none of thoÅ¿e Country women, I pray them not to looke for the Regions in mappa mundi, but for their owne Regiment in ChriÅ¿tian dutie: The Å¿pirituall Law is here an Oracle to the temporall, which euermore Å¿endeth to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Iudge, viz. the BiÅ¿hop, for certification of lawfulnes or vnlawfulnes of Wedlocks when Accouplements come in queÅ¿tion.

div.head: SECT. XXIX. Statutes concerning Marriage.
div.p:
FOr it is true that Newdigat â¢
Å¿aith, 12. He. 8. fo. 6. that marriage and Diuorcements with the circumÅ¿tances of them be properly no parcell of Common-Lawes learning.

Yet it is very nÃ©edfull here that I Å¿hew you here what the Lawes of England haue nÃ©edfully concerning Marriage eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed, 32. H. 8. ca. 38. declareth all perÅ¿ons lawfully to
marry, which are not prohibited by Gods Law. And it was ordeyned, that all Marriages contracted and Å¿olemnized in face of the Church, and conÅ¿ummate with bodily knowledge, Å¿hould remaine indefeaÅ¿able, notwithÅ¿tanding any pre-contract, &c. Further, that neither diÅ¿penÅ¿ation, preÅ¿cription, law, reÅ¿eruation, prohibition, or any thing (Gods law excepted) Å¿hall trouble or impeach any Marriage made without the Leuiticall degrÃ©es, nor any man bee receiued in Å¿pirituall Court to proceÅ¿Å¿e, plea, or obligation, contrary to this Act. This Statute, though it Å¿eemed to be made vpon good and great conÅ¿iderations, (becauÅ¿e precontracts too too Å¿lenderly proued, and Å¿ometime but onely Å¿urmized, helped the RomiÅ¿h oppreÅ¿Å¿ion, and Å¿eparated thoÅ¿e which were at quiet in an honeÅ¿t coniunction) yet many did after the making of it, very diÅ¿Å¿olutely come from their firÅ¿t vowes, and, as it were in Å¿pight of conÅ¿cience and EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall cenÅ¿ure, coupled themÅ¿elues bodily with Å¿uch as they newly fancied, Å¿lipperily leauing their former Contracts: it is repealed 2. & 3. Ed. 6. ca. 3. only in the points of pre-contracts: And they are left in the validity which they were of, by the Kings EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical lawes, immediately before the making of 32. with prouiÅ¿o that all the reÅ¿t of the Å¿aid Act Å¿tandeth whole and in Å¿trength. So is it now againe by 1. Eliz. cap. 1. See alÅ¿o 5. & 6. Ed. 6. ca. 12. that the Marriage of PrieÅ¿ts and EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall perÅ¿ons is lawfull, their Children legitimate, a PrieÅ¿t may be tenant by the courteÅ¿ie, and his Wife haue Dower.

It is a Å¿port to behold how Å¿ome of the CanoniÅ¿ts & GloÅ¿Å¿ographers refreÅ¿hed themÅ¿elues in their diÅ¿putes about Nuptiall queÅ¿tions, how cleare they make it, that, If Adam our firÅ¿t Father were now aliue and a Widdower, he could not take a Wife, quia, all Women are his Children, and that in the right line: Then what a queÅ¿tion it is, whether vnlawfull copulation cauÅ¿e any affinitie or no.

In hoc articulo, (Å¿aith one of them) non parcam in foro verecundiae, that is to Å¿ay, hee will handle the quiddick without Å¿hame or honeÅ¿tie, and then in the plaineÅ¿t that may be, he findeth a difference betwixt a dogges necke in â¢ he Collar, and his noÅ¿e in the King, betwixt knocking at the Barrels head, and Å¿etting it abroach: but the curious learning w. is that of Å¿pirituall kindred, cauÅ¿ed either by holy BaptiÅ¿me, or by the bleÅ¿Å¿ed ChriÅ¿me, and this had power impediendi Matrimonium contrahendum, & dirimend â¢ matrimonium contractum: yea, this was Å¿uch a matter, that 39. Ed. 3. fo. 32. BaÅ¿tardie is pleaded againÅ¿t the Plaintiffe in aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e, and the cauÅ¿e was, that the father married a woman, before which Marriage he had chriÅ¿tned â¢â¢â¢ which was his Wiues couÅ¿in, and for this cauÅ¿e, after and of them was dead, Diuorce was Å¿ued, and Iudgement thereof giuen in the Å¿pirituall Court, though indÃ©ed by IuÅ¿tice Thorpe, and the greateÅ¿t opinion in the temporall Court, the IÅ¿Å¿ue could not be baÅ¿tardized, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the Parents had beene called, and the Nuptials deÅ¿troyed by Å¿entence, which was now impoÅ¿Å¿ible to doe, for death had determined them.

Out of queÅ¿tion therefore, if the parties had liued, a little or no Kindred, had marred great good acquaintance: But howÅ¿oeuer, by thoÅ¿e dayes Å¿ecular Marriage was forbidden in Å¿pirituall men, and Å¿ecular men were Å¿traightly prohibited by Å¿pirituall. Spirituall Kindred, the Statutes afore-going, haue now welcomm â¢â¢ Wedlocke, cleane out of the Popes Å¿tockes, And the 18. of Leuiticus alone, doth in a manner Å¿ufficiently demonÅ¿trate, with what perÅ¿ons Women are reÅ¿tricted to marry.

div.head: SECT. XXX. With what perÅ¿ons Women may not marry.
div.p: SUch are her Grand-father, her Father, her Sonnes Sonne, &c. her Brother, though it be but the one part, her Fathers or Mothers Brother, her Brothers or SiÅ¿ters Sonne, or her Sonnes Sonne. Brothers or SiÅ¿ters Children (Å¿aith Ramus in his Commentaries of ChriÅ¿tian Religion, lib. 2. ca. 9.) are forbiden to inter-marry, ed more, non lege Diuina vel Roman â¢ : ChriÅ¿tians, he Å¿aith further, which haue abrogated the Law, 25. of Deuteronomy, whereby a Brother might bee challenged to raiÅ¿e vp the houÅ¿e of his deceaÅ¿ed brother, haue alÅ¿o conÅ¿tituted a prohibition, within certaine degrÃ©es of affinity, and therefore a man may not marry with the widdow of his Grandfather or of his Father, or with the widdow of his owne Sonne, or of his Sonnes Sonne, or with the widdow of his Brother, or of his Brothers Son, or of his Brothers Sonnes Sonne, &c. Nor with the Grand-mother, Mother, Daughter, Neece, great Aunt, Aunt or SiÅ¿ter of his deceaÅ¿ed wife.

div.head: SECT. XXXII. Of Wooing.
div.p:
I Am affraid my feminine acquaintance will Å¿ay I writ as I liue, I talke much of Marriage, but I came not forward: Å¿tay a while yet I pray you, I know many an honeÅ¿t woman more repenting her haÅ¿tie Marriage ere Å¿he was w â¢ oed, then all the other Å¿innes that euer Å¿he committed. It were good reaÅ¿on we Å¿peake a little of wooing, but to handle that matter, per genus & Å¿pecies, would take vp as much roome, as the Indian figge-tree, euery thrid
whereof, when it falleth to the ground, groweth to a body. I will Å¿lip by it, onely obÅ¿eruing that the giuing of gloues, rings, bracelets, chains, or any thing that is ex Å¿ponÅ¿alioruÌ largitate (as a man would Å¿ay, of loues liberality) or as a pledge of future Marriage betwixt them that are promiÅ¿ed, haue a conditionâª (Å¿ilent for the moÅ¿t part) annexed vnto them, that if Matrimony doe not inÅ¿ue, the things may be demanded backe and recouered, yet there is a diÅ¿tinction of like, for I haue authoritie in it, Si Å¿ponÅ¿us dedit aliquid, & aliquo caÅ¿u impediuntur nuptiae, donatio penitus reÅ¿cinditur, niÅ¿i oÅ¿culum intervenerit; marry if he had a kiÅ¿Å¿e for his money, then the one halfe of that which was giuen, is the womans owne good: And Å¿he hath yet more fauor in the caÅ¿e, for whatÅ¿oeuer Å¿hee gaue, were there kiÅ¿Å¿ing or no kiÅ¿Å¿ing betwixt them, Å¿he may aske all, and haue all againe. Quaere of this in the ConÅ¿iÅ¿torie.

div.head: SECT. XXXII. The Condiments of Loue.
div.p: THere are with vs, as wel as with the Ciuilians, many kinds of Donations propter nuptias, and Å¿ome ex Å¿ponÅ¿aliorum largitate: Good meats are the better for good Å¿auce; veniÅ¿on craueth wine, and Wedlocke hath certaine Condiments, which come beÅ¿t in Å¿eaÅ¿on in the wooing time, and Å¿erue (as Breton Å¿aith) pour doner fees come melier talent d'aymer Matrimonie. A huÅ¿band per se, is a deÅ¿irable thing, but Donements or Feoffements, &c. better the Å¿tomacke, though of it Å¿elfe it be good and eager, And becauÅ¿e the firÅ¿t Marriage made in Paradice, if you marke it well, had a Iointure, I cannot but allow the circumÅ¿pection which is had.

div.head: SECT. XXXIII. Of Franke Marriage.
div.p: IT was, as I Å¿uppoÅ¿e, more frequent in the old time, that men gaue Lands with their Daughters in Marriage, then it was at this day: But now as then, if a man liberally and freely, without money or other conÅ¿iderations, Å¿aue onely loue and naturall affection, giue Lands of Tenements to another man, with a woman which is Daughter, SiÅ¿ter, or CouÅ¿in to the Donor, in Franke Marriage, whether it bee tempore Matrimonij, vel ante vel poÅ¿t, this word Franke Marriage maketh an eÅ¿tate of Inheritance, viz. to the Donees, and the heyres of their two bodies, and they Å¿hall hold quite of all manner of Å¿eruices (except the pure fealtie) till the fourth degree bee paÅ¿t. But the IÅ¿Å¿ue in the fift degree, and his DeÅ¿cendant, Å¿hall hold of the Donor and his Heyres, as they hold ouer.

div.head: SECT. XXXIV. The Gift muÅ¿t bee Franke.
div.p: PEr Rich. 16. aÅ¿Å¿i. p. 66. if a man giue land in Franke Marriage, rendring a rent, the reÅ¿eruation is voyde, till the fourth degree be paÅ¿t per Martine IuÅ¿tice, 4. H 6. 22. Å¿uch a reÅ¿eruation is mÃ©erely voyde, for it is contrary to the nature of Franke Marriage.

By the old tenures, Å¿uch a reÅ¿eruation is good, and the DonÃ©e Å¿hall hold in Common eÅ¿tate taile; by Brooke in his Abridgement, it cannot be any eÅ¿tate taile, for want of the parol heyres. And where Å¿uch a gift is made to a woman,
not couÅ¿in to the Donor, there paÅ¿Å¿eth but eÅ¿tate for life, for it is by a maxime or ground, that Franke Marriage maketh inheritance, and this caÅ¿e is out of the principall: By Bracton fo. 28. & 29. Si terra detur in maritagium viro cum vxore, & eorum haeredibus pro homagio & Å¿eruitio viri, licet detur in liberum maritagium (quaâª Å¿unt Å¿ibi ad inuicem aduerÅ¿antia, &c.) tunc prefe ãâ¦ã um & erit ac Å¿i donatio fieret tai â¢ viro quam vxori, he deliuereth the like learning before, fo. 22. and this rule withall
â¢ x tacita conditione & pacta incontinenti oppoÅ¿ita inÅ¿unt contractibus, & legem dant eis & illos infirmant.

div.head: SECT. XXXII. The gift muÅ¿t be to a Woman, &c.
div.p: IT was deliuered for a Law in tempore H. 8. that Lands cannot be giuen to a man in Frank Marriage, though he be CouÅ¿in to the Donor.

div.head: SECT. XXXVI. It may be tempore Matrimonij, ante, vel poÅ¿t.
div.p: WHat if after the gift made, the man refuÅ¿e to marry, the CouÅ¿in of the Donor marry elÅ¿e-where?

If two DonÃ©es in taile after the Common forme be diuorced vpon a pre-contract made by the woman, they Å¿halâª remaine ioyn-tenants of the Franke Tenementâª and the Inheritance is gone Tail â¢ 9. But per Dyer fo. 147. and 12. aÅ¿Å¿i. p. 22. and 19. aÅ¿Å¿i. p. 2. If Tenants in Franke Marriage be diuorced, the Woman Å¿hall haue all the Land, for the Land was giuen for the womans Å¿ake, and
for her aduancement, and by Iohn Bracton, her huÅ¿band hath no more in it but CuÅ¿todiam, as he is the wiues tutor and Guardian: By the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on therefore that the wife Å¿hall haue the land, if Å¿he be diuorced, by the Å¿ame, I Å¿hould thinke, Å¿he Å¿hould haue it, if her SponÅ¿us refuÅ¿e to marry her: But where I giue Land to one to marry my Daughter, or, if hee marry my Daughter, there, if hee marry another woman, I may enter.

div.head: SECT. XXXVI. The word Franke Marriage maketh Inheritance.
div.p:
IF a man giue lands with his SiÅ¿ter to I. S. in Franke Marriage, habendum â¢ is & haeredibus Å¿uis in perpetuum. By Kniue â¢ , Mowbray and Finchden, 45. Ed. 3. fo. 19. this maketh neither Frank Marriage nor eÅ¿tate taile, with an expectance of fÃ©e, (as in CaÅ¿e where Lands are giuen expreÅ¿ly in taile, habendum eis & haeredibus, but the fee-Å¿imple paÅ¿Å¿eth preÅ¿ently by the gift, for Frank Marriage muÅ¿t be holden of the Donorâª which here hath nothing left in him, but all is holden of the Lord Parainount, and the words doe not make any other eÅ¿tate taile: yet 13. Ed. 1. lands were giuen to one, with the CouÅ¿in of the Donor in Franke Marriage, habendum eis & haeredibus, and it was taken for good Frank Marriage: This, Å¿aith Brooke, was in the yeare, that eÅ¿tates taile were made in. But for all that, if yee look the caÅ¿e in Fitzherbert, Formedone 63. whither Brooke Å¿endeth you, you Å¿hall perceiue that at the time of the gift, it was Franke Marriage in fÃ©e-Å¿imple, for by thoÅ¿e dayes the Donee had poteÅ¿tatem alienandi poÅ¿t prolem Å¿uÅ¿citat â¢ m: But in a gift made after the Statute of quia emptore â¢ , on Å¿uch a faÅ¿hion, I take it the Law will be, as before in the caÅ¿e 45. Ed. 3. According as it was alÅ¿o
holden in the yeares of H. 8. that if a gift bee made in Franke Marriage, the remainder to I. S. in fÃ©e: this is no good Franke Marriage, for warrantie and acquitall that are incident, &c. bee only in regard of the reuerÅ¿ion to the Donor, and they cannot be had when the fÃ©e-Å¿imple is preÅ¿ently conueyed to a Å¿tranger.

div.head: SECT. XXXVIII. The Accompt of the Degrees.
div.p:
LIttl. accounts the Degrees from the Donor to the Donees, the firÅ¿t DegrÃ©e; from the DonÃ©es to their IÅ¿Å¿ue, the Å¿econd; from the DonÃ©es IÅ¿Å¿ue to his IÅ¿Å¿ue, the third, &c. and the IÅ¿Å¿ue in the fift DegrÃ©e Å¿hall doe Å¿eruice. And this (Å¿aith he) becauÅ¿e the IÅ¿Å¿ue of the Donor and the IÅ¿Å¿ue of the DonÃ©e after the fourth DegrÃ©e paÅ¿t, may inter-marrie by holy Churches Law. Bracton accompts thus, donatarius facit primum gradum; haeres Å¿uus facit Å¿ecundum; haeres haeredis facit tertium; haeres Å¿ecundi haeredis facit quartum, qui tenebitur ad Å¿eruitium, yea, hee maketh it an expreÅ¿Å¿e rule, that onely the DonÃ©e and two heyres Å¿uccÃ©eding lineally, Å¿hall enioy the immunitie of being acquitted. And hee Å¿eemeth to vnderÅ¿tand no other reaÅ¿on of the acquitall Å¿o long, but onely an abÅ¿tenancie from homage, leÅ¿t the taking of it Å¿hould hinder a reuerting, if it betided the DonÃ©e, or the IÅ¿Å¿ue to die without IÅ¿Å¿ue. Fitzherbert titulo droit 55. and 60. citeth 6 H. 3. and 15. H. 3. in warrant of Bractons Computation, which I thinke he fetched not any further then out of the Author himÅ¿elfe, in whom fo. 21. I find it. And fo. 22. hee anÅ¿wereth a doubt of his owne aÅ¿king, that is, Whether all other Å¿eruice Å¿hall follow and continue, if homage be done ante ter â¢ ium haeredem, wherein he concludeth, that the Å¿eruice euer followeth homage, quamuis ad damnum Å¿oluentium: And I conclude, whether
it be the third heyre, or the fourth, that Å¿hall doe Å¿eruice, he may Å¿till vouch, haue a Writ of me ne, as if the fourth DegrÃ©e were not paÅ¿t, and if he bring a Formedone, the Writt Å¿hall be Dedit in liberum Maritagium.

div.head: SECT. XXXIX. A Woman giues Lands to one to marry her.
div.p:
AS Franke Marriage maketh Inheritance without the words Heyres, and is alwayes made to a woman, and for her Å¿ake: Å¿o there is another Donatio prop â¢ er nuptias, that is conditionall without words of Condition made euer by a woman to a man. That is, where a woman giues Land to a man in fee-Å¿imple, or for tearme of his life, to the intent that hee marry her, who if hee afterwards when hee is thereto within conuenient time required, refuÅ¿e, &c. there is now an ordinary Writt for remedy granted in this caÅ¿e, to reduce the Land, which Writt may be Å¿ued in the per cui, or poÅ¿t, after one or more alienations, either by the woman Å¿ole, or by her and her huÅ¿band married, againÅ¿t Å¿uch a one as Å¿hould haue married her, after the refuÅ¿all, or after her death by her Heyre, whether it bee Sonne or Daughter, or Daughters with the child of another, and there needs no Å¿cripture or writing to proue that the feoffement was for intent of Marriage: nay, if a woman infeoffe a Å¿tranger, to the intent to infeoffe her, and one which Å¿he intendeth to marrie, if now the eÅ¿pouÅ¿als take not effect, Å¿he may haue Writt cauÅ¿a Matrimonij prelocuti, againÅ¿t the Å¿tranger, though the dÃ©ed of feoffement were Å¿imple and Å¿ans Condition, an. 34. Ed. 3. li. aÅ¿Å¿i. and 40. Ed. 3. li. aÅ¿Å¿i. a woman enfeoffed one which had a wife, and entred for non-performance of the Condition,
ã2 pages missingã heritance of woman, and in this part becauÅ¿e it reÅ¿embleth the Donations, that are propter nuptias, the Doctrine of it being Å¿omething like that of Dower.

div.head: SECT. XLI. Marriage.
div.p: THis CourteÅ¿ie is in the Inheritance of a Wife, therefore a conÅ¿equent of lawfull Marriage, and exceptions of Concubinage, or Å¿uch like, which are impediments of Dower, muÅ¿t needs be good exceptions here.

div.head: SECT. XLII. SeiÅ¿in.
div.p:
THere muÅ¿t be in the wife a Å¿eiÅ¿in and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion; for if Å¿he were but heyre in appearance, & die before her AnceÅ¿tor, this auaileth her huÅ¿band nothing. Similie, If the Father (being Å¿eiÅ¿ed of Lands) dye, and Å¿oone after his Daughter and Heyre dyeth before actuall Å¿eiÅ¿in had by entrie either by the huÅ¿band, wife, or other perÅ¿on for them, Å¿o that no poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion and a naked poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion in law here is all one: yea, the law is taken, that if a man dwell in EÅ¿Å¿ex with his wife, and lands deÅ¿cend to her in YorkeÅ¿hire, if Å¿he die the next day after, before entrie, the huÅ¿band Å¿hall not bee Tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie, for euen in this caÅ¿e is found a default in him, that he did not conÅ¿titute one to make entrie for him maintenant after the AunceÅ¿tors death, & yet if rent deÅ¿cend to a woman Couert, &c. which dieth before day of payment, or after the day, and no demand made of the rent by her huÅ¿band, hee Å¿hall haue CourteÅ¿ie in the rent notwithÅ¿tanding. So it is if an AdvouÅ¿on
in groÅ¿Å¿e deÅ¿cend to a woman married, hauing IÅ¿Å¿ue, &c. though Å¿he die afore auoydance, the huÅ¿band Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, and though the BiÅ¿hop after the deÅ¿cent preÅ¿ent by lapÅ¿e, yet the huÅ¿band Å¿hall haue the Å¿econd preÅ¿entment, for there cannot in theÅ¿e things poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion be taken maintenant and at all times, as they be in Lands: And take with you here theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es out of Dier, 1. Ma. fo. 95. Tenant per Cheualrie in cap. dieth, his Daughter and Heyre being vnder age office is found, and the King grants the wardÅ¿hip of body and Land to me which marrieth the ward and hath IÅ¿Å¿ue by her, and after Å¿hee accompliÅ¿heth the age of Å¿ixetÃ©ene yeares, and the King is Å¿atiÅ¿fied for the two yeares profit, they tender a generall liuerie, and before it be paÅ¿t, the Wife dieth, the Baron Å¿hall haue the CourteÅ¿ie come Å¿emble, Å¿aith the Booke.

But hee addeth, Quod iniurioÅ¿um eÅ¿t Å¿ecundum S â¢ ephanum de Segraue, qui dicebat quod lex ill â¢ male â¢ uit intellecta, & male vÅ¿ â¢ tata: Nam quod dicitur de lege Angliae, intelligi debet de primo vir â¢ , & communibus haeredibus, & non de Å¿ecundo, maxime cum haeredes apparentes extiterint de primo.

div.p:
BEfore WeÅ¿t. 2. cap. 1. all the EÅ¿tates which wÃ©e now call tailed (that is curtailed or cut off) were Å¿Ã©e-Å¿imple Conditionall, If Lands had bÃ©ene giuen to a man and a woman in Franke Marriage, or to them and to the Heyres of their two bodies (which gifts make now a Å¿peciall Taile) as Å¿oone as they had IÅ¿Å¿ue, the Condition was thought to be performed. ã2 pages missingã be inforced to proue, that the Childe Å¿ent forth Å¿ome voyce or cry arguing life and naturall humanity: for if it bellowed, bleated, brayed, grunted, rored, or howled, there accrued no courteÅ¿ie by getting Å¿uch an vnciuill vrchin.

By him therefore there muÅ¿t be a naturall crie heard inter quatuor parietes, for (he Å¿aith) though a Child be borne mutus & Å¿urdus, tamen clamorem emittere debet, Å¿ive maÅ¿culus Å¿it, Å¿iue foemina, nam Dicunt E. vel A. quotquot naÅ¿cuntur ab E â¢ a:

Though they be borne both deafe and dumbe.

Non Å¿ufficit igitur tantum baptizatus & Å¿cpultura: y â¢ t 28. H. 8. Dyer fol. 25. div.p:
NOw this hauing a Childe, is Å¿uch a matter (as it Å¿Ã©emeth) that maine tenant thereupon the title of CourteÅ¿ie beginneth: for example, if a bond woman purchaÅ¿e Land and marrie, if the Lord enter before IÅ¿Å¿ue be had, no Childe borne afterwards Å¿hall make the huÅ¿band tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie: But if the Baron haue IÅ¿Å¿ue by his wife, before the Lords entrie, he Å¿hall be tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie, and the auourie from that time forward Å¿hall reÅ¿t vpon him Å¿olement, And the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion in Law if the wife die,

And if a woman Heyre haue iÅ¿Å¿ue by her huÅ¿band, commit felonie and be attainted, it hath bÃ©en moÅ¿tly holden, that the huÅ¿band Å¿hall be Tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie, notwithÅ¿tanding, and that after IÅ¿Å¿ue had, the Lord may auow for homage vpon the huÅ¿band without the wife 21. div.p: IF a man haue IÅ¿Å¿ue by his wife, that is here in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, the death of the IÅ¿Å¿ue is no loÅ¿Å¿e of CourteÅ¿ie, and by Parkins, if a Daughter and Heyre apparant take a HuÅ¿band, haue IÅ¿Å¿ue by him, and the IÅ¿Å¿ue dieth, if now the Father die, and the Baron and feme enter, he may be Tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie without hauing other IÅ¿Å¿ue, Brooke makes it queÅ¿tionable.

div.p: DOwer is of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of a HuÅ¿band, the ground of it therefore is Marriage, a Concubine then Å¿hall haue no Dower, no more Å¿hall Å¿hee which is but onely contracted, and it was holden by Å¿ome, 10. AlÅ¿o where Marriage is cleerely voyde and vnlawfull, there groweth no title of Dower: But if a woman firÅ¿t contracted to E. I. intermarry afterwards with T. K. this Marriage is voydable, but not clÃ©erely voyde, and if it be not fruÅ¿trated, otherwiÅ¿e then by death of T. K. the Wife Å¿hall haue Dower of his Land. Here yee may perceiue that which deÅ¿troyeth an abÅ¿olute true Marriage, deÅ¿troyeth Dower alÅ¿o: for though by Bracton there may be by Å¿peciall ConÅ¿titution a Dower appointed, that Å¿hall Å¿tand good againÅ¿t the tempeÅ¿t of diuers aÅ¿Å¿aults, yet by ground of the Common Law Matrimonium eÅ¿t fulcimentum do â¢ is. Chapter, Vbi nullum omnino Matrimonium, ibi nulla dost igitur, vbi Matrimonium, ibi dos, quod verum eÅ¿t Å¿i Matrimonium in facie eccleÅ¿iae contrahatur.

div.head: SECT. LVII. Matrimony may be, and yet no Dower.
div.p: THough Matrimony doe alwayes precede Dower, yet doth not Dower alwayes follow Matrimony: for firÅ¿t where the huÅ¿band had no Land, the Wife can haue no Dower by the Common Law, Bracton and Breton which giue a woman Dower in a certaine Å¿omme of money or in other Chattels, Å¿peake rather as Ciuill Lawyers then mÃ©ere EngliÅ¿h: AlÅ¿o Dower is not granted, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the HuÅ¿band is aboue 7. yeers old, and the wife aboue nine, 13. AlÅ¿o if a man marry his bond-woman in groÅ¿Å¿e and die, Å¿he Å¿hall not recouer Dower againÅ¿t the Heyre, for Å¿hee is his bondwoman, but againÅ¿t the FeoffÃ©e of her huÅ¿band Å¿he Å¿hall recouer Dower, vnleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿he be regardant to the Mannor whereof the Feoffement was made.

div.p:
WHere the Huband hath neither poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion in fact, nor poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion in Law, during the Couerture, nor any thing Å¿aue onely a right or title, the wife Å¿hall not haue Dower, as alÅ¿o if the Baron Å¿uffer a DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, an abatement, a Condition broken, an alienation in Mortmaine, or ceÅ¿Å¿er of his rent or Å¿eruices by two yeares Å¿pace, &c. and then he take a wife, dieth before reduction of his Land, or if iudgement be giuen for him in a plea of Lands, and hee marryeth afterward, and die before entry or Å¿uing of execution, the wife Å¿hall not haue Dower of theÅ¿e Lands: So is it if I. S. exchange Lands with T. K. and I. S. entreth, but T. K. taketh a wife, and dieth before entrie, his wife Å¿hall not haue Dower in any of the Lands exchanged, but

He. 7. fo. 1. Brooke 66. in Dower.

But iudgement in a Writ of annuity for the Baron taketh away Dower of a rent charge from the wife, and a woman may haue Dower of an eÅ¿tate that was Å¿uÅ¿pended, as if the Lord married with his Tenant, now is the Seignorie Å¿uÅ¿pended, but if he die, the wife Å¿hall haue Dower, a third part of the rent per ret â¢ igne â¢

div.head: SECT. LIX. There muÅ¿t be in the Husband an Inheritance not cut from the Franke Tenant.
div.p:
A Woman Å¿halll haue no Dower in Lands, whereof the Frankement and Inheritance was neuer conioyned in her huÅ¿band, during Couerture, therefore where the HuÅ¿band had but a reuerÅ¿ion after eÅ¿tate for life, the wife is not dowable: vnder this rule commeth one other, dos de dote peti non debet: And if a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed, &c. take a wife, and alien with warrantie, and then both the feoffor and feoffÃ©e die, if the wife of the feoffÃ©e bring a Writt of Dower againÅ¿t the heyre of the feoffor, which voucheth to warrant the heyre of the feoffor, and hanging the voucher, the wife of the feoffÃ©e demandsâª Dower againÅ¿t the heyre of the feoffÃ©e, if Å¿hÃ©e bring her Writt, not for a third of two pa â¢ ts, but for a third of all that whereof her huÅ¿band dyes Å¿eiÅ¿ed, Å¿he Å¿hall not ha â¢ e iudgement fill the firÅ¿t plea be determined: Littleton. If there be father and Å¿onne
both married; and the Father Å¿eiÅ¿ed of one acre, &c. dieth, and the Å¿onne entreth and dieth: if now the Å¿onnes Å¿onne enter and endow his Grandmother which dieth, his mother is not Dowable of that which the Grandmother held in Dower, for of that his Father had no more in mÃ©ere right, but a reuerÅ¿ion vpon or after a Franke tenement, and the Grandmother endowed was in of her HuÅ¿bands poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, yet if the father had in his life time i â¢ feoffed the Sonne, &c. the Å¿onnes wife might well haue Dower after the Grandmothers death, of that very Land which the Grandmother held.

And if the Å¿onnes Å¿onne voluntarily or compulÅ¿arily â¢â¢ Writ of Dower had endowed his mother, againÅ¿t whom the Grandmother had then receiued her Dower, and died after execution, the mother might well haue entred into the land which the aileÅ¿Å¿e recouered againÅ¿t her, Parkins 63. The Franke tenement and Inheritance may be both in a Å¿ort in the HuÅ¿band, and yet not Å¿ufficiently knit and vnited together to giue Dower: for example, the Lands bee giuen to two, and to the heyres of the body of one of them, if hee which hath the inheritance die firÅ¿t, his Wife is not dowable, no not after the death of the Å¿uruiuor, for the Å¿tate taile was not executed, in her huÅ¿band to all intents, though the IÅ¿Å¿ue in a Formedone againÅ¿t an abater might alleage Å¿eiÅ¿in, and eÅ¿plees (as we call them) in his father. LikewiÅ¿e, if by fine Å¿ur graunt & render, eÅ¿tate be made to a huÅ¿band for terme of life the remainder to I. S. his Å¿onne in taile, the reuerÅ¿ion to the right heyr â¢ s of the huÅ¿band, and the fine is executed, if now the Baron die, liuing I. S. or any of his IÅ¿Å¿ue, the wife of the CognuÅ¿Ã©e is not dowable: But if a LeaÅ¿e be made for yeares, the remainder to I. Sâª for life, the remainder to his right heyres, &c. the wife of I. S. Å¿hall haue Dower of this eÅ¿tate, though erecution of Dower cannot be â¢ aÅ¿ting the terme; And if a LeaÅ¿e be to the HuÅ¿band for life, with a remainder to a Å¿tranger for â¢ eares, the remainder to the HuÅ¿band in â¢ Ã©e, the inheritance
and Franke Tenement are Å¿ufficiently connexed to giue the wife Dower, b â¢ t execution Å¿hall ceaÅ¿e during the terme: for when an eÅ¿tate for yeares is more ancient, or as ancient as the Inheritance, which the HuÅ¿band had during Couerture, there the execution of Dower to the Wife muÅ¿t nÃ©eds tarrie the termes expiration: And Å¿o it is if a man grant me a rent in fÃ©e by Indenture, with Condition that the rent Å¿hall ceaÅ¿e during the non-age of mine heyres, my Wife Å¿hall not bee endowed during mine heyres minoritie.

What if a man that is Å¿eiÅ¿ed in FÃ©e-Å¿imple make a leaÅ¿e for life rendring rent, &c. and then taking a Wife he dieth, the heyre Å¿hall haue this rent incident to the reuerÅ¿ion, and it Å¿hall be a â¢ ets to him in a Formedone in DeÅ¿cender: but the wife gets here no Dower; a â¢ d Å¿aith Parkins, a woman Å¿hall not be endowed of a rent reÅ¿erued by her HuÅ¿band to himÅ¿elfe and his Heyres vpon a LeaÅ¿e for yeares, 1. Ed. 6. titulo Dower in Brooke accordeth. If the Law be Å¿o, Dower hath leÅ¿Å¿e fauour in this caÅ¿e then the eÅ¿tate per Cour â¢â¢ Å¿i â¢ d'Angleterre.

But ClÃ©ere if a man take a wife firÅ¿t, leaÅ¿e his Lands for yeares or for life, and die, now the Wife may recouer Dower of the Land it Å¿elfe, and by Breton, if the woman recouer the third part of Lands leaÅ¿ed for yeares de office, de iuÅ¿tice il Å¿erra a gard que el terti â¢ remnant, les deux parties: que demorent de terre ieÅ¿ques a â¢â¢ nt que il e â¢ t receiue al value de le tierr â¢ partie que il auera perdu â¢ , &c. But if Å¿he recouer all the Land leaÅ¿ed from the termer, he Å¿hall haue recouerie per pl â¢â¢ de garranti, either of Å¿uch other Lands as the LeÅ¿Å¿or had, or if he had no other of the Lands Å¿eiÅ¿ed, when the widdow is dead, by Å¿ â¢ ir â¢ facias out of the Court where the Iudgement was inrolled. Note, That though the Law be as is aboueÅ¿aid, where Lands are giuen to two, and to the Heyres of one of them, yet if the HuÅ¿band purchaÅ¿e to himÅ¿elfe and his wife, and to the heyres of the HuÅ¿band, the wife may relinquiÅ¿h the purchaÅ¿e, and diÅ¿agree
by bringing her Writ of Dower: Like Law Å¿Ã©emeth to be, where the purchaÅ¿e is to the Baron and feme during the life of the Baron, the remainder to his right heyres.

div.head: SECT. LX. Of what things Dower is granted.
div.p: LIttletons ground is of Lands or tenements, But a woman is Dowable alÅ¿o of all manner of rents which are rents of Inheritance, AlÅ¿o of Offices, as for example, of a Bayly-wicke in fÃ©e, a woman may haue the third part of the profit in Dower, and be contributary to the charge: AlÅ¿o at this day where the Baron hath but an vÅ¿e in fÃ©e-Å¿imple or fÃ©e-taile generall, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be in caÅ¿e where the HuÅ¿band may and doth diÅ¿agrÃ©e, the wife Å¿hall haue Dower, and if a bargaine and Å¿ale be made of Lands to the HuÅ¿band which dieth before inrolement, the wife notwithÅ¿tanding Å¿hall haue Dower, and by the inrolement einÅ¿ement, it Å¿hall be indefeiÅ¿able againÅ¿t the Vendor and the Heyre of the VendÃ©e: AlÅ¿o a woman is Dowable of Villaines regardant to a Mannor, and if a villanie in gros, a woman may haue Dower by taking his Å¿eruice euery third day, and if a mill by taking the third part of the profit, and Å¿hee Å¿hall grinde tole-frÃ©e, and if a HouÅ¿e, a woman is Dowable by a Chamber or rent aÅ¿Å¿igned out of the houÅ¿e. Note that if Å¿uch a rent be aÅ¿Å¿igned out of the Land wherein Dower is claimed, the woman may haue AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e without DÃ©ed, contra, if it be aÅ¿Å¿igned out of other Land, 33. H. 6. fo. 2.

AlÅ¿o a woman may hold an AduouÅ¿an appendent, in Dower of the third part of an AduouÅ¿an in gros, by preÅ¿enting at euery third auoydance, or the third part of the moitie of an AduouÅ¿an, by preÅ¿enting at euery Å¿ixt auoydance:
And of a Common in gr â¢ s which is certaine a woman is Dowable. LikewiÅ¿e if any grant to I. S. that hee and his heyres Å¿hall take yearely in his Meadow thrÃ©e load of Hay, &c. For Common appendant, Parkins Å¿aith, If a woman accept two acres parcell of a Mannor in allowance of Dower, Å¿he Å¿hall haue no Common appendant: aliter, if a moitie bee aÅ¿Å¿igned her. E â¢ 5. lacobile Countelle of Oxfords caÅ¿e cited in Harpers caÅ¿e, Coke 11. Rep. fo. 256. Dower Å¿hall be of prediall Tythes, &c.

div.head: SECT. LXI. Of what things Dower is not granted.
div.p:
OF naked Å¿eruices, as homage and fealtie, there is none endowment, nor of a bare annuity granted in fÃ©e, nor of things vncertaine as of Common without number. And if it be granted to I. S. that hee and his heyres Å¿hall take Å¿o many EÅ¿touers in Methold wood as they will burne, in &c. this will yÃ©eld no Dower, no more then a LicenÅ¿e or grant de coylor bois in auter bois: By the old writers, if in the firÅ¿t eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hment of Dower Å¿peciall mention be not made or AduouÅ¿ons or third preÅ¿entments, the wife cannot haue Dower of any AduouÅ¿on pur ceo que aduouÅ¿on d â¢
â¢ Å¿gly Å¿eveÅ¿t mi departible: But when a Mannor with the appurtenances is ordained for Dower, if an AduouÅ¿on be appendant to the Mannor, and the Church become voide, after the HuÅ¿bands death the Wife may preÅ¿ent.
