AlÅ¿o by them a woman cannot challenge a CaÅ¿tle, chiefe MeaÅ¿e, or head of any Baronie or Countie, or any thing within the cloÅ¿e or Circuit of the chiefe MeaÅ¿e, to be aÅ¿Å¿igned her in Dower: But for her habitation Å¿he may chooÅ¿e aliquod honeÅ¿tum MeÅ¿Å¿uagium de villenagijs, that is, Å¿ome bond Tenements within the Mannor-houÅ¿e.

And where there is none Å¿uch to chooÅ¿e, Å¿hee Å¿hall haue one clapped vp for her in aliqua platea competenti de commum boÅ¿co: as long and broad as the third part of her huÅ¿bands chiefe houÅ¿e: A cottage of clay and Å¿plints Å¿et cloÅ¿e in a corner of a cold Common, which is but a rewmaticke Lodge to welcome Suitors to. But how if the Common and all things bee Å¿o incloÅ¿ed that there is not roome to Å¿wing a Cat in, women are not put in Rogum with their HuÅ¿bands any where but in the Indies, and I thinke that cuÅ¿tome is left there alÅ¿o by this time: If there be neither baÅ¿e tenement, nor wood, nor ground wherewith & whereon to build a Widowes habitacle, Å¿he may bee endowed (for neceÅ¿Å¿ity) of the principallâª MeÅ¿Å¿uage, and without neceÅ¿Å¿ity alwayes if the heyre be Å¿o contented: The reaÅ¿ons which Breton and Bracton doe expreÅ¿ly alleadge, for niceneÅ¿Å¿e of Law, making dainty in their time to endow Widdowes in AduouÅ¿ons and great MeÅ¿Å¿uages, is onely the indiuiduity or impartablenes of the things. Of an AduouÅ¿on becauÅ¿e it is but ius quoddam, and not corporall, and great houÅ¿es, &c. for the dignity and Å¿trength which the Realme was thought to haue by their conÅ¿eruation: But conÅ¿idering that the end of Dower is chiefly the maintenance of a Wife, Si vir premoriatur: it may further bee colourably Å¿aid, that Law at firÅ¿t did neuer meane to trouble Widdowes with preÅ¿enting of Clarkes, for that either is not, or ought not to bee a matter lucratiue or of gaine, though indeede Bracton prize a Benefice of an hundred Markes at one hundred Shillings valew.

div.head: SECT. LXII. Of what eÅ¿tate of Inheritance the Husband muÅ¿t bee Å¿eiÅ¿ed.
div.p: THe Learning here is not diÅ¿crepant from that which went before in title of CourteÅ¿ie: Of fÃ©e or fÃ©e-taile generall a Woman Å¿hall haue Dower, Å¿o Å¿hall Å¿he of fÃ©efarme or of a baÅ¿e fÃ©e-Å¿imple, but not of Coppy-hold vnleÅ¿Å¿e the CuÅ¿tome Å¿erue for it: And if Tenant for life make a feoffement in fÃ©e, the wife can haue no Dower, 3. H. 4. fo. 6.

The which Littl. inÅ¿erteth in this Chapter of Dower, viz. where the HuÅ¿band is Å¿eiÅ¿ed, as heyre of Å¿peciall taile, &c. is no interdiction of Dower in all caÅ¿es to her which is married to the DonÃ©e of Å¿peciall taile. Littletons own example is, That if Lands be giuen to a man, and the heyres which he Å¿hall ingender of his wife Alice, if he dies, Alice Å¿hall be endowed of this eÅ¿tate; for no IÅ¿Å¿ue of a Å¿econd wife could be heyre of Å¿peciall taile, and that makes the difference.

The caÅ¿e 41. E. 3 fo. 30. is this, A man Å¿eiÅ¿ed in generall taile by fine made a feoffement and tooke backe an eÅ¿tate in Å¿peciall Taile to himÅ¿elfe and his firÅ¿t Wife, and died, the King Å¿eiÅ¿e by Tenure in capite, and endowed the Å¿econd wife, the IÅ¿Å¿ue of the firÅ¿t Wife came, Å¿hewing the Å¿peciall taile, and by Å¿cire facias againÅ¿t the Wife recouered for default: Å¿he tooke a Å¿econd HuÅ¿band, who with his wife brought a quod ei deforceat againÅ¿t the Heyre, and hee pleaded the Å¿peciall taile, the woman by remitting the heyre to the ancient taile, would haue concluded him to Å¿ay, that her huÅ¿band was Å¿eiÅ¿ed of any other eÅ¿tate. Et non allocatur.

Parkins makes this caÅ¿e Å¿omewhat more auÅ¿tere againÅ¿t Dower, for as he putteth it fo. 60. the IÅ¿Å¿ue is Å¿onne to the
Woman which claimeth Dower, yet the mother by him not Dowable, becauÅ¿e the Å¿onne though hee be Heyre is in of another eÅ¿tate then that which was in the Baron during Couerture, Å¿o likewiÅ¿e 44. Ed. 3. fo. 26. in a Writ of Dower againÅ¿t the Heyre Tenant, hee Å¿heweth that the band was giuen by fine to his father and mother in Å¿peciall taile, and that afterwards his father & mother diÅ¿continued the taile by fine to a Å¿tranger, and taking backe an eÅ¿tate in generall taile, they had IÅ¿Å¿ue this heyre, then his mother dyed, and the father taking the demandant to wife, he died, Å¿o the Å¿onne was now in per lun taile & per lauter, and being adiudged in his eigne right by remitter, the wife was barred of dower, this CaÅ¿e in my conceit fringeth the generality of Littletons rule, for the IÅ¿Å¿ue which by poÅ¿Å¿ibility the Å¿econd wife might haue had, might by poÅ¿Å¿ibility haue inherited, though not indefeiÅ¿ably in Å¿uch eÅ¿tate as was in the HuÅ¿band during Couerture.

To conclude, where Lands are giuen to the Baron and feme in Å¿peciall taile, the remainder to the Heyres of the body of the Baron, and the Wife dies without IÅ¿Å¿ue, there a Å¿econd wife may be endowed, for after the death of the firÅ¿t wife the remainder in generall taile veÅ¿teth maine tenant and is executed: 50. Ed. 3. fo. 4.

Newton Å¿aith, 7. He. 6. fo. 11. if a man make a leaÅ¿e for yeares with Condition, if the LeaÅ¿e pay an hundred pound at the end of the terme, that then he Å¿hall haue fÃ©e, etÅ¿i nemy que il auera que terme: that in this CaÅ¿e by paying an hundred pound at the end of the terme, the termer Å¿hall haue fÃ©e from the beginning, and his wife is Dowable: quere, for it Å¿eemeth tuncâª hath relation but ad tempus Å¿olutionis. If Tenant in Dower leaÅ¿e her eÅ¿tate to the Heyre for her life, and the Heyre dieth, his wife Å¿hall bee endowed notwithÅ¿tanding the life of the firÅ¿t dowager, 45. Ed. 3. fo. 13. In action of Dower the tenant Å¿hewed that Tenant per CourteÅ¿ie granted his eÅ¿tate to him in the reuerÅ¿ion, rendring rent with clauÅ¿e of re-entry, for nonpayment,
he in the reuerÅ¿ion marry the demandant, the tenant per le CourteÅ¿ie re-entreth for the Condition, he in the reuerÅ¿ion died, his wife was barred Dower, for the Å¿urrender might well be vpon Condition, 14. E. 4. fo. 6.

div.head: SECT. LXIII. Where Dower is giuen or not giuen of an eÅ¿tate determined.
div.p: VVHere the HuÅ¿bands eÅ¿tate is loyally enuicted or determined, Dower for the moÅ¿t part faileth, As thus, two men make exchanging of two acres executed in fÃ©e, one of them dieth, his Å¿onne takes a wife and entreth, and the otherpartie being impleaded, voucheth the Å¿onne which entreth into warrantie, Å¿o that the Tenant recouereth in value the acre, which he deliuered in exchange, the Å¿onnes wife Å¿hall neuer be endowed of this acre, for the title of recouerie in value, is from time of the exchange by way of relation, and Å¿o before the Marriage.

LikewiÅ¿e if two Copartners in gauell kinde make partition, one of them marrieth, and the other being impleaded, prayeth ayde of his partner which ioyneth, &c. if the demandant recouer, and the Tenant haue pro rata of the partners part which afterward dieth, his wife Å¿hall not haue Dower of that which is recouered, for the title of recouery pro rata is from the death of the common AnceÅ¿tor, Å¿aith Parkins. As a Villeine takes a wife, purchaÅ¿es lands in fÃ©e, his Lord enters, the Villeine dieth, his wife Å¿hall haue Dower, for the Lords title begun by his entrie, and the wiues by Å¿eiÅ¿en in the huÅ¿band, the Tenant alieneth in Mortmaine, or erecteth a croÅ¿Å¿e (Å¿Ã©e thereof, W. 2. c. 33.) and the Lordentreth, the tenants wife Å¿hall haue Dower notwithÅ¿tanding. So if the Lord recouer in a CeÅ¿Å¿auit, the tenants wife Å¿hall be endowed, yet if the tenant had made
ã2 pages missingã part, and brought a writ of Dower, it came to iÅ¿Å¿ue, ne vnques Å¿eiÅ¿ie, &c.

The Iury found the Å¿peciall matter, and being aÅ¿ked what they thought of it, they anÅ¿wered, becauÅ¿e there was neuer any permanent Å¿eiÅ¿in in the huÅ¿band, that Å¿he was not Dowable. Your thinking (Å¿aid IuÅ¿tice Thorpe) is contrary to your verdict, for here was a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion whereof Å¿he is Dowable, Et ceo fuit opinion de toutes. Littleton alÅ¿o Å¿Ã©emeth to be againÅ¿t me in EÅ¿tate Å¿ur condition, but it is not ipÅ¿e dixit, but pluÅ¿iors ont dit: Therefore if hee were aliue, I might perhaps intreate him to bee on my Å¿ide.

div.head: SECT. LXIV. How much and how a woman Å¿hall hold in Dower.
div.p: THe Common Law alloweth for Dower the third part of that whereof the HuÅ¿band during Couerture, had Å¿uch Å¿eiÅ¿in as is before declared to haue and hold (if it be in lands) by limits and bounds. But this Indowment per metes & bonds cannot be where the huÅ¿band is Tenant in Common.

If one of two Copartners in gauell kinde take a wife, and die before partition made, the Heyre may aÅ¿Å¿igne his mother a third part of his moity to hold in Common, or he may firÅ¿t make partition and then endow her per metes & bonds.

Generally, when a woman recouers Dower the Sheriffe Å¿hall put her in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion per metes & bonds, and it hath beene holden, that whereÅ¿oeuer the heyre aÅ¿Å¿igneth Dower a third part, per mi & per tout, to occupie in Common, if the widdow accept it accordingly, that this Å¿hould be a good endowment: The Law Å¿eemeth to be otherwiÅ¿e, By Common right Parkins Å¿aith, a woman Å¿hall haue Dower, the third auoydance of euery AduouÅ¿on, and the
third part of euery Mannor that was her huÅ¿bands, for if Å¿hee take it in another forme by aÅ¿Å¿ignment from the Heyre Å¿he may Å¿uffer preiudice.

As if a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed of thrÃ©e Mannors takes a wife, and grants a rent charge iÅ¿Å¿uing out of all thrÃ©e Mannors, and dieth: now if the wife by aÅ¿Å¿ignment of the heyre, accept one Mannor in Dower for all, the two parts of this Mannor remaine Å¿ubiect to the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e of the granter, becauÅ¿e the woman (for the two parts) accepted here her Dower in counter comen droit. But had Å¿hee vpon recouery of Dower bÃ©ene aÅ¿Å¿igned this Mannor by the ViÅ¿count, Å¿he Å¿hould haue held all diÅ¿charged.

Yet if a married man Å¿eiÅ¿ed of thrÃ©e AduouÅ¿ons of thrÃ©e Å¿euerall Churches, grant to I. S. that he Å¿hall preÅ¿ent to the Church which next becomes voyde, and the granter dying his wife recouers in a Writ of Dower againÅ¿t the heyre before auoydance, and the ViÅ¿count aÅ¿Å¿igneth to her the AduouÅ¿on of one Church for all, &c. if now the Church thus aÅ¿Å¿igned become voyde aÅ¿cuns diont, Å¿aith Parkins, the grantÃ©e Å¿hall preÅ¿ent, and not the woman, for Å¿he is endowed incounter common droit, and I. S. the grantÃ©e which is a Å¿tranger to the aÅ¿Å¿ignement cannot otherwiÅ¿e take aduantage of his grant. But in the firÅ¿t CaÅ¿e after aÅ¿Å¿ignment of one Mannor by the ViÅ¿count, the grantÃ©e might diÅ¿traine in the other two Mannors.

div.head: SECT. LXV. LeÅ¿Å¿e or more then a third part.
div.p:
THough by the Common Law a woman is to haue no leÅ¿Å¿e then a third part, yet if a widdow will be Å¿o fooliÅ¿h as to accept a fourth or fift part or moity of her huÅ¿bands Inheritance aÅ¿Å¿igned in allowance of all his Franke Tenement, it is a good aÅ¿Å¿ignement: And by cuÅ¿tome in Å¿ome
ã2 pages missingã Å¿eiÅ¿ed of three acres in fÃ©e, marry and die, and a Å¿tranger which hath but two of theÅ¿e acres entreth by abatement into the third, and after hee hath married the Widdow hee infeoffes a Å¿tranger of all thrÃ©e acres by indenture, reÅ¿exuing vt Å¿upra, and dieth, the rent goeth out of all the acres, but if the heyre of the firÅ¿t huÅ¿band recouer his acre and aÅ¿Å¿igne it to the woman in Dower, Å¿hee is Dowable alÅ¿o of the rent, for indÃ©ed it is entirely iÅ¿Å¿uing out of the two other acres: And if a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed of thrÃ©e acres in fÃ©e make a feoffement of two reÅ¿eruing rent out of thoÅ¿e two acres, vt Å¿upra, the wife hauing the acre which remained in Dower, may haue Dower alÅ¿o of the rent reÅ¿erued; qu â¢ ere Å¿aith Parkins, car il eÅ¿t incounter le conÅ¿cience de diuers homes, And making the acres to be of equall value, it muÅ¿t needs bee againÅ¿t law alÅ¿o, for one acre of three equally vallued, or of euery acre one third part is a iuÅ¿t Dower. But if the acre vnÅ¿old were inferior in value, there is both conÅ¿cience and law for the woman to claime Dower of the two acres, or of the rent, for a woman muÅ¿t be endowed of the beÅ¿t poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and not according to the number of acres, but according to the value of the Inheritance whilÅ¿t it was the HuÅ¿bands. Therefore if I make a feoffement of my lands, and dye, and the feoffÃ©e builds a houÅ¿e vpon it, or otherwiÅ¿e improoues it, my wife Å¿hall be endowed no otherwiÅ¿e then according to the value of my poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion; yet if a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or or a feoffÃ©e Å¿ur condition, doe edifie, the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ie or feoffor re-entring, Å¿hall haue the building. If being married I make a feoffement, and the feoffee ruinateth a houÅ¿e which was vpon the Lands before the feoffement, and that was worth foure or fiue pound annually, my wife Å¿hall be endowed according to the value that the land was of, at time of my death, becauÅ¿e a woman hath no right to poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of Dower before the death of her huÅ¿band: But Parkins dares not let this CaÅ¿e goe without a quaere.

div.head: SECT. LXIX. Of Dower at the Church doore.
div.p: THe old kind of endowment at the Church Doore commeth now a dayes Å¿eldome in vÅ¿e: But for all that I would haue women better learned then to be ignorant of it, it is when a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed in fee-Å¿imple, being of full age, comming to the Church doore to be married, doth there affirme affiance and endowe his Å¿pouÅ¿e of all his lands, or of part, as of halfe or a leÅ¿Å¿e quantity openly and with certainty, the woman thus endowed may enter into her Dower, after the huÅ¿bands death without aÅ¿Å¿ignement, and this Dower may be at the Church doore in one County of Lands in another County and without dÃ©ed, Parkins, Å¿ect. 217. Vide Plowd. in Sharington, ca. fo. 304. b. it is good without liuery of Å¿eiÅ¿in, Et per Shelly 28. H. 8 Dyer fo. it may be done within view, and the puiÅ¿ne Å¿onne of Land in borow EngliÅ¿h may not make Å¿uch a Dower.

AlÅ¿o a Å¿onne and heyre apparant when he is eÅ¿pouÅ¿ed by conÅ¿ent of his father, may endow his wife at the Church doore in part of Å¿uch lands and tenements as are the Fathers in fee-Å¿imple, and the Å¿onnes wife after his death (the father liuing) may enter preÅ¿ently without further aÅ¿Å¿ignement into the parcels, thus certainly appointed: But if Å¿hee enter after her huÅ¿bands death and agrÃ©e to any of theÅ¿e endowments ad oÅ¿tium eccleÅ¿iae, Å¿he is concluded from claiming any other Dower. Thus farre Littleton. By Bracton none can endowe his wife in this manner, vnleÅ¿Å¿e hee bee Liber homo; for in his time if I bee not much deceiued, the greateÅ¿t number of bond-men held in manurance Lands of their Lords, which they occupied to the Lords vÅ¿e and profit, in pure villeinage. TheÅ¿e hauing none other lands, could not endow, &c. AlÅ¿o by Bracton, Quis poÅ¿Å¿et dotem conÅ¿tituere, & Å¿ciendum quod tam minor quam maior maÅ¿culus. Cui vxori, tam
ã2 pages missingã Church doore to be married deliuer the Deed to her, Å¿hewing her the lands, Å¿aying, his will is, Å¿he haue them according to the dÃ©ede, if the Baron neuer claime otherwiÅ¿e, then in right of his wife that is a good feoftement.

But he may endow her, of his owne lands ad oÅ¿tium EccleÅ¿iae, without dÃ©ede, though the Land be in a forraigne Countie, marry when the Dower is of the fathers Land, ex aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u, there muÅ¿t bee a deed, for aÅ¿Å¿ent lieth not in auerment 40. Ed. 3. 43. yet this is contrary to Bracton, and in old Bookes the conÅ¿ent hath beene tried by proofes, Dowment may be good, ex conÅ¿enÅ¿u matris, but as they Å¿ay now, not ex conÅ¿enÅ¿u fratris, Å¿ororis, vel conÅ¿anguinei, The aÅ¿Å¿ent ought to be at the Church or Church doore, yet 2. H. 3. the Å¿onne married againÅ¿t the will of his parents, and eight weekes after indowed his wife, of his fathers lands, ex aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u patris per curiam, it was holden good, Fitzherbert 199.

Of the head of a Baronie, or the Capitall MeÅ¿Å¿uage of a Knights fÃ©e, Dowmente ad oÅ¿tium, &c. is not good, but it may be of a moity of all Å¿uch Lands as the Baron Å¿hall hereafter purchace in fee, or of all Å¿uch Lands as the Barons mother holdeth in Dower: But if the Father leaÅ¿e his Lands for life, and the Sonne and Heyre apparant endow his wife, ex aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u, &c. of the reuerÅ¿ion: now if the LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e die, the LeÅ¿Å¿or enter, and the Å¿onne die, the wife Å¿hall not haue Dower, becauÅ¿e Å¿he was not Dowable of the reuerÅ¿ion at the Common Law, though it had beene in her huÅ¿band during couerture; Å¿o is it if the Father were Å¿eiÅ¿ed for life, or iointly with another in fee: But if the father had beene Tenant in taile, the endowment by conÅ¿ent had beene good during his life, though no concluÅ¿ion after his death to his IÅ¿Å¿ue, or his wife claiming Dower, euen as by Election if tenant in taile, being himÅ¿elfe in actuall Å¿eiÅ¿in, endow his wife ad oÅ¿tium EccleÅ¿iae, & die, if his wife enter, the IÅ¿Å¿ue may out her, and Å¿o may hee in the reuerÅ¿ion if iÅ¿Å¿ue faile: If the Father at time of endowment ex aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u
bee Å¿eiÅ¿ed none otherwiÅ¿e then in his wiues right: Yet Parkins argueth, hee Å¿hall bee bound during his life, quaere.

I haue held young Maides now indeed Å¿omewhat long in the old endowments, and I would proceed to inÅ¿truct them in the dower of the new learning iointures, I meane, for my deÅ¿ire is, that they Å¿hould be able to haue when they are Widdowes a coach or at the leaÅ¿t an ambler, and Å¿ome money in their purÅ¿es. But they are of the minde for themÅ¿elues I perceiue, that ThemiÅ¿tocles was in for his daughter, He deÅ¿ired a man rather without money, then money without a man, here is a wiÅ¿e adoe yee Å¿ay, I tell you of Dower, of the Widdowes eÅ¿tate, and God knowes whether ye Å¿hall euer haue the grace to be widdowes or no, yee would know what belongeth to wiues, on then in a good way, I haue brought you to the Church doore, if ye be not Å¿hortly well married, I pray God I may.

with her HuÅ¿bands protection and Å¿upereminency: Now the Law that giueth Dower to her that is able to deÅ¿erue it, and enableth at Å¿o greene yeares, knoweth well enough that women are at their HuÅ¿bands commandement: If Titus being dead haue left his wife her maidenhead, immunis a culpa, a poena immunis erit, This I might dilate as in probabilitie or likelineÅ¿Å¿e of reaÅ¿on at Common Law, but it Å¿eemeth the matter reÅ¿teth otherwiÅ¿e determinable.
For in action of Dower the Tenant Å¿hall not plead nunquam carnaliter cognouit, nor the demandant be driuen to auerre a knowledge, &c.

But the caÅ¿e may perchance bee drawne to an iÅ¿Å¿ue of ne vnques accople in loyall Matrimonie, and that muÅ¿t be tried by the BiÅ¿hop: Therefore for the better direction of Brides, take the caÅ¿e verbatim, as it is propounded with the Å¿olution 22. Eliz. Dyer 369. A woman of full age contracts Matrimonie by words of the preÅ¿ent inÅ¿tant, with a young man of twelue yeares age, and this being Å¿olemnized in face of the Church with conÅ¿ummation after a Å¿ort, the young man being put to bed to her died vnder age, quaere if the Ordinarie ought to certifie an accomplement in loyall Matrimonie, Solutio doctorum quindecem.

We be all of opinion that Å¿he is to be taken for a loyall wife coupled in loyall Matrimony, and in queÅ¿tion of Dower, that the BiÅ¿hop ought Å¿o to certifie; for albeit that in other regards theÅ¿e were but SponÅ¿alia de futuro, yet in caÅ¿e of Dower, and the priuiledge thereof, they are extended to Matrimony conÅ¿ummate, Et iudicium datum pro dote; heere ye Å¿ay was the Law as cleere as ChriÅ¿tall on your Å¿ide, when Å¿upper is done dance a while, leaue out the long meaÅ¿ures till you be in bed, get you there quickly, and pay the MinÅ¿trels tomorrow.

div.head: SECT. II. Baron and Feme one perÅ¿on.
div.p: NOw that Matrimony is celebrated and conÅ¿ummate, here is Å¿o Å¿trait a fellowÅ¿hip or rather identitie of perÅ¿on, that if a feoffement bee made to a man and his wife iointly with I. S. the Baron & Feme take but a moity, and in a feoffement to Baron and Feme, and I. S. and T. K. they take but a third part, and where a feoffement is made to a man and his wife ioyntly, they take not Å¿euerall moities, as other ioynt Feoffees doe, but the Baron and feme take intirely together, and in Law they are Å¿aid to be Å¿eiÅ¿ed by intierties, and there is no halfing betwixt them: For if the Baron charge the whole land or part of it with a rent, the wife Å¿hall hold it diÅ¿charged after his death, and if he Å¿ell all or part and die. the wife Å¿hall recouer all by Writt of cui in vita. See 40. aÅ¿Å¿i. pla. 7. If a Villeine and his Wife purchaÅ¿e land ioyntly, the Lord enter, and the Villeine die, the Feme or her Heyre Å¿hall haue the whole Land, Eadem lex videtur, where the HuÅ¿band ioynt-purchaÅ¿er is an Alien borne, or attaint in premunire, or of fellonie. But the booke of AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿es goeth not Å¿o farre.

The videtur is Parliament 43. in Brooke, where likewiÅ¿e ye Å¿hall Å¿ee it was holden 5. H 7. fo. 31. that if T. infeoffe W. and A. his wife, & afterward it is by Parliament enacted that all eÅ¿tates, made by T. to W. Å¿hall bÃ©e voyde, that the feoffement Å¿hall be voyd as well towards the wife as towards the HuÅ¿band, becauÅ¿e they are but one perÅ¿on in Law, and the Feme taketh nothing but by agrÃ©ement of the huÅ¿band. And vpon the like reaÅ¿on is the caÅ¿e Dyer 3. Eliz. fo. 196. Sir Rob. Catline purchaÅ¿e land held in capite to him and his wife and his heyres without licence, and the Queene pardons all offences, pro quacunque alienatione Å¿ibi facta, and doth not Å¿peake of the wife in the pardon, and yet it was allowed in the Exchequer.

But if the feoffement had beene to W. and I. S. this I. S. Å¿hould haue held his moity, notwithÅ¿tanding the Parliaments decrÃ©e, and this Å¿eemeth to bee the better opinion, though there were in manner equall number to maintaine, That if the feoffement were before couerture, the Parliament Å¿hould voyd it for a moity, but if it were after couerture, it Å¿hould voyde for no part againÅ¿t the Feme, when Å¿hee was diÅ¿couerte, leauing to Parliaments their omnipotencie, it is clÃ©ere the huÅ¿band cannot Å¿euer the Ioynture betwixt him and his wife, as an other Ioynttenant may, if the Ioynture were made during Couerture, becauÅ¿e there is then no moity: OtherwiÅ¿e it is if the Ioynture were made before the Marriage: And if lands be giuen to a man and his wife, habendum one moity to the huÅ¿band, and habendum the other moity to the wife, now they bee Å¿eiÅ¿ed of moities as Tenants in Commom: But for this I finde no other authority, then the opinion of Knightly in Dyer, 28. H. 8. 10. b.

div.head: SECT. III. Baron & feme cannot infeoffe one another.
div.p:
MOreouer, this Conglutination of perÅ¿ons in Baron and feme, forbiddeth all manner of feoffing or giuing by the one vnto the other, for a man cannot giue any thing vnto himÅ¿elfe, therefore 27. H. 8. fo. 27. In action of debt vpon an obligation to performe couenants, where it paÅ¿Å¿ed for the Plaintiffe, becauÅ¿e the Defendant had not paid annually Å¿eauen pound to his wife, it is alleaged in areÅ¿t of Iudgement, that the Couenant was impoÅ¿Å¿ible in it Å¿elfe, &c. But Chomeley, Shelley, and Fitzherbert moued the huÅ¿band to agrÃ©e with the Plaintiffe Car le exception
Å¿ert de riens, for although in Å¿trict intelligence of Law, money and Chattels, paid, deliuered, or giuen to the wife by the huÅ¿band, are Å¿till his owne, yet a man may giue his wife a paire of hoÅ¿e (Å¿aith the booke) as a man is bound by honeÅ¿ty, Å¿o he may be bound by red waxe and parchment to finde his wife Å¿uÅ¿tenance, and to bee bound to giue her money for her Å¿ecuritie, is all one; from this Lanthorne I thinke he tooke his light, which bound a gentleman of mine acquaintance to giue his Wife the ObligÃ©e his Daughter, yearely Å¿uch and Å¿o many g â¢ wnes, Hertles. &c.

And the meaning muÅ¿t bee taken and obÅ¿erued: in the booke of 4. H. 7. fo. 4. is another memorable CauÅ¿e, A man was bound to I. S. by obligation to make a Å¿ure eÅ¿tate to a woman in certaine tenements within three moneths after his fathers death: The Obligor marrieth the woman in his fathers life time, and the Matrimony continueth, till the three moneths be expired; the obligation is forfeited, VauiÅ¿or Å¿aid, the huÅ¿band might well haue performed the condition by fine leuied, vpon a writt of Couenant brought by a Å¿tranger, againÅ¿t the Baron and feme. FiÅ¿her Å¿aid he might haue performed it by making a LeaÅ¿e vnto a Å¿tranger, the remainder to the wife, quaere of that. VauiÅ¿ors performance had beene good I thinke, if there had beene in the beginning a full purpoÅ¿e and intent of intermarriage betwixt the woman and the Obligor: But that appeares not, and therefore being that hee hath brought himÅ¿elfe to an impoÅ¿Å¿ibility of performance either of words or meaning, the ObligÃ©e muÅ¿t nÃ©eds be allowed the aduantage. If the obligation had bÃ©ene to the woman her Å¿elfe, the condition by inter-marriage had bÃ©ene diÅ¿penÅ¿ed with; for where the Obligee is a cauÅ¿e that the condition cannot be performed, the not performing is without penalitie to the Obligor, as if in the old dayes, I had bÃ©ene bound to an Abbot that A. Å¿hould infeoffe him, &c. before ChriÅ¿tmas, if A. had preÅ¿ently entred into Religion, my
bond had preÅ¿ently beene forfeited: not Å¿o, If A. had bÃ©ene profeÅ¿Å¿ed, vnder the obedience of the ObligÃ©e.

And if I bee bound to C. that A. Å¿hall marry B. before EaÅ¿ter: If I marry B. and our EÅ¿pouÅ¿als continue till EaÅ¿ter, my bond is forfeited. Similiter, If C. marry B. or if A. and B. cannot marrie, becauÅ¿e one of them dieth or wareth mad before the day.
I finde none other cauÅ¿e in our YÃ©ere-bookes alleaged why things may not paÅ¿Å¿e by gift, betwÃ©ene Baron and feme, Å¿aue only vnitie of perÅ¿on.
But vndoubtedly the reÅ¿traint Å¿pringeth from a politique conÅ¿ideration, rather to brÃ©ed, cheriÅ¿h and maintaine the vnity, then in iudging of an impoÅ¿Å¿ibility becauÅ¿e of the vnitie.

But the Ciuill Law, vir non poteÅ¿t dare vxori, ne foeminae amorem coniugalcm in quaeÅ¿tu habeant, & prohibenter inter coniuges donationes, quia Å¿ilicerct coniugibus inuicem donare matrimonia fierint venalia & Å¿aepe diÅ¿traherentur, &c. And becauÅ¿e it would amount to arguing inter coniuges, there is a reÅ¿traint by that law. Ne priuignus dare queat nouercae vel nouerca priuigno. What if the Matrimonie be inualidum & legibus non conÅ¿iÅ¿tens, yet non valet inter coniuges putatiuos facta donatio, ne melioris Å¿int conditionis quam illi qui recte faciont: But a gift to a plaine Concubine is good enough: vnleÅ¿Å¿e the giuer be a Soldier. By old Iohn Bracton, lib. 2. ca 5. Non valent donationes inter virum & vxorem; non enim poterit vir dare vxori, nec e conuerÅ¿o conÅ¿tante Matrimonio, quia huiuÅ¿modi donationes prohibitae Å¿unt inter tales perÅ¿onas, nec infraudem facere poÅ¿Å¿int conÅ¿titutioni, veluti Å¿i Maritus donet extraneae perÅ¿onae ea mente vt redonet in vita viri vel poÅ¿t mortem: hee maketh his reaÅ¿on in the 14. Chapter, Si tales donationes fieri poÅ¿Å¿int ob amorem inter virum & foeminam poÅ¿Å¿et alter eorum egeÅ¿tare & inopia premi.

But at this day, though lands cannot paÅ¿Å¿e betwixt Baron and Feme, right out by plaine liuery, or bargaine, yet
in the obliquitie of fines, recoueries and vÅ¿es, there is an Expedite tranÅ¿porting of Inheritance betwixt them, to the vndoing perhaps of the partie whoÅ¿e Lands are tranÅ¿ferred and auferred, with not Å¿o much as coniugall loue alwayes in recompence.

div.head: SECT. IIII. In what Å¿ort things may paÅ¿Å¿e betwixt Baron and Feme.
div.p: LAnds cannot paÅ¿Å¿e from the Baron by feoffement to put the Å¿tate from him immediately to the wife, though he were infeoffed to that intent and vpon Å¿uch a condition: But one man may infeoffe another vpon condition to infeoffe the wife of the Feoffor, (whatÅ¿oeuer Bracton Å¿ay) and the condition good. AlÅ¿o a feoffement, fine, or recouery may be made, knowledged or Å¿uffered, to the vÅ¿e of her and her heyres which is wife to the Feoffor, ConuÅ¿or or Å¿ufferer, &c. And as I may make another man the inÅ¿trument to conuey lands to my wife, Å¿o may I be the meanes to conuey Lands to my wife, from another man, for by Letters of Atturney-Å¿hip I may deliuer Å¿eiÅ¿en of Lands to my Wife for another, and the feoffement Å¿hall be good by Parkins 41. And a man may deuiÅ¿e in his laÅ¿t Will and TeÅ¿tament, either by the cuÅ¿tome, or by the Statute, 32. H. 8. Lands to his Wife in fÃ©e, fÃ©e-taile for life, or for yeares, becauÅ¿e this taketh none effect, till the Couerture be diÅ¿Å¿olued.

It is Å¿aid in ScolaÅ¿ticus caÅ¿e, If I deuiÅ¿e that he Å¿hall haue greene acre after the death of my wife, my wife Å¿hall haue eÅ¿tate for life by the intent, &c. And although a wife by the generall rule hath no will but her HuÅ¿bands, and all TeÅ¿taments of a feme-couert to deuiÅ¿e any Mannors, Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments are ineffectuall, by expreÅ¿Å¿e declaration of 34. Henrici 8. capite 5.
ã2 pages missingã Å¿oeuer be the courteÅ¿ie among Dames of honor, a womans name of dignitie changeth with the degree of her huÅ¿band, and of Å¿uch women as haue not their honor by birth, but acquire that by Marriage the rule of Law taketh order, Si mulier nobilis nupÅ¿erit ignoblem, deÅ¿inet eÅ¿Å¿e nobilis when Å¿he taketh a Å¿econd huÅ¿band.

But what though the Å¿crupuloÅ¿itie of the Common pleas were obÅ¿erued throughout the Realme, that EÅ¿quires Ladies Å¿hould be no Ladies in Court and Country, wherevnto I will neuer giue voyce what inequality were in this depreÅ¿Å¿ing? Å¿hall not likewiÅ¿e a Knights widdow marrying with a Baron or Earle as be much exalted verament, yet you Å¿ee the dignitie hangeth meerely on the male Å¿ide, carrying the Å¿cepter of Wedlocke.

div.head: SECT. VI. Touching Å¿eruitude.
div.p: NOw touching the Å¿tate of frÃ©edome or bondage, Littleton Å¿aith, that if a free-man marry a bond-woman, the Lord cannot Å¿eiÅ¿e her; but there is remedie by action, for taking her Å¿ans gree or licence.

Fitzherbert in his liber â¢ are probanda agreeth 78. G. that Å¿he Å¿hould be frÃ©ed perpetually: But the Law Å¿eemeth to be otherwiÅ¿e. And Å¿o you may find the opinion of Doct. & Stud. fo 139 b. And that indeed it is no more but a Temporarie priuiledge and exemption from Å¿eiÅ¿ure of her Lord, during time of couerture, for if the Seigniour of a Mannor marrie his Niefe regardant, the beÅ¿t authority that I can finde is, that this Niefe is no more but Å¿hrined in the honour of her Lord, if he die Å¿he Å¿hall haue no Dower, but remaine Å¿till in her niefitie regardant to the Mannor. And to Å¿ay truth, I perceiue not how a womans being married can in any Å¿ort be an infranchiÅ¿ement, no not for a time: it is no more but a Å¿conÅ¿ing or hiding of the Å¿eruitude. Bracton
Å¿aith elegantly manumiÅ¿Å¿ion is a detection or laying open of the freedome which is a natura. A womans liberty is free licence to doe what Å¿he liÅ¿t vnleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hee be letted by force or by Law, it is not reÅ¿tored to Niefe when Å¿he marrieth, Marriage rather pulleth it from her which before was free: When a Seignieur therefore marrieth with his bond-woman Å¿he muÅ¿t not turne her bumme to him and Å¿ay, heretofore my Lord; I lay in your bed, and now I lye in mine owne, as the French Concubine Å¿aid being married newly to her French Lord, but let her bee burome and mindfull of her Å¿ubiection, for if this louing Seignior of hers die, Å¿he may right well be an apparant Niefe againe to her owne Å¿onne for ought that I know, why not as well as cauÅ¿es may happen that the father to Å¿onne, or one Å¿onne to another may be a villeine, the caÅ¿e did happen 3. Ed. 3. that the villaine married his Lords mother, and Å¿o the father in Law, and the brother de demiÅ¿ank were villeines: If a free woman marry a villeine, her naturall freedome is not otherwiÅ¿e infringed then by Å¿ubiection to her huÅ¿band: If the villeine purchaÅ¿e Lands and die before Å¿eiÅ¿ure made by the Lord, the wife Å¿hall haue Dower: But if a frÃ©e-woman Å¿eiÅ¿ed in fee or fee-tails, take a huÅ¿band which is a villeine and die, the Lord may enter vpon the huÅ¿bands poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion per le CourteÅ¿ie, or vpon the IÅ¿Å¿ue being Tenants in fee-Å¿imple or fee-taile: SÃ©e the Booke 22. H. 6. fo. 18. &. 19.

But may the Lord enter vpon the Land during Couerture, quaere. If a villeine be poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed of certaine goods, and the Lord make Å¿eiÅ¿ure of them by poll, this is Å¿ufficient without Å¿eiÅ¿en in fait: But if the villeine die before any Å¿eiÅ¿in, and ordaine Executors, theÅ¿e Executors Å¿hall haue his goods, 3. H, 4. 15. 16.

And a Villeine Å¿hall retaine goods which hee hath as Executor againÅ¿t his Lord, yea hee may bring Action of debt againÅ¿t him as an Executor, all to the v â¢â¢ of the TeÅ¿tator. AlÅ¿o if a Feme gardian in Å¿occage marrie with a
villeine, I take it the Lord Å¿hall haue nothing to doe in this gardianÅ¿hip: If a SeignioreÅ¿Å¿e of a Mannor marry her bond-man, he is made free, and where before hee was her footÅ¿toole, he is now her head and her Seignior, here is part of the particularitie.

div.head: SECT. VII. The Baron may beate his Wife.
div.p: THe reÅ¿t followeth, IuÅ¿tice Brooke 12. H. 8. fo. 4. affirmeth plainly, that if a man beat an out-law, a traitor, a Pagan, his villein, or his wife it is diÅ¿puniÅ¿hable, becauÅ¿e by the Law Common theÅ¿e perÅ¿ons can haue no action: God Å¿end Gentle-women better Å¿port, or better companie.

But it Å¿eemeth to be very true, that there is Å¿ome kind of caÅ¿tigation which Law permits a HuÅ¿band to vÅ¿eâª for if a woman be threatned by her huÅ¿band to bee beaten, miÅ¿chieued or Å¿laine, Fitzherbert Å¿ets downe a Writ which Å¿he may Å¿ue out of Chancery to compell him to finde Å¿urety of honeÅ¿t behauiour toward her, and that he Å¿hall neither doe nor procure to be done to her (marke I pray you) any bodily damage, otherwiÅ¿e then appertaines to the office of a HuÅ¿band for lawfull and reaÅ¿onable correc â¢ ion. See for this, the new Nat. bre. fo. 80. f. & fo. 238. f.

How farre that extendeth I cannot tell, but herein the Å¿ere feminine is at no very great diÅ¿aduantage: for firÅ¿t for the lawfulneÅ¿Å¿e; If it be in none other regard lawfull to beat a mans wife, then becauÅ¿e the poore wench can Å¿ue no other action for it, I pray why may not the Wife beat the HuÅ¿band againe, what action can he haue if Å¿he doe? where two tenants in Common be on a horÅ¿e, and one of them will trauell and vÅ¿e this horÅ¿e, hee may keepe it from his Companion a yeare two or three and Å¿o be euen with him;
Å¿o the actionleÅ¿Å¿e woman beaten by her HuÅ¿band, hath retaliation left to beate him againe, if Å¿he dare. If he come to the Chancery or IuÅ¿tices in the Country of the peace againÅ¿t her, becauÅ¿e her recognizance alone will hardly bee taken, he were beÅ¿t be bound for her, and then if he be beaten the Å¿econd time, let him know the price of it on Gods name.

div.head: SECT. VIII. That which the Husband hath is his owne.
div.p: BUt the prerogatiue of the HuÅ¿band is beÅ¿t diÅ¿cerned in his dominion ouer all externe things in which the wife by combination deueÅ¿teth her Å¿elfe of proprietie in Å¿ome Å¿ort, and caÅ¿teth it vpon her gouernour, for here practice euery where agrees with the Theoricke of Law, and forcing neceÅ¿Å¿ity Å¿ubmits women to the affection thereof, whatÅ¿oeuer the HuÅ¿band, had before Couerture either in goods or lands, it is abÅ¿olutely his owne, the wife hath therein no Å¿eiÅ¿in at all. If any thing when hee is married bee giuen him, hee taketh it by himÅ¿elfe diÅ¿tinctly to himÅ¿elfe.

If a man haue right and title to enter into Lands, and the Tenant enfeoffe the Baron and Feme, the wife taketh nothing. Dyer fol. 10. The very goods which a man giueth to his wife, are Å¿till his owne, her Chaine, her Bracelets, her Apparell, are all the Good-mans goods.

If a Woman taketh more Apparell when her huÅ¿band dyeth then is neceÅ¿Å¿arily for her degree, it makes her Executrix de Å¿on tort demeÅ¿ne, 33. H. 6. A wife how gallant Å¿oeuer Å¿he be, gliÅ¿tereth but in the riches of her huÅ¿band,
ã2 pages missingã Executors; if Å¿uch chattels bee giuen to the wife and to a Å¿tranger, the huÅ¿band alone is tenant in Common of them with the Å¿tranger. Secondly, the Court did hold cleerely, that in Brackbridges CaÅ¿e, and Å¿uch like, the immediate inheritance in the Baron, did not drowne the intereÅ¿t of the Feme, for the one he had in his owne right, and the other in his wiues: But by an expreÅ¿Å¿e act, as by feoffement or grant of a new leaÅ¿e, he might haue giuen away the intereÅ¿t of his wife.

But leauing all to Law, the Law Å¿hall Å¿aue that intereÅ¿t diÅ¿tinct, and preÅ¿erue it: And it was holden in this CaÅ¿e, that Baron & feme might not ioyne in an eiectione firmae with Anticle, but he alone might bring his action and the Baron chaÅ¿ed to more higher and more reall Writt.

AlÅ¿o it was holden the Baron might diÅ¿traine or haue action of debt for a moity of the rent, and as I comprehend the end of Brackbridges caÅ¿e, a feoffement by Thomas Brackbridge made of the Mannor whereof the Land Å¿eiÅ¿ed was parcell, and might well drowne all intereÅ¿t Executory which his wife had, but not a LeaÅ¿e executed except liuery had beene made in the very Lands Å¿eiÅ¿ed, for a LeaÅ¿e in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of thrÃ©e acres maketh them to bee no parcell of a Mannor during the LeaÅ¿e, but a rent charge, or a leaÅ¿e executory which is but an intereÅ¿t, leaueth the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion entire, and no reuerÅ¿ion in the Baron, there is further in the Commentaries the CaÅ¿e of Dame Hales, viz. Sir Iames Hales LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e for yeares, in his owne right taking a new LeaÅ¿e for twelue yeares ouer in remainder to himÅ¿elfe and his Wife, died felo de Å¿e, the whol â¢ intereÅ¿t was iudged forfeit â¢ , for the felonye had relation from the act done, id eÅ¿t, from entrance into the water, &c. At which time the Baron had power to grant, and conÅ¿equently to forfeit it.

If the Wife haue a ward by reaÅ¿on of her Seigniory, this likewiÅ¿e is a Chattell reall, and the HuÅ¿bands intereÅ¿t in it Å¿hall be as in a terme or leaÅ¿e for yeers: But if the wife be gardian in Å¿ocage, no leaÅ¿e of the infants land, though it be made by Baron and feme, per Indenture Å¿hall binde the wife, but Å¿he may enter after the huÅ¿bands death, and if Å¿he die, the huÅ¿band Å¿hall not haue the GardianÅ¿hip.

For in this CaÅ¿e, the wife hath nothing to her owne vÅ¿e, but Å¿he is an officer appointed, vpon confidence in her naturall loue, and this office is not grantable nor forfeitable. vide nat. bre. 145. I haue hitherto, but Å¿hewed what is wrought as it were ipÅ¿o facto, vpon marriages conÅ¿ummation while it is grÃ©ene, not paÅ¿t a day or a wÃ©eke old, and I thought it methodicall to inÅ¿ert the learning of battery, becauÅ¿e in my poore opinion it were better to combat for houÅ¿hold maÅ¿try in the beginning, then to bring a Writt of right for it, when it hath gone too long, by title of ruÅ¿ty preÅ¿cription.

div.head: SECT. XI. Of the Wiues intereÅ¿t of affaires before Marriage.
div.p: NOw let vs looke backe a little and Å¿ee what Å¿hall become of the dealings which MiÅ¿tris Titus had whileÅ¿t Å¿hee was Sempronia, an agent in the world, widdow or maide Å¿ola and vncouert.

div.head: SECT. XII. Of Infancie.
div.p: TO debate matters of infancie would aÅ¿ke a whole volume perÅ¿e: But breefly know that all deeds, gifts, grants, &c. made by an Infant which take not effect, by deliuery of the infant be abÅ¿olutely void, By matters in fait or writing, which take effect, by hand and deliuery are onely voydable by the infant, or by them which haue the infants eÅ¿tate.

Out of his rule are excepted acts apparently of neceÅ¿Å¿ity or profit to the infant, or which can be no diÅ¿profit to him, for manger boire, neceÅ¿Å¿arie apparell and Å¿chooling, the obligation or couenant of an Infant is good.

AlÅ¿o an Infants preÅ¿entation to a Church is good enough for danger of lapÅ¿e, and becauÅ¿e it is no matter of emolument, and things done by vertue of office, as giuing of goods, or payment of debts by an infant Executrix, are good, Å¿o are acts which concerne the infants proper purchace. As if eÅ¿tate be made to an Infant of two acres, to haue and to hold, the one for life, the other in fee, a feoffement of one acre made by the Infant is a good election: And it is Å¿aid fo. 104. in Dyer, that an Infant is bound by
all Statute Lawes, if there be not an expreÅ¿Å¿e exemption; Now whatÅ¿oeuer a Feme Å¿ole might auoyd by infancie, Å¿he and her huÅ¿band may auoid it by entry or action after Marriage, if they take the time, elÅ¿e not.

For example, An infant feme Å¿ole hath title to enter for Mortmaine, within a yeare after alienation, or title to enter into the purchaÅ¿e of her villeine before his alienation, if by lacheÅ¿Å¿e Å¿he let Å¿lip her aduantage, as Å¿he may doe notwithÅ¿tanding her infancie, no wiÅ¿e huÅ¿band that Å¿he taketh afterward can mend it, for here was but a title to that which neither Å¿he nor her aunceÅ¿tor euer had: But if an infant Feme Å¿ole haue a right, as vpon diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in done to her or her aunceÅ¿tor, Å¿he may alwayes enter, whilÅ¿t Å¿he is Å¿ole, notwithÅ¿tanding any deÅ¿cent during infancie; And Å¿o may her huÅ¿band which marrieth her after the deÅ¿cent: Littl. teacheth vs, fo. 95. Chap. DeÅ¿cents, that lacheÅ¿Å¿e of a huÅ¿band which Å¿uffers deÅ¿cent, Å¿hall not toll the entry of a Feme couert, or her heyres after Marriage diÅ¿Å¿olued. But there is an addition to Littleton, that it is otherwiÅ¿e where a title is already giuen to a Feme Å¿ole which taketh a huÅ¿band, and Å¿uffers deÅ¿cent, &c. for it Å¿hall now be accounted the Womans folly that Å¿hee would take Å¿uch a huÅ¿band.

HowÅ¿oeuer it be Law, or howÅ¿oeuer it be vnderÅ¿tood, the CaÅ¿e before muÅ¿t nÃ©eds be good Law, for an infant Feme hath as much fauor as an infant Male: And taking of an huÅ¿band cannot toll an entry which was Å¿aued to a Feme Å¿ole by infancie, neither doe I perceiue, how the huÅ¿bands lacheÅ¿Å¿e at the time of deÅ¿cent, can toll the Wiues Infancie to make any imputation of folly, where infancie might excuÅ¿e it.

By Parkins, If a man leaÅ¿e two acres to me for life, the remainder of one of theÅ¿e acres to a Feme Å¿ole, which afterwards takes a huÅ¿band, and then the LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e dying, the Baron entreth into one acre, and thereof enfeoffes a Å¿tranger by mets and bonds, the wife Å¿hall not after his death enter
ã2 pages missingã and if Baron and Feme make a gift in taile or leaÅ¿e for life of the wiues Land rendring rent, Å¿o Å¿oone as the Baron dies the reuerÅ¿ion is onely in the wife, who by accepting the rent Å¿hall bind her Å¿elfe and her heyres: But if Å¿hÃ©e will refuÅ¿e the rent becauÅ¿e Å¿he was vnder age at time of the feoffement, it Å¿Ã©emes Å¿he may be receiued to a dum fuit Infra etatem, wherby Å¿he affirmes the feoffement to be her owne. If this be infallible Law, I doubt not then if a Feme infant diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed doe marry, and during her infancie the huÅ¿band Å¿uffereth a deÅ¿cent, but her entry is Å¿aued, and Å¿he may enter, after Couerture diÅ¿Å¿olued if not before: But Fitzherbert concludeth with a quaere, and Å¿o muÅ¿t I.

div.head: SECT. XIII. Acts, &c. of a Feme Å¿ole being full Age.
div.p: VNderÅ¿tand now by a Feme Å¿ole, a Woman of Å¿ull age. If a Feme Å¿ole become indebted, and marry, the Baron and Feme may be Å¿ued for this debt during life of the Feme: If the Creditor Å¿ue the recouer, the Baron Å¿hall be charged with it after the wiues death, aliter non.

A Feme Å¿ole, LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e for life, rendring rent takes a huÅ¿band, the rent is arrere, the wife dieth, though here be no recouery in the wiues life time, yet becauÅ¿e the Baron tooke the profit, he is Å¿till chargeable in a Writt of debt for the rent, for quiÅ¿entit commodum Å¿entire debet & onus, If a Feme endowed of rent take a huÅ¿band and die, the huÅ¿band Å¿hall haue action of debt for the rent arere, for it was a duty accrued during couerture: But if a man be bound to a Feme Å¿ole, and Å¿he takes a huÅ¿band, and the day of payment comes during Couerture: now if Å¿he die, her huÅ¿band cannot haue an action of debt vpon the obligation, for this was a thing in action before marriage, Nat. bre. fol. 120. & 121. And agrÃ©eing to that is 39. H. 6. 27. Br. TeÅ¿taments
10. but by that booke the Wife may make the Baron her Executor and Å¿o Å¿aith the Booke of 12. Hen. 7. 22.

If a Feme Å¿ole being made Executrix, take a huÅ¿band, Å¿he remaine Å¿till a diÅ¿poÅ¿er of the TeÅ¿tators goods to his vÅ¿e: and after payment of his debts Å¿he may deliuer Legacies, and after all that giue the reÅ¿t for Gods Å¿ake maugre le teÅ¿t Å¿a Baron. But vpon Å¿uch a giuing of goods or deliuering of Legacies before payment of debts the huÅ¿band may haue an action of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, for gift before payment is not a right adminiÅ¿tration, but a deuaÅ¿tation of the TeÅ¿tators goods, Par. fo. 2. and 18. H. 6.

A feme Å¿ole Å¿eiÅ¿ed of a carue of land, grants out of it a rent Charge by dÃ©ed, and deliuers this deed to a Å¿tranger with Condition to deliuer it to the grantÃ©e as her dÃ©ed, if he goe to Rome and returne before EaÅ¿ter, the Woman takes a huÅ¿band, the grantÃ©e performes the Condition, the dÃ©ed is deliuered to him, he hath a good rent Charge, yet the Baron was Å¿eiÅ¿ed of the land before the grant tooke effect, what though, if the Feme had infeoffed a Å¿tranger of the land, he Å¿hould haue held it charged, for to Å¿ome intent the grant hath relation from deliuery of the deed as an eÅ¿crow though for the rent, the grantÃ©e cannot haue that but for the dayes incurring after the darraine deliuery, and if the Feme at the deliuery of the eÅ¿crow had bÃ©ene marryed all had bÃ©ene voyd, Par. fo. 2. & 3. and fo. 29. Å¿ome hath maintained, he Å¿aith, where a Feme Å¿ole deliuers an obligation or other dÃ©ed of grant, as an eÅ¿crow with condition, &c. vt Å¿upra; that it Å¿hould haue no relation at all Å¿aue onely to the laÅ¿t deliuery; for if hÃ©e to whom an obligation is Å¿o made, releaÅ¿e all action to the Feme Å¿ole, before performance of the condition, and before deliuery of the dÃ©ed by the baylÃ©e, he may notwithÅ¿tanding Å¿ue vpon the obligation, when it is deliuered, which proues that it takes none effect till the laÅ¿t deliuery; and then it muÅ¿t nÃ©eds bee void if the Woman be married at time of this deliuery, if all
were not countermanded preÅ¿ently by taking a huÅ¿band. But Parkins will not yÃ©eld to theÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons, for the Feme Å¿ole was a perÅ¿on able to oblige her Å¿elfe in any manner of Contract, and her couenants and agrÃ©ements made vpon conÅ¿ideration, Å¿he could not countermaund though Å¿he would.

If a Feme Å¿ole Å¿eiÅ¿ed of Land, infeoffe a Å¿tranger by dÃ©ede indented reÅ¿eruing rent to her and her heyres, to be paid annually at EaÅ¿ter, with a conditionall clauÅ¿e of entry for non-payment, and then they two inter-marry, &c. hÃ©ere can be no failing in performance of payment during couerture, for all this while the rent and condition are Å¿uÅ¿pended.

If the condition had bÃ©en to pay ten or an hundred pound, it had bÃ©ene drunke vp by the inter-marriage, for if a feme Å¿ole make a feoffement to a Å¿tranger vpon condition to pay her ten pound, and then Å¿he marrieth with I. S. I. S. before the day of payment may releaÅ¿e all manner of conditions, duties and demands, and the condition Å¿hall be determined. But Å¿uch a releaÅ¿e comming after the day wherein the condition Å¿hould haue beene performed at what time the wife hath a title of entrie will not binde her or her heyres, after the huÅ¿bands death. Par. fo. 148.

There followeth a queÅ¿tion, if a Feme Å¿ole infeoffeth a man of blacke acre by indenture with Condition, that hee Å¿hall infeoffe her of green acre before EaÅ¿ter, and they two marry and continue married till after EaÅ¿ter, whether the huÅ¿band be maine-tenant Å¿eiÅ¿ed of blacke acre in-the right of his wife, There followeth in Par. fo. 149. a caÅ¿e ayding towards Å¿olution of this doubt. If I be bound by obligation to a Feme Å¿ole to marry her by munday next, if Å¿hee marry a Å¿tranger and the eÅ¿pouÅ¿als continue till tewÅ¿day, I nÃ©ed not tender my Å¿elfe to her.

A Feme Å¿ole makes cognizance of her right to leuie a fine before CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners per dedimus poteÅ¿tatem, hauing the Writt of Couenant (vt oportet) and at the
day giuen in banke, when the Concord Å¿hould be recorded, the woman is married, but notwithÅ¿tanding the fine was recorded and ingroÅ¿Å¿ed, as leuied by a Feme Å¿ole: the queÅ¿tion was whether it Å¿hould binde the HuÅ¿band, or not, it was Å¿aid, death of a partie, &c. which as the act of God diÅ¿Å¿olues the whole buÅ¿ines, by abatement of the Writ, but marrying after the teÅ¿te of the Writ of Couenant, and dedimus poteÅ¿tatem, and Cognizance made, doth not Å¿o: The woman therefore and her heyres are bound for euer; and the HuÅ¿bands releaÅ¿e of all his right to the ConuÅ¿Ã©e, makes all clÃ©ere 7. & 8. Eliz Dyer 246. the Lord Keeper of the great Å¿eale of England his caÅ¿e.

div.head: SECT. XIII. Of Acts done by a Feme Couert.
div.p:
EUery Feme Couertis quodammodo an infant, for Å¿Ã©e her power, euen in that which is moÅ¿t her owne: A wife may be Å¿eiÅ¿ed in her owne right with her huÅ¿band in eÅ¿tate of Inheritance: but if Å¿he make liuery and Å¿eiÅ¿in to another in any parcell of this Inheritance by her Å¿elfe alone without grÃ©e of her HuÅ¿band it is voyd, yea her HuÅ¿band and Å¿hee together may maintaine an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e vpon the entry: but where onely the Baron is Å¿eiÅ¿ed, and the Feme maketh liuery, the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e muÅ¿t bee onely by the Baron in his owne name: Par. 38. LikewiÅ¿e fo. 2. he telleth vs, where a man is Å¿eiÅ¿ed in the right of his wife, and the wife grants a rent charge out of her owne Land, the HuÅ¿band not knowing it, or the HuÅ¿band knowing, but not conÅ¿enting; but the dÃ©ed is onely in the name of the wife, this grant is voyd. Admit the HuÅ¿band be vagrant out of the Countrey, and the Wife (ignorant of his life or death) grants a rent Charge by deede reciting thatâª Å¿hee is Å¿ole; yet
if the GrantÃ©e enter and diÅ¿traine for the rent, the huÅ¿band may maintaine an Action of TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e for this entrie.

Admit that this vna caro Baron and Feme through falÅ¿e loue or iealouÅ¿ie, bee Å¿et at nine miles aÅ¿under variance, and certaine Lands are aÅ¿Å¿igned to the Wife by the Baron for her maintenance, if the Wife grant a rent Charge out of this Land, it is meerely void.

If a Feme Couert grant a rent Charge out of her land by fine, as though Å¿he were Å¿ole, this bindeth not the HuÅ¿band; but if he die before hee and his Feme haue reuerÅ¿ed their fine by error, the Feme Å¿hall be bound.

And if to a Feme Couert there be a feoffement made (a feoffement and liuery is of great celebritie) yet a naked diÅ¿agrÃ©ement of the Baron auoydeth it 1. H. 7. fo. 16. If a Feme Couert (her HuÅ¿band being beyond the Seas) bee enfeoffed of an acre of Land, and the HuÅ¿band comming home refuÅ¿eth, and cauÅ¿eth the Wife likewiÅ¿e to relinquiÅ¿h all manner of Å¿eiÅ¿in or taking any profits of the Land, this in a Writt of entry, Å¿ur diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in in le per brought againÅ¿t the Baron and Feme will diÅ¿charge the HuÅ¿band of damages from the time of the refuÅ¿all, but not for the occupation before refuÅ¿all, tamen quaere, Par. fo. 10. yet (Å¿aith he) they remaine Tenants (for all the refuÅ¿als) of the Franke Tenement to vÅ¿e any action Å¿o long as none other perÅ¿on entereth: but if a Tenant when his Seignior is beyond the Seas, doe infeoffe his Lords wife ioyntly with a Å¿tranger of the Tenancie, and the Lord comming home diÅ¿traines the cattle of the Å¿tranger for his rent, this diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e is a compleat diÅ¿agrÃ©ement, and puts the Wife out of Å¿eiÅ¿in, Å¿o that now the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion remaines intirely to the Å¿tranger the ioynt feoffÃ©e; otherwiÅ¿e the huÅ¿band Å¿hould be at a Å¿hrewd miÅ¿chiefe viz. without remedie for his rent, for all the time incurred before the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e, Par. 10. Note that in theÅ¿e CaÅ¿es it is no plea, for the grauntor to Å¿ay that
the Baron did not agrÃ©e, but hee muÅ¿t Å¿hew the diÅ¿agrÃ©ement.

A Feme Couert may be a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ereÅ¿Å¿e without aÅ¿Å¿ent of the Baron, and hee Å¿hall be charged with damages, in aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e againÅ¿t him and his wife: But if the Baron doe a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in to the vÅ¿e of his wife and Å¿he agrÃ©es to it, the Franke Tenant for all this Å¿etleth not in her, for the entry of a huÅ¿band gaineth nothing to his wife, but where Å¿he hath either right of entry (as vpon diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in) or title of entry as vpon a Condition, &c. A Feme Couert makes a TeÅ¿tament of the goods of her huÅ¿band, Å¿he dieth, the Executors proue the teÅ¿tament, if the Baron now will deliuer the goods to the Executors, this maketh the TeÅ¿tament good; for howÅ¿oeuer it might be accounted voyd, being made without the huÅ¿bands conÅ¿ent, yet being once proued, it gathereth Å¿pirit (as it were) and the deliuery of the goods, Å¿hall imploy an aÅ¿Å¿ent before the will was made, note that licence or aÅ¿Å¿ent here, is Å¿ufficient per paroll, Par. 97.

A Feme Couert may take an aÅ¿Å¿umption from any man for her HuÅ¿band, Å¿hee may take an obligation or feoffement to her Å¿elfe, Å¿he may commit a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, and her huÅ¿band by his aÅ¿Å¿ent Å¿hall be a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or, ab initio: Shee may giue, Å¿ell, or charge her huÅ¿bands Chattels, by his aÅ¿Å¿ent, as a horÅ¿e or Å¿uch like, and Å¿he is not Å¿o like a Monke that all her acts Å¿hould haue an impoÅ¿Å¿ibility of taking any Å¿trength, but her huÅ¿bands agrÃ©ement comming after them, Å¿hall make them good whether they be to his aduantage or diÅ¿aduantage, 27. H. 8. fo. 24. But the acts of a Monke cannot be made good by agrÃ©ement of the Soueraigne.

And in the end of the caÅ¿e, Fitzherbert affirmes, that when a Woman makes a gift of her huÅ¿bands goods, the HuÅ¿bands poÅ¿t-aÅ¿Å¿ent is a new gift. One thing I will adde, That though a gift made by a wife of things which are quickly gotten, and quickly gone, (chattels I meane which require no Å¿olemne conueyance) and the Wife hath
a med â¢â¢ ng with them may bee made good by agrÃ©ement, yet a feoffement made by the Feme, cannot be made good by the HuÅ¿bands bare conÅ¿ent Å¿uccÃ©eding.

Now for ExecutorÅ¿hip of a Feme Couert note that per Brian, 2. H. 7. fo. 15. b. Å¿he cannot be an Executor without the agrÃ©ement of her HuÅ¿band, and per meÅ¿me le reaÅ¿on, Å¿he cannot giue goods of the TeÅ¿tator without his conÅ¿entâª for vpon returne of deuaÅ¿tauerint, the HuÅ¿bands goods Å¿hall be put in execution: The caÅ¿e in the booke, is of an ExecutorÅ¿hip, before Couerture. And remember that Fitzherbert Å¿aith, 28. H. 8. Dyer fo. 7. If the wife haue a LeaÅ¿e by ExecutorÅ¿hip, the huÅ¿band connot Å¿ell it, Å¿ed tota curia con
â¢ ra eum: But a Feme Executrix to her firÅ¿t huÅ¿band may retaine goods againÅ¿t the Executors of her Å¿econd HuÅ¿band, if hee neue â¢ did alienate them. 21. H. 7. per Fineux.

div.head: SECT. XIV. Of Elopement.
div.p:
AMongÅ¿t the acts of a Feme Couert, I muÅ¿t not forget to admoniÅ¿h her that Å¿he take hÃ©ed of Elopements, A woman Å¿hall not forfeit Dower by not Å¿uing appeale of her HuÅ¿bands death, or by not viÅ¿iting her huÅ¿band, or not comming to comfort him when he is wounded or excÃ©eding Å¿icke in a forraigne Å¿hire; but i â¢ he be in his home Countie where he dwelleth, quaere: A woman in her frenzy may cut her huÅ¿bands throat, and it is no forfeiture of Dower; but if Å¿he make an Elopement (which is a mad tricke) Dower is forfeited. Elopement by the Å¿ound and quality of the offence might Å¿Ã©eme to be deriued from alopex a foxe, for it is when a woman Å¿eekes her prey farre from home, which is the foxes qualitie. But the word Å¿eemeth to bee
French, there is a faire Statute againÅ¿t Elopement, WeÅ¿t. 2. ca. 34. Si vxor Å¿ponte reliquerit virum & abierit & m â¢
retur cum adultero Å¿uo, amittat in perpetuum actionem p â¢
tendi dotem, quae â¢ i competere poÅ¿Å¿et de tenementis viri Å¿ui, Å¿i Å¿uper hoc conuincatur, niÅ¿i vir Å¿uus Å¿ponte & abÅ¿
que cohertione EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tica cam reconciliet & Å¿ecum habitare permit â¢ at, in quo caÅ¿u reÅ¿tituatur â¢ i actio. A Woman that leaues her huÅ¿band, goeth away and abides with her adulterer, if Å¿he be conuicted thereof, loÅ¿eth for euer her command of Dower, &c. vnleÅ¿Å¿e the HuÅ¿band of his owne frÃ©e accord without eccleÅ¿iallicall compulÅ¿ion Å¿uffer her to be reconciled and to cohabite with him, in which caÅ¿e her action is reÅ¿tored for Dower.

It is commonly holden (Å¿aith Parkins) that a Woman Å¿hall loÅ¿e her Dower by voluntary Elopement, though her abiding be inuoluntary, and though Å¿he make none abode at all with her Adulterer: But if Å¿he be rauiÅ¿hed, and demurre with the RauiÅ¿hor, againÅ¿t her will, Å¿he loÅ¿eth no Dower. If when the huÅ¿band is commorant at one mannor, his wife depart to another of his mannors, and there liue in adultery, this is none Elopement, for it cannot but be intended, Å¿he cannot abide there without grÃ©e and goodwill of her Baron; ye Å¿hall haue a caÅ¿e for your erudition out of my Lord Dyer concerning this matter: of Dower was demanded of a Mannor, ex dotatione Domini Powes by R. H. and Anne his Wife, it was pleaded that the Å¿aid Anne in vita Domini Powes.

lg.l: Left her Husband and her Lord,
And from Bednallâª Greene Å¿he ran

div.p:
To the pariÅ¿h of Saint Clements Danes, where Å¿he liued in adultery, all the life long of Lord Powes, abÅ¿ â¢
âª hoc that euer Å¿he was reconciled, the demandants pleade â¢ a reconciliaui â¢
& cohabitare permiÅ¿it, the reioynder is non reconciliauit modo & forma.

To proue the reconciliation, a lying together diuers nights at diuers places was giuen in euidenceâª with demeanure, as Baron and Feme; againÅ¿t this it was obiected that they neuer were reÅ¿ient or abiding in one houÅ¿e together, but alwayes in Å¿under, and that the woman continued in adultery with one or other continually, as long as her huÅ¿band liued. Et non allocatur, for there may be many Elopements with many reconciliations, and the Defendant at his perill muÅ¿t take iÅ¿Å¿ue vpon one, 1. & 2. Phi. & Mariae, Dyer, fo. 107. But me thinkes here wanteth equality in the Law, women goe downe Å¿tile, and many graines a â¢ lowance will not make the ballance hang euen: A poore Woman Å¿hall haue but the third foote of her HuÅ¿bandâª lands when he is dead, for all the Å¿eruice Å¿he did him during the accouplement (perhaps a long time and a tedious) an â¢ if Å¿he be extrauagant with a friend vt Å¿upra, this is an Elopement and a forfeiture, &c. But as the Å¿aying is, men are happy by the maÅ¿Å¿e, they may goe where they liÅ¿t I warrant yÃ©e, and becauÅ¿e they are enforced to trauell in the world, they will pay deare abroad for that which theyâª Å¿tÃ©eme of no value at home. Their adulterous Å¿oi â¢â¢ rning â¢ is not diÅ¿cerned, they may lope ouer ditch and Dale, a thouÅ¿and out-ridings and out-biddings is no forfeiture, but as Å¿oone as the good wife is gone, the badman will haue her Land, not the third, but euery foote of it.

Haue patience (my Schollers) take not your opportunitie of reuenge, rather moue for redreÅ¿Å¿e by Parliament, and in the meane Å¿eaÅ¿on be perÅ¿waded that liberty or impunity in doing euill by immodeÅ¿t life and laÅ¿ciuious gallops, is no freedome or happines: no, but rather act thus farre your HuÅ¿bands duty of inÅ¿truction, namely, to learne him to leaue his incontinencie abroad, by your modeÅ¿t and chaÅ¿t life at home. And if this will not produce you, the comfort of your HuÅ¿band, yet a farre greater comfort the
effect of Balaams deÅ¿ires, Let me die the death of the righteons, and let my end be like his.

div.head: SECT. XV. The Husbands power in Lands, which the Wife holdeth in Dower or otherwiÅ¿e for life.
div.p: THe HuÅ¿bands Soueraigntie ouer his wife, her goods, and chattels perÅ¿onall or reall, is no leÅ¿Å¿e then hath bÃ©en declared. The dominion likewiÅ¿e ouerâª all manner of Franke Tenements his owne or his Wiues, is Å¿upereminent in him during Couerture, but Å¿o that he Å¿tandeth well bridled from doing any thing a per luy, whereby either the Dower which his wife had by a former marriage, or expecteth by the preÅ¿ent or any other eÅ¿tate for life or in fÃ©e, can be taken from her when he â¢ is gone: If a Widdow tenant in Dower marry, and her new huÅ¿band Å¿urrendreth, &c. this is good during Couerture, but if the Feme Å¿uruiue, or if there be a Diuorce cauÅ¿a praecontractus, the Feme may enter and defeate the Å¿urrender, though he to whom it was made be dead, and his Heyre in by deÅ¿cent, yea and the Law differeth not heere though the Wife had ioyned with the HuÅ¿band in the Å¿urrender: But if Baron and Feme will Å¿urrender Lands which the wife holdeth for life by fine, this Å¿hall bind the wife, for the wife which is giuer Å¿hall be examined, &c. for no particular Tenant can Å¿urrender by fine without being named in the writt, wherevpon the fine is leuied, Par. 117.

If a leaÅ¿e be made to Baron and Feme for life, and the Baron make ali â¢ nation in fee, the LeÅ¿Å¿our may enter for a forfeiture, and maintaine an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e, if he be ouÅ¿ted: but the Wife Å¿ur â¢ i â¢ ing, may haue a cui in vira poÅ¿t mortem
ã2 pages missingã is by a huÅ¿band diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed, releaÅ¿e all his right to the huÅ¿band, and afterward notwithÅ¿tanding the releaÅ¿e brings a writt of entry in nature of an AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e, and recouereth againÅ¿t him by default, the wife of the releaÅ¿Å¿Ã©e Å¿hall bee indowed. But if the Heyre of a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or being in by deÅ¿cent, the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿Ã©e re-enter, and take a wife, now a recouery againÅ¿t the Baron by default or reddition in a writt of entry in nature of AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e taketh away Dower from the wife, for the recoueror had right according to the nature of his action, and the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion which the Baron had during Couerture is deÅ¿troyed: But it falleth out otherwiÅ¿e where a man is married, and then there is a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, deÅ¿cent, entry and recouery, vt Å¿upra.

If a Precipe be brought againÅ¿t the Baron which pleadeth miÅ¿noÅ¿mer, or iointenancy, and it is found againÅ¿t him, whereby the demandant recouereth, this ouÅ¿teth not Dower, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the Demandant had right.

In a writt of entry in le poÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Baron, hee voucheth himÅ¿elfe to Å¿aue the Å¿tate taile, and Å¿heweth how his father gaue him the land in taile, and that the fÃ©e Å¿imple is deÅ¿cended vnto him, and vpon a trauerÅ¿e of the gift in taile, it is found for the demandant which recouereth, and the Baron dieth: Now if Å¿o be that the Baron might well haue pleaded a releaÅ¿e of all actions or all right of the demandant, the Wife may falÅ¿ifie this recouery in her writt of Dower: Tenant in taile hauing IÅ¿Å¿ue dieth, a Å¿tranger abateth, dieth, his heyre entreth, and takes a wife, the IÅ¿Å¿ue of tenant in taile, arraignes an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e of MortdanceÅ¿tor, againÅ¿t the Baron which trauerÅ¿eth the points of the writt, and they are found againÅ¿t him, Å¿o that the demandant recouereth, and the Baron dieth. It hath bÃ©ene holden that the wife Å¿hall not recouer Dower heere, vntill the heyre haue reuerÅ¿ed the verdict by attaint. But it Å¿eemes (Å¿aith Parkins) he may falÅ¿ifie the recouery in a writt of Dower maine tenant; for the huÅ¿band might haue pleaded to the action of the demandants writt, and if the Feme (which by
no meanes might haue attaint) muÅ¿t tarry till the Heyre haue defeated the verdict, perhaps he will neuer Å¿ue attaint, or he will releaÅ¿e, & Å¿o the wife which once was intituled to dower by her huÅ¿bands poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, neuer defected but by his owne lacheÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿hould loÅ¿e her Dower maugre Å¿at eÅ¿t, which Å¿eemeth vnreaÅ¿onable: Yet quaere (Å¿aith he) for the iudgement is upon a verdict, comprehending matter repugnant and contrary to that which Å¿hould hee pleaded againÅ¿t the writt: But if the demandants entry had bÃ©ene congeable: then out of doubt the wife had had no power of falÅ¿ifying, for the entry had wrought a remitter.

The Heyre of a DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or entreth, taking a wife, and the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿Ã©e in a writ of entry, ad terminum qui preterit, recouereth againÅ¿t the Baron by default, the wife may falÅ¿ifie this recouery in a writ of Dower: But it is Å¿eldome that the demandant in Dower Å¿hall falÅ¿ifie a recouery againÅ¿t the huÅ¿band, had by his lacheÅ¿Å¿e in not pleading a plea, which went mÃ©erely in abatement of the writt.

And therefore to Å¿ay that the Baron might haue pleaded miÅ¿noÅ¿mer or ioynt-tenancie will not Å¿erue to falÅ¿ifie a recouery: But if Å¿he can proue that the demandant had no right nor cauÅ¿e of action, but iointly with a Å¿tranger, which Å¿tranger by his deed Å¿hewed forth to the Court had releaÅ¿ed before commencement of Å¿uit all his right to her huÅ¿band being in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, this will Å¿erue to falÅ¿ifie the recouery for a moity.

Thus hath Parkins in his treatie of Dower at large diÅ¿couered, that a title neuer tryed againÅ¿t the Baron in his life time, may be tryed by his wife when he is in his grane: And Å¿o further 36. H. 6. titulo fauxifier de recouerie in Fitzherbert, 15. That a woman may falÅ¿ifie a recouery had againÅ¿t her huÅ¿band by action tried, but it muÅ¿t be in another point, and not in the very Å¿ame which was tried by the recouery.

div.head: SECT. XVII. LoÅ¿Å¿e of Dower by the Husbands attainder.
div.p:
HEe that hath a notable grudge againÅ¿t his wife, and would be Å¿ure to delude her hope of Dower, hath adirect way, though it be Å¿omewhat dangerous, and I will not be of his CounÅ¿ell: Hee needs doe no more but imagine, compaÅ¿Å¿e, and conÅ¿pire Å¿ome deteÅ¿table renowned treaÅ¿on of the old Å¿tampe; and if he be once attainted thereof, according to his deÅ¿ire, &c. But if he doe but pingle, as Å¿uffer himÅ¿elfe to bee outlawed, in action of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, this was neuer any forfeiture of Franke Tenement: The Law was in the late dayes of Littleton and Parkins that euery attainder of murther or felonie done by the Baronâª was an ouÅ¿ter of dower to the wife. The firÅ¿t Solons of the EngliÅ¿h Law be like thought that tender regard of a wiues eÅ¿tate, Å¿hould reÅ¿traine a huÅ¿band from all inormious tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion againÅ¿t the Å¿acred Crowne and dignitie Royall, would God it might: but the true reaÅ¿on why the law was Å¿o penall for Å¿uch offences of the huÅ¿band toward the wife, (in whom perhaps was no fault) that thereby Å¿hee Å¿hould haue no Dower: and towards the children that they Å¿hould haue no deÅ¿cent of inheritance, but the hereditary blood Å¿hould be corrupt) was vpon theÅ¿e reaÅ¿ons grounded vpon the Law of nature, and giuen by IuÅ¿tice Stamford in his booke fo. 194. Å¿aith he to this effect, men will now eÅ¿chew thoÅ¿e Capitall crimes when they Å¿hall Å¿Ã©e thoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons who in nature and affection are nÃ©ereÅ¿t and deareÅ¿t vnto them, and moÅ¿t to bee beloued, Å¿hall be puniÅ¿hed with themÅ¿elues: Å¿o that if themÅ¿elues will not refraine Å¿uch crimes for themÅ¿elues, yet they Å¿hould the rather refraine for the loue of their wife & children vpon whom they bring Å¿o perpetuall loÅ¿Å¿e and puniÅ¿hment and Å¿taine of Å¿o infamous a note as that their Å¿tocke,
blood and Lineage Å¿hall be corrupted and attainted, their children diÅ¿inherited, and the wiues of their boÅ¿omes becauÅ¿e the wiues of Å¿uch impious and fooliÅ¿h HuÅ¿bands, by their defaults depriued of all their meanes and liuelihood. And Breton fo. 258. makes another reaÅ¿on why a wife of a man attainted, &c. Å¿hall loÅ¿e her Dower eÅ¿t pur ceo que eÅ¿t a Å¿uppoÅ¿er que el Å¿cauoit del felony Å¿on mary, and by him a woman loÅ¿t no Dower, in caÅ¿e the felony were committed before Couerture.

King Edward the Å¿ixt in the firÅ¿t yeare of his Reigne abrogating Å¿ome Statutes concerning treaÅ¿ons or felonie, for their auÅ¿terity, and making Å¿ome new decrees concerning treaÅ¿on, preÅ¿erued Dower againÅ¿t all perpetrations of an euill huÅ¿band: But 5. & 6. eiuÅ¿dem regis ca. 11. by the laÅ¿t prouiÅ¿o, It was againe enacted, that no Wife of any perÅ¿on attainted of treaÅ¿on Å¿hould bee receiued to demand or haue Dower, &c. Yet for felonie 1. Ed. 6. is Å¿till in force.

And treaÅ¿ons by Act 5. Eliz. ca. 1. for aÅ¿Å¿urance of her MaieÅ¿ties royall power, or by the Act eodem anno cap. 11. againÅ¿t clipping, waÅ¿hing, rounding or filing of Coynes, or by the Act 18. Eliz. ca. 1. againÅ¿t diminiÅ¿hing or impayring the QuÃ©enes Coyne or other coyne currant here, doe none of them make any corruption of blood, or forfeiture of Dower.

Note, if after attainder the Baron purchaÅ¿e his pardon, this is Å¿o farre forth a new birth vnto him, that his Wife Å¿hall haue Dower of the Lands which come to him after pardon, if his IÅ¿Å¿ue by her may per poÅ¿Å¿ibilitie inherite. Par. 75.

And remember this CaÅ¿e, 3. & 4. Phi. & Marie, Dyer 140. b. Marie the wife of Sir Iohn Gate, attainted of treaÅ¿on brought a Writt of Dower, againÅ¿t WiÅ¿eman the attainder of Sir Iohn; was certainly pleaded in barre, Å¿he replyed, that long time before the attainder and before the treaÅ¿on committed, after the EÅ¿pouÅ¿als, the Å¿aid Sir Iohnâª
Gate was Å¿eiÅ¿ed in fee of the Land whererof Å¿he demands Dower, and thereof enfeoffed A. B. whoÅ¿e eÅ¿tate the tenant hath vpon a demurrer, without argument at barre or bench the Councell of the parties being heard in IuÅ¿tice Brookes Chamber, the demandant was barred of Dower, by opinion of all the IuÅ¿tices, becauÅ¿e the Statute is, The Wife of a man attainted of any manner of treaÅ¿on whatÅ¿oeuer Å¿hall in no wiÅ¿e bee receiued to aÅ¿ke, challenge, demand or haue dower of any her HuÅ¿bands Lands during the force of that attainder: And by Stamford, 195. this extendeth to petty treaÅ¿on: But nota, (Å¿aith Dyer) the Lands here Å¿old and gone before treaÅ¿on committed, were neuer Å¿ubiect to forfeiture or eÅ¿cheate, vt in cauÅ¿a VauiÅ¿or, M. Littleton in the Chapter of Dower: And therefore Anthoâª Browne Serieant was angrie at the heart for this Iudgement: See Littleton fo. 11. per VauiÅ¿or. If a man commit felonie, aliene his land, and then be attainted, the Wife Å¿hall haue action of Dower againÅ¿t the FeoffÃ©e, but not againÅ¿t the King or Lord, if it be eÅ¿cheated.

div.head: SECT. XVIII. The Husbands power in his wiues inheritance, and of diÅ¿continuance.
div.p: A Womans Inheritance is Lands of Inheritance which Å¿he hath by deÅ¿cent or purchaÅ¿e, and her Marriage Å¿uch as was giuen her in Franke Marriage by learned M. Littleton: But take heere all fÃ©e-Å¿imple or fÃ©etaile, which Å¿he hath Å¿ole by her Å¿elfe, or ioyntly with Å¿ome other to be her Inheritance.

Then know that at Common Law a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed in the right of his Wife of greene acre, may make a feoffement
of it to a Å¿tranger, and this is Å¿uch an interruption (called a diÅ¿continuance) of the wiues eÅ¿tate, that not onely the Baron is bound whileÅ¿t he liueth, but the Wife alÅ¿o when he is dead is by common Law forbidden entry into her owne land, and put to her action of cui in vita, but if a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed in the right of his wife be diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed and releaÅ¿e to the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or (though it bee with warrantie) this is no DiÅ¿continuance.

If a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed in fÃ©e in the right of his Wife, haue IÅ¿Å¿ue by her a Å¿onne and die, and then a Å¿econd HuÅ¿band makes a LeaÅ¿e of the Land, for terme of his life, and the Wife dyeth, if now the LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e Å¿urrender to the Å¿econd Baron, it is a queÅ¿tion, whether the Å¿onne can enter during the life of leaÅ¿e for life: But cleere (Å¿aith Littleton) when he is dead, the Å¿on may enter for the diÅ¿continuance which was but forthe life, was determined.

If Tenant in the right of his Wife make a LeaÅ¿e for his owne life, the reuerÅ¿ion in fÃ©e is in the Baron: If hee die in the life time of his Wife and of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, and his heyre grant the reuerÅ¿ion with atturnament, now though the grantee enter, after the death of the LeÅ¿Å¿ee, yet the wife may re-enter: for as an eÅ¿tate taile cannot be diÅ¿continued, but by one which is Å¿eiÅ¿ed by force of the intaile, Å¿o the eÅ¿tate of a Wife, is not diÅ¿continuable but by him which is Å¿eiÅ¿ed in the wiues right.

div.head: SECT. XIX. Of a Remitter.
div.p: YOu muÅ¿t vnderÅ¿tand Å¿omewhat alÅ¿o of a Remitter. And becauÅ¿e women learne faÅ¿ter by example then by precept, I will not Å¿tay to define a Remitter: Baron and Feme Å¿eiÅ¿ed together in Å¿peciall taile, haue IÅ¿Å¿ue a daughter, the wife dyeth, the Baron catcheth another wife, hath IÅ¿Å¿ue by her another daughter, diÅ¿continueth the taile, diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿eth the diÅ¿continuee and dieth, now is the Land deÅ¿cended to the two daughters, the eldeÅ¿t daughter is remitted (that is remaunded and Å¿etled in the ancient eÅ¿tate) for a moitie, and driuen to a Formedone againÅ¿t her SiÅ¿ter for the other moity, for here the SiÅ¿ters are by Å¿euerall titles tenants in common not parceners.

If Tenant in taile infeoffe a Feme Å¿ole and die, and then his Å¿onne being vnder age, intermarrieth with the Feme FeoffÃ©e, this is a remitter to the Sonne, and his wife which before had fÃ©e-Å¿imple hath now nothing at all in the land. But if the Å¿onne had beene of full age at the time of eÅ¿pouÅ¿als, hee had not regained the ancient eÅ¿tate, but Å¿tood Å¿eiÅ¿ed onely in droit Å¿a feme. If a Woman Å¿eiÅ¿ed, &c. take a huÅ¿band which alieneth in fee, and then takes backe an eÅ¿tate to him and his wife for life, this repriÅ¿all (though it were by Indenture or by fine) is meerely the act of the HuÅ¿band, and the woman Å¿ans folly is adiudged in her Remitter, the reuerÅ¿ion of the LeÅ¿Å¿or running to Å¿moke, rightly to Å¿moke, which is Å¿omething more then nothing: for if after all this the LeÅ¿Å¿or bring an action of waÅ¿te againÅ¿t the Baron and Feme, the Baron cannot barre her by Å¿hewing her repriÅ¿all and remitter; but hee is Å¿topped from Å¿peaking againÅ¿t his owne Feoffement and receipt.

So that here may bee an eÅ¿toppell or concluÅ¿ion by a matter not witneÅ¿Å¿ed with Å¿pecialty or any manner Scripture: But if in the action of waÅ¿te the Baron will make default, at the grand diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e, the wife vpon her prayer receiued to Å¿hew her matter Å¿hall barre the LeÅ¿Å¿or of his action right well.

For in euery caÅ¿e where a woman is receiued to plead in her huÅ¿bands abÅ¿ence, Å¿he Å¿hall haue aduantage as if Å¿hee were a Feme Å¿ole. And the reaÅ¿on why rendring backe the land by the Alien to Baron and Feme worketh a remitter, though it were by â¢ ne, is becauÅ¿e a Feme Couert that taketh any thing by fine is neuer examined by the IuÅ¿tices.

But where Å¿omewhat is to bee conueyed, from a Feme Couert, by a fine, as if Baron and Feme make cognizance to another, &c. or a grant or render, or a releaÅ¿e by fine, in all or Å¿uch like caÅ¿es, becauÅ¿e the right of a Wife is paÅ¿Å¿ing, and Å¿he Å¿hall be eternally concluded, Å¿he muÅ¿t bee examined before the fine can be receiued: and if Å¿hee confeÅ¿Å¿e that her huÅ¿band menaced her if Å¿hee would not leuie the fine, &c. it Å¿hall not be receiued 15. Eâª 4âª
â¢ 0. 1. But where nothing is moued in fines, Å¿aue onely a wiues purchaÅ¿e and gaining, there is vÅ¿ed none examination of her, and therefore Å¿uch fines doe not conclude her.

If Tenant in taile diÅ¿continueth it and dieth, and the diÅ¿continuee makes a LeaÅ¿e to the Daughter and heyre of the Tenant in taile being of full age, and to her huÅ¿band for their two liues, the daughter is remitted: If Baron and Feme Tenants in Å¿peciall taile be, and the Baron alieneth in fÃ©e, and takes backe an eÅ¿tate to him and his wife, for their liue â¢ , becauÅ¿e they are but one perÅ¿on, and the eÅ¿tate is likewiÅ¿e one and intire without moities, and the Feme cannot be remitted here without the HuÅ¿band be alÅ¿o remitted, they are adiudged both in their remitter: But the Baron himÅ¿elfe is Å¿topped from claiming Å¿o much contrary to his owne alienation.

If Lands he giuen to a Woman in taile, remainder to another in taile, remainder to a third in taile, with remainder ouer in Fee, if the woman take a huÅ¿band that diÅ¿continueth in fee, all the remainders are diÅ¿continued, and if the Wife dyeth without IÅ¿Å¿ue, there is no remedie but a Formedon by turne, if the firÅ¿t, Å¿econd or third DonÃ©e die without IÅ¿Å¿ue: But if after the diÅ¿continuance an eÅ¿tate be made to the Baron and Feme for their owne life or another mans life, or any other eÅ¿tate, the Wife is remitted and Å¿o are all they in remainder. If the Feme die, the next in remainder may enter, and Å¿o is it for them in the reuerÅ¿ion after the caile is ended.

A LeaÅ¿e of a houÅ¿e is made to a Feme Å¿ole for terme of her life, and in a â¢ aint or falÅ¿e action a Å¿tranger recouereth this houÅ¿e againÅ¿t her by default, Å¿o that Å¿he may haue a quod ei deforcear by WeÅ¿t. 2. ca. 4. now is the reuerÅ¿ion of the LeÅ¿Å¿or diÅ¿continued, and hee cannot haue an action of waÅ¿te. But if the woman marries, and the recouerer leaÅ¿e this houÅ¿e to the Baron and Feme for life, the wife is remitted to her firÅ¿t eÅ¿tate by the LeaÅ¿e, the firÅ¿t LeÅ¿Å¿or to his reuerÅ¿ion, and he may haue action of waÅ¿te if there becauÅ¿e.

Yet here if the other which recouered in the falÅ¿e action bring an action of waÅ¿te, the Baron hath no other remedie but to make default at the grand diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e, and then the wife receiued, may bar him by Å¿hewing the fain â¢ nes or falÅ¿hood of his action whereby he recouered.

If after diÅ¿continuance, &c. the Baron take backe eÅ¿tate to himÅ¿elfe and his Wife, and to a third perÅ¿on, this is a remitter for a moity, and for the other moity the Feme muÅ¿t Å¿ue her cui in vita after the death of her HuÅ¿band.

If after diÅ¿continuance of the Wiues eÅ¿tate, the Baron goe beyond the Seas, and the discontinued leaÅ¿e the Land to the Wife for life, and deliuer Å¿eiÅ¿in; if the Baron agree thereunto at his returne, this is a remitter, for the Feme
Å¿hall be adiudged as an Infant, and not as a Feme Å¿ole in this CaÅ¿e, Quaere (Å¿aith Littleton) if the Baron at his returne diÅ¿agree, &c. whether this ouÅ¿t the Feme of her remitter.

If the Baron diÅ¿continue, the diÅ¿continuÃ©e be diÅ¿eiÅ¿ed, and the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or leaÅ¿e! the tenements to the Baron and feme for life, this is a remitter to the Wife, though the Baron were conÅ¿enting to the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in: But if the Baron and Feme were both of Conen and ConÅ¿ent to the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in, the wife Å¿hall be a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ereÅ¿Å¿e and not remitted.

If the diÅ¿continuÃ©e make backe eÅ¿tate to Baron and Feme by indenture vpon condition, viz. rendring rent, and for fault of payment re-entry, and becauÅ¿e the rent is ar
â¢ eare, the diÅ¿continuÃ©e doth re-enter, vpon this entry the woman may haue an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e of nouell diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in after the huÅ¿bands deceaÅ¿e, for the condition by the remitter, was cleane extinct in truth, though during couerture the Baron was eÅ¿topped, &c. Å¿o that he and his Wife could not haue an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e together.

If the Baron diÅ¿continue, take backe eÅ¿tate to himÅ¿elfe for life, the remainder after his deceaÅ¿e to his wife for her life, here is no remitter till the huÅ¿band be dead: but the Wife Å¿uruiuing, Franke Tenement is caÅ¿t vpon her maine Tenant will Å¿he nill Å¿he by act of Law, and Å¿hee is remittted, for though Å¿hee enter not, yet Å¿hee can haue none action againÅ¿t any body for this land; but any man that hath cauÅ¿e may haue action of it againÅ¿t her, becauÅ¿e a recipe quod reddat is maintainable againÅ¿t tenant in ley, and that is the widdow here: But Tenant of Franke Tenement in fair, is one which hath an actuall Å¿eiÅ¿in, and vpon diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿in thereof may maintaine an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e.
