The Statute of GloceÅ¿ter perceiued how by common Law a man may play faÅ¿t and looÅ¿e with his Wiues Inheritance by feoffement to diÅ¿continue her eÅ¿tate, and to continue it againe by reÅ¿umptionâª and Å¿o to make it Inheritance or not to his wiues at his pleaÅ¿ure.
But a feoffement doth onely barre the Wiues entry, what if to his feoffement the Baron aimes warrantie, what if to his warrantie aÅ¿Å¿ets, what if he leuie a fine? GloceÅ¿ter, ca. 3. anno 6. Ed. 1. is,

If Tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie alion, &c. his Å¿onne Å¿hall not be barred in a Writt of MortdanceÅ¿ter by the deed of his Father, from whom none heritage is deÅ¿cended, to demand and recouer the mothers land, although his Fathers Charter be with warrantie for him and his heyres: But if land deÅ¿cend to him de part Å¿on pere, he Å¿hall be fore-cloÅ¿ed, for the value of Å¿o much as is deÅ¿cended.

If after the Fathers death, any heritage deÅ¿cend from the Father, the Tenant Å¿hall recouer againÅ¿t him of the mothers Å¿eiÅ¿in by a writt of indgement out of the rolles, &c. which the IuÅ¿tices before whom the plea was pleaded, Å¿hall grant to re-Å¿ommon the warrantie, as hath bÃ©ene accuÅ¿tomed in other caÅ¿es where the voucher pleads
â¢ iens a luy deÅ¿cen â¢ r â¢
from him vpon whoÅ¿e deed he is vouched, &c.

And in like Å¿ort, the IÅ¿Å¿ue of the Å¿onne Å¿hall recouer by Writ of CouÅ¿inage, aile, or beÅ¿aile. In like manner the Wiues heyre Å¿hall not be barred after the death of his father and mother to demand by Writt of entry, his mothers heritage, which his father in her life time aliened dont nul fine eÅ¿t le uie in court le roy.

div.head: SECT. XVII. Mr. Littletons gloÅ¿Å¿e vpon the Statute of GloceÅ¿ter.
div.p:
BEfore the Statute (Å¿aith M. Littleton) if Tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie did alien, &c. in fee with warrantie, onely this, after his diÅ¿ceaÅ¿e, Å¿hould barre the Heyre: for this was a collaterall warrantie before the Statute. Since the
Statute it is cleere, that whether tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie, or tenant in the right of his wife, doe alien the wiues heritace or marriage by his deede in pais, which warrantie leauing none aÅ¿Å¿ets, it is no barre to the heyre: But what if the Baron alien by fine leuied in the Kings court, with warrantie, Å¿hall this barre the heyre without any thing deÅ¿cended in value?

Newton Chiefe IuÅ¿tice of the Common place, thought it Å¿hould by implication of words: for hee tooke dont nul fineâª &c. to be a generall exception, and therefore this alienation by fine with warrant to remaine a collater all warrantie, as it was at Common Law.

But Littleton giueth his voyce with them of contrary opinion which thought it an obÅ¿cure expoÅ¿ition to permit irreuocable alienation by Tenant in droit Å¿a feme onely by his warranting concord without aÅ¿Å¿etts when the Statute hath in the beginning taken it expreÅ¿ly from tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie alienating by Feoffement. Nul fine therefore, is as much to Å¿ay, nul loyall fine rightfully leuied, viz. a fine leuied by Baron and Feme, for it is true that before this Statute was made (and Å¿omewhat after it too) there was no eÅ¿tate taile come into England. A fine might then well and rightfully haue beene leuied by Baron & Feme, the Barons heire be bound with warrantie, and the wiues heire barred for euer: But now Å¿ince the Statute if Baron and Feme had made a feoffement in fÃ©e by deede in the Countrey, the womans heyre after deceaÅ¿e of them both may haue a Writ of entry, Å¿ur cui in vita, for all the huÅ¿bands warranty. And this Statute of GloceÅ¿ter, had left a fine no more force then a feoffement here, if the finall exception had not beene; for when it comes with inÅ¿emente & in meÅ¿me le manner giuing a writt of entry to auoyd the alienation made by the father in the mothers life time, this might be extended perhaps to a fine leuied by them both, for where the Baron and feme doth alien by fine, its true that the Baron doth alien:
LeÅ¿t therefore a fine leuied by Baron and Feme Å¿hould be thought to be infÃ©ebliÅ¿hed, this exception of a fine was neceÅ¿Å¿ary, and it is to be intended of a fine loyall: For when the IuÅ¿tices know once that tenant in right of his wife, commeth to leuie a fine onely in his owne name they will not receiue it.

div.head: SECT. XXI. Dyers ExpoÅ¿ition.
div.p: LIttleton in this diÅ¿courÅ¿e Å¿eemeth to Å¿peake, as if hee tooke a warrant without aÅ¿Å¿ets made by tenant per CourteÅ¿ie, or iure vxoris, to bee no collaterall warrantie now a dayes, whereat I maruell. A man may haue a veyne cut vnder his eare, that Å¿hall diÅ¿able him from performing a great part of manhood; but he Å¿hall be a man notwithÅ¿tanding, and a horÅ¿e may be Å¿o foundred that he Å¿hall neither well goe or Å¿tand, and yet a horÅ¿e Å¿till: So this kinde of warrantie gelt or foundered by Statute remaines collaterall nomine & Å¿pecie, Dyer is Å¿o fo. 148. at Common Law (Å¿aith he) garrantie by tenant per le courteÅ¿ie was collaterall & vncore eÅ¿t come ieo intend: But it it is no barre in MortdanceÅ¿ter, aiel or couÅ¿inage, without aÅ¿Å¿ets in fÃ©e Å¿imple deÅ¿cended ie & facto, whereas before the Statute it was brought to bee intended and Å¿uppoÅ¿ed, and this Statute is taken Å¿trictly: for the law at this day is come ieo intend, if the heyre doe not enter vpon the aliene of his father in vita patris, that he Å¿hall be bound and barred of his entry by the warrantie.

If the Father be diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed, and releaÅ¿e with warrantie, the heyre Å¿hall be barred without aÅ¿Å¿ets both of entry and action alÅ¿o, for this is none alienation by tenant by the CourteÅ¿ie. In the laÅ¿t point of the Statute of GloceÅ¿ter for alienation by the huÅ¿band, in vita vxoris, &c. if he alien
the purchaÅ¿e of his wife with warranty: this is out of the Statute, for heritage or marriage is not intended purchaÅ¿e by her.
So much my Lord Dyer, note that both he and Littleton Å¿tand vpon the word Marriage, which indeed is not in the letter of the Statute.

div.head: SECT. XXII. The Statute of 32. H. 8. ca. 28.
div.p: WEe haue paÅ¿Å¿ed the pillers, not of Hercules but of Littleton in the HuÅ¿bands power ouer his wiues Inheritance, now let vs looke plus vltra with Columbus.

King Henry the eight and the Parliament ordained in the yeare aboue Å¿pecified, That all LeaÅ¿es of Mannors, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments hereafter to bee made by Indenture Å¿ealed for yeares or for life, by any perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons being of the age of one and twenty yeares and Å¿eiÅ¿ed in fee-Å¿imple or fÃ©etaile, in the right of themÅ¿elues, their Churches or wiues, or iointly with their wiues of any eÅ¿tate of Inheritance made before Couerture or after, Å¿hall be good, &c. againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿ors, their wiues heyres and SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, &c. according to the eÅ¿tate compriÅ¿ed in Å¿uch Indenture of leaÅ¿e, in like manner and forme, as if the LeÅ¿Å¿ors and euery of them at time of the LeaÅ¿e making, had beene Å¿eiÅ¿ed in pure fÃ©e-Å¿imple to her owne onely vÅ¿es: prouiÅ¿o, that this act extend not to LeaÅ¿es made of Mannors, Lands, Tenaments or Hereditaments, being in the hands of any fermor or fermors by vertue of any old LeaÅ¿e, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the old LeaÅ¿e be expired, Å¿urrendred, or ended within one yeare next after making of the new LeaÅ¿e, nor Å¿hall extend to any grantÃ©e of reuerÅ¿ion, &câª nor to
any LeaÅ¿e of any Mannors, Lands, Tenements, &c. which hath not beene commonly let to ferme or occupied by fermors by Å¿pace of 20. yeares next before Å¿uch LeaÅ¿e, nor to any LeaÅ¿e made without impeachment of waÅ¿te, nor to any LeaÅ¿e to be made for aboue 21. yeares or thrÃ©e liues at the moÅ¿t from the day of the making thereof: And vpon euery Å¿uch LeaÅ¿e there Å¿hall be reÅ¿erued yearly to the LeÅ¿Å¿ors, their heyres and Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ors to whom the Lands Å¿hould haue come after the LeÅ¿Å¿ers death, if Å¿uch LeaÅ¿e had not bÃ©ene made, or to whom the reuerÅ¿ion Å¿hall appertaine Å¿o much or more, annuall ferme or rent as hath bÃ©ene moÅ¿t accuÅ¿tomably yÃ©elded, &c. within twenty yeares next before Å¿uch LeaÅ¿es were made. And euery perÅ¿on to whom the reuerÅ¿ion Å¿hal appertaine after the death of Å¿uch LeÅ¿Å¿ors or their heyres, Å¿hal haue Å¿uch remedies a aduantages to all intents, againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©es, their executors or aÅ¿Å¿ignes, as the LeÅ¿Å¿or might haue had: So that if the LeÅ¿Å¿or were Å¿eiÅ¿ed in in Å¿peciall taile, &c. the iÅ¿Å¿ue or heyre of that Å¿peciall eÅ¿tate, Å¿hall haue the reuerÅ¿ion, rent and Å¿eruices, &c.

ProuiÅ¿o, that the wife bee made party to euery LeaÅ¿e made by her HuÅ¿band of any Mannors, Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments, being the wiues Inheritance, and that euery Å¿uch LeaÅ¿e be by Indenture in the name of the HuÅ¿band and the Wife, and Å¿he to Å¿eale the Å¿ame: And that the ferme be reÅ¿erued to the HuÅ¿band and wife, and to the heyres of the Wife according to her eÅ¿tate of Inheritance: And that the HuÅ¿band Å¿hall not in any wiÅ¿e alien, diÅ¿charge, grant or giue any the rent, or any part therof, longer then during Couerture, without it be by fine leuied by the HuÅ¿band and wife, but the rent Å¿hall remaine, deÅ¿cend, reuert, or come, &c in Å¿uch Å¿ort and manner as the land Å¿hould haue done if no Å¿uch LeaÅ¿e had bÃ©ene made prouided that this act extend not to giue liberty of taking more fermes, &c. then before was lawfull, &c. nor inable Vicar, or ParÅ¿on to make or grant their LeaÅ¿e of MeÅ¿Å¿uages, Lands, Tenements, Tythes, &c. or Hereditaments belonging
to their Church or Uicarage: And it is further enacted that all LeaÅ¿es made within thrÃ©e yeares before the twel â¢ th of Aprill in the 31 yeare of H. 8. made by Indenture Å¿ealed by perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons of full age, of whole memory, not vnlawfully coacted, nor vnder Couert Baron, for terme of yeares, of any Mannors, Lands, tenements, or Hereditaments, whereof the LeÅ¿Å¿or or LeÅ¿Å¿ors were Å¿ei
â¢ ed in any eÅ¿tate of Inheritance, to their onely vÅ¿e at the time of their LeaÅ¿e-making, and whereof the LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©es, their executors or aÅ¿Å¿ignes at time of this act Making, were in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion by vertue of the LeaÅ¿e, no cauÅ¿e of re-entry or forfeiture being had or made, Å¿hall be good and effectuall in law againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿ors, their heyres and Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ors according to the couenants and agrÃ©ements Å¿pecified in the Indenture, &c. Å¿o that there be reÅ¿erued to the LeÅ¿Å¿ors their heyres, Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ors, &c. as much yearely rent as was at any time yÃ©elded within 20. yeares before making of any Å¿uch leaÅ¿e, or elÅ¿e the LeaÅ¿es to be of none other effect then they were of before this act.

And moreouer it is ordained that no fine, feoffement, act or acts to be made, Å¿uffered, or done by the huÅ¿band onely of any Mannors, Lands, &c. being the Inheritance or frÃ©ehold of the wife during Couerture betweene them, Å¿hall in any wiÅ¿e be, or make any diÅ¿continuance or be preiudiciall to the Å¿aid wife or her heyres, or to Å¿uch as Å¿hall claime right, title or intereÅ¿t by her death: But that Å¿hÃ©e or her heyres, or they to whom Å¿uch right or title Å¿hall appertaine, after her deceaÅ¿e Å¿hall and may lawfully enter into Å¿uch Mannors, Lands, &c. any Å¿uch fine, feoffement or other act notwithÅ¿tanding, except fines onely leuied by Baron and Feme, wherunto the wife is priuie and a partie. Prouided that this clauÅ¿e extend not to giue any liberty to any Wife or her heyres to auoid any LeaÅ¿e hereafter to bee made of any her Inheritance by her huÅ¿band and her Å¿elfe for 21. yeares or vnder, or for thrÃ©e liues at the moÅ¿t, whereupon yearely rent Å¿hall be reÅ¿erued vt Å¿upra: Prouided alÅ¿o that
this act extend not to any LeaÅ¿e heretofore made by EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall or other perÅ¿on by Co â¢ e â¢ t or Common-Å¿eale, which LeaÅ¿e is made voyd by act of Parliament, nor to make good any LeaÅ¿e of any EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall perÅ¿on made by c â¢ uent, Å¿eale or otherwiÅ¿e, or of any other perÅ¿on attainted of â¢ reaÅ¿onâª &c.

div.head: SECT. XXIII. The ExpoÅ¿ition.
div.p: THis Law in the firÅ¿t part is affirmatiue, or I may Å¿ay leaÅ¿atiue, a leaÅ¿ing Law or Statute, Tenant in fÃ©e-Å¿imple, iure mero Å¿uo nothing reÅ¿trained by it: No more is Tenant iure vxoris, but he may make a LeaÅ¿e for yeares, to continue till the laÅ¿t hower of Platoes great yeare, or till King Arthur come againe (for all this Statute) for no greater rent then thrÃ©e bundle of bulruÅ¿hes, as well as he might before although her land were neuer leaÅ¿ed before, Å¿ince Noa â¢ s floud, and Å¿uch a LeaÅ¿e Å¿hall bind him during Couerture.

But if the HuÅ¿band make a LeaÅ¿e by paroll or by poll dÃ©ede, or by Indenture, and the wife not partie; or if the Land were not informer times demiÅ¿ed, or if the ancient rent or more be not reÅ¿erued, then as the earth Å¿tayeth in the worlds center vpon nothing but Gods prouidence and permiÅ¿Å¿ionâª the DemiÅ¿Ã©e leaneth vpon no Statute, but hangeth at the wiues courteÅ¿ie, ponderibus librata Å¿uis, as at Common Law.

div.head: SECT. XXIV. Law before the Statute.
div.p: HOw that was, yÃ©e Å¿hall perceiue by the caÅ¿es following; If before the Statute of quia emptoresâª tenant in fÃ©e, iure vxoris infeoffed a Å¿tranger expreÅ¿Å¿ing no tenure, the feoffÃ©s was to hold of the Baron by Å¿uch Å¿eruices as he and the Wife held by of the Lord Paramount. If the Baron and Feme had ioyned in a Feoffement to hold of the Baron, &c. th expreÅ¿Å¿ed tenure had bÃ©ene voyd, and the Feoffee muÅ¿t haue held of them both by Å¿uch Å¿eruices as they held ouer, &c.

If the Baron in this caÅ¿e had died, and the Wife accepted the rent in her viduity, this acceptance here barred her for euer from auoyding the Feoffement by Writt of cui in vita. If Tenant iure vxoris and his Wife, had made a Feoffement to hold of the Wife, the Feoffor Å¿hould haue held of them both, and if the Wife had died, the Feoffor was to hold of the Baron till the feoffement were auoyded by Å¿ur cui v â¢ a, Par. 126.

Againe, if before this Statute of 32. H. 8. Tenant in fÃ©e iuro vxoris, and his wife had ioyned in exchange for other lands in fÃ©e, and the exchange being executed, the HuÅ¿band had dyed; now the Feme by entring in vpon the Land giuen her vpon the exchange, Å¿hould be barred for euer from defeating the exchange. But if it had bÃ©ene made by the Baron alone, Å¿he might haue defeated it notwithÅ¿tanding her entrieâª for that could giue noÅ¿eiÅ¿in by force of the exchange to her that was neither partie nor priuie to it, Par. fo. 8.

And if a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed in right of his Wife, &c. make a LeaÅ¿e for life rendring rent with a letter of Atturney to his Wife to make liuery, the Wife deliuers Å¿eiÅ¿in, the Baron dieth, Å¿he accepts the rent, the may haue a cui in vita by the
common Law, for the acceptance here maketh not the LeaÅ¿e good, becauÅ¿e the liuery which the wife made, was as Å¿eruant to her MaÅ¿ter and onely the act of the Baron, Par. 41. we haue concerning acceptances Å¿ome plentifull Learning, 21. H. 6. fo. 24. AÅ¿cu Å¿aith there, That if LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e for yeares bee in arrerage of rent and die, his Executors Å¿hall pay the arrerages if they occupie the Ferme, contra, if they waiue poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and Å¿o if a LeaÅ¿e for life be made to Baron and Feme, the Baron commits waÅ¿te and dies, the wife Å¿hall be Å¿ubiect to an action for waÅ¿te done by the huÅ¿band if Å¿he occupie the land; contra, if Å¿he waiue the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and by PaÅ¿ton in the end of the caÅ¿e, if Baron Å¿eiÅ¿ed
â¢ ure vxorisâª make a leaÅ¿e for life of the land, and die, the wife can haue no action of waÅ¿te, for Å¿he was not partie to the leaÅ¿e, & ex hoc Å¿equitur, that a woman vpon acceptance of rent of leaÅ¿e for yeares made by her huÅ¿band without being her Å¿elfe a partie, is not bound, but Å¿hee may enter: And albeit the leaÅ¿e were for life, yet acceptance barreth not a cui in vita, if Å¿he were not partie, &c. 26. H. 8. â¢â¢ . 2. per curiam, if Baron and Feme Å¿ell the Wiues land, make feoffement, and the VendÃ©e by the Indenture of Å¿ale couenants to pay ten pounds annually to the Baron and Feme during their liues, if the Baron die and the feme accept the ten pounds, this is no bar in cuiâª in vita, no more then acceptance of rent after Marriage diÅ¿Å¿olued, where the Baron a per luy made a feoffement or leaÅ¿e.

But acceptance of rent, &c. where they both made a feoffement or leaÅ¿e for life is a barre of all actions. I will hunt for no farre fetcht learning of acceptances: but this I finde, if a man leaÅ¿e his land to
â¢ . 8. to hold at will by certaine rent, none acceptance of the rent here, after the LeaÅ¿Å¿ors death can barre the Heyre of entrie, or make any â¢ ffirmance of the leaÅ¿e, for acceptance can neither make good a leaÅ¿e determined by entry, or a leaÅ¿e already void without entry by the leÅ¿Å¿ors death.

And he that leaÅ¿eth to hold at will endeth that will when
he endeth his life: but a leaÅ¿e for yeares by an Abbot or Tenant in taile, is not by their death preÅ¿ently void, but voydable, and the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿our or IÅ¿Å¿ue by acceptance of the rent affirmes the LeaÅ¿e; So doth the Feme affirme the LeaÅ¿e made for yeares, by her huÅ¿band of her Land, by acceptance when Å¿he is become Å¿ole: and Å¿Ã©e Dyer, 5. Mar. 159. by the opinion of thrÃ©e IuÅ¿tices, Dyer, Stamford and Browne, if Baron and Feme had made a LeaÅ¿e by Indenture rendring rent, and the Baron before rent day die, and the Feme before the day take another huÅ¿band, who accepts the rent and dies, this acceptance Å¿hall bind the Wife: but note and take with you this peculiar rule, where acceptance binds her that Å¿he be a partie to the LeaÅ¿e, and that by writing, for if a man makes a LeaÅ¿e for yeares without dÃ©ed, of land, which he holdeth in right of his wife, this was mÃ©erly void towards the wife, Å¿o Å¿oone as the HuÅ¿band is dead, and acceptance of the rent is to no purpoÅ¿e, Plo. 431. per Bromley.

Againe 9. H. 6. If tenant in FÃ©e iure vxoris make a LeaÅ¿e for yeares and the wife dieth, the LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e Å¿hall pay the rent vntill the Wiues heyre enter, for Å¿o long there is a continuance of a Fermour by force of the LeaÅ¿e; but none â¢â¢ owry lyeth for the HuÅ¿band, becauÅ¿e he hath no reuerÅ¿ion. And an action of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e vi & armis may be againÅ¿t him, but he cannot haue action of debt for the rent.

But to come home to the very brinke of the Statute, nota (Å¿aith Dyer) That the common opinion amongÅ¿t all IuÅ¿tices at this day is, If Baron and Feme make a LeaÅ¿e for terme of yeares, before the Statute of 32. Hen. 8. by Paroll reÅ¿eruing rent to them both, if the wife when Å¿hee is become Å¿ole, accept the rent at the Fermors hands, this binds her not from anoyding the LeaÅ¿e, if it were not by Indenture, for her aÅ¿Å¿ent was requiÅ¿ite at the beginning, and that ought to haue appeared by dÃ©ed Dyer, 1. Mar. fo. 91. The Å¿ame Learning is, 4. Mar. fol. 146.

When a Feme Couert departs from her Land the intent, conÅ¿ideration and cauÅ¿e ought to be expreÅ¿Å¿ed in Å¿cripture to proue her conÅ¿ent to the whole Mannor; for it is agrÃ©ed for Law, That if before the Statute, Baron and Feme had made a LeaÅ¿e by paroll of the Wiues Land for terme of yeares, rendring rent, though after the Barons death Å¿he had accepted the rent, yet Å¿he might out the Termer, becauÅ¿e her priuitie to the LeaÅ¿e appeares not per eÅ¿cript; likewiÅ¿e if a feme couert Å¿uffer a recouery or fine of her Land, it Å¿hall be intended by Law to be to her owne vÅ¿e, if there appeare none other intent expreÅ¿ly by Writing.
And none auerment Å¿hall be taken of intent or conÅ¿ideration in Å¿uch CaÅ¿e other then the Indenture Å¿pecifieth.

div.head: SECT. XXV. ObÅ¿eruations vpon the very Statuteâª
div.p: I Haue Å¿hewed what Å¿trength a DemiÅ¿e or LeaÅ¿e for yeares made of the Wiues Land by Baron and Feme, or by the Baron onely was of before the Statute, and is of being made Å¿ince the Statute without the appointed circumÅ¿tance and Å¿olemnitie: Now a little to the very Statuteâª As I Å¿aid before, the ordinance is that LeaÅ¿es Å¿hall bee good, &c. But not directly that any terme Å¿hal be boyd, though voyd of Å¿trength by this Statute they may be many wayes, as appeares by the prouiÅ¿o.

Note that the forerunning LeaÅ¿e, DemiÅ¿e or occupation by Fermors muÅ¿t bee deriued from one that had Inheritance (for if at the end of a primitiue LeaÅ¿e made by the Lord of whom the Tenancie is holden, or by the Kings grantÃ©e or committÃ©e of wardÅ¿hip, or by tenant in Dower, or by Tenant per le CourteÅ¿ie, Å¿ome of which may by good
poÅ¿Å¿ibilitie haue had power to make LeaÅ¿es by Å¿pace of twice twenty yeares, a tenant in tayle makes a LeaÅ¿e, this Å¿uccÃ©eding demiÅ¿e hath no vertue or ingredience of the Statute though it Å¿Ã©eme to haue good correÅ¿pondence with it; And it is doubted whether a Ferme continued twenty yeares by the Donors demiÅ¿e, be Å¿ufficient or no, to make roome for a new LeaÅ¿e.

This for ought I perceiue is by a prudent interpretation of the ConÅ¿titution rather vpon equitie and intent, then vpon the Text, tenants in fÃ©e Å¿imple or tailed which tranÅ¿mit their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion to their dÃ©ere off-Å¿pring, will not make LeaÅ¿es to any great diÅ¿aduantage of any of their owne babes or blood, and therefore their LeaÅ¿es may well bee â¢ mitated.

But like enough it is that Tenant per le courteÅ¿ie, or in Dower, or in right of his owne or in another mans Seignory, may LeaÅ¿e away their eÅ¿tate, for a proud fine and a little rent: Nay yÃ©e may be Å¿ure, that if they might Å¿et the example, they Å¿hould be gotten to make LeaÅ¿es for eÅ¿peruiers annuall, and Å¿mall yearely income in hope that my young MaÅ¿ter at his full age, Å¿hould be content with the old rent, and a kennell of ãâ¦ã ds: King Henries and the Parliaments meaning was not therefore, that their LeaÅ¿es Å¿hould be any patternes for reÅ¿eruation of rent by Tenant in Taile, or as I Å¿uppoÅ¿e in the right of his Wife. If Baron and Feme make a LeaÅ¿e by Indenture for twenty yeares to commence at Michaelmas it might Å¿Ã©eme doubtfull by the booke 7. & 8. Eliz. Dyer, 246. whether it be a good LeaÅ¿e, by this Statute.

If Baron and Feme by their Indenture make a LeaÅ¿e to commence after the Wiues deathâª I thinke this no good LeaÅ¿e, according to the Statute, for twenty one years ought to be from the making of the LeaÅ¿e, &c. If the Baron and Feme die, the Heyre is not bound to accept the rent or allow the LeaÅ¿e. And though he doe accept it, if the
Land were tailed, he may enter notwithÅ¿tanding: vide 10. Eliz. Dyer, 279.

If Baron and Feme make a LeaÅ¿e by Indenture, &c. for 31. yeares, quaere, the Baron dying, whether this be a good LeaÅ¿e, for 21. yeares or no, I thinke it is not, but Å¿tandeth mÃ©erely at Common Law. For the firÅ¿t ProuiÅ¿o of this act is that it Å¿hall not haue reÅ¿pect or extend to LeaÅ¿es made for aboue 21. yeares.

When King Henry the eight in 31. of his Reigne by Parliament had made voyd all LeaÅ¿es to bee made of Lands, which Å¿hould afterward come to him, if any LeaÅ¿es former were in eÅ¿Å¿e, or being, with prouiÅ¿o viz if he which had an old vnexpired leaÅ¿e, tooke a new that he Å¿hould hold for 21. yeares, from making of the new LeaÅ¿e, Å¿o that it excÃ©eded not twenty one yeares, it was admitted in FalmeÅ¿tones CaÅ¿e, that Å¿uch a LeaÅ¿e made for fifty yeares, was good for 21. Plo. 110.

And when Thomas Vmpton after (32. Henry the 8.) ca. 1. which gaue power to Tenant per Chiualrie to deuiÅ¿e two parts of his land, had deuiÅ¿ed a whole mannor in fÃ©e, before 34. Ed. 3. 5. Hen. 8. of explanation, which will by the Å¿aid Statute of explanation, was referred to the Law, the deuice was adiudged good for two parts, contra Kelwais opinion, as you may Å¿Ã©e 4. & 5. Phil. & Mar. Dyer, 150. But theÅ¿e caÅ¿es differ farre from the former as yee may finde by the comparing the Statutes: If after a DemiÅ¿e by Baron and Feme for twenty Å¿hillings of vÅ¿uall rentâª the huÅ¿band releaÅ¿e all his right, except twelue pence, &c. or grant that the LeÅ¿Å¿Ã©e Å¿hall hold diÅ¿puniÅ¿hable for waÅ¿te, the Wife accepting twelue-pence poÅ¿t mortem viri, may diÅ¿traine for the reÅ¿t notwithÅ¿tanding, and haue an action of waÅ¿te, Dyer 304.

Note, before this Statute was made the Count Bridge water being tenant in taile, the remainder to BaÅ¿Å¿et in taile, he bound himÅ¿elfe in recognizance to the Å¿aid BaÅ¿Å¿et to make no alienation, grant, Å¿ale, conueyance or exchange,
otherwiÅ¿e then for his owne life, it was a queÅ¿tion after the Å¿tatute, whereunto BaÅ¿Å¿et and all men were parties, whether the Earle might now make a leaÅ¿e for xxi. yeares without forfeiture of his Recognizance, reÅ¿olved by Bromely, Portman and Harris Å¿erjeants that he could not, but if hee did make Å¿uch a leaÅ¿e, they thought that neither hee in remainder or the donour Å¿hould euer auoid it by any dying Å¿ans iÅ¿Å¿ue, 33 H. 8. f. 49. in Dyer, who, concludeth and Å¿o Å¿hall the Å¿tatute be expounded, for Å¿o was the intent, a meaning of the makers, yet the text hath no word of donours, or of them in remainder, I heare that law is taken now to bee cleane contrary in the laÅ¿t point viz, that remainders and reuerÅ¿ions are freed from this act, and I beleeue it the rather becauÅ¿e 34. H 8. ca. 20. that fruÅ¿trateth fained recoueries againÅ¿t tenant in tayle, where the King is in reuerÅ¿ion or remainder, in the prouiÅ¿ion for Å¿trength of leaÅ¿es, made according to the Statute, is only againÅ¿t the Heyre or heyres of tenant in taile, &c.

div.head: The laÅ¿t part of the Statute. SECT. XXVI.
div.p:
THe LaÅ¿t part of the Statute is negatiue againÅ¿t ãâã continuance, which how farre it preuailed before or after the act, the former inÅ¿tructions, with the act it Å¿elfe, doe put in Å¿ome cleereneÅ¿Å¿e. But a caÅ¿e or two will make it more plaine, Amy TownÅ¿end Å¿eiÅ¿ed of a Mannor in tayle, take a huÅ¿band, the huÅ¿band made a feoffement, 29. of H. 8. to diuers perÅ¿ons in fÃ©e, to the vÅ¿e of himÅ¿elfe and his wife for life of them two, with remainders of vÅ¿e ouer. After this Statute made, Amy and her huÅ¿band made a LeaÅ¿e for 21. yeares of part of this Manuor, according to this act of 32. H 8 Amy died firÅ¿t, then her huÅ¿band diedâª the queÅ¿tion is, whether Amy were remitted to her former eÅ¿tate taile by vertue of 27. H. 8. ca. 10. and Å¿o the LeaÅ¿e good, ãâã
was argued on the one part, that reduction of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion by the Å¿tatute 27. &c. was of effect alone with their feoffement, and becauÅ¿e this poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion was regained without either tort or folly in the wife, whoÅ¿e agrÃ©ement whether Å¿he would or no, was included in her husbands agreement during Couerture, Å¿he muÅ¿t nÃ©eds when Couerture was diÅ¿Å¿olued, till diÅ¿claimer, or Å¿ome act done to the contrarie be â¢ diudged in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, there was then no tenant againÅ¿t whom to bring her cui in vita, if Å¿he Å¿hould not bring her cui in vita to purge the firÅ¿t wrong, Å¿he muÅ¿t needs be remitted, if Å¿he were remitted, this cauÅ¿e muÅ¿t nÃ©eds be good. And although the Statute of 27. Å¿ettle poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions according to qualitie and quantitie of the vÅ¿e, yet it Å¿Ã©emeth not that Å¿o it Å¿hall continue, but they may change by a former ancient right, for the Act being affirmatiue takes not the Common Lawes operation in remitters: beÅ¿ides that, it hath an expreÅ¿Å¿e Å¿auing of eygne right: further, if that the wife Å¿hould not be remitted, this inconuenience followeth, the Baron might charge the Wiues inheritance with a rent, to the whole yearly value, or be bound in a Statute merchant, &c. and then making a feoffement to his wiues vÅ¿e, Å¿hee Å¿hould hold the land charged after his death. To this it was anÅ¿wered on the other part, that the feoffement at the time therof made a diÅ¿continuance, which puts Amy to her cui in vita, which becauÅ¿e Å¿he hath not vÅ¿ed, but is come to poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion onely by force of 27. &c. Å¿he muÅ¿t take it onely by the manner, order, and limitation of the Å¿ame Statute, Couerture, or infancie, being no whit materiall, becauÅ¿e the Statute hath none exception. The words are in manner, forme, qualitie and condition of the vÅ¿e, &c. and becauÅ¿e this was a new ConÅ¿titution of that which was not at the Common Law, it hath not the force of a negatiue implying in nul auter manner then is therein deÅ¿cribed: Amy is therefore a ioynt purchaÅ¿er with her huÅ¿band in eÅ¿tate for life, and not in or by deÅ¿cent of eÅ¿tate ta â¢â¢ e: Now to Å¿ay that her right and eÅ¿tate Å¿hould change
by Å¿ilent operation of the Law after Å¿hee was repoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed, that cannot be, for the whole entry is tolled, and if Å¿he be not remitted by her firÅ¿tâª poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion and repriÅ¿all, Å¿he is neuer remitted.

If a DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿our make feoffement to the vÅ¿e of the DiÅ¿feiÅ¿Ã©e, and after the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or enter, he Å¿hall be remitted, but before his entry he Å¿hall not be remitted, for he Å¿hall be adiudged in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion by vertue of the Statute, but Å¿o Å¿oone as hee entreth he is remitted, for his entry was neuer tolled: But Amy TowneÅ¿ends entry was cleane taken away, by the diÅ¿continuance, &c. further if Å¿he Å¿hould be remitted by the Statute of 27. the remainders Å¿hould be all deÅ¿troyed contrary to the text of the Å¿ame Statute. And to the inconue â¢ iencie alleadged, if Å¿he Å¿hall not be remitted Å¿hee Å¿hall hold incombred with the charges of her HuÅ¿band, that is none at all, for Amy after her huÅ¿bands death might haue diÅ¿agrÃ©ed and relinquiÅ¿hed the vÅ¿e with poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion annexed to it, by bringing a cui in vita, againÅ¿t him next in remainder; for in him by Å¿uch diÅ¿agrÃ©ement or vÅ¿er of action had the remainder veÅ¿ted, as though the woman had beene a Monke or dead perÅ¿on in Law, or neuer named in the limitation: If the vÅ¿e had bÃ©ene to Amy TownÅ¿end in fÃ©e, Å¿he might haue brought her cui in vita againÅ¿t the Feoffor or his heyre, by which they Å¿hall be Tenants to her action, and Å¿o might the in â¢ umbrance haue bÃ©ene auoydedâª for when a feoffement is to the vÅ¿e of one which refuÅ¿eth the vÅ¿e, it Å¿hall be in effect as if the vÅ¿e had beene limited to Paules Å¿tÃ©eple or to Charing-CroÅ¿Å¿e, all falling or reflecting becauÅ¿e the Feoffor hath no recompence or conÅ¿ideration to his vÅ¿e, and hee Å¿hall be Tenant to euery Precipe: It was further agreed, that as the CauÅ¿e fell out, Amy TowneÅ¿end could not be remitted, though her poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion had returned by refeoffemeÌt at the Common Law, becauÅ¿e Sir Roger TowneÅ¿end her HuÅ¿band outliued her, for 21. Ed. 3. the CaÅ¿e is, Baron made a Feoffement, the FeoffÃ©e â¢ einfeoffe the Baron and Feme and heyres of the wife,
Å¿he woman dyed, the Heyre entred, the Baron brought an AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e, which was iudged maintainable: for whileÅ¿t the Baron liued he was tenant to the heyres action; And the th â¢ Iudgement was, that Amy TownÅ¿end was neuer remitted; the reaÅ¿on was indÃ©ed becauÅ¿e there is nothing in the Statute of 27. to make a remitter: for the clauÅ¿e of Å¿auing of Dr â¢ its, Titles and Actions, is of Å¿uch right, &c. as was before the Statute, and not of any right, title, or action, riÅ¿en Å¿ince or after it: Now note that as a LeaÅ¿e made for twenty yeares by Baron and feme Tenants for life binds not any remainder by the Statute, which Å¿peaketh onely that LeaÅ¿es made by Tenants of Inheritance, Å¿hall binde heyres and SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, Å¿o I would inferre that if the LeaÅ¿Å¿ors inheritance be determined, whether it were iure vxoris in taile or otherwiÅ¿e in taile, the remainder muÅ¿t be frÃ©e from the Statute: But note that the point which made me chooÅ¿e this caÅ¿e for illuÅ¿tration of the Statute, is this, Amy TowneÅ¿end was iudged not remitted, becauÅ¿e Å¿he had no title of entry, but onely by the 27, &c. of vÅ¿es, and therefore Å¿he muÅ¿t nÃ©eds claime her poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, according to the vÅ¿e.

But put CaÅ¿e the Feoffement had bÃ©ene Å¿ince the Statute of 32âª the Law would then haue iudged a remitter; for by Littleton, where any perÅ¿ons entry is congeable, which taketh eÅ¿tate for life or in fÃ©e, it is a remitter, if the repriÅ¿all be not by Indenture, or record, or Å¿ome matter of eÅ¿toppell, for alwayes where there is a double right or title, the Law muÅ¿t iudge for the beÅ¿t, as well in the entry as in the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and an Indenture made by Baron and Feme is none eÅ¿toppell to the Wife by the Common Law.

Concerning the CaÅ¿e 21. Ed. 3. Wilby which gaue iudgement, thought the Barons aduantage a hinderance to the Remitter, yet if he died the wife Å¿hould be remitted: But if you looke, Brooke remitter 21. and 41. ye Å¿hall finde that
the Feme was maintenant remitted though to Å¿aue the huÅ¿bands aduantage of warranty, they would not Å¿o iudge it, quod mirum Å¿aith Brooke, and quaere quia contrarium a ceo iour.

div.head: SECT. XXVII. Whether acceptance or taciturnity may not take away an entry at this day.
div.p:
NO fine, feoffement or other act done by the huÅ¿band onely Å¿hall make any diÅ¿continuance or be preiudiciall to the wife, but that Å¿he may enter, &c. what if Baron and Feme make a feoffement or LeaÅ¿e for life, by Å¿olemne Indentures with Liuery and Å¿eiÅ¿in cleere, this takes not away at this day the wiues entry after Couerture ended. But admit when Å¿hee is a widdow, Å¿hee refuÅ¿eth to enter and accept payment of rent or performance of couenants: is not now both her entry, and her action gone alÅ¿o, euen as in caÅ¿e of an Infant, which makes Å¿uch a feoffement or LeaÅ¿e, and accepts the rent when he is of full age: The queÅ¿tion muÅ¿t be anÅ¿wered out of the Statute, and in mine opinion there is nothing in it to ayde a woman after Å¿uch ratification by acceptance volenti non fit iniuria, nec inuitis confirmantur beneficia. A LeaÅ¿e by Baron & Feme per Indenture is not voyd preÅ¿ently by the Barons death. But whereas before Å¿he was driuen to Å¿uit and action, Å¿hee may now enter by the Statute, yet it compels her not to enter, neither ca â¢ teth any frÃ©e-hold vpon her. In like manner if the Baron alone alien his Wiues Land by fine with proclamation, the Wife may enter by force of this Statute, but per opinionem totius curiae Ed. 6. Dyer fo. 72. If Å¿he Å¿uffer fiue yeares to paÅ¿Å¿e and expire without entry or vÅ¿er of action Å¿he and her heyres Å¿hall be barred for euer, for this
Statute of 32. though it limit no time for the womans entry, yet it Å¿peaketh nothing of fines with proclamation, and therefore it takes not the generall Law made 4. Hen. 7. cap. 24. of fines, with proclamation. And Å¿Ã©e Sir Ed. Cokes 8. Rep. fo. 72. in Grenlies caÅ¿e.

div.head: SECT. XXVIII. Of Fines.
div.p: SEe further the caÅ¿e 18. Eliz. Dyer 351. Land holden in Å¿ocage was giuen to a man and his wife in taile, the remainder in Å¿Ã©e to the Barons right heyres, the Baron alone leuied a fine with proclamation to his owne vÅ¿e, and afterward by his laÅ¿t will and TeÅ¿tament in writing, deuiÅ¿ed the Land to his wife for life, the remainder ouer to a Stranger vpon condition to pay certaine rent annually out of the land with ClauÅ¿e of diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e, &c. the Baron died, the wife entering and claiming eÅ¿tate onely for life paid rent according to the will and died. Now the queÅ¿tion is, wh â¢ the IÅ¿Å¿ue in taile or DeuiÅ¿Ã©e of the remainder Å¿hould haue this Land, Et per iudicium curiae. Partly becauÅ¿e his mother had waued the eÅ¿tate taile, and although Å¿hee had not done Å¿o, yet becauÅ¿e he could not conuey his title and diÅ¿cent, but aÅ¿well as heyre to his father as to his mother, the fine with proclamations leuied onely by his father barres him: So farre goeth the Booke. And you may obÅ¿erue, that it barres the wife if Å¿he will.

See alÅ¿o 5. Eliz. 224 in Dyer, the huÅ¿band leuied a fine with proclamations of his owne land, and after fiue yeares died, his widdow continuing Å¿ole, of full age, whole memory, out of priÅ¿on, within compaÅ¿Å¿e of the foure Seas, and doth not make any demand or claime of dower, within 5. yeers after her huÅ¿bands death (quaere if he which pleadeth in
barre of Dower, ought expreÅ¿ly to auerre this:) The queÅ¿tion was, if Å¿he were barred of Dower, Dyer telleth vs termino Hillarij 4. H. 8. rotulo 344. Å¿uch a barre pleaded was admitted good, for the ground of Dower was the HuÅ¿bands Å¿eiÅ¿in, and the action giuen by his death. So that it is within the Å¿econd Å¿auing of 4. H 7. which preÅ¿erueth to all which are not parties purÅ¿uit of right growne after the fine, by or vpon cauÅ¿e before the fine, Å¿o that they take it within fiue yeares.

In Plowden fo. 373. IuÅ¿tice Dyer arguing Stowell and the Lord Zouches caÅ¿e, affirmes the learning which I haue recited out of his owne booke: But Plowden inÅ¿erts his note, that he takes the Law to be otherwiÅ¿e, and that a woman is bound to no time of her Dower, after Å¿uch a fine, for (Å¿aith he) the ayme of 4. H. 7. as againÅ¿t future droicts is wholly againÅ¿t Å¿uch rights, as either Å¿uffered wrong before the fine, or by the fine, and in this caÅ¿e of Dower, the title is all after the fine, and Å¿tandeth well in accord with it, not touched by the Statute, the woman therefore may demand when Å¿he liÅ¿teth.

So if there be a ceÅ¿Å¿or begun, a yeare before a fine with proclamations continued a yeare after, the Lord is not reÅ¿treyned at the end of 5. or 15. yeares to bring a ceÅ¿Å¿auir. Å¿o he Å¿aith likewiÅ¿e, if a morgage be diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed, a fine lenied by the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or with Proclamations paÅ¿Å¿ed, yet the morgager paying his mony to the Morgagee may at any time, within 5. years or more, after the payment re-enter. When Giants fight, PigmÃ©es may not part them: but howÅ¿oeuer Å¿ome incertainty ariÅ¿e in euery corner of the Law, this is here certaine, that a fine leuied by the huÅ¿band onely, of his owne land, tolleth not the wiues action of Dower, if Å¿he come in time: And a fine Å¿o leuied, by him, of the wiues Land, taketh not away her Å¿eaÅ¿onable entry; but the gulfe that Å¿walled vp entrie, action right, and all poÅ¿Å¿ibility of reducement by Law is a fine lawfully leuied by baron and feme, where (forÅ¿ooth) becauÅ¿e a woman is examined by
a IuÅ¿tice or one that hath a Dedimus poteÅ¿tatem, &c. and acknowledgeth her frÃ©e conÅ¿ent and agrÃ©ement, what cannot men get wiues to doe if they liÅ¿t, Å¿he Å¿hall be barred and for euer excluded of a great many acres of ground, for a few kiÅ¿Å¿es and a gay gowne. That is a fine finem litibus imponens, for till it be done and diÅ¿patcht, the poore woman can haue no quiet her huÅ¿band keepes Å¿uch a iawling.

div.head: SECT. XXIX. Of common recoueries.
div.p:
AS for trickes of Common recoueries I perceiue not how that can be greatly preiudiciall to women: for firÅ¿t if a man will Å¿uffer a faigned recouery of his owne Land to defeate his wiues Dower, Å¿he may falÅ¿i â¢â¢ e it, &c. Å¿Ã©e the Eiectione firmae per Eare againÅ¿t Snow, Plowd. fo. 515. the baron there being tenant in taile, his wife hauing nothing in the Land, he and his wife Å¿uffered a common recouery with voucher to his owne vÅ¿e, &c. the opinion of all the IuÅ¿tices was, that though the woman Å¿uruiued, yet the eÅ¿tate taile Å¿hal be barred, for it was found preciÅ¿ely by verdict that the wife had no intereÅ¿t in the Inheritance: The baron therefore, which alone loÅ¿t eÅ¿tato taile by the recouery, might recouer alone eÅ¿tate taile in value. But as for the wife, no man can Å¿ay what eÅ¿tate Å¿hee had; nor whether Å¿he Å¿hould haue a quod ei deforceat, or a Writt of right, if Å¿he had loÅ¿t the land by default. So likewiÅ¿e hauing loÅ¿t by the recouery, nothing or no man can tell what her recompence in value muÅ¿t be: She was named (Å¿aid the IuÅ¿tices) vpon intent to barre her of Dower, and Å¿uch is the meaning of huÅ¿baÌds which wil haue their wiues named in Å¿uch recoueries: but cleere the eÅ¿tate taile is barred, if in this caÅ¿e the wife might Å¿ue execution in value againÅ¿t the
vouchÃ©e by eÅ¿toppell, yet the iÅ¿Å¿ue in taile Å¿hould not be concluded by the act of his Father, but he might ouÅ¿t her of that which Å¿he had Å¿o recouered in value, &c. Å¿ee Sir E. Cokes 10. Rep. 43. a. in Mary Portingtons ca. that the vÅ¿age hath bÃ©en alwayes vpon common recoueries againÅ¿t Baron and Feme to examine the wife, and to grant a dedimus poteÅ¿tatem, to take vpon her examination her ConuÅ¿ance as in caÅ¿e of a Fine.

But let the caÅ¿e be, Tenant iure vxoris is agrÃ©ed with Iohn a Stile to Å¿uffer a recouery of his wiues Lands to certaine vÅ¿es compriÅ¿ed in Indentures betwixt them two, a Writ of entry in the poÅ¿t is brought againÅ¿t the Baron and Feme, which appeare in perÅ¿on or by Atturney, calling to warranty the common vouchÃ©e, a man well worth a couple of new roÅ¿ted egges, which re-enters into warrantie, Then after declaration and imparlance, at the day of the appearance Å¿hall the demandant recouer againÅ¿t Baron and Feme, and they in right of the Wife Å¿hall recouer againÅ¿t the Vouchee of Å¿uch lands as he hath, or is like to haue when time hath a hairy crowne: Å¿hall this recouery or poÅ¿Å¿ibility of vnlikely recouery in value binde the wife when the Baron is dead whether Å¿he will or no: by Brooks nouell caÅ¿es, 23. H. 8. pl. 37. it Å¿Ã©emes that Å¿uch a recouery did then bind the wife to: but without examination mee thinks it Å¿hould not bind the wife: The Statute of 32. is that none Act of the Barons Å¿hall make diÅ¿continuance, &c. except onely a Fine by Baron and Feme, Ergo Å¿uch a recouery notwithÅ¿tanding though it be executed the wife may enter. See 23. Eliz. cap. 3. and there is a Å¿auing to euery Feme couert or her heyres her Writt of error to be Å¿ued within 7. yeares after Å¿he become Å¿ole, for reuerÅ¿ing of Fines and recoueries paÅ¿t, if they muÅ¿t be reuerÅ¿ed by error, it Å¿Ã©emes without error, they were very dangerous. For a rule to conclude withall, take this, That whereÅ¿oeuer the Baron doth any thing out of Court, which thing he and his Wife were compellable to doe, it Å¿hall be deemed and conÅ¿trued
to be the act of both of them, as if the Baron Å¿eiÅ¿ed in right of his Wife, or ioyntly with his wife, aÅ¿Å¿igne Dower to another woman, it bindeth, and Å¿o granting of a rent for equality of partition and atturnement by the Baron alone, bindes the Wife.

div.head: SECT. XXX. of Iointures.
div.p: I Will enter no further into the Å¿treame of Fines and recouerie, they require a cunning Å¿wimmer: And a Å¿hort DiÅ¿courÅ¿e cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly make any plaine diÅ¿couery of them; otherwiÅ¿e this place would haue borne the Doctrine fitly about making of ioyntures, for all huÅ¿bands are not Å¿o vnkinde or vntruÅ¿ty as to endamage their Wiues by alienation of their Lands: but contrariwiÅ¿e the greateÅ¿t part of honeÅ¿t, wiÅ¿e and Å¿ober men, are of themÅ¿elues carefull to purchaÅ¿e Å¿omewhat for their Wiues, if they be not, yet they Å¿tand Å¿ometimes bound by the womans parents to make their Wiues Å¿ome Ioynture.

If huÅ¿band, Father, Mother and all would be vnmindfull of prouiÅ¿ion in this point, yet very many of our EngliÅ¿h women haue with their Å¿ingular vertue, Å¿o much wiÅ¿edome of their owne, as to foreÅ¿ee for themÅ¿elues, and diÅ¿cerne the difference betwÃ©ene that which wee call Dower and Ioynture: Ioyntures Å¿aith Dyer 4. M. fo. 148âª are made for the moÅ¿t part to Baron and Feme ioyntly, or to the Feme onely, this alÅ¿o is comprehended vnder the terme Ioynture before Marriage or after, for Å¿uÅ¿tentation of the charge and neceÅ¿Å¿ities of EÅ¿pouÅ¿alls; and they are made cauÅ¿a matrimon â¢â¢ & gratisâª without the conÅ¿ideration of money, bargaine or any thing Å¿auing for loue and affection of the Baron or his anceÅ¿Å¿ors, and theÅ¿e Iointures are a preÅ¿ent poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion: But Dower muÅ¿t be tarried for till the
HuÅ¿band be dead: It muÅ¿t be demanded, Å¿ometime Å¿ued, for Å¿ometime neither with Å¿uit or demand obtained. Againe, Dower was Å¿ubiect to forfeiture in times paÅ¿t, by felony done and proued in the Baron by the Barons treaÅ¿on, by the Wiues elopement, and euery queÅ¿tion in the validitie of Marriage maketh a Å¿cruple of Dower, all which inconueniences being wiÅ¿ely foreÅ¿Ã©ene, women did learne to become ioynt purchaÅ¿ors with their huÅ¿bands of Å¿uch eÅ¿tates, as would auoid all weathers, and a good while they did enioy Ioyntures and Dowers after their HuÅ¿bands were dead; againÅ¿t which the Statute of 27. H. 8. of vÅ¿es, ordeineth as followeth.

div.head: SECT. XXXI. A part of 27. H. 8. ca. 10.
div.p:
IT is prouided, &c. that where any perÅ¿ons haue purchaÅ¿ed or haue eÅ¿tate of lands, &c. made to them and their Wiues, and to the heyres of the HuÅ¿band, or to the HuÅ¿band and wife, and the heyres of their two bodies, or to the heyres of one of their bodies, or to the huÅ¿band and wife for terme of their liues, or for the life of the wife, or where any Å¿uch eÅ¿tate hath bÃ©ene or Å¿hall be made, to any huÅ¿band and his wife or to other perÅ¿ons their heyres and aÅ¿Å¿ignes to the vÅ¿e and behoofe of the Å¿aid huÅ¿band and wife, or to the vÅ¿e of the wife for the ioynture of the wife, that in euery Å¿uch caÅ¿e the woman hauing Å¿uch a Ioynture, &c. Å¿hall not claime any Dower of the reÅ¿idue of any Hereditaments that were her HuÅ¿bands, by whom Å¿he had Å¿uch a Ioynture, or make any demand thereof againÅ¿t the Tenants of the Å¿aid lands, &c. prouided that if any woman be lawfully expulÅ¿ed or euicted from her Å¿aid Ioynture or from any part thereof without fraud or Couen, by lawfull entry, action or diÅ¿continuance of her HuÅ¿band, that euery Å¿uch woman Å¿hall
be endowed of as much of the reÅ¿idue of her HuÅ¿bands hereditaments as the Lands or Tene â¢ ents Å¿o euicted Å¿hall amount or extend vnto: Prouided that nothing in this act extend to hurt or preiudice any woman heretofore married, concerning her right, title, vÅ¿e, intereÅ¿t or poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion which Å¿he may claime or pretend to haue for her Ioynture or Dower in any Lands, &c. of her late HuÅ¿band being now diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed: Prouided alÅ¿o, that if any Wife haue or hereafter Å¿hall haue any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments vnto her giuen or aÅ¿Å¿ured after Marriage for terme of her life, or otherwiÅ¿e in Ioynture (except the aÅ¿Å¿urance be made to her by act of Parliament, and the Wife after that fortune to out-liue her huÅ¿band, in whoÅ¿e time the Ioynture was made, that the Wife Å¿o ouer-liuing, Å¿hall and may at her pleaÅ¿ure refuÅ¿e the Lands appointed or aÅ¿Å¿ured in Ioynture, and thereupon haue, demand and take her Dower by Writt or otherwiÅ¿e, according to the Common Law.

div.head: SECT. XXXII. The ExpoÅ¿ition.
div.p:
THe firÅ¿t obÅ¿eruance is that no eÅ¿tate gained by matter of concluÅ¿ion, Å¿hall be dÃ©emed a purchaÅ¿ement within this Statute, or bee auerred to bee made pro iunctura: But the Statute muÅ¿t be intended of true and Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall eÅ¿tates. Therefore if an owner or tenant of certaine land make anÅ¿wer to Baron and Feme in an action of waÅ¿te, or if he pray ayde of them, as if they were Å¿eiÅ¿ed of the reuerÅ¿ion, or if he bring a quod ei deforceat, againÅ¿t them as if he had none other then a particular eÅ¿tate; though theÅ¿e things were purpoÅ¿ed for Ioynture, yet they Å¿eclude not a Woman from right or demand of Dower: ReleaÅ¿es Å¿uch as inure to make eÅ¿tates, as where a ioynt-tenant releaÅ¿eth
to his Companion, or Å¿uch as goe to inlarge an eÅ¿tate, as where he in reuerÅ¿ion releaÅ¿eth to his particular Tenant, may well make and accompliÅ¿h a Ioynture: but Å¿uch ReleaÅ¿es as worke no more but vn mitter le droit, as where he that is diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed by Baron and Feme, releaÅ¿eth to the woman the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ereÅ¿Å¿e, &c. are no purchaÅ¿e intended within this Statute, for it is meant onely of Å¿uch purchaÅ¿es as the wife hath by gift either of her huÅ¿band or of Å¿ome other body, and not of Å¿uch eÅ¿tates, as Å¿hee hath gained by her owne wrong: likewiÅ¿e is it of releaÅ¿es that goe by way of extinguiÅ¿hment, as where a DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or infeoffeth Baron and Feme, and the DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿Ã©e releaÅ¿eth to one of them, this is alike auaileable to both, but this releaÅ¿e can make no Ioynture, for there is no eÅ¿tate conueyed by it.

Per iuÅ¿ticiarios, 6. Ed. 6. Brooke titles Dower, a deuiÅ¿e of Land by the HuÅ¿band to his Wife in his laÅ¿t will and teÅ¿tament, is no barre of Dower, for it is but a beneuolence and no Ioynture: Yet in M. Brograues reading it was holden contrary, 5. Eliz. Dyer, 220. the caÅ¿e is, that a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed of Lands in taile, and of Å¿ome other in fÃ©e-Å¿imple, holden in Å¿ocage, deuiÅ¿eth the third part of all his Lands to his wife for her life, in full recompence of all Å¿uch Ioynture and Dower as Å¿he Å¿hall haue or may claime, &c. the Wife without any aÅ¿Å¿ignement or vÅ¿er of Action of Dower entreth after his death, into that which was holden in FÃ©eÅ¿imple to a value of a third part of all, and the opinion was, Å¿he had determined her election and barred her Å¿elfe of Dower.

But this CaÅ¿e maketh nothing to the variance or queÅ¿tion, becauÅ¿e the Legacie was with an expreÅ¿Å¿e excluÅ¿ion of Dower, &c. But Å¿ee Sir Ed. Cokes 4. Rep. fo. 4. a. in Vernons caÅ¿e, reÅ¿olued that vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be expreÅ¿Å¿ed in the will to bee for her Ioynture it Å¿hall be no Å¿atisfaction for her Dower: See 38. H. 8. Dyer 61. William Whorewhod Å¿eiÅ¿ed of Land, to the value of 360. pound, of which 60. pound was by ioynt purchaÅ¿e to him and his Wife during Couerture,
deuiÅ¿ed, that his wife Å¿hould haue the third part of all his land during her life, with thoÅ¿e Lands, which Å¿he had in Ioynture, the aÅ¿Å¿ignement to be made by his executors, if it were not contrary to Law, this Widdow refuÅ¿ed her Iointure of 60. pound, and demand a third part of the whole inheritance; viz. 120. pound as her Legacie, with a third part of that which remained for her D â¢ wer, viz. 80. pound: at laÅ¿t by agrÃ©ement it was ordered and decrÃ©ed in the Court of Wards, that Å¿he Å¿hould haue the Legacie, vt Å¿upra, and forty pound ouer for Dower: This CaÅ¿e decideth the queÅ¿tion, for it is againÅ¿t the latter opinion expreÅ¿Å¿e, ideo quaere. Brooke noteth alÅ¿o Dower 69. that per IuÅ¿ticiarios, if a man make his Wife ioynt-purchaÅ¿er with him after Couerture, of any eÅ¿tate of Franke Tenement, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be to him and his Wife and their Heyres in fÃ©eÅ¿imple, it is a barre of Dower if Å¿he agrÃ©e to the Ioynture poÅ¿t mortem viri, otherwiÅ¿e it is of fÃ©e-Å¿imple, for thereof the Statute Å¿aith nothing. But M. Brograue in his reading did maintaine for all the foreÅ¿aid opinion, that where fee-Å¿imple is conueyed to a Feme for Ioynture expreÅ¿ly, it is a good Iointure within compaÅ¿Å¿e of this Statute: for if eÅ¿tate in taile or for life be a good Iointure, and exclude Dower by acceptance, &c. a fortiore, fÃ©e-Å¿imple Å¿hall barre. And Å¿Ã©e in Vernons caÅ¿e reported by Sir Ed. Coke 4. Rep. fo. 3. b. that the caÅ¿e in Brooke is miÅ¿-reported and the Lord Dyer is againÅ¿t it, and confuteth Brooks reaÅ¿ons of this opinion.

Hee relied alÅ¿o vpon dame Dennis caÅ¿e, 8. Elizâª Dyer 248. An Indenture was made 36. H â¢ n. 8. Betwixt Sir Maurice Dennis and Elizabeth Statham, that in conÅ¿ideration of expected Marriage, and other things reaÅ¿onable the Å¿aid Sir Maurice and his heyres, Å¿hould from thenceforth Å¿tand Å¿eiÅ¿ed of certaine Lands, &c. to the vÅ¿e of himÅ¿elfe and his heyres vntill Marriage were had and Å¿olemnized, and then to the vÅ¿e and behoofe of the Å¿aid Maurice and Elizabeth, and their heyres after Marriage, Sir Maurice
dyed, entred into the Lands, and demanded Dower of his other Lands, it was a queÅ¿tion whether this conueyance and matter, vt Å¿upra, with auerrement that it was for a Ioynture, Å¿hould barre her of Dower, Catline, Saunders, and Dyer were againÅ¿t the Dower by equitie of the Statute, which in the third prouiÅ¿o is of Ioyntures for terme of life or otherwiÅ¿e: AgainÅ¿t them were IuÅ¿tice Browne and Whiddon, and they reÅ¿embled this Statute to another of the 11. H. 7. ca. 20. which cannot be extended to fÃ©e-Å¿imple, but is meant and expreÅ¿Å¿ed onely of eÅ¿tate for Life, or in taile Å¿euerally or ioyntly with the Baron.

But IuÅ¿tice Dyer as it Å¿Ã©emeth by M. Brograue vpon diligent conference with Å¿age men of Law, did Å¿trongly adhere to his former opinion, that this conueyance with auerment made a good Ioynture: Yee Å¿hall finde againe, 14. & 15. El â¢ zâª he affirmeth for Law, that where FÃ©e-Å¿imple is limited ouer to a Wife, or eÅ¿tate made to Baron and Feme in fÃ©e, it is auerrable pro iunctura, if the conueyance he not expreÅ¿ly contrary: SÃ©e a queÅ¿tion for auerment, Dyer 226.

One that had an vÅ¿e in FÃ©e of certaine Lands, to the value annuall of 100. pound, tooke a wife, 22. H. 8. and after eÅ¿pouÅ¿als at requeÅ¿t of his wiues friends and Parents, cauÅ¿ed the Feoffees to execute eÅ¿tate to him and his wife, and to the heyres of himÅ¿elfe of parcell of this Land to twenty pound value, &c. He then purchaÅ¿ed other Lands, and after 27. dyed Å¿eiÅ¿ed of all: The wife by taking rents and profits of the twenty pound land agreed to her eÅ¿tate therein, and afterward brought a Writ of Dower, detertia par â¢ e reÅ¿idui omnium terrarum, &c. becauÅ¿e the Statute is expreÅ¿Å¿ed of Iointure, and the dÃ©ed whereby eÅ¿tate was made to the baron and feme hath no mention of Ioynture or Dower, quaere, whether this matter generally alledged without auerment, that it was pro juncturaâª vel pro do â¢ e, Å¿hall barre or no: See the InÅ¿titutions of Sir Ed. Coke, â¢ o. 36. much matter concerning Ioynture.

In all conueyance or purchaÅ¿e for Ioynture, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be by fine, or common recouerie, he which makes the eÅ¿tate muÅ¿t be a perÅ¿on able to conuey &c. at the time of Ioynture making, or elÅ¿e it is not good.

He muÅ¿t not therefore be non compos mentis, attaint of treaÅ¿on, an alien borne, or vnder ageâª but the non-age of the Wife, is not materiall whether the Ioynture be made, before Couerture or after, if Å¿he accept it, agrÃ©ed at M. Fi â¢
ches reading.

div.head: SECT. XXXII. The Words, Land, Tenement or Hereditament.
div.p: LAnd is intended as well of paÅ¿ture, meadow, woods, heath, &c. as of arable, and lands couered with water or Å¿urrounded is within the Statute: So is a Towne an IÅ¿le, &c. but veÅ¿tura terrae, or an vpper Chamber cannot make a Ioynture as Land.

Tenements aÅ¿Å¿ured in Ioynture, may bee AduouÅ¿ans, Rectories, Windmils, an vpper Chamber, a Seigniory in Chiualrie, and a reuerÅ¿ion Å¿ur eÅ¿tate pur vi â¢ , all comming within the mea â¢ ing of the Statute.

As for a reuerÅ¿ion vpon or after eÅ¿tate for yeares, it is rather in account of law, land, then a tenement: for the Franke Tenement, which is the principall, is as the preÅ¿ent Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Land it Å¿elfe: And the reuerÅ¿ion of either of theÅ¿e particular eÅ¿tates, if rent be reÅ¿erued, may well be aÅ¿Å¿igned for a Ioynture.

Yea and whether rent be reÅ¿erued or no vpon a LeaÅ¿e for yeares, it might be Å¿omewhat doubted whether the reuerÅ¿ion be aÅ¿Å¿ignable for a Ioynture, &c. becauÅ¿e the Frank Tenement paÅ¿Å¿eth preÅ¿ently, and a woman may haue an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e thereof.

But cleere a nude reuerÅ¿ion, Å¿ur eÅ¿tate pur vie Å¿ans rent, becauÅ¿e it is no preÅ¿ent commoditie, cannot make a Ioynture, yet if Å¿uch a reuerÅ¿ion be aÅ¿Å¿igned, and it turne to a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion in the HuÅ¿bands life time, it may be a good Ioynture by matter of Å¿ubÅ¿equent Hereditament, within the Statute may be a rent charge granted to a woman for life, though it were neuer in eÅ¿Å¿e before; or a rent reÅ¿erued vpon a LeaÅ¿e for life: But the Hereditament aÅ¿Å¿igned muÅ¿t bee a profit and commodity, or elÅ¿e it is not aÅ¿Å¿ignable, &c, for homage or fealtie, Å¿hall not make any Ioynture.

Rent payable euery fiue yeare may be aÅ¿Å¿igned for Ioynture, for is a profit though it be not annuall. And an ancient kÃ©eperÅ¿hip of a Parke with a fÃ©e belonging to it, may be appointed or aÅ¿Å¿igned in Dower.
But Å¿o is not a kÃ©eperÅ¿hip newly granted and Å¿ans fÃ©e, which is a charge, without gaine or vtility.

div.head: SECT. XXXIII. EÅ¿tates Taile.
div.p: ALl eÅ¿tates tayle, are within the equitie or compaÅ¿Å¿e of this branch of 27. and the formes or Å¿pecies within the â¢ etter are but as patternes or examples of Ioyntures. And therefore where an eÅ¿tate is limited to Baron and feme, and to the Heyres Males of their bodies, or to them and the heyres Males or Females of the body of one of them, although this be an abridgement or amputation of one Å¿exe, from the examples within the very Statute; yet it is a good Ioynture.

There is a CaÅ¿e in proofe thereof, Dyer, 97. 1âª Marie the DucheÅ¿Å¿e of SomerÅ¿et was ioynt-purchaÅ¿er with her huÅ¿band of eÅ¿tate to them two, and to the heyres Males of her HuÅ¿bands body, betweene them begotten, which is none of
the fiue eÅ¿tates expreÅ¿Å¿ed in the Statute, but the IuÅ¿tices held cleare vnleÅ¿Å¿e it were refuÅ¿ed it excluded Dower.

So is it if eÅ¿tate be made to Baron and Feme, to them and the heyres Males which the Baron Å¿hall haue of the body of his wife, vel e conuerÅ¿o. Or if the gift be to Baron and Feme, and thrÃ©e heyres of their two Bodies, which is an eÅ¿tate determinable vpon death of the third IÅ¿Å¿ue, or if it be to them and to the heyres de corpore, the Å¿onne of both of them or of one of them all theÅ¿e eÅ¿tates limited for Ioynture are good enough.

div.head: SECT. XXXV. EÅ¿tate for Life, &c.
div.p:
THeÅ¿e words, Or for life of the Wife, are intendable as well for an eÅ¿tate made to the Wife onely during her life, as of an eÅ¿tate made ioyntly to Baron and Feme during the life of the Wife: Therefore an eÅ¿tate made onely to the Wife for her life, or to the Baron for his life, with a remainder to the Wife for her life, is a good Ioynture within meaning of the Statute; yet it Å¿eemeth not to agrÃ©e with the nature of a Ioynture by the etimology of the word, and the Statute Å¿peaketh not of any remainder, Dyer 14. & 15. Eliz. fol. 387. agrÃ©eth and Å¿aith that Ioyntures may bee conditionall, which if the Wife accept after the huÅ¿bands death, Å¿he Å¿hall be barred of Dower, as where the condition is, that Å¿hee Å¿hall kÃ©epe her Å¿elfe vnmarried, and, Å¿aith he, a Conueyance to a wife during her life in remainder, after the immediate death of her HuÅ¿band, vpon condition reaÅ¿onable may well bee intended pro iunctura, yet he himÅ¿elfe afterwards, fo. 340. thinketh that Å¿uch a remainder to the wife for her life, after the death of her HuÅ¿band, cannot bee termed a Ioynture, becauÅ¿e the Etimologie Å¿erueth not, and 11. H. 7. ca. 20. & 27. H. 8. demonÅ¿trateth
no Å¿uch Ioynture for women in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion or in vÅ¿e of any eÅ¿tate in remainder after the HuÅ¿bands death, &c. quaere.

If an eÅ¿tate bee conueyed to a mans Wife, and to a Å¿tranger for their two liues for the Wiues Ioynture, it is good enough, yet the Statute mentioneth onely eÅ¿tates betwixt Baron and Feme: And although the eÅ¿tate be not conueyed to the Feme by preciÅ¿e termes for her life; yet words that amount to as much, Å¿hall be of as great effect: As if Lands be giuen to a wife, vntill I. S. hath leuied an hundred pound, or till he be promoted to a Benefice: This maketh an eÅ¿tate for life, within the branch of 27. &c.

div.head: SECT. XXXVI. EÅ¿tate to the vÅ¿e of Baron and Feme.
div.p: IF eÅ¿tate be conueyed to Baron and Feme to the vÅ¿e of a Stranger, this is no Ioynture; but if it be to Baron and Feme, or to one of them, or to a Stranger to the vÅ¿e of the Feme, it is a good Ioynture, and in euery limitation of vÅ¿e to the Baron and Feme it is requiÅ¿ite that he or they that Å¿hall take the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion may be Å¿eiÅ¿ed to an vÅ¿e, for if Lands be giuen to the King, or a Corporation, or to an alien borne to the vÅ¿e of Baron and Feme, this is no good Ioynture, for theÅ¿e perÅ¿ons cannot Å¿tand Å¿eiÅ¿ed to another bodies vÅ¿e, no more can a Rector or ParÅ¿on of a Church, or a BiÅ¿hop, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be in reÅ¿pect of their naturall capacitie; but a man attainted may take for another bodies vÅ¿e, and therefore a Feoffement to him, to the vÅ¿e of Baron and Feme may be a Ioynture.

div.head: SECT. XXXVII. How a Woman may haue a Ioynture and Dower, and how neither Ioynture nor Dower.
div.p:
A Woman may haue Dower notwithÅ¿tanding her Iointure, by the kind ouerÅ¿ight of her HuÅ¿band, or of his heyre: As if a Ioynture aÅ¿Å¿igned, the Baron himÅ¿elfe will endow his Wife, ad oÅ¿tium EccleÅ¿iae, or ex aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u patris; Or if after the huÅ¿bands death, his heyre or FeoffÃ©e will aÅ¿Å¿igne other Lands in Dower to her which hath a Ioynture already: Or if the heyre plead to her in a Writt of Dower, ne vnque Å¿eiÅ¿i
que Dower, &c. or nient accouple in loyall matrimonie; or any other plea Å¿aue Ioynture, &c. in barre of Dower, for in Å¿uch CaÅ¿e if it be found againÅ¿t him, the woman Å¿hall recouer Dower, and retaine her Iointure neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, quia volenti non fuit iniuria. On the other Å¿ide a Woman Å¿hall haue neither Ioynture nor Dower, if by her owne folly or wrong done, Å¿he haue forfeited her Ioynture: As by breach of a condition annexed to her eÅ¿tate, or doing of waÅ¿t, or making a Feoffement: And if her Ioynture by lawfull title, and without any folly in her, be euicted from her yet where the heyre is remitted to another eÅ¿tate then that which her huÅ¿band was Å¿eiÅ¿ed of during Couerture, Å¿he getteth no Dower. So is it if the eÅ¿tate whereof Dower is demanded, were conueyed to the Baron and his heyres during the life of I. S. But if it were to the Baron and his heyres, for Å¿o long time as I. S. had heyres of his body lawfully begotten, this eÅ¿tate may yÃ©eld Dower.

div.head: SECT. XXXVII. The firÅ¿t ProuiÅ¿o for Dower vpon euiction of Ioynture.
div.p: THis ProuiÅ¿o is to be conÅ¿trued fauorably for women, as the premiÅ¿es be in fauour of the Heire: And therefore as well tayled Lands as FÃ©e-Å¿imple are bound to render value and recompence; if therefore the Ioynture euicted were to the value of twenty pound per annum, and the heyre haue twenty pound per annum of Land tayled to his Father, the woman Å¿hall recouer euery whit of it in recompence of her loÅ¿t Ioynture, for this latter and new Statute controlleth the ancient Statute, de donis conditionalibus.

div.head: SECT. XXXVIII. In what caÅ¿e a Woman may refuÅ¿e her Ioynture to demand Dower.
div.p:
THe Statute is plaine, that a woman may refuÅ¿e a Ioynture made during Couerture, and take her Dower, or waiue Dower, and reÅ¿t on her Ioynture, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the Ioynture were by act of Parliament, &c. And M. Brograues opinion was, that if the Ioynture were made by other aÅ¿Å¿urance, and afterward confirmed by Parliament, that Å¿uch ratification tooke away a womans election as well as if the originall aÅ¿Å¿urance had bÃ©en by Parliament: But if the Ioynture were made before Marriage, the woman muÅ¿t nÃ©eds hold her to her Ioynture, Å¿ans election. And this is by implication vpon the third prouiÅ¿o, as appeareth by the report of AnderÅ¿on, &câª SÃ©e Commentaries Plowden, 390. The CaÅ¿e 6. Eliz. Dyer, 228. is, That Richard AÅ¿hton EÅ¿quire in accompliÅ¿hment of certaine Indentures
ã1 page duplicateã
