dentures betwixt him and Sir William Barenport, concerning Marriage to be had betwixt Richard AÅ¿hton the Å¿onne and Elizabeth the daughter of Sir William, which gaue Å¿euen hundred Markes with her in marriage, infeoffed certaine perÅ¿ons before Marriage of Land to the annuall rent of twenty pound to the vÅ¿e of the Å¿aid Elizabeth for terme of her life: The Marriage being conÅ¿ummate, firÅ¿t Richard the Father, and then Richard the Sonne died, then it was found by office that Richard the Å¿onne died Å¿eiÅ¿ed in FÃ©e if theÅ¿e Lands, whereof the Feoffement was made, and of other Lands holden by Chiualry, as of the Dutchie of La â¢
caÅ¿ter his heyre being vnder age, the firÅ¿t queÅ¿tion was whether Å¿hee might retaine the twenty pound Lands, â¢â¢ d haue Dower of the reÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e Å¿he was not Richard A â¢â¢
â¢ ons wife at the time of the Feoffement firÅ¿t made, neither was it made of the barons lands, or by the baron reÅ¿olued by Councell of the Court, that Å¿hÃ©e was barred of Dower: And it was Å¿o likewiÅ¿e reÅ¿olued in Vernons CaÅ¿e, Sir Ed. Cokes 4. Report, wherein is much learning touching Ioynture.
The Å¿econd queÅ¿tion in Eliz. AÅ¿tons ca. was whether Å¿he were Dowable from the QuÃ©ene, becauÅ¿e the feoffement was not found by the Office.

The third queÅ¿tion, whether it might be a â¢â¢ r â¢ ed for the QuÃ©ene in Å¿tay of petition of Dower, that the Feoffement was made pro iunctura, no Å¿uch matter being expreÅ¿Å¿ed neither in the dÃ©ed of Feoffement or Indenture of Co â¢â¢
â¢ ants.

The fourth queÅ¿tion, whether the Widdow Elizabeth might be receiued to auerre, and proue by CommiÅ¿Å¿i ãâ¦ã the Court of Wards, that the Feoffement was not meant for a Ioynture. Here is enough to make Women be w â¢â¢ e how they take Ioyntures before Marriage: Take ãâ¦ã
ther to admoniÅ¿h you, beware of fines after Marri â¢â¢â¢ , Ioynture was made to a Feme Couert by her Baronâª Å¿hÃ©e and her baron aliened the land by fine Å¿ur connuÅ¿ance de
droit, by the opinion of IuÅ¿tices, Wrayâª Bell, Manhoodâª and Dyer, Å¿he Å¿hall not demand Dower of the reÅ¿idue of her huÅ¿bands Land after his death; for Å¿he aliened her Ioynture before time of election was giuen her, by the Statute, quaere. But if the fine had bene Å¿ur connuÅ¿ance de droit, come ceo que le connuÅ¿eead de done le Baron tantum, this had bÃ©ene a better forme for the wife and leÅ¿Å¿e dangerous, 19. Eliz. Dyer, 358.

div.head: SECT. XXXIX. What is a Å¿ufficient refuÅ¿all or agreement of or to a Iointure made after Couerture.
div.p: See Sir Edw. Cokes 3. Rep. in Butlers and Bakers CaÅ¿e.

THe refuÅ¿ing or agreement, &c. becauÅ¿e they are peremptory, muÅ¿t not bee clouded, darke, doubtfull or implicatiue, but plaine and expreÅ¿Å¿e, a bare word or Å¿aying, by a woman, that Å¿he will refuÅ¿e her Ioynture or accept it, is not materiall, as diuers IuÅ¿tices doe hold it: But if Å¿hee come vpon the Land whereof Å¿he is Dowable, and there refuÅ¿ing her Ioynture pray the heyre to aÅ¿Å¿igne her Dower, this is Å¿uch a refuÅ¿all that the heyre by this Å¿hall be charged in damages from this time forth in a writt of Dower, and this refuÅ¿all muÅ¿t be to the heyre himÅ¿elfe, and not to a Stranger. If a Widow waiue the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of a houÅ¿e or tenement aÅ¿Å¿igned in Ioynture by her huÅ¿band, and get her to another place, this is no refuÅ¿all: But if Å¿he haue any medling with the land aÅ¿Å¿igned in Ioynture, or doe any other act amounting to aÅ¿Å¿ent or diÅ¿Å¿enting, as for example, If Å¿he bring a writt of Dower and declare vpon it, this is peremptory although Å¿he bee vnder age, Couert or not Couert of a Å¿econd HuÅ¿band; for the Law Å¿aith, that they which haue diÅ¿cretion to acquire
and get things, haue Å¿ufficient diÅ¿cretion to giue and preÅ¿erue thoÅ¿e things gotten. Therefore if an Infant cdme to any thing by purchaÅ¿e, hee Å¿hall not in that haue any aduantageâª or bee in better plight then a parÅ¿on of full age.

As where eÅ¿tate is made to an Infant of two acres, to haue and hold the one for life, the other in fÃ©e, &c. aâª Feoffement made of one whileÅ¿t he is yet vnder age is a Å¿ufficient election. And if a rent charge bee granted to an Infant, whereupon he bringeth a Writt of annuity, he Å¿hall neuer auow for it, as a vent, when he commeth to full age: So if an Infant recouer debt, and Å¿ue execution by elegit, &c. he Å¿hall neuer haue a Å¿cire facias: And an Infant is Å¿ubiect to an action of waÅ¿te or entry for condition broken as well as any other perÅ¿on, TheÅ¿e collections gathered, as I thinke, by Å¿ome well learned and induÅ¿trious Student out of M. Brograues reading, though they want of the fulneÅ¿Å¿e and perfection which the owne pen of Å¿o great a Lawyer might haue giuen themâª yet are they pertinent and important. And I not a little beholding to him, from whoÅ¿e hands I obtaine them.

div.head: SECT. XL. Of Actions brought by Baron and Feme, or by one of them.
div.p:
NOw becauÅ¿e the common Å¿ayings are found by common experience true, Qui capit vxor â¢ m, capit lites, and qui habet terras habet guerras, A Wife brings iarres, and wealth brings warres, quarrels, Å¿uits and controuerÅ¿ies at Law, Å¿ans c â¢ o, that it hath any other intendment, it will not be amiÅ¿Å¿e a little to declare how and in what manner actions at law muÅ¿t be commenced and purÅ¿ued by ba
â¢ on and Feme, or againÅ¿t them, or by or againÅ¿t one of
them according to preÅ¿cription of Law, and their Å¿euerall and ioynt IntereÅ¿ts, &c.

div.head: SECT. XLI. Where the Baron Å¿hall Å¿ue onely in his owne name.
div.p:
A Man Å¿hall Å¿ue for his Wiues Marriage money onely in his owne name, but how or where, that is a matter of Å¿ome obÅ¿curity: by Bracton, lib. 5. ca. 10. 407. money that is promiÅ¿ed cauÅ¿a Matrimonij, is as a Å¿equell of Marriage, and Å¿o being annexed to a thing Å¿pirituall, requires a Å¿pirituall Å¿uite; yet he confeÅ¿Å¿eth that it is otherwiÅ¿e for Land promiÅ¿ed or couenanted, &c. Fitzherbert in his Writ of Debt citeth 31. Ed. 3. that if a man promiÅ¿e one twenty pound to marry his Daughter, which marrieth her accordingly, he may haue a Writ of debt vpon his promiÅ¿e, but he forgets not the â¢ Ã©ere difference in the Booke of aÅ¿Å¿izes; for in the Writt of prohibition, he tels vs, if a man promiÅ¿e one twenty pounds if he marry his Daughter, after marriage if the promiÅ¿er will not pay the money, the huÅ¿band may not Å¿ue in Court ChriÅ¿tian, if hee doe a prohibition lyethâª marry if I promiÅ¿e one twenty pounds with my Daughter in Marriage, &c. nowâª vpon nonpayment, he may Å¿ue in Court ChriÅ¿tian, for this concerneth Matrimony. The Å¿ame learning he inÅ¿iÅ¿teth vpon his Writt of ConÅ¿ultation, adding that if he die which made the promiÅ¿e, the other may Å¿ue in Court ChriÅ¿tian againÅ¿t the Executor, or Executors of Executors, 22. aÅ¿Å¿. pla. 70. is thus, vpon Contract had betwixt two men, that if one of them will marry the others Daughter, hee Å¿hall haue ten pound, &c. the ten pound after Marriage muÅ¿t be demanded in the Kings Court, becauÅ¿e the promiÅ¿e was not with his Daughter in Marriage, but by Couenant,
that he Å¿hould, &c. But if he had promiÅ¿ed the money with his Daughter in Marriage, it muÅ¿t haue bÃ©ene demanded in Court ChriÅ¿tian: And if a man promiÅ¿e vpon his faith to pay ten pound, the Ordinarie cannot compell him to pay it, but he may enioyne corporall penance, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the promiÅ¿er will voluntarily redÃ©eme it: Thus teacheth IuÅ¿tice Thorpe in declaration of the Statute of circumÅ¿pecte agatis 45. Ed. 3. fo. 24. The Demandant declares vpon a couenant betwixt him and the Defendant, that if he married the Daughter of the defendant, hee Å¿hould haue an hundred pound, &c. It was moued that this demand of debt vpon a Couenant concerning Matrimony was not good, but the matter concerned the Court ChriÅ¿tian per articulos cleri, NotwithÅ¿tanding becauÅ¿e the demand was vpon a dÃ©ed, and a written dÃ©ed maketh a lay couenant, the defendant was compelled to anÅ¿wer: But 14. of Ed. 4. fo. 6. in an action of debt the Plaintiffe declares that he had married the Defendants daughter, vpon agrÃ©ement of twenty pound to be paid, &c. and all the Iudges of the common pleas (without tarrying the Defendants anÅ¿wer) awarded que le plaint priÅ¿t rieu perÅ¿on brief, for the demand is, Å¿ay they, of the Å¿ame nature with the eÅ¿pouÅ¿als, viz. ius Å¿pirituale, and determinable no where but in Court ChriÅ¿tian, and yet the Booke of aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿es was there remembred 15. Ed. 4. fo. 32. the plaintiffe in a Writt of debt demanding fiue markes declares vpon a couenant quod not â¢ , for fiue pound where he had marryed, &c. and 33. pound fiue Å¿hillings foure pence was paid, but the reÅ¿idue being 5. Marks, the defendant denyed to pay, yet I care not Å¿aith Catesoy though he be diÅ¿charged: for I know well enough that vpon Å¿uch a matter, the action lieth not at common Law, quod fui â¢ conceÅ¿Å¿um per curiamâª And the cauÅ¿e alledged was that there was not quid for quo 17. Ed. 4. fo. 5. The maÅ¿ter of the Rowles aÅ¿keth the IuÅ¿tices of the Common pleas, if a man promiÅ¿e money to another to marry his daughter or Å¿eruant, which marrieth her accordingly, whether an action
of debt will lye at the common Law or no: No Å¿aith TownÅ¿end, for it is but a nude promiÅ¿e of no more effect then if I promiÅ¿e you 20. pound to build you a new Chamber, and ex nudo pacto non oritur actio. But if I promiÅ¿e you Å¿ixe Å¿hillings euery wÃ©eke for the bording of I. S. here is quid for quo, for law intendeth here, that I haue aduantage and profit by the Å¿eruice of I. S. But further in your caÅ¿e, the thing that is to bee done is Å¿pirituall which cannot bee Å¿old, neither can the party be compelled to doe it: Rogers and Siliard were contrary to him in opinion, That a promiÅ¿e vpon Marriage is no â¢â¢ dum pactumâª becauÅ¿e the daughter couÅ¿in or friend is by intendment aduanced. And if I promiÅ¿e a Schoole-maÅ¿ter money to teach my childe, he Å¿hall haue action of Debt. LikewiÅ¿e if I promiÅ¿e a Surgeon money to heale a poore mans wound, or a Labourer money to mend a high-way. But in the end Choke & Little
â¢ on agrÃ©ed with the MaÅ¿ter of the Rowles, that in the caÅ¿e by him propounded none action lyeth at common Lawâª becauÅ¿e Matrimony whereupon the promiÅ¿e is founded is a thing Å¿pirituall, and by no manner of meanes vendable. 19. Ed. 4. fo. 10. in an action of debt, brought vpon Å¿uch a bargaine: Collow Å¿aith, it is true, a man muÅ¿t demand a woman contracted to him in the Å¿pirituall Court, but money is a temporall thing: And when a ParÅ¿on of a Church is to recouer tythes, he muÅ¿t Å¿ue in Court ChriÅ¿tianâª but if he Å¿ell his tythes, when they be Å¿euered, hee Å¿hall Å¿ue for the money in the Kings Court, but then and afterward in the Å¿ame or like caÅ¿e 20. of Ed. 4. fo. 3. Bryan aÅ¿keth him then, to what end Å¿erueth the Statute, that things touching Matrimony and TeÅ¿taments muÅ¿t be tryed in Courts ChriÅ¿tian, cui des vous quam vous purres achate les Sacraments. Sir, Å¿aith Neale, diÅ¿mes are a thing Å¿pirituall, but if a ParÅ¿on of a Church leaÅ¿e his Tythes, hee muÅ¿t Å¿ue for the rent in a temporall Court, and Collow Å¿tands to it, that per emptionem & venditionem res Å¿pirituales efficiuntur temporales, he neuer Å¿pake a truer word in his life.

Out of theÅ¿e opinions conÅ¿orting together like harpe and harrow, may be gathered this Å¿ure learning. That hee which will wed Å¿hall doe well, (and according to the Statute of circumÅ¿pecte agatis) to take as much as he can of his wiues marriage money before hand, with faire Indentures or good obligation for the reÅ¿idue. And by the aboue-Å¿aid Bookes, as alÅ¿o by M. Plowden in that caÅ¿e he may haue action of debt, for euery dÃ©ed Å¿ealed and deliuered carrieth Å¿ufficient conÅ¿ideration, to wit, the will of him that made it.

Concerning the old Å¿cruple, though money be a viÅ¿ible Å¿igne of inuiÅ¿ible grace Sacramentall and Spirituall, Å¿pecially if it be in Angels; yet I truÅ¿t it is not more Å¿pirituall then the woman her Å¿elfe with whom it is promiÅ¿ed. And as there is no queÅ¿tion made but a man may Å¿ue in Court ChriÅ¿tian for his lawfull wife vnlawfully taken and witholden, vpon which Å¿uite if a prohibition be granted, a conÅ¿ultation may be had for procÃ©edings, quatenus p â¢ r reÅ¿titutione vxoris duntaxat proÅ¿equitur, &c. So by Fitzherbert in his Writt of ConÅ¿ultation an Action may be brought at Common Law, de vxore abducta cum bonis viri, or an action of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e for taking onely of the Wife. But for a cleare proofe that in theÅ¿e promiÅ¿Å¿ions of money vpon Marriage, neither the money is any GhoÅ¿t, nor the promiÅ¿e any nudum pactum. SÃ©e the caÅ¿e 10. Eliz. Dyer, 272.

An Action of the CaÅ¿e was brought vpon promiÅ¿e of twenty pound made to the Plaintiffe in conÅ¿ideration, that at Å¿peciall InÅ¿tance and requeÅ¿t of the Defendant he had married his CouÅ¿in: this was a good cauÅ¿e of action in the Queenes Court, although the Marriage were celebrated and perfected before the aÅ¿Å¿umption, becauÅ¿e the Nuptialls did enÅ¿ue the Defendants requeÅ¿t.

And as Lands may bee giuen in Franke marriage after the EÅ¿pouÅ¿als, and yet the EÅ¿pouÅ¿als be cauÅ¿e and conÅ¿ideration
of the gift: Å¿o may money be promiÅ¿ed after EÅ¿pouÅ¿als, and yet the EÅ¿pouÅ¿als be cauÅ¿e of the promiÅ¿e.

But Reader be not confident of the Law in that CaÅ¿e of Dyer, for I haue Å¿Ã©ene a report of a CaÅ¿e betwÃ©ene Sandill Plaintiffe, and Ienny Defendant, entred in Banco Regisâª Hillar. 2. Iacobi Rotâª 571, where the Plaintiffe declared that the Defendant in conÅ¿ideration that the Plaintiffe had formerly married his Daughter at his Å¿peciall requeÅ¿t, the Defendant promiÅ¿ed the Plaintiffe to pay him euery yÃ©ere during the life of the Defendant ten pound, &c. and as my report Å¿aith, the Plaintiffe vpon non aÅ¿Å¿umpÅ¿it pleaded, had verdict and iudgement in the Kings Bench, but vpon a writ of error in Exchequer Chamber, the Iudgement was reuerÅ¿ed, for that the Marriage was executed before the promiÅ¿e made, and yet the declaration Å¿uppoÅ¿ed that the Defendant requeÅ¿ted the Plaintiffe to Marriage, &c.

But let me not run Å¿o farre from my Tert as neuer to finde the way backe againe: A man may Å¿ue for Marriage money in his owne name onely, and Å¿o is it generally where that which is in demand, or to be recouered, commeth mÃ©erely and onely to the Baron. Example, 43. Ed. 3. fo. 8. The Earle of Arundell brought a Writt of TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t one, for chaÅ¿ing in a free Chace that he held in right of his Wife, and the Writt awarded good, though the Wife were not named in it, becauÅ¿e nothing was to be recouered by damages.

LikewiÅ¿e is it if the Baron bring a Writt of TreÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e for Å¿trayes taken in Lands holden in right of his Wife. And eod. anno fo. 26. for breaking of a houÅ¿e and carrying away of timber, the HuÅ¿band alone Å¿hall haue the action becauÅ¿e hee may when hee liÅ¿t pull downe a houÅ¿e or Å¿ell timber Å¿tanding vpon his Wiues Inheritance, or make a releaÅ¿e to any body vpon Å¿uch manner of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, and the Wiues action is gone for euer.

There is alÅ¿o the Å¿ame yeare fo. 16. another CaÅ¿e, wherein becauÅ¿e a decies tantum was brought by Baron
and Feme, the Writt abated; for though the firÅ¿t action concerned the Wiues IntereÅ¿t, yet nothing is to be recoueredin a decies tantum but damages, &c. SÃ©e the Booke of 20. H. 6. fo. 1. a Writt of maintenance wherein nothing is recouerable, but damages, was brought by Baron and Feme vpon maintenance in a bill of freÅ¿h force againÅ¿t them, by the better opinion they might ioyne, &c. And the Defendant paÅ¿Å¿eth OuÅ¿ter, but not by award, 41. Ed. 3. f. 9. a Writ of Champertie brought by the Baron onely vpon an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e which had paÅ¿Å¿ed againÅ¿t him and his wife, was allowed good notwithÅ¿tanding exceptions taken of the wiues IntereÅ¿t, &c. vpon the reaÅ¿ons before expreÅ¿Å¿ed. And by Finch, if a man haue a Ward in right of his Wife, Dower Å¿hall be demanded againÅ¿t him onely, becauÅ¿e the gard is a Chattell veÅ¿ted: But if a Writt of WardÅ¿hip be to be brought, it Å¿hall be againÅ¿t the Baron and feme, &c. becauÅ¿e of voucher.

And in treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, if the Plaintiffe recouer againÅ¿t Baron and Feme by falÅ¿e verdict, they both muÅ¿t wyne in the attaintâª for that muÅ¿t be according to the record 46. Ed. 3. fo. 20. a man brought a Writt of rauiÅ¿hment de gard, declaring vpon a poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, iure vxoris, and the Writ held good: yet in this caÅ¿e there is more then damages to be recouered, for the Plaintiffe Å¿hall haue the Infant reÅ¿tored by the very words of his Writt. But there againe it was agrÃ©ed, that an action to recouer a Ward muÅ¿t be againÅ¿t them both, becauÅ¿e of voucher, though in a writt of Dower it be vt Å¿upra, becauÅ¿e therein there is no voucher, &c. If Baron and Feme Å¿ell the Wiues Inheritance by fine for twenty pound, an action of debt for the money Å¿hall bee brought by the Baron onely, for the grant was onely the Barons grant, and if he die, the Executors Å¿hall haue the action and not the Feme. 48. Ed. 3. fo. 18.

And a reple â¢â¢ n muÅ¿t bee brought by the Baron onely, becauÅ¿e a Feme Couert cannot haue a propertie in any goods or Chattels: But for Å¿uch goods as the Wife hath
as Executrix, it Å¿Ã©emeth the Baron and Feme may ioyne in ar pleuen: Å¿o Å¿hall they for goods of the Wife taken dum Å¿ola fuit, Fitz. in the title reception. In treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e at Common Law, or vpon the Statute, Anno 5. Rich. 2. the Baron alone Å¿hall haue action of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e for taking away Charters, concerning the Wiues inheritance. So is it if he alone deliuer Å¿uch Charters, he alone may haue action againÅ¿t the Bayliffe, &c.

But a Writt of Detinue of Charters of the Wiues inheritance muÅ¿t be Å¿ued by both, &c. becauÅ¿e the Charters themÅ¿elues are to be recouered. And therefore vpon recouery of them the Baron and Feme muÅ¿t ioyne for recouery. A quare impedit was brought 50. of Ed. 3. fo. 13. and the Baron declared of an agrÃ©ement betwixt thrÃ©e SiÅ¿ters to preÅ¿ent by turne to a Church, whereof they had the AduouÅ¿an, and this was the turne of his Wife, &c. The Defendant demands Iudgement of the Writt, becauÅ¿e the Wife being Å¿till aliue was not named, but this Writt alÅ¿o was awarded good, becauÅ¿e nothing was to be recouered here but onely the PreÅ¿entment and not the AduouÅ¿an. And if a Writt Å¿hould be awarded to the BiÅ¿hop againÅ¿t the Baron, the Wife thereby Å¿hould not be out of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, becauÅ¿e Å¿he is not partie to the Iudgementâª beÅ¿ides that, Å¿he is ayded by WeÅ¿t. 2. cap. 3. And for a generall rule where the HuÅ¿bands releaÅ¿e is good, the action may be brought in his name onely, as vpon cutting of trÃ©es, graÅ¿Å¿e, Corne, &c. And Å¿uch actions may be brought in the name both of the HuÅ¿band and the Wife. An aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e of â¢ arraigne preÅ¿entment is a mixt action, and the AduouÅ¿an it Å¿elfe, Å¿hall be recouered in it, therefore of neceÅ¿Å¿ity it muÅ¿t be brought both by Baron and Feme 15. Ed. 4. fo. 9. The Baron Seignior in right of his wife, ioyned in a writt of reÅ¿cous, and it was argued that he alone ought to haue brought the writt: But it was awarded well brought by them both. Though per Littleton it were good enough in noÅ¿me le Baron tantum. And per Pigot, when an obligation is made to Baron and
Feme, the Baron alone may haue the action, or they may ioyne â¢ adem lex in treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, &c. maintenance, &c. for alwayesâª where the action may Å¿uruiue to the wife, the wife may ioyne in the writt: They which Å¿hall read theÅ¿e two laÅ¿t CaÅ¿es argued 50. Ed. 3. and 15. Ed. 4âª in the yeares at large, Å¿hall not nÃ©ed to repent it.

div.head: SECT. XLII. When a Wife may Å¿ue or be Å¿ued alone.
div.p: IT is Å¿eldome, almoÅ¿t neuer that a marryed woman can haue any action to vÅ¿e her writt onely in her owne name: her huÅ¿band is her Å¿terne, her primus motor, without whom the cannot doe much at home, and leÅ¿Å¿e abroad: But if her HuuÅ¿band commit felonie, take the Church and abiure the Realme, Å¿he is now in caÅ¿e as a Widdow inabled to make alienation of her owne land as a Feme Å¿ole, or to bring a cui in vita for her Lands aliened by her huÅ¿band, quod vide cui in vitaâª Fitz. 3. LikewiÅ¿e 1. H. 4. fo. 1. The Kings writt of Ward againÅ¿t Sybill Belknap, is awarded good, though it were brought by the King; but iudgement was aÅ¿ked of it, becauÅ¿e Sybill was a Feme Couert, iour del briefe purchaÅ¿e, and the huÅ¿band not named; whereunto was anÅ¿wered, that for offence againÅ¿t the King and his PÃ©eres, Belknap was baniÅ¿hed to GaÅ¿coigne, there to remaine till he obtained the Kings Grace, &c. IuÅ¿tice GaÅ¿coigne by the aÅ¿Å¿ent of his fellowes, commands the Defendants to anÅ¿wer, and Å¿he pleads in barre. Againe 2. H. 4. fo. 7. all the IuÅ¿tices teÅ¿tifie, that the wife of Sir Robert Belknap who was baniÅ¿hed, Å¿ued a writt alone without naming her huÅ¿band, and by their common award it was holden good, for that as Å¿ome Å¿aid, the Å¿aid Sibyl was the Kings Fer â¢ er.

But howÅ¿oeuer it were, Markham exclaimes Ecce modo mirum quod foemina fert breue regis, Non nominando virum coniunctum robore legis. Some Å¿ay it Å¿hould be conuictum, &c. It is like a miracle that a wife Å¿hould commence any Å¿uit without her huÅ¿band, 18. Ed. 4. fo. 4. If a feme Couert be impleaded without her huÅ¿band and outlawed, the baron and feme may ioyne in a writt of error to reuerÅ¿e the outlary, for the wife cannot Å¿ue without the HuÅ¿band. If a fine be leuied to a feme Couert, yet Å¿he and her huÅ¿band muÅ¿t ioyne in the quid juris clamat, as the book of 11. H. 4. 7. teÅ¿tifieth: If Baron and Feme be beaten, &c. they muÅ¿t Ioyne in action for battery of the Feme, but for his owne Å¿tripes the Baron Å¿hall bring his owne action by himÅ¿elfe, or elÅ¿e his writt abates for that part, 9. Ed. 4. fo. 52. BecauÅ¿e a feme Couert hath nothing to doe to participate in the Å¿uites of her huÅ¿band, nor in the priuiledges of her huÅ¿band: Therefore a Å¿uite againÅ¿t the Wife of an atturney Å¿hall not be in the Court where hee Å¿erueth by bill, but by originall writt, and none eÅ¿Å¿oine de Å¿eruitio Regisâª or other eÅ¿Å¿oine caÅ¿t for the HuÅ¿band, Å¿hall Å¿erue for the wife, for if in a praecipe quod reddat againÅ¿t baron & feme at the grand Cape the Baron be eÅ¿Å¿oyned de Å¿eruitio regis, and the wife make default, Å¿hee Å¿hall loÅ¿e her Land. So likewiÅ¿e if the Baron be a Å¿eruant of the Chancellor, &c. no writt of priuiledge Å¿hall Å¿erue for him and his wife, but actions againÅ¿t them both muÅ¿t be Å¿ued at the Common Law; But a protection caÅ¿t by the Baron, diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿eth the plea Å¿ans iour for both, becauÅ¿e the Feme cannot anÅ¿wer without her huÅ¿band, 35. H. 6. f. 3 & 4. a feme couert Å¿hal not be receiued to diÅ¿auow the atturney of her huÅ¿band, but he Å¿hal make an atturney for them both 33. H. 6. f. 31. And cod. â¢ n. fo. 43. If the wife will come into the Court & offer to plead any other plea then that which her huÅ¿band hath pleaded, or to confeÅ¿Å¿e the actionâª Å¿he Å¿hal not be receiued to it, but the huÅ¿band may not forcher per eÅ¿Å¿oin. And if baron & feme wage the law, &c. If the wife appeare not at the day giuen, the baron Å¿hall be condemned: But a wife Å¿hal neuer be receiued to diÅ¿auow the
Å¿uite of her huÅ¿band and her Å¿elfe, quod vide 39. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿arum pla. 1. a good CaÅ¿e.

div.head: SECT. XLIII. Of Felonies.
div.p: IN matters criminall and capitall cauÅ¿es, a Feme couert Å¿hall anÅ¿were without her huÅ¿band, 15. Ed. 4. foâª 1. And note, if a Feme Couert Å¿teale any thing by coherÅ¿ion of her HuÅ¿band, this is not felonie in her 27. lib. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿arum 40. It was found that a woman had Å¿tollen bread to the worth of two Å¿hillings by compulÅ¿ion of her huÅ¿band, and awarded that Å¿he Å¿hould goe quite. It Å¿eemeth to be all one if a woman Å¿teale by commandement of her huÅ¿band, quaere.

If a man and his wife commit felonie ioyntly, it Å¿Ã©emeth the wife is no felon, but it Å¿hall be wholly iudged the HuÅ¿bands fact, Å¿aith Stamford: Seuen men and a woman were arraigned of felonie, found guilty, and becauÅ¿e th â¢ woman cryed out Å¿he was wife to one of the Å¿euen, the Iudges Å¿ent to the BiÅ¿hop to be certified of the Marriage. But a woman by her Å¿elfe without the priuitie of her huÅ¿band may commit felonie to become either principall or acceÅ¿Å¿ary: As if Å¿hee Å¿teale goods, or receiue thÃ©eues to her houÅ¿e, &c. and if the huÅ¿band Å¿o Å¿oone as hee perceiue it waiue and forÅ¿ake their company, and his owne houÅ¿e, in this caÅ¿e the Womans offence makes not felonie in the baron. But if the baron commit felonie, his wife not ignorant of it may kÃ©epe his company Å¿till notwithÅ¿tanding, and not be deemed acceÅ¿Å¿ary; for a woman cannot bee acceÅ¿Å¿ary to her huÅ¿band, inÅ¿omuch as Å¿hee is forbidden by the Law of God to bewray him: note alÅ¿o that a woman cannot be thiefe of her huÅ¿bands goods, if Å¿hee take and giue them away, the receiuer is no felon, Stanford. lib. 1. cap. 19. Briton allowes that the wife Å¿hall keep her huÅ¿bands counÅ¿ell,
but yet Å¿o that if Å¿he acquit her Å¿elfe per pais del fait & conÅ¿ent, for felons wiues hee Å¿aith haue often held men whiles the huÅ¿band killed them, and in that caÅ¿e it is reaÅ¿on and Law that they hang together, fo. 47. By Bractonâª non debet virum accuÅ¿are vxor, nec de â¢ egere â¢ ur â¢ um Å¿uum neque feloniam, con â¢ en â¢ ire tamen non debet, nec co â¢ diutrix eÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿ed feloniam & nequi â¢ iam viri quantum poteÅ¿t impedire. And by him if goods Å¿tollen be found Å¿ub cla â¢ ibus vxoris, Å¿he Å¿hal be culpable with her huÅ¿band of his felonie. Item, Å¿i vxor cum viro coniuncta fuerit, vel confeÅ¿Å¿a fuerit quod viro conÅ¿ilium vel auxilium praeÅ¿titerit, â¢â¢ n â¢ bun â¢â¢â¢ ambo, nam licet obedire debeat vxor viro in a â¢â¢ ocioribu â¢ tamen, & la â¢â¢ o â¢ inijs, nec eÅ¿t ei obediendum. Poterit vir ligare & tenere, atque vxor Å¿ponte & non coacta occidere, & ita â¢ ene â¢ ur de maleficio vterque: libro 3. ca. 32. In the end he Å¿heweth how execution of iudgement Å¿hall bee deferred when the woman condemned is with child, Å¿iue ante delictum conceperi â¢ , Å¿iue poÅ¿t. Hee coteth ciuill Law for it. But Stanford hath it perfecter.

If a woman bee arraigned of felonie, it is no plea to Å¿ay Å¿he is with child, but Å¿he muÅ¿t plead to the felonie, and if Å¿he bee found guilty, Å¿hee may then claime the benefit of her wombe, wherevpon the MarÅ¿hall or Vicount Å¿hall bee commanded to put her in a chamber, and cauÅ¿e Å¿ome women to examine and try her, whether Å¿he be enÅ¿oint de vn infant, which if Å¿he be not, Å¿he Å¿hall be hanged maintenant: And though Å¿he be quicke with child, yet Iudgement Å¿hall not be delayed, but onely execution deferred. If after Å¿uch reÅ¿pite when Å¿he is once deliuered, Å¿he become great againe, and obiect to prolong her life, the Iudge ought to command execution preÅ¿ently, for this benefit Å¿hall bee claimed but once, If the Iudge inquire further of it, it muÅ¿t be but to Å¿et a fine on the MarÅ¿hall or Sheriffe for looking no better to her. Stanford, lib. 3. ca. vl â¢ imo. And by the bookes which he citeth the obiection muÅ¿t be not priuiment enÅ¿oint, but en
â¢â¢ int de viue enfant.

div.head: SECT. XLIV. Of TreaÅ¿ons.
div.p:
ANd this obiection of enÅ¿eintment is aÅ¿well to delay execution for treaÅ¿on as for felony. A woman for committing either grand or petty treaÅ¿on Å¿hall be burned. The latter part of the Statute 25. of Ed. 3. ca. 2 is, That if any Å¿eruant kill his MaÅ¿ter, any woman kill her huÅ¿band, or any man Å¿ecular or religious perÅ¿on kill his Prelate to whom he owes obedience, this is treaÅ¿on, and euery Lord Å¿hall haue the EÅ¿cheates for Å¿uch treaÅ¿ons of his owne proper fÃ©e, the Statute is but declaration of the common law titulo Coronae, in Fitzh. A woman compaÅ¿Å¿eth with her Adulterer the death of her huÅ¿band, they aÅ¿Å¿ailed him riding on the high way, beating, wounding, leauing him for dead, and then they fled: The huÅ¿band got vp, leuied hue and cry, came before the IuÅ¿tices, they Å¿ent after the offendors, which were gotten, arraigned, and the matter found by verdict, the adulterer was hanged, the woman burned to death, the huÅ¿band liuing, voluntas reputabitur per facto, 15. E. 2. A woman Å¿eruant conÅ¿pired to rob her MiÅ¿tris, and brought a Å¿tranger to the bed-Å¿ide where the MiÅ¿tris lay aÅ¿leepe, the Å¿tranger killed her, the Å¿eruant Å¿ilent nothing doing but holding the Candle, the two chiefe IuÅ¿tices and H â¢ re thought the Å¿eruant a TraytreÅ¿Å¿e, and a principall, 2. & 3. Eliz. Dyer, 128. yet MiÅ¿tris is not verbatim in the Statute, Stanford was one of them againÅ¿t the chiefe IuÅ¿tices opinion in this caÅ¿e; yet in his owne booke he teacheth that abettors & procurers, are within the meaning and intent of the Law: The Å¿eruant and the wife conÅ¿pire the huÅ¿bands death, he is killed by the Å¿eruant, in abÅ¿ence of the wife, this is petty treaÅ¿on in them both, by opinion of diuers IuÅ¿tices, otherwiÅ¿e it is if the murtherer be no Å¿eruant, Dyer 16. Eliz 332. for Saunders wife which
procured Browne to kill her huÅ¿band, but barely hanged as acceÅ¿Å¿arie, becauÅ¿e the principall was but a murtherer. 8. Eliz. Dyer 254.

div.head: SECT. XLV. Actions by Baron and Feme together.
div.p:
THe baron and feme may ioyne in a writ of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, quare vi & armis clauÅ¿uÌ fregit, &c. for treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e done in the wiues land, either before couerture, or during couerture. SÃ©e 21. H. 6. fol. 30. Å¿uch a Writ brought of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e in the CloÅ¿e of Baron and Feme, and fÃ©eding vp blada Å¿ua. Iudgement is aÅ¿ked of the Writ, becauÅ¿e a Feme couert hath no propertie in goods and chattels during the couerture. The Declaration, Å¿aith Markham, is blada Å¿ua dum Å¿ola fuit depaÅ¿tus fuit. That, Å¿aith Newton, is not poÅ¿Å¿ible, but it ought to be blada ipÅ¿ius Katherinae, &c. Yeluerton Å¿aith, that both the Writ and Declaration ought to haue bÃ©ene Dum Å¿ola fuit, which Newton denies, and Å¿aith, that the Count ought only to be Å¿o, and affirmeth, that as the matter is brought forth, there is an intendment of depaÅ¿turing before couerture, and of breaking the CloÅ¿e after couerture, of which the Baron and Feme may haue a Writ ClauÅ¿um Å¿uum fregit, &c. So the Action Å¿eemeth to be by two Å¿euerall titles: But in the end the record was viewed, which was Quod clauÅ¿um ipÅ¿ius Katherinae fregit & blada eiuÅ¿dem Katherinae depaÅ¿tus fuit; and the Declaration Dum Å¿ola fuit, which made the Writ to be awarded good. And there it is Å¿aid, that by the RegiÅ¿ter the Writ is not Dum Å¿ola fuit but generall, and the Declaration Å¿peciall. Yet 7. H. 7. fol. 2. vpon the like Writ of Quare clauÅ¿um fregit & bon â¢ & catella Å¿ua cepit, which Declaration of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e to the Feme Dum Å¿ola fuit, iudgement being giuen, was afterwards found erroneous, for fault in the Writ which Å¿hould haue
bÃ©ene not bona Å¿ua, but bona ipÅ¿ius le Feme, and therefore a Repleader awarded. The baron & feme may haue a Writ of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e of aÅ¿Å¿ault made to the Feme, and impriÅ¿onment of her, vntill the Baron compounded and paid a fine, and the briefe and count Å¿hall be ad damna ipÅ¿orum quod nota. 46. Ed. â¢ . 3. Nota per Cu â¢ iam, Å¿aith Brooke, Baron and Feme may ioyne in appeale De â¢â¢ pe le feme, for the huÅ¿band alone cannot haue it without his wife, 8. H. 4. fol. 21 The caÅ¿e there is, A woman priÅ¿oner in the MarÅ¿halÅ¿ey, makes a Å¿uggeÅ¿tion to the Court, that the MarÅ¿hals man had rauiÅ¿hed her in priÅ¿on: G â¢ Å¿coigne commanded the MarÅ¿hall to take his man to his cuÅ¿tody, and his Å¿taffe from him, and the Court told the woman, that Å¿he alone could not bring appeale, Å¿ans Å¿on Baron, but if her huÅ¿band would come, and they two together would proue the rape, the rauiÅ¿her Å¿hould be hanged. By this caÅ¿e it is plaine, that the wife alone cannot haue the appeale, but the Baron and Feme may haue it. But neither by this caÅ¿e, or any other Å¿tatute, can I finde that the baron may not haue it alone, Whether ne vnque a couple in loyall matrimony be a Å¿ufficient plea in this appeale, and whether he which is but Baron in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion only, that is, that huÅ¿band which is at the time of the rape may haue it, quaere, and Å¿ee 11. H. 4. 13. Baron and Feme may ioyne in a Writ of Debt, and 16. Edw 4. fol. 8. Å¿uch a Writ brought for arrerages of account, with Declaration that the defendant was the wiues receiuer, Dum Å¿ola fuit puraccount render, and that the Baron and Feme after eÅ¿pouÅ¿als, aÅ¿Å¿igned Auditors, which found the defendant in arrerages, &c. InÅ¿omuch as the ground of the Action begun by the wiÅ¿e, and the aÅ¿Å¿ignment of the Auditors was purÅ¿uing. And likewiÅ¿e by the wife they might ioyne. So if an Obligation be made to Baron & Feme, they may ioyne in a Writ of Debt, and if the Baron die, his wife and not the Executors Å¿hall haue the Action, 3. H. 6. fol. 37. Per curiam Baron and Feme may ioyne in a Writ of Debt vpon an Obligation made to them during
couerture. And Babington affirmes that the Baron may haue the Action alone if he will, 43. Ed. 3. fol. 10. Å¿uch a Writ was brought, and exception taken that it ought to haue been by the huÅ¿band alone, Å¿ed non allocatur, Though for chattels veÅ¿ted, as goods that are giuen to a man and his wife, the Baron alone muÅ¿t purÅ¿ue his Action for taking them out of his poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion: OtherwiÅ¿e it is of matters conÅ¿iÅ¿ting onely in Action, &c. for they Å¿uruiue to the Feme, like to a LeaÅ¿e granted to Baron and Feme for yeares. So is it of rauiÅ¿hment, or eiectment of Guard, for theÅ¿e are Chattles reall: But if a man and his wife be bound by Obligation, a Writ againÅ¿t them both vpon that Obligation Å¿hall abate car fait del Feme couert eÅ¿t void. See 15 Ed. 4 fol. 10. that if an Obligation bee made to Baron and Feme, and the huÅ¿band dieth, the wife or huÅ¿bands Executor, which of them Å¿hall hap to haue the Obligation Å¿hall Å¿ue, &c. as it is Å¿aid by Bryan. And Detinue of Charters Å¿hall bee brought by Baron and Feme for Charters concerning her ioynt poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, 38. H. 6. fol. 25.

If Baron and Feme make a LeaÅ¿e for yeares of the wiues lands, they muÅ¿t ioyne in an action of waÅ¿te, or elÅ¿e the Writ Å¿hall abate, 7. H. 4. 15. yet 3. H. 6. fol. 53. a Writ of waÅ¿te Å¿o brought was doubted of, becauÅ¿e forÅ¿ooth a Feme couert cannot make any LeaÅ¿e: But at the laÅ¿t the Writ was holden good, for the wife might accept the rent, or diÅ¿traine for it, and make auowrie after the huÅ¿bands death, at what time, and not before, Å¿hee hath power to agree, or diÅ¿agree; but during the Couerture, the leaÅ¿e was the Act of them both, baron & feme tenants for yeares, may ioyne in an Action of couenant, againÅ¿t the LeÅ¿Å¿or that outeth them, for the wife Å¿uruiuing Å¿hall haue the terme, if the huÅ¿band doe not aliene, 47. of Ed. 3. fol. 12. And where a remainder is to bee executed to a Feme couert by force and conueyance of a fine, &c. the Baron and Feme may haue a Scire facias, to Å¿hew why the land Å¿hould not remaine to I. S. and to N. his wife,
for the land cannot remaine to one of them, but it muÅ¿t remaine to them both: But a Formidon in DiÅ¿cender, or Reuerter. or a Writ of EÅ¿cheat differeth, 11. H. 4. fol. 15. 44. Ed. â¢ . fol. 10. a Writ of Dower was brought by Baron and feme, and the tenant pleaded, that the former baron had neuer any thing in the land during the eÅ¿pouÅ¿als, which the Demandants did not deny, therefore the Tenant prayed they might be barred, and their confeÅ¿Å¿ion recorded, but it would not be granted, becauÅ¿e it Å¿hould bee preiudiciall to the wife, yet at the requeÅ¿t of the Tenant they were receiued to acknowledge their right by fine, and the woman was examined. Quod nota, for Å¿he Å¿hall not be examined vpon confeÅ¿Å¿ion of an Action.

div.head: SECT. XLVI. Actions againÅ¿t Baron and Feme.
div.p:
AS Actions are rightly pu â¢ Å¿ued by Baron and Feme when right is withholden from her, or wrong done to her Å¿elfe, her intereÅ¿t or poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, Å¿o when the wife is, or is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed a wrong doer, or her huÅ¿band doth wrong vnder pretext of her intereÅ¿t, writs muÅ¿t be Å¿ued againÅ¿t them both; for as it hath bÃ©ene Å¿hewed already, if a Feme couert bee condemned in any ciuill Action without her huÅ¿band, Å¿he and her huÅ¿band may haue a Writ of error. Therefore if a woman which is indebted take a huÅ¿band, an Action of Debt Å¿hall be againÅ¿t her and her huÅ¿band in the Debent, 9. E. 4. fol. 24. 7. H. 7. fol. 2. agrÃ©eth, and if any thing were owing to the Feme before marriage, the Writ of Å¿uch a debt Å¿hall bee Quas â¢ is debet. If a man baile goods to a Feme Å¿ole which marrieth afterward, an Action of Detinue Å¿hall be againÅ¿t her and her huÅ¿band for theÅ¿e goods per curiam, 39. Ed. 3. 17. And 1. H. 4. fol. 31. a Writ of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ur le caÅ¿e, was brought for not repairing certaine bankes, vpon lands which the defendant
had in Dale, by reaÅ¿on wherof the plaintiffes ground was Å¿urrounded, and becauÅ¿e the Defendants whole intereÅ¿t in Dale was only jure vxoris, which wife was not named in the Writ, it abated, for they ought to haue bÃ©en ioyned. 3. H. 4. fol. 1. Upon a LeaÅ¿e made to Baron and Feme for yeares, rendring rent, the LeÅ¿Å¿or brings a Writ of Debt, &c. againÅ¿t Baron and Feme, and Iudgement was aÅ¿ked of the Writ, becauÅ¿e it was not brought againÅ¿t the Baron onely: Thi â¢â¢ ing holdeth the Writ good, aÅ¿well as an Action of waÅ¿te Å¿hall bee againÅ¿t both Baron & Feme vpon Å¿uch a Leafe, and Å¿o doth one other IuÅ¿tice, but Å¿ome pleaders argued contra. And in Actions againÅ¿t Baron and Feme, the woman muÅ¿t be named wife, 42. Edw. 3. fol. 23. A writ of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e is brought againÅ¿t Iohn and Alice with others, Alice Å¿aith Å¿hee was and is the wife of Iohn, iour del briefe purchaÅ¿e iudgement del briefe, and this is a good plea in abatement of the writ. So if a writ be againÅ¿t Iohn and Alice his wife, Alice if Å¿hÃ©e be Å¿ingle may plead, not the wife, Iudgement del briefe. But Iohn Å¿hall not haue that plea per totam curiam, for none as Brooke maketh the reaÅ¿on; Å¿hall plead MiÅ¿noÅ¿mer, but the partie, 7. H. 6. fol. 9. In AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e againÅ¿t Baron and Feme the Uicount returned, that hee had attached the Baron per centum ones matrices, but the wife had nothing to be attached of, within his B â¢â¢ liwicke, he â¢ e â¢â¢ in eÃ¡dem inuenta, the beÅ¿t opinion is, that the returne is not good, for he was commanded to attach the wife, which the Law would neuer command if the thing were impoÅ¿Å¿ible, but it is poÅ¿Å¿ible enough for the wife to be attached, by her huÅ¿bands goods, and by him Å¿hee muÅ¿t bee brought into the Court. Babington Å¿aith, an Attachment muÅ¿t bee by a meere chattle, which Å¿hall be forfeited by Default, but not by any Chattell reall, as a LeaÅ¿e for yeares, or a ward, or by appartell, &c.

Now note, it hath bÃ©ene Å¿aid, that in an Action of debt or treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, or other perÅ¿onall Actions, if the Baron appeare, and the wife make default, or if the wife appeare,
and the baron make default, they Å¿hall not anÅ¿wer the one without the other, 44. Ed. 3. fol. 1. A writ of debt was brought againÅ¿t Baron and Feme, the wife outlawed, the Baron rendred himÅ¿elfe at the Exigent, at returne whereof hee appeared in ward, and the Plaintiffe prayed becauÅ¿e the ProceÅ¿Å¿e was determined againÅ¿t the wife, that the huÅ¿band might anÅ¿wer Å¿ed non alocatur. But Å¿Ã©e in the next leaÅ¿e a writ of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e purÅ¿ued againÅ¿t Baron and Feme to the Exigent, the Uicount returned that hee had taken them at the day, the Baron came inward without the wife, &c. The Plaintiffe declared againÅ¿t him, he was compelled to anÅ¿wer, and pleaded not culpable le Vicont fuit charge de le corps le Feme. & amerc â¢ e, and a writ went out to haue the wife at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter at a certaine day, with a Venire facias betwixt the Plaintiffe and the huÅ¿band, returnable the Å¿ame day, Å¿Ã©e 34. H. 6. fol. 29. A writ of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t Baron and Feme, and the Baron as Å¿eruant to the Chancellor brought a Super
â¢ edeas for himÅ¿elfe and his wife. Littleton Å¿aid it was to be allowed for neither of them, no more than where treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e is brought againÅ¿t one of the Chancery; and another man, &c. Nay not Å¿o much, Å¿aith PriÅ¿ot, for in that caÅ¿e the Plaintiffe may take his bill in Chancery againÅ¿t him which is of the Chancery, and leaue out the other, hut hee cannot doe Å¿o here, Å¿pecially the treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e being Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be done by the wife. The priuilege being diÅ¿Å¿olued, Littleton praieth that the Defendant may anÅ¿wer: Nay, Å¿aith Billing the wife neuer yet appeared, therefore take your ProceÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t her, and we wil pray an Idem dies for the huÅ¿band. In an Action of Debt, Å¿aith Littleton, againÅ¿t Baron and Feme, it is true that one Å¿hall not anÅ¿wer without the other, and in treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e alÅ¿o the wife Å¿hall not anÅ¿wer without her huÅ¿band, but the huÅ¿band may anÅ¿wer without the wife, if Å¿he make Default. Truth, Å¿aith PriÅ¿ot, all is one, in euerie writ of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e, whether it be of â¢ attery, or otherwiÅ¿e, and in euerie other perÅ¿onall Action one of them Å¿hall not plead without the other. But in a
Praecipe quod reddat the default of a wife is the default of the huÅ¿band and wife, aliter in treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e or debt againÅ¿t baron and feme, for there if the baron appeare by cepi corpus or exigent, and the wife makes default, the baron Å¿hall haue an idem dies ê mainepriÅ¿e, and if the wife waiu â¢ be, the huÅ¿band Å¿hall goe Å¿ine die, for in euery caÅ¿e where the wife is party to the writ it muÅ¿t be intended prima facie, that the cauÅ¿e of action beginneth from the wife. Bryan a Protonotaries Clarke Å¿aid it had bÃ©ene holden by the Court before this time, that if the baron came in gratis, he Å¿hould anÅ¿wer Å¿ans Å¿a feme, but if he come by coherÅ¿ion, &c. then vt Å¿upra. But Å¿aith PriÅ¿or all is one, and there is no diuerÅ¿ity, to whom all the IuÅ¿tices, and many Serieants agrÃ©ed, qÌ il ne reÅ¿pondra vnques Å¿ans Å¿a feme en nul caÅ¿e: yet afterward 36. H. 6. fo. 1. in an action againÅ¿t baron and feme vpon the Statute
â¢ . Hen. 6. of forcible entries, the Sheriffe returned the plur' capias mandaui balliuis, &c. which anÅ¿wered they had taken their bodies, etc. the Bailiffes were demanded to bring in their priÅ¿oners, the Baron appeared, and Å¿he wife made default. It is a doubt whether the huÅ¿band Å¿hould anÅ¿wer maintenant, and a writ goe out to the Sheriffe ad habendum corpus vxoris, or whether the baron Å¿hould haue an idem dies with the wife, and goe in the meane Å¿eaÅ¿on Å¿ans mainepriÅ¿e, for by Wangford he might not anÅ¿wer without his wife, becauÅ¿e of the impriÅ¿onment, &c. PriÅ¿or here aÅ¿ked, what was the Å¿uppoÅ¿all of the writ? and when he vnderÅ¿tood it was of an entry by baron and feme ioyntly, hee affirmed the baron Å¿hould anÅ¿wer preÅ¿ently without the wife. And Å¿o Å¿aid he in treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e & battery, when it is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed by the writ that baron and feme together did beat the Plaintiffe, the baron appearing, fans le feme, Å¿hall anÅ¿wer, otherwiÅ¿e Å¿hould it be here if the writ had Å¿uppoÅ¿ed the forcible entry dum Å¿ola fuit, for it were vnreaÅ¿onable when the action riÅ¿eth and is cauÅ¿ed from the wife, that then her default Å¿hould bee her huÅ¿bands default. And likewiÅ¿e is it in action of debt if the wife bee waiue, the baron appearing
at the exigent, Å¿hall goe Å¿ans mainepriÅ¿e, for it cannot be intended, but that the action riÅ¿eth onely from the wife. But if an action of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e done by baron and feme ioyntly, the baron appeare at the exigent, and the wife be waiue, the huÅ¿band Å¿hall anÅ¿wer, and if the iÅ¿Å¿ue bee found againÅ¿t him, and afterwardâª the wifeâª Å¿ue her Charter of pardon, it Å¿hall not bÃ©e allowed, vnleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hÃ©e bring her huÅ¿band with her. div.head: SECT. XLVII. Of Fourching.
div.p:
THis interchange or Å¿hifting of appearance and default by Baron and Feme is called Å¿ourching or fourcher: The terme being of no greater linage than from a hay forke or pitchforke, which in french is fourth: The Logicians call their dilemma a forke: And our Ancients haue giuen a like name to a Å¿ubtill kinde of delay which parceners, ioyntenants, and married couples had at the common Law when Å¿uits were commenced againÅ¿t them called forcherâª for euen as a cunning fighting bull when he is bayted, offering to the dog firÅ¿t one horne, and then another, might be Å¿aid to forth, Å¿o theÅ¿e conioyned aduerÅ¿aries were wont to play with both tynes, when firÅ¿t one Å¿hould appeare, and his fellow be â¢ Å¿Å¿oyned, and at the next
day of appearance he Å¿hould make default, which formerly appeared and be eÅ¿Å¿oyned by him which firÅ¿t made default. AgainÅ¿t this WeÅ¿t. 1. ca. 42. complaining that demandants were greatly delayed by ãâ¦ã , which might not anÅ¿wer but together and by ioyntenants which knew not their owne Å¿euerall, that vÅ¿ed to four â¢ h by â¢ Å¿Å¿oine, till euery one were once eÅ¿Å¿oinedâª Ordeineth that Å¿uch tenants henceforth Å¿hall bÃ©e allowed no eÅ¿Å¿oine more than at one day, and as one perÅ¿on. The Statute of GlouceÅ¿ter made 6. eiuÅ¿ â¢ em. Regis ãâ¦ã

In the booke 12. Hâª 4. fo. 1. Culpeppe â¢
affirmeth, that fourcher which was at the common Law in a writ of debt is not to be re ãâ¦ã died by this Statute of ãâ¦ã . And Thi ãâ¦ã confeÅ¿Å¿eth, that the Statute i ãâ¦ã l â¢â¢ dâª

div.head: SECT. XLIX. Outlarie of Baron and Feme or of one of them.
div.p: 44. Ed. â¢ . fo. 3. The Baron and Feme being outlawed in an action of debt, got each of them a Å¿euerall Charter of pardon, Å¿ued Å¿cire facias againÅ¿t the Plaintiffe, and found mainepriÅ¿e ioyntly, the ViÅ¿count returned that the Å¿cire facias came tardy, at which returne the Baron appeared without his wife, and praying to haue Å¿cire facias Å¿icut alias vpon the firÅ¿t mainepriÅ¿e, or a new Å¿cire facias by new mainepriÅ¿e, neither of them might be allowed without his wife, yet it was agrÃ©ed that if two men were outlawed, one might Å¿ue pardon and Å¿cire facies without the other, for in that caÅ¿e, the one may plead alone vpon the firÅ¿t originall without his fellow, againÅ¿t whom the proceÅ¿Å¿e is determined: but the Baron cannot plead here without his wife, Å¿Ã©e the booke 11. H. 4. fo. 89. Baron and Feme being outlawed, the wife appeared and brought a Charter of pardon, Å¿hee was Å¿uffered to goe at large, but the pardon might not bee allowed becauÅ¿e the baron appeared not, and the wife could not plead without him.

14. â¢ . 6. fo. 14. Iune Å¿aid that one kinde of diuorce betwixt baron and feme is, when an action of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e is brought againÅ¿t them, and the baron only appearing, proceÅ¿Å¿e goes out againÅ¿t the wife till Å¿he be waiue, &c. Shee can neuer purchaÅ¿e her pardon, vnleÅ¿Å¿e her huÅ¿band appeare, Å¿o that if he will he is diuorced. The like Å¿ubtilty hath M. Littleton 13. Ed. 4. fo. 4. where he affirmes, that if a woman be outlawed by erronious proceÅ¿Å¿e, if the huÅ¿band will not bring a writ of error, hee may Å¿o be rid of a Å¿hrew; for that counteruailes a diuorce.

11. H. 4. Sheweth that a woman may be Å¿uffered to goe at large, though her pardon bÃ©e not allowed till her huÅ¿band appeare with her, &c. And Å¿Ã©e Dyer 10. Eliz. 271. In debt againÅ¿t baron and feme, proceÅ¿Å¿e was continued till the baron was outlawed, and the wife waiue, afterward the wife came in ward by proceÅ¿Å¿e, brought the queenes pardon for her waiuery: Though the pardon could not bÃ©e allowed, becauÅ¿e the wife without the huÅ¿band could not Å¿ue Å¿cire facias againÅ¿t the platntiffe, to make him declare vpon the firÅ¿t originall, for the pardon had a condition in law, ita quod ipÅ¿a Å¿taret recta in curia, which Å¿hÃ©e could not doe alone, yet by the opinion of the Court Å¿hÃ©e was to bee diÅ¿charged of the impriÅ¿onment, I thinke the Å¿hrew went home. But that a woman outlawed by her Å¿elfe alone for an offence touching her in an action brought againÅ¿t her huÅ¿band and her, and the huÅ¿band appeared before outlagary was diÅ¿charged of her impriÅ¿onment vpon Å¿ight of her pardon, I find not here nor no where elÅ¿e, and therefore it may be M. Iunes way will Å¿erue Å¿ometime to bee rid of a Å¿hrew, and that by a like manner a woman may be voided of a Å¿louin, or vncumbred of a Churle. An action of treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e is brought againÅ¿t baron and feme, and the baron outlawed, the wife appearing at the exigent, goeth Å¿an â¢ iour: if a capias vtlagatum lay hold of the huÅ¿band, I perceiue not well how he can get looÅ¿e without his dames fauour.

div.p:

Of which there is authority, 2. But Å¿Ã©e Sir Edw. Cokes 5. Report. fo. 98. in Buryes caÅ¿e, that the Doctors were deceiued, for the parties diuorced cauÅ¿a frigiditatis cannot liue together againe, and the iÅ¿Å¿ue by the Å¿econd wife is legitimate, for a man may bee habilis & inhabilis diuerÅ¿is temporibus. Againe, 13. and 14. of Eliz. Dyer fol. 305. teacheth that right and lawfulneÅ¿Å¿e of marriage is euer to be iudged, not by the temporall, but by the Å¿pirituall Iudge: And therefore in an iÅ¿Å¿ue of ne vnques accouple in loyall matrimonie, if the BiÅ¿hop certifie not the lawfulneÅ¿Å¿e of wedlocke, but the circumÅ¿tances. hÃ©e Å¿hall be amerced, and a melius certiorando awarded. SÃ©eing therefore right of marriage is to be diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ed by the Å¿pirituall Iudge, they which are married ought in no caÅ¿e to Å¿euer themÅ¿elues, and remarry without the Å¿pirituall Iudge: if they doe, the Å¿econd marriage is no marriage, the children had in it are illegitimate, and the woman not dowable, except in the caÅ¿e firÅ¿t Å¿pecified. And generally where eÅ¿pouÅ¿als are not mÃ©erely void but defieÅ¿able, if they bee not auoided by diuorcement, the iÅ¿Å¿ue which is had without defeiting that Å¿hall inherit: as if a man marry his coÅ¿in or his Å¿iÅ¿ter, Å¿aith the booke, and haue iÅ¿Å¿ue by her, and die before diuorce had, now nothing can baÅ¿tardize the iÅ¿Å¿ue, for though the CommiÅ¿Å¿ary was wont in his viÅ¿itation to make a kinde of diuorce in Å¿uch caÅ¿es after death of one of the parties, it was neuer any more than an InquiÅ¿ition of office, Ad inquirendum de peccatis, for the heire could not be baÅ¿tardized, when the parents both or one of them were dead, and therefore not citable to appeare, &c. div.head: THE WOMANS LAWYER. The fourth BOOKE.
div.p:
PAle death equo pulÅ¿ans pede pauperum tabernas regnumque â¢ urres: Death, I Å¿ay, to whom the Poet did attribute Å¿o much power in this his verÅ¿e, Omnia Å¿ub leges mors vocat a â¢â¢ a Å¿uas, hath called the huÅ¿band hence, left the houÅ¿e full of mourning, and Å¿pecially the wife cannot chuÅ¿e but Å¿orrow and lament. If my â¢ oure legged beaÅ¿t Å¿hould fall into halues, the one halfe Å¿tarke dead without motion or Å¿pirit, and the other halfe Å¿tanding Å¿till vpright, Å¿enting, Å¿Ã©eing, fÃ©eling, gazing; muÅ¿t it not, thinke you, be wonderfully aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed. If an Elephant, in whom (as Å¿ome d â¢ e write) is vnderÅ¿tanding of his countries Å¿pÃ©ech, a wonderfull memorie and recenting of things paÅ¿t, a great delight in loue and glorie, beÅ¿ides prudence, equitie, and religion, Å¿hould haue his head cut off, his body remaining Å¿till for & all that vegetable and Å¿enÅ¿itiue, would he not (trow yÃ©e) be excÃ©eding Å¿orrowfull for the forgoing Å¿uch an ornament, I dare be bold to giue a woman as much as Pliny gaue the Elephant:
She hath vnderÅ¿tanding, and Å¿pÃ©ech, firme memorie, loue naturall, and kindneÅ¿Å¿e, deÅ¿ire of glorie and reputation, with the accompliÅ¿hment of many meritorions vertues: But alas, when Å¿he hath loÅ¿t her huÅ¿band; her head is cut off, her intellectuall part ãâ¦ã gone, the verie faculties of her Å¿oule are; I will not Å¿ ãâ¦ã cleane taken away, but they are all be ãâ¦ã ned, di ãâ¦ã ed and dazled, Å¿o that Å¿he cannot thinke or remember when to take reÅ¿t or ref â¢
ction for her weake body. And though her Å¿pirits and naturall moyÅ¿ture beingâª inwardly exhauÅ¿ted, with Å¿orrow and extreme griefe, Å¿he be called and inforced to Å¿eeke reÅ¿tauration, by Å¿uch aliments as life is prolonged by, yet is Å¿he nothing deÅ¿irous of life, hauing loÅ¿t a moytie of herÅ¿elfe, yea the principall maytie now beÅ¿t priÅ¿ed and eÅ¿tÃ©emed, but neuer beÅ¿t loued: Time muÅ¿t play the PhyÅ¿itian, and I will helpe him a little: Why mourne you Å¿o, you that be widowes? ConÅ¿ider how long you haue beene in Å¿ubiection vnder the predeminance of parents, of your huÅ¿bands, now you be frÃ©e in libertie, & frÃ©e proprii â¢ uris at yo â¢ r owne Law, you may Å¿ee num. cap. â¢ 0âª That maidens and wiues vowes made vpon their Å¿oules to the Lord himÅ¿elfe of heauen and earth, were all diÅ¿auowable and infringible, by their parents or huÅ¿bands, vnleÅ¿Å¿e they ratified and allowed them, either expreÅ¿Å¿e or by Å¿ilence, at the day when Å¿uch vowes came firÅ¿t to their notice and knowledge: But the vow of a widow, or of a woman diuorced, no man had power to diÅ¿allow of, for her eÅ¿tate was free from controlment. MuÅ¿t a woman nÃ©eds wÃ©epe thus for the loÅ¿Å¿e of her Buckler, Shield, and defence, in the perÅ¿on of him with whom Å¿he held daily commutation of all offices proceeding from loue and Å¿uperlatiue kindneÅ¿Å¿e. Let her learne to caÅ¿t her whole loue and deuotion on him, that is better able to loue and defend her than all the men in the world, Him I meane that hath forbidd â¢ n to afflict widdowesâª or orphans, with promiÅ¿e to heare their cries, and vindicate their wrongs, by killing them by the Å¿word, and making the wiues widdowes, and
their children fatherleÅ¿Å¿e, of them which breake this Commandement, Exod. cap. 22. Then becauÅ¿e a Å¿ober carefulneÅ¿Å¿e and moderate Å¿edulitie, in buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e of profit or diÅ¿profit, doth mitigate greatly the Å¿orrowing for Å¿uch actions, as opinion or fancie makes thus grieuous, let her looke to her affaires as cauÅ¿e and need requireth.

div.head: SECT. VI. AÅ¿signement to her Å¿elfe, or de la pluis beale.
div.p:
IF a man Å¿eiÅ¿ed of forty acres of land, 20. by Chiualry, and 20. by Å¿occage die, &c. and his wife being gardian in Å¿occage, bring her Writ of Dower in the Kings or Å¿ome others Court, againÅ¿t the Lord which is gardian in Chiualry, he may plead this matter, and pray to haue it adiudged, that the woman indow her Å¿elfe of the fa â¢â¢ eÅ¿t in her owne poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and if Å¿he cannot deny the caÅ¿e, it Å¿hall be iudged for the Lord, to retaine quietly the lands which hee hath during the nonage of the Infant. And after this iudgement the woman may indow her Å¿elfe in preÅ¿ence of her neighbours, by limits and bounds de la pluis beale part of the Å¿occage lands, to haue & to hold to her Å¿elfe for terme of her life. This manner of indowment is neuer before iudgement bee giuen for it, either in the Kings or Å¿ome other Court, and it is to Å¿aue the Å¿tate of gardian in Chiualry, Perkins giueth this matter, which Litlton leaueth thus raw, a turne or two more. And Å¿o doth Keble 14. Hen. 7. 26. If, Å¿ay they, the land which the woman hath by her gardianÅ¿hip, bee not the whole valew of her iuÅ¿t Dower for the Å¿malneÅ¿Å¿e of it, or becauÅ¿e it is charged with Å¿ome rent, Å¿he may Å¿hew the matter in her replication: And if the Lord cannot deny it, or doe trauers it, and it is found againÅ¿t him, then Å¿hall the woman haue Å¿o much of the lands holden in Chiualry, as together with that Å¿hee hath in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion already, may make vp iuÅ¿t a third part of her huÅ¿bands inheritance. If the inheritance were all of Å¿occage tenure, the widdow being gardian cannot indow her Å¿elfe de la pluis beale, but Å¿hee Å¿hall be allowed a third part in her accompt for Å¿o long time, as Å¿hee is
Gardian, for if Å¿he bring her Writ of Dower in this caÅ¿e againÅ¿t the heire he cannot plead her gardinÅ¿hip, and that Å¿he may indow her Å¿elfe, SÃ©e 45. Edw. â¢ . fol. 6. If Å¿uch a Feme gardian bring a Writ of Dower againÅ¿t one whom her huÅ¿band infeofed with warranty, hee Å¿hall not pray that Å¿he ãâ¦ã ow her Å¿elfe, for he may vouch the heire which Gardin ãâ¦ã Chiualry cannot doe. It is no good plea for Gardine in Chiualry to Å¿ay the Demandant was gardian in Å¿occage, &c. but hee muÅ¿t Å¿hew that Å¿he is gardian in Å¿occage â¢ our del brief purchaÅ¿e, and this is good till Å¿hÃ©e haue Å¿hewed by replication the land deueÅ¿ted from her poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion.

As if the huÅ¿bands Feoffee in a writ of Dower againÅ¿t him call to Warrantie the heire in the wardÅ¿hip of the King, &c. the woman Å¿hall recouer againÅ¿t the Tenant, and no recouerie Å¿hall be as yet againÅ¿t the heire: But neither any common perÅ¿on, nor yet the Kings Committee of wardÅ¿hip, Å¿hall haue this prerogatiue: But for the King himÅ¿elfe, if in the caÅ¿e Iudgement to recouer is value be giuen for the Tenant, he muÅ¿t Å¿tay for execution till the Kings hands be amoued, &c.

If a woman be endowed by her huÅ¿bands Feoffee, of Å¿uch lands as the huÅ¿band did not die Å¿eiÅ¿ed of, whereof alÅ¿o for this reaÅ¿on the King can haue no wardÅ¿hip. Stamfords opinion is, that Å¿he cannot marrie Å¿ â¢ ns licence.

For by
â¢ 6. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿arum Pl. 57. it appeareth that where a woman was endowed, by Gardian in Chiualrie, who was afterward attainted of treaÅ¿on, and his Seigniorie forfeited to the King, Å¿he muÅ¿t hold now of the King, and not of the heire which was in reuerÅ¿ion of the land: Hee accords with Fitzherbert, that the Statute of Prerogatiue
is vnderÅ¿tood onely of lands holden in capite, and therefore Å¿he muÅ¿t demand Dower of lands holden of a BiÅ¿hoprick, or of Tenant in capite, when the temporalities, or the heire are in CuÅ¿todia regis, Å¿he muÅ¿t be indowed in Chancery, but Å¿he may marrie when Å¿he liÅ¿t, and Å¿hall take no oath to the contrarie: AlÅ¿o if a widdow will relinquiÅ¿h her Dower of lands holden in capite, Å¿he may marrie
â¢ ans licence. And Å¿ee Dyer 3. M. 123. b. affirmeth, that the wife of Tenant parauaile Å¿hall not be Å¿worne as widdow of the King in the Chancery, when her Dower is aÅ¿Å¿igned to her. The reaÅ¿on per Stamford is the copulatiue connexion of Et Å¿i Å¿e maritauerit, to the former words of the Statute of demanding Dower, and Å¿wearing not to marrie: The words Å¿i viduae voluerint, he takes to imply no more but election of refuÅ¿all, or taking of Dower, and that is manifeÅ¿t by the laÅ¿t clauÅ¿e of the Statute.

But by Fitzherberts writ, which hee Å¿ets downe for forme of Å¿eiÅ¿ure, when a widdow is married Å¿ans licence, it appeares that the King may grant to another the marriage of his widdow or widdowes, and for marriage before agreement with Å¿uch a Grantee the King may Å¿eize, and compoÅ¿ition with Å¿uch a Grantee by Baron or Feme before or after marriage, is as good as if it were with the King himÅ¿elfe. But now by the Statute 32. H. 8. cap. 46. This compoÅ¿ition is giuen to the MaÅ¿ter of the Wards and Liueries, with three of the Councell of that Court, who haue alÅ¿o authoritie to tax according to the Statute of Prerogatiue, a reaÅ¿onable fine for marriage Å¿ans licence.

How much it ought to be is plaine by the Statute, as alÅ¿o what lands are Å¿ubiect to the Statute, as alÅ¿o what lands are Å¿ubiect to Å¿eiÅ¿ure aÅ¿well of the huÅ¿bands lands as of the wiues. If that were reaÅ¿on, Å¿aith Fitzherbert, a womans inheritance might be Å¿eiÅ¿ed too, Et Å¿emble a moy, the King cannot grant marriage of his widdowes as he may of his wards; for a widdow may remaine Å¿ole without penalite, or paying for it, by Mag. Chart. cap. 7.

But Stamford includeth, that a widdow endowed o â¢ lands holden in capite by the Kings Committee, or huÅ¿bands heire, though vnÅ¿worne is not freed from marriage Å¿ans licence, for Å¿he is preÅ¿ently as Å¿oone as Å¿he is endowed, tenant to the King, and not to the heire which is in reuerÅ¿ion, yet only the heire is he, which Å¿hall haue action of waÅ¿te againÅ¿t her; but if treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e bee done vpon the ground, Å¿he may haue a writ out of Chancerie, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing entrie vpon the Kings poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion. And Auowrie to bee made by the King reÅ¿teth onely vpon her, as holdeth Wood, 1. H. 7. fol. 17. and 4. H. 7. 1.

Now note that Endowment in Chancerie is of Å¿uch Å¿trength, that be it by wrong or by right, it cannot be auoyded by plea without Å¿uit in Chancerie: And if it bee too little, the woman muÅ¿t Å¿tand in her owne harmes, that hath once attempted it in Chancerie, bee Å¿hee within a â¢ e, or of full age, as appeares, 18. Ed. 3. fol. 29.

If any office bee trauerÅ¿ed, becauÅ¿e the land is holden not of the King, but of Å¿ome other Lord, who therefore hath an OuÅ¿ter le maine vna cum exitibus, yet Dower which is already aÅ¿Å¿igned remaineth vndefeated, till another Å¿uit be made in Chancerie to auoid it.

Yet in this caÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e AdmeaÅ¿urement, is no preiudice to the King of whom the land is not holden, the Lord that tendreth trauerÅ¿e, may haue a Writ of AdmeaÅ¿urement at yâ¢ Common Law. And the heire may haue AdmeaÅ¿urement of Dower aÅ¿Å¿igned by his AnceÅ¿tor: But an Abator cannot haue AdmeaÅ¿urement, neither can Gardian in fait haue AdmeaÅ¿urement vpon aÅ¿Å¿ignment by Gardian in droit, nor if the heire were at full age at his AnceÅ¿tors death, and died, his heire being within age can the Gardian haue AdmeaÅ¿urement, but where a woman is endowed in Chancerie, and afterward the heire, or Å¿ome other for the King Å¿urmiÅ¿eth e â¢ ceÅ¿Å¿e of value, it may bÃ©e admeaÅ¿ured beginning with Scire facias, as Fitzherbert hath taught Å¿upra, and fol. 249. â¢ . If the huÅ¿band had l ãâ¦ã in diuers Counties, by reaÅ¿on whereof diuers writs of
diem clauÅ¿it extremum were awarded after his death into euerie of thoÅ¿e Counties, the widdow cannot be endowed till Å¿uch time as all the writs be returned into Chancery. If after Å¿he is once endowed in Chancerie, her Dower be recouered from her by any title, Å¿he hath no remedie but to remoue the record of this recouerie into Chancerie, and then vpon the firÅ¿t record which Å¿heweth that Å¿he was endowed, and vpon this other of recouerie Å¿he Å¿hall haue Scire facias, reciting both the records againÅ¿t him which is tenant of the two parts, to reÅ¿eiÅ¿e them into the Kings hands, and Å¿o to bee newly endowed, but not to recouer any dammages, though dammages were recouered againÅ¿t her, Lib. 43. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ar. Pl. 32. for by the latter part of the Statute Prerogatiue, cap. 4. It Å¿Ã©emeth the King hath loÅ¿t his prerogatiue, and that he is bound by, WeÅ¿t 1. cap. 22. Note that woman Ioynt purchaÅ¿er with her huÅ¿band is not within this Law to fine for her marriage, when Å¿he becomes a widdow (Å¿ay I) therefore well fare a Ioynture.

div.head: SECT. VIII. Suit for Dower at the Common Law.
div.p:
THus we haue Å¿Ã©ene how, and when a widdow mu â¢â¢ f â¢â¢ for Dower in the Ch â¢â¢â¢ er â¢â¢ , viz. when either her huÅ¿band died the ãâ¦ã tenant in cap â¢ te, or by â¢ nights Å¿eruice, his heire vnder age, or otherwiÅ¿e tenant to Å¿ome other, â¢ hole lands are in the Kings hands by vacancie, or nonage of the heire. But if the huÅ¿band, which held in Socage, or by â¢ nights Å¿eruice, not of the King, did giue or alien any man â¢â¢ r of way his lands, or were diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed of them, or died Å¿ â¢ iÅ¿ â¢â¢ of them. The widdow, if by Å¿imple demand Å¿he cannot obtaine her Dower to bee aÅ¿Å¿igned her, may haue a w â¢â¢ t of Dower Vnde nihil habet at the Common Law againÅ¿t him which is tenant of the Franktenement,
by the old Nat. breuium this writ is maintainable againÅ¿t him which hath poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the land, by what manner Å¿oeuer, or againÅ¿t the Gardian in Chiualrie; in this or like forme, Rex V â¢ cecomiti, &c. command A. to render to B. which was the wiÅ¿e of C. â¢ er reaÅ¿onable Dower, quae ad cam contingit de libero â¢ enemento, quo â¢ fuit praedict C. â¢ i â¢â¢ abet, & vnde queritur quod A. ei defortiat, &c. & niÅ¿i fecerit & B. fecerit t â¢ Å¿ecurum de clamore proÅ¿equendo, &c. Å¿ummoneas A. vt Å¿it apud WeÅ¿tmÌ oÅ¿tenÅ¿urus. If the Dower were ad oÅ¿tium EccleÅ¿iae, or ex aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u patris, or otherwiÅ¿e there is mention made of it in the writ. In London there may be a writ from the King to the Maior and Sheriffes in theÅ¿e words, Quod IuÅ¿ticietis A. quod iuÅ¿te & â¢â¢ ne delatione, & Å¿ecundum conÅ¿uetudinem ciuitatis noÅ¿trae London redd' B. quae fuit vxor C. rationabilem dotem, &c. Et IuÅ¿ticietis D. quod iuÅ¿te, &c. whereby appeares that a widdow in London may haue a writ of Dower againÅ¿t Å¿euerall tenents by Å¿euerall IuÅ¿ticies, as well as at the Common Law Å¿euerall Precipes againÅ¿t Å¿euerall tenants all in one writ, the ProceÅ¿Å¿e in the Common Place, is Å¿ummons, Grand cape & pettie cape, in the Common Place this writ of Dower, vnde nihil habet, muÅ¿t be returned into the Kings Court, Et per grand reaÅ¿on, Å¿aith Britton cap. 10. 4. For if two or more women Å¿hould Å¿triue, euerie of them affirming her Å¿elfe to be the lawfull wife of him which is dead, not minding to be buried with him, as is the corÅ¿e in India, but to get a third of his lands: This muÅ¿t be tried by Certificate from the BiÅ¿hop, vnto whom if any but the King Å¿hould write for the deciding of debate, it might fall out to be all in vaine, becauÅ¿e none hath power but the King to compell the BiÅ¿hop to make Certificate. In the next Chapter Britton Å¿heweth, that if the Tenant vouch to warranty one which appeareth according to Å¿ummons, the Plea Å¿hall proceed betwixt the Plaintiffe, & the Warrantor, or VouchÃ©e, the Tenant keeping Å¿eiÅ¿en till the Warrantie be determinedâª
Then if the Garrantie cannot be denied, nor the womans right diÅ¿proued, if that which Å¿he demandeth were certainly aÅ¿Å¿igned to her for Dower from her huÅ¿band, Å¿hee Å¿hall recouer againÅ¿t the Tenant, Et le renant le value.

But if the demand bee of no other than reaÅ¿onable Dowerâª the woman Å¿hall recouer in value againÅ¿t the Warrantor, and the Tenant Å¿hall hold his land in peace: If Å¿o be this Warrantor be vnder age, yet the Law fauoureth widdowes Å¿o much, that the plaint Å¿hal not attend his full age. Therefore if the Tenant Å¿hew forth any Charter, DÃ©ed, or Å¿peciall cauÅ¿e, whereby the Court may perceiue that the Infant is bound to Warrantie by the AnceÅ¿tors act, he Å¿hall anÅ¿wer preÅ¿ently, what age Å¿oeuer he be of. And though the Infant in ward be aliened by his Gardian or Gardians from hand to hand, this Å¿hall not preiudice the Voucher, for alwayes he Å¿hall vouch to warrantie the Heire and not the Gardian, who is bound to preÅ¿ent his ward Å¿o vouched in Court without difference, whether it be one or many parceners. Thus Å¿aith Britton, and 48. Ed. 3. fol. 5. agreeth, that he which voucheth an heire vnder age, muÅ¿t vouch him in ward de vntiel. If he be a ward, it is Å¿aid there alÅ¿o, that hee which voucheth an heire at full age, muÅ¿t Å¿hew a DÃ©ed, quaere. But when the lands are in the Gardians owne poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion to his owne profit and vÅ¿e, the writ of Dower muÅ¿t â¢ Ã©e brought againÅ¿t the Gardian, and not againÅ¿t the Infant. 46. Ed. 3. fol. 19. Where Mowbray Å¿aith, where an Infant is vouched in ward of the King, the woman Å¿hall recouer Dower maintenant. 3. H. 6. fol. 17. It was agrÃ©ed per curiam, that in Action of Dower, if the tenant vouch the heire in the Kings ward within the Å¿ame Countie where the writ is brought, the Demandant Å¿hall not recouer before the warrantie be determined: but the Law is contra, if the Voucher had prayed Å¿ummons in another Countie, for then the Demandant Å¿hould recouer maintenant, yet by the RegiÅ¿ter fol. 7. if in a writ of Dower the tenant vouch in Durham, the Demandant Å¿hall abide
triall of the warrantie, and not recouer preÅ¿ently. But by Fitzherbert for a rule in tituloâª Voucher, if the tenant vouch in a forraine Countie, Å¿hee Å¿hall recouer maintenant, and neuer attend triall of the warrantie, but when Voucher is in meÅ¿me l â¢ countie. If the heire vouched to warrantie, aft â¢ r â¢ hee hath appeared and count â¢â¢ pleaded the warrantie, or before appearance, being lawfully Å¿ummoned do ãâ¦ã ke default, the Defendant Å¿hall haue execution againÅ¿t him maintenant, if hee haue lan â¢ s within the Countie, Brooke Dower 5. div.head: SECT. IX. Plees in a writ of Dower.
div.p:
ADmitting there were no Voucher, let vs run ouer other matters vÅ¿ually pleaded. 14. H. 4. 33. in Dower was demanded a third part of two mils & of other lands, yâ¢ tenant aÅ¿ked Iudgement of the plaintiffe: for they were during the whole time of couerture, but the â¢â¢ te of two mills, viz. to â¢ ts. 38. Ed. 3. fol. 13. In a writ of dower againÅ¿t one as Gardian of land, and heire of K. de R. the defendant anÅ¿wered that the Infants father was
â¢ . de R. Iudgement del briefe, and if the writ were good, hee was ready to render dower: You cannot, Å¿aid Knyuet, plead to the writ & render dower both at one day, Å¿o the demandant
praying Iudgement, Å¿eiÅ¿en was awarded her. And becauÅ¿e Å¿he auerred that the defendant was not touts temps priÅ¿t, to render dower, an InqueÅ¿t of dammages was awarded, and that execution Å¿hould ceaÅ¿e till the InqueÅ¿t were paÅ¿t.

13. Ed. 4. fol. 7. In action of dower the tenant pleaded touts temps priÅ¿t de render Dower, & vncore eÅ¿t. The demandant Å¿aid that I. S. her huÅ¿band died Å¿eiÅ¿ed, and that Å¿uch a day and yeere Å¿he required the tenant to indow her at Dale, which refuÅ¿ed, &c. he replyed that at the Å¿ame day he offered to goe with her to the lands, and to aÅ¿Å¿igne her dower, but Å¿he refuÅ¿ed, Å¿ans ceo, that he refuÅ¿ed: The Court held the IÅ¿Å¿ue well taken by this Å¿peciall pleading. But if hee had Å¿aid generally and barely hee refuÅ¿ed not, Å¿ome thought it had not beene Å¿ufficient, inÅ¿omuch as it denies not the requeÅ¿t.

Bryan Å¿aid the demandant here might not haue Å¿euerall Iudgements of one thing, for note, Å¿hee was to recouer dower vpon the firÅ¿t plea, but all the other IuÅ¿tices were of opinion cleere, that Å¿hee Å¿hould haue Iudgement, of Dower maintenant, and 18. Ed. 3. In action of Dower Iudgement was to recouer dower with an inqueÅ¿t for dammages. As in a Quare impedit the Plaintiffe may haue one writ to the BiÅ¿hop, and another to the Sheriffe to enquire of dammages.

LikewiÅ¿e 14. H. 8. fol. 25. in a plea of dower vpon confeÅ¿Å¿ion the demandant recouered Iudgement, and after Iudgement auerring that her huÅ¿band died Å¿eiÅ¿ed, Å¿hee prayed a writ to enquire of dammages, & habuit: for if the demandant in dower will recouer dammages, Å¿hee muÅ¿t euer Å¿urmize that her huÅ¿band died Å¿eiÅ¿ed, though the Tenant confeÅ¿Å¿e the Action, or plead but onely to the Writ, and in the end of her DemiÅ¿e Å¿hee may maintaine the Writ, for Å¿ur plee & briefe, the dying Å¿eiÅ¿ed appeares not, without Å¿urmiÅ¿e, &c. 22. H. 6. fol. 44.

div.head: SECT. X. Deteiner of Euidence.
div.p: BY Perkins, none may deteine Dower for deteining of euidence but only the heire to whom the euidence belongeth, and the heire, when he pleads, muÅ¿t Å¿hew what the euidence is, &c. And they muÅ¿t concerne the lands diÅ¿cended, vnto him whereof Dower is demanded; for hÃ©e may not deteine Dower of land which the Charters concerne not, or for Charters concerning his purchaÅ¿ed lands, or thoÅ¿e whereof he hath no Å¿eiÅ¿in. Aliter, if they concerne Å¿ome reuerÅ¿ion deÅ¿cended; But if the heire come in vouched to warranty by the Barons feofÃ©e, hÃ©e cannot plead this Deteiner of Euidence, becauÅ¿e in verity the land is another mans to whom moÅ¿t rightly the Charters belong. But one copercener may haue this plea after partition againÅ¿t her mother or other Demandant in Dower, though the euidence concerne the other parceners and her all alike; Å¿ee 41. Titulo Dower in Brooke, If a widdow that is with child deteine euidence againÅ¿t her huÅ¿bands daughter and heire, or other heire collaterall, it Å¿hall bÃ©e no Å¿ufficient plea to delay Dower. 1. Perkins 70. & 71.
18. Hen. 8. fol. 1. The heire Å¿aid, the Demandant deteined a bagge enÅ¿ealed with the euidence, concerning the land, which if hÃ©e would deliuer hee was ready to render Dower, bone plee per Curiam.

33. Hen. 6. fol. 51. The Tenant pleaded for part of the land, whereof Dower was demanded non tenure, for another part detinue of Charters, for another part Ioyntenancie which his father, for a fourth part demanded view: but it might not be granted, becauÅ¿e he tooke notice to himÅ¿elfe of that part by pleading to the reÅ¿t. And the Plaintiffe to his plea of Å¿uruiuor pleaded his releaÅ¿e made to the father her huÅ¿band in his life time, IÅ¿Å¿i â¢â¢ Å¿eiÅ¿i que Dowre, &c. The plea of Euidence detained as Littleton

Where Newton Å¿aith, the reaÅ¿on of this barre is, becauÅ¿e the euidence being Å¿Ã©ene and looked into, may yÃ©eld matter to barre the Demandant of her Dower, for Å¿uch lands therefore as the Charters doe not touch, Dower Å¿hall be granted of them, this plea notwithÅ¿tanding. div.head: SECT. XI. Deteining of the heire.
div.p: AS the heire only may deteine Dower for deteining of euidence, Å¿o the Gardian in Chiualry onely may dete â¢â¢â¢ Dower for deteining the heire, and that he may plead and conclude qÌ il ad en touts temps priÅ¿t, for the ward belongeth to him.

If a widow eloigne the infant or heire of her huÅ¿band, though Å¿ome other body haue him by her deliuery, yet the Gardian in Chiualry may detaine Dower, except Å¿hee can redeliuer him to the Gardian in as good plight, as hÃ©e was at the time of the eloig â¢ ment, that is, vnmarried if he were eloigned vnmarried. But a woman nouriÅ¿hing her owne Infant, the Å¿onne or heire which her huÅ¿band left her, if a Å¿tranger clauning as Gardian fake him from her, the right Lord Å¿hall not detaine dower for this cauÅ¿e. But if a woman take and remoue the heire from the place where hee was nouriÅ¿hed at time of the Barons death; Now if a Å¿tranger wrongfully take him from her, the true and right Gardian may detaine dower. And this matter is pleadable by Gardian in Chiualrie, though hÃ©e come into Court, by reaÅ¿on that the heire is vouched to be in his ward; for by right the cuÅ¿todie of the Infant can appertaine to none but to him, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be by his grant or agrÃ©ement. Certaintie is required in pleading of this detainer, aÅ¿well as in the other, viz. that Å¿he which demandeth dower hath eloigned or detained I. S by name, Å¿on, or daughter W. &c. 22. H. 6. fol. 16. 2. H. 7. fol. 6.

Fitzherbert Å¿aith likewiÅ¿e, If a woman take a leaÅ¿e for yeares of land, whereof Å¿he is dowable, Å¿he Å¿hall not Å¿ue for Dower during theÅ¿e yeares, Nat. br. 149. c. Bracton propoundeth to be conÅ¿idered what Å¿hall be done when the widdow brings her Writ of Dower, vnde nihil habet, and yet it is Å¿o that Å¿he hath part of her Dower already: If (Å¿aith he) it be proued, or Å¿he cannot deny it, cadit breue, and Å¿he Å¿hall not recouer the reÅ¿idue, but by Writ de recto de dote: Therefore let her accept no part of her Dower, before Å¿he purchaÅ¿e her Writ, and let it containe all the Deforcers, be they in one Countie, or in many.

When they are Å¿o put together, if now Å¿he accept any thing of her Dower without Iudgement, the acceptation of part Å¿hall be no exception againÅ¿t her, for Å¿he may confeÅ¿Å¿e Å¿atisfaction for that part: If peraduenture Å¿hee haue already taken part of her Dower from Å¿ome one perÅ¿on before the obtaining or purchaÅ¿e of her Writ, let his name and the Å¿ummons for him be in the Writ notwithÅ¿tanding, and then if it be obiected Å¿he hath accepted part, Å¿hee may acknowledge that hee hath Å¿atisfied her for his
part, and whether before or after Å¿uit is not greatly to be Å¿tood vpon. But if he of whom Å¿he receiued part be not named in the Writ, Å¿he cannot againÅ¿t the obiection of acceptance reply, that the land which Å¿he accepted is not in the Å¿ame Towne, but in another. For vnde nihil habet in the Writ non debet referri ad villas Å¿ed ad dotem. It is nothing worth therefore, to Å¿ay Å¿he hath nothing in tali villa, if Å¿he hath any thing nomine dotis, whereÅ¿oeuer it be it is not then materiall. And when a woman replyeth nihil habet, her defence Å¿hall not be per legem that is wager of Law, but per patriam. LikewiÅ¿e, if a woman plead that Å¿he hath nothing nomine dotis but by Å¿ome other title, as ratione cuÅ¿todiae & huiuÅ¿modi, InquiÅ¿ition may be in the Countie where it is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed Å¿hee receiued Dower, to finde whether Å¿hÃ©e haue any thing in Dower of the tenements which were her huÅ¿bands, and if Å¿hÃ©e had, and now hath not, to enquire what is become of it, this was a Nor â¢â¢ . caÅ¿e of Holda the late wife of W. in Trinitie Terme, 4. div.head: SECT. XXII. The charge of Dower.
div.p: ADmitting the Dower aÅ¿Å¿igned to be both for quality and quantity iuÅ¿t, there is yet to be declared with what immunity a woman Å¿hall hold her Dower. FirÅ¿t Bracton Å¿aith, Si peculia ma â¢ iti Å¿ufficiant ad Å¿olutionem tenentur, Å¿ed vxori dos Å¿ua deonerabitur. Et heres defendere dotem & warrantizare eam mulieri debet & pro ea Å¿equi comitatus hundreda & curia dominorum, vt viduatae domui Å¿uae intendat & nutritioni Å¿uorum (Å¿i qui fuerint) puerorum. If the huÅ¿bands goods bee not Å¿ufficient for payment of his debts, the heire muÅ¿t diÅ¿charge Dower of the burden, &c. for he is the widd â¢ wes warrant of her Dower, and ought toâª follow for her, County Court, Court lÃ©et, and hundred, &c. That Å¿hÃ©e may Å¿Ã©e to her houÅ¿e, and nurture of her children.

Fitzherbert in his Writ of AdmeaÅ¿urement, firÅ¿t affirmes, that a woman Å¿hall not be diÅ¿treined in her Dower, in her Inheritance, or in the ioynt purchaÅ¿ed lands to her or her huÅ¿band, for her huÅ¿bands debts. The Writ which he Å¿ets downe for remedy, Å¿aith almoÅ¿t as much, R â¢ x Vicicounti, &c. cum Å¿ecundum legem & conÅ¿uetudinem regni angliae, mulieres in terris & tenementis quae ten â¢ nt in dotem de dono virorum, vel quae Å¿unt de ipÅ¿arum haereditate, vel quae Å¿ibi queÅ¿iuerint, pro debitis virorum diÅ¿tringi non debent, &c.
