But it Å¿Ã©emes reaÅ¿onable, Å¿aith Fitzherbert, that a woman Å¿hall not hee diÅ¿treined in her Inheritance for the Kings debts, neither in her Dower or Ioynt purchaÅ¿ed lands which her huÅ¿band, if her title commenced before her huÅ¿band became debtor, and there is a Writ in the regiÅ¿ter importing no leÅ¿Å¿e, yea hee affoord â¢ it to be good reaÅ¿on that lands purchaÅ¿ed by Baron
and Feme, after the Baron is entred in debt to the King Å¿hould be diÅ¿charged in the widdowes hands. But let widdowes agrÃ©e with the King as well as they can, the heire is lyable to the debts of his AnceÅ¿tor before the widdow: The heire likewiÅ¿e diÅ¿chargeth her of Å¿uit and Å¿eruice, and is Å¿o farre forth her warrant, that by Britton, if Å¿hee be impleaded and vouch any other to warranty, Å¿he forfeiteth her Dower pur Å¿a malice, and though her huÅ¿bands feofee be not called her warrant: yet if Å¿he be indowed by him Å¿hee muÅ¿t hold of him. And regularly Tenant in Dower muÅ¿t be Attendant to her huÅ¿bands heire, or to the heires Gardian, or to the Gardenis Executor, or to him in the reuercion, according to the rate of rent whereby they hold ouer: if Tenent by fealty and xij. d. rent bÃ©e diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿ed and dye, his wife being indowed by the diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or, Å¿hall be an attendant to the Å¿ame diÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿or of iiij. d. annuall. And now if the heire will bring a Writ of entry in to quibus againÅ¿t the woman thus indowed, Å¿hee may Å¿hew her Å¿peciall matter, and that Å¿hÃ©e is ready to attend to whom the Court will award: which Å¿hall award, that Å¿he retaine her Dower Å¿till, and bee attendant to the heire, quaere, Å¿aith Parkins if the heire haue any other remedy, for hee cannot enter vpon the Tenant in Dower. D.Å¿t. 82. a. Å¿aith, That a Feme tenant in Dower leaueth the reuerÅ¿ion in him againÅ¿t whom Å¿hee demands her Dower, although he be a diÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿or, and doth not reduce the reuerÅ¿ion by her recouery to him which hath right, as other Tenants for life doe. And as it is Å¿aid in Sir Edward Cokes 8. Rep. 35. in Paynes ca. if Å¿he recouer againÅ¿t Tenant for life, Å¿hee leaueth the reuerÅ¿ion in him. But by nat. br. fol. 265. a. if the King aÅ¿Å¿igne Dower in Chancery as Gardian, the reuerÅ¿ion repoÅ¿eth in the heire, for which he Å¿hall Å¿ue liuery. If after iudgement the heire grant his reuerÅ¿ion, and the woman atturne, Å¿he Å¿hall be Attendant to the grantÃ©e. If Lord Meane & Tenant be, the Tenant holding by iij. d. rent, and the Meane by 20. d. If the Tenant marry, and the Meane releaÅ¿e to him all his right in the
tenancy, the Tenant dieth, the wife muÅ¿t bee endowed, according to her huÅ¿bands beÅ¿t poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions, and therefore Å¿hall bee Attendant to the heire by a penny, and not the third part of twenty pence. If hee which holdeth by fealty and xij. d. hauing a wife, Å¿ell the tenancie to his Lord, and the eÅ¿tate is executed, the Tenants wife Å¿hall be indowed Å¿ans attendancie, for the Seignory extinct is not reuiuable: If Lord MeaÅ¿ne and Tenant be, the Tenant holdeth by xij. d. which dieth, & his wife is endowed, Å¿hee Å¿hall bee attendant to the heire by iiij. d. now if the Lord releaÅ¿e all his right in the tenancy to the heire, the meanalty is extinct, and the attendance gone, for it was but in reÅ¿pect of the charge which the heire was at to his next Lord.

If a man loÅ¿e by default in a writ of right brought in a Court Baron, he may remoue the record, and haue a quod ei deforciat, in the Common place, and quaere Å¿aith Fitzherbert, if he neuer remoue the record, if he then may not Å¿ue his quod ei deforciat in which Court hÃ©e will, either the common place, or the Court Baron. If lands be giuen to Baron and Feme in eÅ¿peciall taile, the remainder to the Baron in generall taile, and the wife die Å¿ans iÅ¿Å¿ue, now if the Baron loÅ¿e by default, in a Praecipe quod reddat, his writ of Quod ei deforceat muÅ¿t be Quod clamat tenere Å¿ibi & haeredibus de corpore Å¿uo, for Å¿o Å¿oone as the wife died, the Å¿tate apres poÅ¿Å¿ibility drowned in the remainder, 50. Ed. 3. 21. If tenant for life loÅ¿e by a default in a C â¢ Å¿Å¿auit, he Å¿hall haue a Quod ei deforceatâª by this Statute of WeÅ¿t. 2. If â¢ e in reuerÅ¿ion vpon default of tenant for life pray to bÃ©e receiued, plead, and loÅ¿e by action tried: yet the tenant for life may haue a Quod ei deforceat, for the Iudgement muÅ¿t be againÅ¿t him by his default. If Baron and Feme, t â¢ nants for life in the wiues right, loÅ¿e by default, and the Baron dye, a Quod ei deforceat lieth not, but a Cui in vita, as vpon a DemiÅ¿e made by the baron: In a Quod ei deforceat the Demandant muÅ¿t count, that he was Å¿eiÅ¿ed, &c. in his DemeÅ¿ne as of Francktenement, or in his DemeÅ¿ne as of FÃ©e tail â¢ , laying the EÅ¿plees in himÅ¿elfe, but he nÃ©eds not Å¿hew of whoÅ¿e gift, leaÅ¿e, or demiÅ¿e, though he claime for life, or Å¿he claimes in Dower, or Å¿ibi & haeredibus de corpore. 10. Ed. 4. fol. 2. Dictum f â¢â¢ t, and the tenant may plead a releaÅ¿e of all the Demandants right in a Quod ei deforceat. But the old Nat. Breu. obÅ¿erueth, that if the Demandant vouch â¢ one that entreth into Warrantie, hee which recouered Å¿hall not plead the VouchÃ©es releaÅ¿e made after recouerie. the Demandant vouch, his VouchÃ©e cannot vouch ouer. 10. H. 7. 39. The old N â¢ t. B â¢ eu. acknowledgeth, that in a Scire f â¢ cias there lies no oucher: yet if a man recouer by default in a

The queÅ¿tions aroÅ¿e vpon the Demandants vouching, 10. H. 7. fol. 10. The firÅ¿t, whether he muÅ¿t Å¿hew cauÅ¿e of the Warrantie, or no. The Å¿econd, whether hÃ©e may vouch one that hath nothing in the reuerÅ¿ion. The third, whether he Å¿hall recouer in value. div.head: SECT. XXVII. Admonition for women to take heed of him in the reuerÅ¿ion.
div.p: THe reÅ¿t of this fourth booke Å¿hall conÅ¿iÅ¿t moÅ¿t in warnings to widdowes and women tenants in â¢ articular eÅ¿tates, that they doe nothing preiudiciall to their warrant. It is true for the moÅ¿t part, Ex quibus rebus maxima vtilitas, ex ii â¢ dem Å¿umma pernicies: Water waÅ¿heth and drowneth, fire reaÅ¿teth and it burneth, the Sunne ripeneth, and it Å¿cortcheth and Å¿earethâª They that can help can hurt. The reuerÅ¿ioner of a widdowes eÅ¿tate, of whom Å¿he Å¿hall haue aid to defend her, Å¿hall take her eÅ¿tate from her in many caÅ¿es, if Å¿he offend him in his reuerÅ¿ion.

div.head: SECT. XXVIII. Of WaÅ¿te.
div.p:
EVen by the antique Law of England, if Bracton Å¿ay truth, fol. 316. The Gardian in Chiualrie, committing waÅ¿te, did loÅ¿e the wardÅ¿hip, was auerred, Et damna reÅ¿taurabat. But if Tenant in Dower committed waÅ¿te, there was no forfeiture of her land, or parcell of it, but he in reuerÅ¿ion might Å¿top and let her, from doing waÅ¿te, and Å¿uch hinderance was no DiÅ¿Å¿eiÅ¿en. AlÅ¿o he might haue, if nÃ©ed required, a Non permittas to the Sheriffe, commanding him not to Å¿uffer waÅ¿te, vendiction or exile in lands, tenements, houÅ¿es, woods, garden, &c. and he might haue attachment againÅ¿t the widdowes, or a Pone per vadios & Å¿aluos plegios, to make her come, &c. Å¿hew why Å¿hÃ©e committed waÅ¿te. If the waÅ¿te in a wood were found by InquiÅ¿ition, the paine was no more, but that from thenceforth Å¿hÃ©e Å¿hould take no manner of EÅ¿touers, either to
build, burne, or incloÅ¿e, but it muÅ¿t be per viÅ¿um foreÅ¿tarior â¢ m haeredis. And Bracton Å¿ets forth the W â¢â¢â¢ for placing and appointing of the F â¢ r â¢ e â¢ cor, or by the heire ad praedict' ãâ¦ã
cuÅ¿todiendum. But now by the Stat. of Gloc. cap. 5. A writ of waÅ¿te lyeth againÅ¿t Tenant in the courteÅ¿ie, or for life, or for yeares, or in Dower, and the partie attainted in waÅ¿te Å¿hall loÅ¿e the thing waÅ¿ted, and make grÃ©e to trebble value of Å¿o much as the value Å¿hall be taxed at. This Statute made 6. Ed. 1. ordaineth alÅ¿o that the Gardian which loÅ¿eth his wardÅ¿hip for committing waÅ¿te Å¿hall render dammages, if loÅ¿Å¿e of wardÅ¿hip be not equiualent to the harme. Peraduenture Bracton wrote after the Statute for in one part of his Booke Ed. 1. is named
â¢ . 3. But it is Å¿aid Sir Edw. C â¢ kes 3. Rep. fol. 40. a. that Glanuile wrote temps H. a. Bracton, temps H. 3. Britton, temps Ed. 1. and in Sir Edw. Cokes 8. Rep. in Iohn Webs caÅ¿e, fol. 46. b. he Å¿aith, that Bracton wrote in fine del Roy H. 3. and Fleta wrote in temps E. 1. But note a woman Å¿hall not anÅ¿wer for waÅ¿te done before her time: yea, if land bÃ©e leaÅ¿ed to Baron and Feme, for terme of their liues, and they commit waÅ¿te: if the Baron die, now the widdow is not puniÅ¿hable for this waÅ¿te: For that which the Baron did during couerture, was only his act and offence, dead and determined with his perÅ¿on. ConceÅ¿Å¿um per curiam, 2. H. 4. and Br. 59. in his Writ of waÅ¿te. Yet if the leaÅ¿e had beene made to a Feme Å¿ole, who takes a huÅ¿band which commits waÅ¿te, otherwiÅ¿e it is by 9. H. 6. 52. women need no further warning to take hÃ©ed of waÅ¿te, they are of themÅ¿elues Å¿o hauing.

div.head: SECT. XXIX. The Writ of Entrie in caÅ¿u prouiÅ¿o.
div.p:
BVtlet e â¢â¢â¢ rie good woman take hÃ©ed, how Å¿he maketh any gift or alienation of Å¿uch lands as Å¿he holdeth in
Dower. For GloceÅ¿t. cap. 3. is, if a woman Å¿ell, or giue away in fÃ©e, or for life, the tenement which Å¿hÃ©e holdeth in Dower; the heire, or he which is in reuerÅ¿ion, may maintenant haue his recouerie by Writ of Entrie, and this is termed a writ of Entrie in CaÅ¿u prouiÅ¿o. There is no doubt but FÃ©e in this Statute Å¿ignifieth both FÃ©e Å¿imple and FÃ©e taile. And he which hath FÃ©e Å¿imple, FÃ©e taile or EÅ¿tate for life in the reuerÅ¿ion, may haue this Writ againÅ¿t the AlienÃ©e, or againÅ¿t him which is tenant of the Francktenement. And this during the life of the tenant in Dower which aliened, for when Å¿he is dead, it lieth not per â¢ el N â¢ t. Breu. The Statute expreÅ¿Å¿eth not the writ, but the forme is, Praecipe A. quod reddat B. vnum tonemen um quod clamat, in quod non habet ingreÅ¿Å¿um niÅ¿i per C. quae Å¿uit vxo D. qui illud ei demiÅ¿ â¢â¢ & illud tenuit in dotem de dono praedicti D. quondum viri Å¿unt cuius haeres, &c. & quod poÅ¿t eemiÅ¿ionem per iÅ¿tud C. praefat' A. contra formam Statuti GloceÅ¿t. &c. ad praefatum â¢ reuerti debet performameiuÅ¿dem Statuti. And it may be in the Per, Cui, or PoÅ¿t. If a woman recouer Dower againÅ¿t the heire, and then alien in FÃ©e, the recouerie muÅ¿t be mentioned by the heire in his writ of Entrie in CaÅ¿u prouiÅ¿o. In like manner as it muÅ¿t be in a writ of Entrie â¢ d Communem Legem vpon an alienation by tenant in Dower, and though this alienation be but in taile, or for life, yet the forme of the writ varieth not: If he which hath the reuerÅ¿ion in FÃ©e grant it to another, and the Tenant in Dower after Atturnment, alieneth in Fee, the GrantÃ©e of the reuerÅ¿ion Å¿hall haue Writ Å¿pecifying the grant. LikewiÅ¿e if the heire grant his reuerÅ¿ion with Atturnment, and the GrantÃ©e grants it ouer with Atturnment, the third GrantÃ©e may haue a writ Å¿pecifying that the woman held of the firÅ¿t, Å¿econd, and third, ex aÅ¿Å¿ignatione, &c. div.head: SECT. XXX. The Writ if Enirie in CaÅ¿a coaÅ¿imili.
div.p: THis Writ is in nature like the other, and it lyeth when Tenant by the courteÅ¿ie, or Tenant for his owne life, or another mans, alieneth in fÃ©e, or in taile, or for terme of life, he in the reuerÅ¿ion which hath it for life, or in taile, or in fÃ©e, may haue this Writ of Entrie in CaÅ¿u conÅ¿imili, during the life of him which aliened, and this is formed and granted vpon WeÅ¿t. 2. cap. 24. which willeth, That as often as there is a Writ found in Chancerie for one caÅ¿e, and another caÅ¿e falling Å¿ub eodem â¢â¢â¢ e, and requiring like remedy, there is none in the regiÅ¿trie of the Chancerie, for that the Clerks of the Chancerie Å¿hall concord in framing a writ Vel atterminent quaer â¢ ntes in proximo Parliamento, & Å¿cribantur vÅ¿us in quibus concordare non poÅ¿Å¿unt, &c. & referant eos ad proximum Parliamentum, & fiat breue de conÅ¿enÅ¿u IuriÅ¿peritor â¢ m: ne conting â¢ td â¢ caetero quod curia Domini Regis deficiat conquerentibus in IuÅ¿titia perquirenda.

The Writ is, Reuerti debet performam Å¿tatuti in conÅ¿imili caÅ¿u prouiÅ¿i. And if this writ be brought vpon alienation made by Baron and Feme, the writ Å¿uppoÅ¿eth that the wife aliened with her huÅ¿band, but yet Å¿hÃ©e may haue a Cui in vita after her huÅ¿bands death, the alienation
not letting it: If Tenant for life grant his eÅ¿tate to another, and the grantee alieneth in fÃ©e, the Writ Å¿hall be in quod non habet ingreÅ¿Å¿um niÅ¿i per C. cu â¢ D. qui illud tenuit ad vitam ex demiÅ¿Å¿ione B. de â¢â¢ Å¿it ad eusdem te â¢ m â¢
num &c. If a man make a leaÅ¿e for life, and dye, and his heire grant the reuerÅ¿ion to B. and the Tenant att â¢â¢ nes, If now the leÅ¿Å¿Ã©e grant his eÅ¿tate to another, which alieneth in fee to A. B. Å¿hall haue a Writ comprehending the aÅ¿Å¿ignation and grant of all the eÅ¿tates.

P. 17. Ed. 3. A leaÅ¿e made for life, the remainder to another in fÃ©e, the leÅ¿Å¿es aliened in fÃ©e, and a writ de conÅ¿imili caÅ¿u brought by him in the remainder, and it abated, for

div.head: SECT. XXXI. The Writ of Entrie ad communem legem.
div.p:
THe Writ of Entry at Common law, is giuen in CaÅ¿e where Tenant in Dower, or per curteÅ¿ie, or for life doth alien in fÃ©e, or in taile, or for life, &c. now if the Tenant which aliened doe dye, hec in the reuerÅ¿ion muÅ¿t take this Writ of Entry ad communem legem, which is very like the former Writs, and may be in the per, cui, & poÅ¿t; If a woman recouer Dower, alien, and dye, the Writ of Entry ad communem legem, muÅ¿t make mention of the recouery; And if Tenant by the curteÅ¿ie ali â¢â¢ in fÃ©e, and dye, he in the reuerÅ¿ion if he be heire in fÃ©e Å¿imple, may Å¿ue this Writ, or his AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e of Mo â¢â¢ danceÅ¿ter, giuen by the Statute of GloceÅ¿ter. ca. 3. If Tenant for life alien in fÃ©e, and dye, the Writs for him in reuerÅ¿ion are in diuers formes, for if hee haue the reuerÅ¿ion by diÅ¿cent, the Writ is in quod idem A. non habet ingreÅ¿Å¿um niÅ¿i per C. c â¢ i D. pator vel anteceÅ¿Å¿or, of the Demandant cuius haeres, &c. demiÅ¿ed, &c. But when the Demandant
himÅ¿elfe made the leaÅ¿e to him which aliened, then the Writ is or may be P â¢ aecipe quod recidat, &c. omitting theÅ¿e words, quod clomat vt ius & haereditatem; and note, if Tenant for life alien in fee, and dye, hee in reuerÅ¿ion may chuÅ¿e whether he will haue this writ, or an ad terminum qui praeteriit. div.head: SECT. XXXIII. The Statute of 11. H. 7. cap 20.
div.p:
THe Common Law reÅ¿trictiue of it Å¿elfe, and helped Å¿omething by the Statute of GloceÅ¿ter, was Å¿ufficient, a great while, to bridle women from making alienations for any land that they held in Dower or Ioynture, as arguments of their owne good deÅ¿erts and teÅ¿timonies of their huÅ¿bands loue; But time, which made
the art of fencing more fine than it was at the firÅ¿t, when Combattants fought all at head and Å¿houlders, and it was greater Å¿hame to Å¿trike vnder the girdle than it is now, made law alÅ¿o more Å¿ubtile than in the beginning it was, when lands went altogether, or for the moÅ¿t part by liuery of Å¿eiÅ¿in.

And women witty of themÅ¿elues, inÅ¿tructed by crafty men, grew cunning at the laÅ¿t, that they could alien lands, holden for life, or in taile, to whom they liÅ¿ted in fÃ©e. And hee which Å¿uffereth diÅ¿inheritance Å¿hould not eaÅ¿ily helpe himÅ¿elfe by Writ of Entry, either ad communem legem or in caÅ¿u prouiÅ¿o: for remedy whereof was made this Å¿euere Å¿tatute in effect as followeth. 11. div.head: SECT. II. How a woman Å¿hall Å¿ue this Appeale.
div.p:
IT Å¿Ã©emes that all Appeales ought to be Å¿ued in proper perÅ¿on, and not by Atturney, as Appeale of Mayhem muÅ¿t be in proper perÅ¿on, 21. E. 4. 7 â¢ , & 73. A woman which was groÅ¿Å¿ment enÅ¿eint, Å¿ued this Appeale, and the Defendant was attainted, the womans appearance was recorded for the whole terme, and yet by the better opinion, Å¿he might not pray execution, by her Councell, but ought to come in proper perÅ¿on; therefore one of the Iudges did ride to IÅ¿lington to her, to Å¿Ã©e if Å¿he were aliue, and deÅ¿ired execution, which Å¿he required, and the Defendant had iudgement. An Appeale is called but a Å¿uit of reuenge, and therefore is not much fauoured, Dver 5. M. 152. If one of the Defendants in an Appeale makes default, the Court cannot procÃ©ed, but otherwiÅ¿e in an In â¢ itement, as it is there Å¿aid. This by Common. Law; If any Liege Å¿ubiect be Å¿laine by another Å¿ubiect in any forreine Realme, the wife of him which was Å¿laine, may haue an Appeale in England, before the ConÅ¿table and MarÅ¿hall, &c. And this is by Statute, 1. Hen. 4. cap. â¢ 4âª Stanford, fol. 65. Feme auer â¢ appeal â¢ de mort viri tue in eÅ¿co â¢ e per commen L â¢ y comme Å¿embleâª 13. H. 4. Brooke 153. By the Å¿aid Statute it is alÅ¿o ordained, that none Appeales from henceforth bee purÅ¿ued in Parliament. LikewiÅ¿e I finde by Statute, v â¢ z. 15. R. 3. cap. 2. That of the death of a man, an â¢ of Mayhem done in great Å¿hips,
being and houering in the Å¿treame of great riuers, onely beneath the bridges of the Å¿ame, nigh to the Å¿ea, and in none other places of the Å¿ame riuers, the Admirall Å¿hall haue conuÅ¿ance, &c. Å¿auing to the King all manner of forfeitures, &c.

div.head: SECT. III. The Statute 3. H. 7. cap. 1.
div.p:
BVt for the ordinarie courÅ¿e of Å¿uing of Appeales, 3. H. 7. cap. 1. layeth the beÅ¿t foundation: This Statute reciteth the Law of the land to be, that if any man bÃ©e Å¿laine in the day, and the Felon not taken, the TownÅ¿hip Å¿hall bee amerced. If any man bee wounded, and in perill of death, the offender Å¿hould be arreÅ¿ted, and put in Å¿uretie, till knowledge be had, whether hÃ©e which is hurt will liue or no. And where any man is found dead, the Coroner vpon view of the body, Å¿hould enquire who were the murderers, their abettors, conÅ¿enters and who were preÅ¿ent at the murder committed, whether man or woman, and he ought to inroll, and certifie their names. The vÅ¿e had bÃ©ene alÅ¿o (as Å¿aith the Statute) that within a day and years after any death or murder, the felony Å¿hould not bÃ©e determined at the Kings Å¿uit, and that for Å¿auing of the parties Å¿uit, or elÅ¿e the partie was agrÃ©ed with, by which it is the more chargeable, and thereby murders were increaÅ¿t: and alÅ¿o, he that will Å¿ue in Appeale, muÅ¿t Å¿ue in proper perÅ¿on. The conÅ¿titution of this Law therefore is, that euerie Coroner henceforth doe his office, and that if any man be Å¿laine or murdered, the Å¿layers, murderers, their abettors, maintainers, and comforters Å¿hould bÃ©e indicted, arraigned, &c. at the Kings Å¿uit, within the yeare after the felony or murder done, without tarrying a yeare and a day for any Appeale. And if any, either principall or acceÅ¿Å¿arie thus arraigned, bÃ©e
acquited at the Kings Å¿uit with â¢ n the yeare and day, the IuÅ¿tices before whom he is acquite, Å¿hall not Å¿uffer him to goe at large, but either remit him againe to priÅ¿on, or let him to baile, till the yeare and day be paÅ¿t: And the wife or next heire of the partie Å¿laine, may take their Appeale within the yeare and day, after the felony or murder done, (if the benefit of Clergie be not yet had) with all aduantages that acquitall or Attainder at the Kings Å¿uit notwithÅ¿tanding. Furthermore, the wiÅ¿e or heire of the perÅ¿on Å¿laine or murdered, may commence their Appeale in proper perÅ¿on, any time within a yeare after the felonie done, before the Sheriffes and Coroners, &c. or before the King in his Bench, or IuÅ¿tices of Gaole deliuerie: And the Appellant in any Appeales of murder, of death of man, where battaile by the courÅ¿e of Common Law lieth not, may make Atturney, and appeare by the Å¿ame in the Å¿aid Appeales, after they bÃ©e commenced to the end of the Å¿uit, and execution of the Å¿ame. And if the murderer doe eÅ¿cape vntaken, the TownÅ¿hip, &c. Å¿hall be amerced, and the Coroners Å¿hall deliuer their inquiÅ¿ition afore the IuÅ¿tices of the n â¢ xt Gaole deliuerie, which IuÅ¿tices Å¿hall procÃ©ed againÅ¿t the murderer, if they bee in Gaole, or elÅ¿e the Å¿aid IuÅ¿tices Å¿hall put the InquiÅ¿ition before the King in his Bench. The Statute alÅ¿o giueth the Coroner thirtÃ©ene Å¿hillings and foure pence, for taking inquiÅ¿ition Å¿uper v â¢ Å¿ â¢ m corporis.

By this Statute and the other of Gloc. cap. 9. a womon perceiues that within a yeare and a day, Å¿he commeth timely enough with her Appeale. Stanford notes, that (though the Law haue bÃ©ene taken otherwiÅ¿e) if hÃ©e which is robbed make freÅ¿h Å¿uit, albeit he commence not his Appeale, two or thrÃ©e yeares after the robberie, yet his Appeale is good: for if the partie robbed haue his endeuour to take the Felon, he may commence his Appeale at any time, at the IuÅ¿tices diÅ¿cretion. For Gloc. if it be rightly vnderÅ¿tood, Å¿eemeth to Å¿peake only of Appeales de mort. And where it Å¿aith, Deins l'an & iour apres le fait,
this (le fait) is vnderÅ¿tood the felony, whereupon Appeale muÅ¿t commence. Therefore if a man bee Å¿trucken and wounded on one day, and dye within the yeare another day, the Appeale muÅ¿t be begun within a yeare and a day after the wound giuen: And if a yeare after a murder committed, one become acceÅ¿Å¿arie, there lyeth an Appeale againÅ¿t this acceÅ¿Å¿arie, as it Å¿eemeth within the yeare and day after he became a Felon. And the Appellant is not confined to a yeare and a day next after the murder committed, Stamford fol. 63. a.

But in Heydons caÅ¿e Sir Edw. Cokes 4. Rep. fol. 42. Wray Chiefe IuÅ¿tice Å¿aid, that the common experience of the Kings Bench was, and Å¿o was the Law without queÅ¿tion, that the yeare for the bringing of the Appeale, Å¿hall be accounted from the death, and not from the Å¿troke, againÅ¿t Stamfords opinion. And the reÅ¿t of the Iudges there Å¿aid, that there is no felony vntill the death. And in the 7. Rep. fol. 30. it is Å¿aid, If the Appeale be deliuered to the Sheriffe within the yeare, and before its returne, or that the Sheriffe hath done nothing, and the King dieth, and the yeare ends before the returne, in that caÅ¿e the Plaintiffe Å¿hall haue a Certlorare to the Sheriffe, returnable in the Kings Bench, and vpon that the Plaintiffe Å¿hall haue Reattachment, &c. and that for neceÅ¿Å¿itie, &c. otherwiÅ¿e Å¿he Å¿hould loÅ¿e her Writ lawfully purchaÅ¿ed.

div.head: SECT. IV. Within what Countie an Appeale muÅ¿t be brought.
div.p:
REgularly this Appeale ought to be brought into the Countie, where the homicide or murder was committed. But admitting that a man he wounded in one Countie, and goe into another and there dye, where Å¿hall the appeale commence, by Common Law? Titulo coronae.
In Fitzherbert 59. it appeares, that it â¢ as commenced in the Countie where the wound was giuen: but both Counties ioyned in triall, as well where the wound was, as the death. And in the Å¿ame title Placito 60. in Å¿uch caÅ¿e the Appellant commenced in the Countie where the partie died; and triall by ambideux Counties. By theÅ¿e bookes it Å¿hould Å¿Ã©eme, that at Common Law the Appellant might chuÅ¿e his Countie, but now the Statute, 2, & 3. E. 6. is plaine, which ordaineth, whereas Iurors in one Countie could not take knowledge of things done in another by the Common Law. That in caÅ¿es, vt Å¿upra, an Inditement found by Iurors of the Countie where the death happeneth, whether before the Coroner, Å¿upra viÅ¿um corpo â¢ s or before IuÅ¿tices of Peace, or other IuÅ¿ticesâª or CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, which haue authoritie to enquire of Å¿uch offences, Å¿hall be as good, as if the Å¿troke, wound or poyÅ¿oning had bÃ©ene in the Å¿ame Countie, where the partie Å¿hall die, &c. And the IuÅ¿tices of Gaole deliuerie, or if Dyer and Terminer, a â¢ the Å¿ame Countie where Å¿uch Indictment Å¿hall be taken, And the IuÅ¿tices of the Kings Bench (after the Indictment remoued before them) may procÃ©ed as if the Å¿troke, or poyÅ¿oning, and the death had bÃ©ene all in one Countie. And the partie to whom Appeale is giuen, may commence, take, and purÅ¿ue in the Å¿ame Countie, where the partie feloniouÅ¿ly Å¿tricken or poyÅ¿oned Å¿hall dye, againÅ¿t the principals, or acceÅ¿Å¿aries, in whatÅ¿oeuer place or Countie the Å¿ame acceÅ¿Å¿aries Å¿hall be guiltie. And the IuÅ¿tices before whom the Appeale Å¿hall be commenced, Å¿ued, and taken, within the yeare and day after the Å¿laughter committed, Å¿hall proceed againÅ¿t all Å¿uch acceÅ¿Å¿aries in the Countie where the Appeale Å¿hall be Å¿o taken in like manner and forme, as if the offence of Å¿uch acceÅ¿Å¿arie had beene done and committed in the Å¿ame Countie, where Å¿uch Appeale Å¿hall be taken, as well by triall of twelue men of the Å¿ame Countie where â¢â¢ Å¿uch Appeale is Å¿o Å¿ued, vpon plea of not guiltie, or otherwiÅ¿e. And further it is ordained, that where murder, â¢â¢
any manner of felony Å¿hall be committed in one County, and another perÅ¿on or more Å¿hall become acceÅ¿Å¿ary, or acceÅ¿Å¿ories in another County; an Indictment found or taken by IuÅ¿tices of Peace, or other IuÅ¿tices or CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, to enquire of fellonies, in the County where Å¿uch offence of acceÅ¿Å¿ories is committed or done, Å¿hall bÃ©e as good, as if the principall offence had bÃ©Ã©ne committed and done in the Å¿ame County, wherein the Indictment of acceÅ¿Å¿ary is found. The Statute appointed further, how the CuÅ¿tos rotulorum, or Keeper of the Records, of the principals attainder, or aquitall Å¿hall certifie, &c.

Before this Statute, if one man had committed murder in one County, and another had bÃ©ene acceÅ¿Å¿ary in another County, there was no remedy againÅ¿t this AcceÅ¿Å¿ary by the Common Law, Stanford fol. 63. yet Kinuet Å¿aid, 43. E. 3. fol. 18âª If a man were Å¿laine in one part of the Towne, and another man receiued the Manqueller in another part of the Towne, which is in another County, Appeale might bee Å¿ued againÅ¿t them both in the Courty where the killing was committed, and that Å¿o it had bÃ©ene adiudged.

div.head: SECT. VI. Of Appeale by Writ.
div.p: HOw an appeale Å¿hall be begun by Writ, Stamford Å¿aith no more thereof, but onely cheÅ¿cun Å¿ceit comment a ceo purchaÅ¿er: And as his knowledge made him preÅ¿ume that other men were not ignorant of it, Å¿om â¢ ignorance makes me pr â¢ Å¿ume, that many doe not know it. Bracton â¢ . 3. cap. 30. Å¿aith, that Å¿ometime it happeneth by negligence of the ViÅ¿count and Coroner, that the appeales muÅ¿t be attached by the Kings Writ in hac forma: Rex vicecomiti, &c. div.head: SECT. VII. Diuers appeales for one felony is but in few CaÅ¿es.
div.p:
BY the ancient Law one might haue diuers appeales, againÅ¿t the principall, oneâª and againÅ¿t the acceÅ¿Å¿ory, another, as appeares by the old Writers. And 28. E. 3. fol. 90. But Å¿ince that time the Law hath bÃ©ene changed, Å¿o that vnleÅ¿Å¿e in a few Å¿peciall caÅ¿es a man can haue but one appeale, which muÅ¿t comprehend both principals and ace â¢ Å¿ â¢ aries. And therefore 9. Her. 4. fol. 1 â¢ . in appea â¢ e againÅ¿t two, whereof the one was preÅ¿ent, and the other appeared not, the Plaintiffe declared againÅ¿t the â¢

E. 3. that a woman brought an appeale againÅ¿t one as prin â¢ ipall, which was attainted and hanged at her Å¿uitâª and then Å¿hÃ©e brought an appeale againÅ¿t two others of the Å¿ame fellony, againÅ¿t one, as

div.head: SECT. VIII. The Declaration in Appeale.
div.p:
THe Count or Declaration in Appeale of murder, according to the ancient forme was thus. A. appellat. B. de morte. C. fratris Å¿ui, &c. quod cum ipÅ¿e A. & C. eÅ¿Å¿ent in pace Dei & Domini regis apud S. &c. venit idem B. cum talib. &c. & nequiter & in felonia, in aÅ¿Å¿ultu premeditato, contra pacem domini regis fecit idem B. praedict' fratri Å¿uo & vnam plagam mortalem in capite cum quodam gladio, vel quouis alio genere, armorum multorum, &c. vt obierit infra triduum de plaga illa. Et quod hoc fecit nequiter & in felonia, & contra pacem Domini regis, offert Å¿e dirationare verÅ¿us â¢ um per corpus Å¿uum, Å¿icut ille qui praeÅ¿ens â¢ uit & hoc vidit, Å¿icut curia Domini regis conÅ¿iderauerit, Et Å¿i de eo male contigerit per corpus fratris Å¿ui, vel alterius parentis, &c. Et Å¿ic plures poÅ¿Å¿unt appellare vnum de vno & eodem facto, Å¿iloqui poÅ¿Å¿unt, de viÅ¿us Å¿ui teÅ¿timonio. So that Bracton Å¿heweth, if one of the appellants had died, or made default, the other might take the appeale, and bee admitted ad dirationandum. But if the Appealee had defended himÅ¿elfe againÅ¿t one, or bÃ©ene aquit by iudgement; hee was frÃ©ed from them all. The reaÅ¿on why no man was admitted to bring appeale de morte, vnleÅ¿Å¿e hee could Å¿peake of his owne eye witneÅ¿Å¿e, was (Å¿aith Stanford) the reaÅ¿onableneÅ¿Å¿e, which Å¿Ã©emed to bee in it, that a man Å¿hould not combate for the truth, when the AccuÅ¿er was not able to verifie it, but by relation from others. And
therefore in a Writ of right, vntill WeÅ¿t. 1. cap 40. had changed the Law, the Demandants Champian in his oath, did euer affirme, that he or his â¢ ather, had Å¿Ã©ene the Å¿eiÅ¿in of his Lord or MaÅ¿ter, Å¿o that his owne Å¿ight, or his fathers, cauÅ¿ed him to combat. And as it Å¿eemes battaile did not lye in any appeale de morte in Bractonâª time, except the wound were giuen with Å¿ome Å¿word, dagger, or Å¿uch like, as he cals
ãâã moÅ¿ â¢â¢â¢ . AlÅ¿o his forme Å¿peaketh nothing of the length, breadth or dÃ©epneÅ¿Å¿e of the wound, as the Declarations doe at this day; I will leaue Stamfords preÅ¿ident, and take one or two out of the booke of Entries. There
â¢ ol. 43. Katherin IohnÅ¿onâª late wife of Robert IohnÅ¿on, comes in perÅ¿on and doth inÅ¿tantly appeale, Iohn BiÅ¿hop late of Harling in the County Norff. Ye â¢ man, and W. F. late of the Å¿ame Towne and County, Yeoman, and R. W. late of H. in the Å¿ame County, Yeoman, of the death of the aforeÅ¿aid Robert IohnÅ¿on late her huÅ¿band. videlicer, of that, that whereas the Å¿aid Robert IohnÅ¿on was in Gods peace and the Kings, at Harling aforeÅ¿aid, vpon Munday next before the FeaÅ¿t of Saint Mathew the ApoÅ¿tle, in the Å¿econd yÃ©ere of eur late King H. 7. about two of the clocke after noone, of the Å¿ame day, Iohn BiÅ¿hop, and W. F. there came felloniouÅ¿ly, and as Felons of our Lord the King that now is, of their premeditate aÅ¿Å¿ault, againÅ¿t our Lord the Kings peace, Crowne and dignity, in the day, yÃ©ere, houre, place, and County aforeÅ¿aid, and the aforeÅ¿aid Iohn BiÅ¿hop with a Å¿harp pointed weapon called a dagger of twelue price, which hee had and â¢ eld there in his right hand, did feloniouÅ¿ly Å¿trike the aforeÅ¿aid Robert IohnÅ¿on vpon his breaÅ¿t, and into the hart, giuing to the Å¿ame Robert IohnÅ¿on then and there, a mortall wound foure inches dÃ©epe, of the which mortall wound, the Å¿aid Robert IohnÅ¿on, did forthwith then dye, at Harling aforeÅ¿aid. And Å¿o the aforeÅ¿aid Iohn BiÅ¿hop, did then feloniouÅ¿ly kill and murder the aforeÅ¿aid Robert IohnÅ¿on, at Harling aforeÅ¿aid. And W. F. the Å¿ame munday, in the Å¿ame yÃ©ere, at the Å¿ame towne
of Harling, was preÅ¿ent, feloniouÅ¿ly procuring, conÅ¿enting and keeping the Å¿ame Iohn BiÅ¿hop, to doe the felony and murder, in forme aforeÅ¿aid done and committed. And after the felony and murder aforeÅ¿aid committed by the aforenamed Iohn BiÅ¿hop, the Å¿ame W. F. and R. W. the Å¿ame Munday in the Å¿ame Å¿econd yÃ©ere of our Lord the King, at Harling in the County aforeÅ¿aid, did feloniouÅ¿ly receiue the Å¿aid Iohn BiÅ¿hop, harboure, comfort, and maintaine him, knowing that he the Å¿aid Iohn, had done the felony and murder in forme aforeÅ¿aid, and as Å¿oone as the Å¿ame felons had committed the Å¿aid murder and felony, they fled, and the Å¿aid Katherin did freÅ¿ly follow them from Towne to Towne, into foure of the next Townes, &c. And if the Felons will deny the felony ab â¢â¢ eÅ¿aid, in forme aforeÅ¿aid alleaged againÅ¿t them, Katherin the Appellant, is ready to proue it againÅ¿t them, as the Court Å¿hall thinke mÃ©et.

Againe fol. 51. is another Declaration. Thus, Elizabeth, &c. in perÅ¿on doth inÅ¿tantly appeale the aforeÅ¿aid Iohn Clerke of this: That whereas the aforeÅ¿aid Iohn Browne was in peace of God and our Lord the King that now is, at W. in the City of N. in a certaine place called Carrow, the twelft day of Ianuary, &c. about ten of the clocke aforenoone; There came the aforeÅ¿aid Iohn Clerke which now appeareth, and the aforeÅ¿aid William Clerke which appeareth not, and whom the aforeÅ¿aid Elizabeth would likewiÅ¿e appeale, of the death of her Å¿aid huÅ¿band, if he were preÅ¿ent; And they two did feloniou â¢ ly, and as felons, of our Lord the King that now is, in the day, yeer â¢ , houre, and City aforeÅ¿aid, giue to the aforeÅ¿aid Iohn Browne a certaine drinke, which they, the Å¿aid Iohn Clerke and William Clerke, had mixed and compounded with powders, and intoxicatiue Å¿pices, viz. Ratsbane, and others, and they did feloniou â¢ ly incite and prouoke the Å¿aid Iohn Browne, to drinke vp the Å¿aid drinke Å¿o intoxicate, which Å¿aid Iohn Browne hauing good truÅ¿t & confidence in them, and being vtterly ignorant of the intoxication
aforeÅ¿aid, did then and there, and at their perÅ¿waÅ¿ion, drinke vp the Å¿aid drinke, and therewith was then and there, by the Å¿aid Iohn and William feloniouÅ¿ly poiÅ¿oned: And afterward the Å¿aid Iohn Browne at Billingford in the County of Norff. the 20. day of Ianuary next enÅ¿uing in the Å¿ame yÃ©ere, being Å¿o poiÅ¿oned of the Å¿ame poiÅ¿on, died, and Å¿o the aforeÅ¿aid Iohn Clerke and William Clerke, feloniouÅ¿ly, and as felons of the King, at Billingford aforeÅ¿aid, in the County aforeÅ¿aid, the 20. of Ianuary, the aforeÅ¿aid Iohn Browne did kill and murder, &c. And if Iohn Clerke, which now appeareth, denyeth the felony aforeÅ¿aid of death and murder layed againÅ¿t him, the aforeÅ¿aid Elizabeth is ready to proue it againÅ¿t him, as the Court Å¿hall thinke good.

It might bee collected out of theÅ¿e preÅ¿idents without any more helpe, that a woman may maintaine her appeale, without expreÅ¿Å¿ing any arma moluta, as the faÅ¿hion was: Bracton Å¿aith, the Appellant nÃ©eds not Å¿et downe the houre wherein the party was Å¿taine, but the Statute of Gloc. makes it materiall, yet Stanford acknowledgeth, that the Declaration which was at Common Law, without the houre may be vÅ¿ed at this day, becauÅ¿e Gloc. is but affirmatiue and prohibits nothing. But the place where, &c. muÅ¿t nÃ©eds be Å¿et downe certainly in the count, for Å¿o commandeth the Statute, therefore in Appeale againÅ¿t diuers men, n â¢ ming them to bee of Å¿undry places and Townes, if it be Å¿aid afterward, at the place aforeÅ¿aid, this is not good, there are diuers other formes of Declarations in this Appeale: As 44 E. 3. fol. 33. in Appeale againÅ¿t thrÃ©e as principals, the Appellant declared that one of them, Å¿uch a day, and houre, wounded her huÅ¿band to the braine, whereof hee died, and at the Å¿ame houre another, with a dagger Å¿trooke him to the hart, Å¿o that if hee had not died at the firÅ¿t wound, he muÅ¿t haue died of the Å¿econd, and the third wounded him in another place, &c. counting Å¿euerally againÅ¿t them, that euery one gaue him a mortall Å¿troke, according to the fact. For Å¿o willeth the Statue
que il counta le fact, and this fact muÅ¿t bee declared as it was done, or as the Law doth expound it to b â¢ e doneâª Therefore if two bee pr â¢ Å¿ent at the death of a man, and one of them Å¿triketh neuer a Å¿troke, but onely comm â¢ ndeth the other to kill, &c. in the appeale, declaration muÅ¿t be, that they both did wound him mortallyâª
â¢â¢ . E. 4. fol. 71âª And there it is Å¿aid, that where the Count goeth, that they all did Å¿tricke, &c. the Å¿tricking is not t â¢â¢â¢ erÅ¿ab â¢ e. So is it in Appeale of Rape, where one doth the Rape, and the other being preÅ¿ent doth abet him, for there the Count Å¿hall goe that both rauiÅ¿hed her, for Å¿o the Law Å¿aith. In the Å¿ame booke 21. E. 4. in appeale de mort againÅ¿t two, whereof but one appeared; the Plaintiffe declared againÅ¿t him which appeared, and would haue counted againÅ¿t them which made default, that they likewiÅ¿e wo â¢ nded, &c. and the IuÅ¿tices â¢ ade him Å¿peake, but only of him which appearedâª Ga â¢ coigne was of contrary opinion 9. Hen. 4. â¢ o. 2. and with GaÅ¿eoigne agrÃ©e very many preÅ¿idents. But Å¿Ã©e Waits CaÅ¿e Sir Edward Cokes 4. Rep. fol. 47. there ought to bee but one Appeale againÅ¿t all the principle â¢ and acceÅ¿Å¿aries, except where there bee acceÅ¿Å¿aries after the Appeale brought, for there ther may bee another appeale brought againÅ¿t them, for that they could not bee named in the firÅ¿t Writ, and if an Appeale bee brought againÅ¿t diuerÅ¿e, and all but one make default, yet the Plaintiffe ought to count againÅ¿t all, Å¿aith that booke.

div.head: SECT. VIIII. Defence in Appeale.
div.p: THe Defence in Appeale, is that the Defendant came and defended all felonies, awa â¢ ts, aÅ¿Å¿aults, forethinkings, and all that is againÅ¿t the Kings peace, Crowne, and dignity, and pleaded non culpable. E â¢ ponit Å¿e Å¿uper patriam de bono & malo. This is the generall plea, &c.

div.head: SECT. X. Pleas to the Writ.
div.p: AGainÅ¿t the Writ to abate that, may be pleaded falÅ¿e Latine, or want of formeâª And note that none may haue more writs of Appeale than one of one fellony hanging at once. 7. Hen. 7. fol. 6. Yet where there are two Å¿uch Writs hanging, they muÅ¿t not be abated, but by notifying to the Court, that they bee both purÅ¿ued by the Plaintiffe, and that muÅ¿t appeare by Å¿ome â¢ t of his. As that he hath appeared and declared vpon them both. For though one Writ were deliuered to the ViÅ¿count of Record to Å¿erue it, this might be as well the Act of a Å¿tranger as of the Plaintiffe, and therefore no concluÅ¿ion toward â¢ him, but that he may Å¿ay, it was not at his Å¿uit.

So where an Appeale is commenced in the County by bill, remoued to a Court of Record, and there hanging, if now the Plaintiffe purÅ¿ue another appeale of the Å¿ame felony by writ, the appeale by writ abateth: But where the Appeale by briefe is purchaÅ¿ed, before the Appeale by bill remoued out of the County, there the Court ought to Å¿end, for the Appeale in the County without abating the Appeal â¢ which is commenced by Writ, for the Appeale by Writ is more worth than that Appeale commencedâª i â¢ the County, which is not but a ãâã
âª vntill it be remoued in an Appeale againÅ¿t two; â¢â¢â¢ may plead that his companion named with him in the Writ died at Å¿uch a place before the Writ purchaÅ¿ed; or that there was no Å¿uch perÅ¿on in re â¢ um natura, when the Writ was purchaÅ¿ed, as is named with him, for there is no body elÅ¿e to plead theÅ¿e pleas, but only he which appeareth: But he cannot plead, that the partie named with him in the Writ is entred into religion, or is a married woman, &c. for there is another party to plead Å¿o, but in the other caÅ¿es there is none. And in theÅ¿e caÅ¿es of appeales againÅ¿t more than one, an
appeale abated towards one is abated towards all. In appeale where miÅ¿nomer of the Plantiffe is pleaded, if it be confeÅ¿Å¿ed, the Plaintiffe Å¿hall be examined whether it were by couin â¢ or no â¢ The caÅ¿ â¢ is 9. Hen. 5. fol. 1. A woman Å¿ued appeale by name of Cicely, B. whereas her name wasâª Iohan, and after the defendants imparlance â¢ he came and Å¿aidâª her name was Iohan, Å¿hee was examinedâª and it was found to be done Å¿ans couin. ê

It Å¿Ã©emeth in appeales the Defendant may ha â¢â¢ e 1, 2, 3, or 4. or more pleas to the Writ, as well as hee which is Tenant in an AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e may; But then hee muÅ¿t take good hÃ©ed, that one be not Contrary to another. Bracton, Et in omnibus appellis maioribus vel minoribus non poteÅ¿t appellans variare vel â¢ ppellum Å¿uum in aliquo mutare, adiicere tamen poteÅ¿t interdum, vt Å¿i prius non dixerit, quibus armis, &c. poteÅ¿t nominare â¢â¢ ma, Å¿cilicet gladium vel b â¢ Å¿acutum, Et poteÅ¿t, qui actionem ci â¢â¢â¢ iter ãâã mutare eam, & agere criminaliter & Å¿ic accreÅ¿ce â¢â¢ & appellum augere, â¢ ed non contra. In the booke of Entryes fol. 47. the Defendants came in proper perÅ¿on, & defenderunt vi â¢â¢ & iniuriam, quando &c. om â¢ em felloniam & quicquid &c. and they Å¿aid that in the Å¿aid County of W. there were two Townes called M. one old M. and another new M. abÅ¿queâª hoc, that in the County, there was any Towne, Villadge, Hamlet, or place, â¢ nowne and named by the name of M. only, without addition, & hoc p â¢ rat â¢ Å¿unt verificare, vnde petunt iudicium de breue illo & petunt inde allocationem & quoad feloniam praedictam Å¿eperatim dicunt quod ipÅ¿i in nullo Å¿unt inde culpabil â¢ s, & inde de bono & malo ponunt Å¿e Å¿uper patriam. It â¢â¢â¢ found non habebatur aliqua villa, &c. named M. ãâã . Ideo conÅ¿ideratum, vt nihil capiat per bre. and that the Defendants

div.head: SECT. XI. Pleas in Barre of the Action.
div.p: IN Barre of the Action may bee pleaded, that the woman which bringeth the Appeale, &c. hath taken another huÅ¿band, or that Å¿hee was neuer accoupled in loyall matrimony, to him of whoÅ¿e death Å¿hee brings the Appealeâª And if it bee brought by the heire, it is a good plea in Barre, to Å¿ay, the wife of him which is dead, is yet aliue, and the Action giuen to her.

In the booke of Entries fol. 50. Praedicta Alicia dicit quod â¢â¢ mpore mortis praedicti Thomae â¢ adem Alicia fuit v â¢ o â¢ praedicti Thomae, in quo caÅ¿u, â¢ idemâª Aliciae, & non praedicto Nicholao, de â¢ ure pertinet h â¢ bere, & proÅ¿equi appellum, &c. Et v â¢ terius â¢ adem defendens dicit, quod praedictus Nichola â¢ s appellum praedictum verÅ¿us â¢ andem Aliciam inter Alios per couinam ea intentione, ad eam de proÅ¿ecutione appellinus de morte, praedicti Thomae excludendam impetrauit, que oia & Å¿ingula, &c. & petit inde allocationem &c. & quoad felonia, non culpabilis. Et inde, de bono & malo ponit Å¿e Å¿uper patriam. 30. H. 6.

AlÅ¿o it is a good plea in Barre to Å¿ay, that the Plaintiffe hath Å¿ucceaÅ¿ed her time, in that Å¿hee hath not brought her Appeale within the yeere and day after his death, which is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed Å¿laine; or to Å¿ay, that he of whoÅ¿e death the Appeale is brought, is yet aliue at Å¿uch a place, and to bring him in the Court, that hee may bee viewed and knowne; Å¿Ã©e thereof 43. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿. pa. 26. in Appeale de morte viri, the Defendant pleaded le Baron in vi â¢ , &c. and the Plaintiffe contra â¢
day was giuen to bring in their proofes, which, when they came, were found, one both Å¿ides defectiueâª The Defendant therefore, for his Å¿afeÅ¿t way pleaded
â¢ on culpabilis vide â¢ ur ergo, that the firÅ¿t iÅ¿Å¿ue if it had bÃ©ene found againÅ¿t him, Å¿hould haue bÃ©ene peremptacy, and that hee may waiue it before triall, in fauorem vitae.
And note, that if a man plead not guilty, and pute himÅ¿elfe vpon the Iury in an Inditement of felony, and hÃ©e may confeÅ¿Å¿e the fact before verdict and pray a coroner, otherwiÅ¿e in an Appeale as it was holden 11. Hen. 7. 5.

8. Hen. 4. fol. 18. In Appeale de morte viri, and at the day the Baron was brought into Court examined ãâã knowne: and the woman for her falÅ¿e Appeale was committed to priÅ¿on, till Å¿he payd a fine. The generall barres againÅ¿t all Appeales, of which Å¿ome may bee obiected againÅ¿t the Plaintiffe here, are thoÅ¿e, That the Plaintiffe is attainted of felony or treaÅ¿on, or a Monke, or a PrieÅ¿t, a mayhemed body (by Å¿ome other than by the Plaintiffe) or of non Å¿ane memorie, or deafe and dumb, or a lay â¢ r, or a naturall foole. Attainder by outlawry, if it be erronious, is a barre no longer than vntill it bee reuerÅ¿ed; It is a good plea in barre alÅ¿o; that heretofore the Plaintiffe brought an Appeale of the Å¿ame felony, in which Å¿hÃ©e was at non Å¿uit after Declaration, or withdrew her Å¿elfe from her Action: Or that heretofore Å¿hÃ©e Å¿ued Appeale of the Å¿ame fellony againÅ¿t another perÅ¿on, which was acquited or condemned at her Å¿uit. Or the Plaintiffes releaÅ¿e may bee pleaded in barre, if it were made to the Defendant himÅ¿elfe; for releaÅ¿e made to another will not Å¿erue, though it were made to one, ioyned with the Defendant in the Appeale. Corone in Fitzherbert 9. and 2. Rich. 3. 9. agrÃ©es. And Å¿o if the Plaintiffe withdraw her Å¿elfe, as againÅ¿t one of the Defendants, her Appeale Å¿hall Å¿tand good againÅ¿t the other. And note where the Defendant pleads in barre any of theÅ¿e pleas, yet in fauour of ãâã the Law permits him to plead ouer to the fellony, and his pleading Å¿hall not therefore be counted double, exceptin the caÅ¿e of releaÅ¿e, in which indÃ©ed he may not plead to the felony, for not guilty in contrary to accepting of rel â¢â¢â¢â¢ , which â¢â¢ t â¢ li â¢ th guilt. So alÅ¿o of a woman bring Appeale of robery, and the Defendant pleads villenage in the Plaintiffe, hee Å¿hall not conclude ouer to the felony ãâã
culpable, for that were an i â¢ franchiÅ¿ment.

But perchance when the villenage is found againÅ¿t the Defendant, hee may then take his plea of rien culpable as well, as hee Å¿hall haue when hÃ©e plead any other pleas, for if he plead them without concluding to the fellony, hÃ©e may after his barre is found againÅ¿t him plead rien culpable notwithÅ¿tanding. quod vide 28. E. â¢ . fol. 91. 22. E. 3. fol. 38. 18. E. 3. fol. 32. except only in pleas of releaÅ¿e, as is Å¿aid, which implieth alwayes a confeÅ¿Å¿ion of felony. 9. Hen. 4. fol. 2. in Appeale de morte viri, the Defendants pleaded the wiues releaÅ¿e, made Å¿ince the darraine, continuance of all accords, reall and â¢â¢ rÅ¿onall, and Å¿hÃ©e demurred, the beÅ¿t opinion was, t â¢ at reall actions are of things reall and durable, as lands, rents, &c. and perÅ¿onall actions are of dammages and Å¿uch like, yet p Hulls, perÅ¿onall is as well the puniÅ¿hment of the perÅ¿on as dammages, and the puniÅ¿hment here is death, which is releaÅ¿ed & le barre is good.

But Littleton teacheth vs contrary in his booke, for hÃ©e Å¿aith, that Appeales of robery, rape or death, or any Appeale wherein the â¢â¢ dgement is of death, are more high than perÅ¿onall Actions, and therefore they are not barred by releaÅ¿e, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be of all manner of Actions, or of all Appeales.

See Sir Edward Coke in his Commentaries vpon Littleton fol. 287. b. in any Appeale wherein iudgement is of death, a releaÅ¿e of all Actions reall and perÅ¿onall is no barre, for that releaÅ¿e extendeth but to common or ciuill actions, and not to criminall, but if a releaÅ¿e of actions perÅ¿onals is good in an Appeale of mayhem for euery Action wherein dammages are onely recouered, is in Law taken for perÅ¿onall, fol. 288. a. And in Sir Edw. Cokes 4. Rep. in HudÅ¿ons CaÅ¿e it is Å¿aid, although the Appeale of mayhem runneth feloniouÅ¿ly,
â¢ uy mayma, yet he Å¿hall recouer but dammages, and therefore recouery in treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e is a good barre therein.

div.head: SECT. XII. Auterfoits acquit.
div.p: ALthough it be now no plea in Appeale of death, for the Defendant to lay, that he was here to fore acquite of the Å¿ame felonie; yet becauÅ¿e Stanfords handling of it containeth good learning, and it may Å¿till Å¿erue in appeal â¢ of rape: And likewiÅ¿e in Ind â¢ ctments of death, for hÃ©e that was acquite in appeale may haue it: I will not omit it. By Common Law therefore, in all Appeales or Inditements of felony, for the Defendant to Å¿ay, that hÃ©e was A â¢ ter â¢ oirs a â¢ raigne de meÅ¿me le felonie, before â¢ uth IuÅ¿tices, and acquited (vouching the record) is a good plea, and he nÃ©eds not to haue the record in Court, becauÅ¿e this plea is not delatorie, but in barre, Coron. in Fitzherbert, 2 â¢ .

This plea the Common Law diÅ¿alloweth not, becauÅ¿e it alloweth, that a man Å¿hould not put his life in ieopardy twice for one and the Å¿ame offence. The acquitall then muÅ¿t be of the verie Å¿ame offence, or elÅ¿e this plea is to no purpoÅ¿e: Therefore if two men be indited of felony, as principals, and afterward by another Inditement, it is â¢ ound that one of them did the felonie, and the other did feloniouÅ¿ly receiue him; after the felony committed; hÃ©e that is Å¿econdarily indicted and arraigned as acceÅ¿ â¢ ar â¢ e, Å¿hall not be diÅ¿charged, by pleading arraignment, and acquitall vpon the firÅ¿t Inditement; for the offence is not Å¿uppoÅ¿ed the Å¿ame and one, but committed at diuers dayes, 27. AÅ¿Å¿. p. 10. And this for acceÅ¿Å¿aries after the felony: But when felony i â¢ done by force of commanding, and procurement of another, he that Å¿hall be arraigned as acceÅ¿Å¿arie, may plead that he was acquit, &c. though it were as principall, and the offences were at diuers dayes, for, Vulnus, pre â¢ eptum, & factum, Å¿unt quaÅ¿i vnum factum. Yet Stanford noteth the antient Law to haue bÃ©ene
taken otherwiÅ¿e. SÃ©e 8. E. 2. is, PoteÅ¿t quiuis acqui â¢ tari pro morte alicui â¢ s per patriamâª & ho â¢ non obÅ¿tant â¢ ex indictamento, vel Å¿ecta alicuius de â¢â¢ xilio, abetto, v â¢â¢ procuramento, poteÅ¿t Å¿uÅ¿pendi pro morte eiuÅ¿dem. And note that hee that was indicted and arraigned of the death of Iohn at Stile, may plead that hÃ©e was heretofore indicted and acquite of the death of Iohn at Noke, auerring that Iohn at Sti â¢ e and Iohn at Noke were one perÅ¿on. E â¢ Å¿eira diÅ¿c â¢ arge. Fitzherbert Co â¢ one, 189.

So likewiÅ¿e if a man were Å¿laine two yeares Å¿ince, and one which was indicted and acquit of his death, is againe indicted of the Å¿ame mans death, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing that â¢ e killed him this preÅ¿ent yeare; he Å¿hall plead the firÅ¿t acquitall, and bee diÅ¿charged notwithÅ¿tanding the variance; for a man can be Å¿laine but once, and the Court in this ãâã Å¿hall charge the InqueÅ¿t with the time of his death, which is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed Å¿laine, and whether it were the Å¿ame parÅ¿on Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be Å¿laine, by the ãâã Indictment. So likewiÅ¿e if a man be indicted, and acquit in one Countie, and afterward indicted of the Å¿ame death in another Countie, the acquitall at firÅ¿t Å¿hall diÅ¿charge, &c. But in robberis it Å¿Ã©emeth otherwiÅ¿e; for one and the Å¿ame man may be robbed by one other man Å¿ â¢ ndrie tunes; and therefore acquittance of a robberie done at one day, is no diÅ¿charge of a robberie done at another day. Now if a man be indicted of robberie in one Countie, he Å¿hall not plead th â¢â¢
â¢ e was indicted and acquit, of the Å¿ame robberis, in another Countie, 4. H. 7. fol. 5. But it is Å¿aid there, that in appeale of robberie it is a good plea; becauÅ¿e the Plaintiffe is to recouer his goods againe by the Common Law; not Å¿o in Indictments, in the booke at large the Defendants plea is, that hee was indicted of taking the Å¿ame goods, &c. which ãâã Å¿aid â¢ uÅ¿t be take ãââã i â¢ lly for the King, that the Å¿ame goods â¢ ere Å¿hall â¢â¢ twiceâª
ãââã Å¿aid the Count â¢â¢ s ãâã not ioyns in triall of the a â¢â¢ rment de â¢ me â¢â¢ ne â¢â¢ felonie, when one Countie had acquitted him. Fro â¢ ioke Å¿aid, That by the Å¿ame â¢ e â¢ Å¿on, ãâã
