by he might be found culpable in one Countie, of felonie done in another, by the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on acquitall in one Å¿hould diÅ¿charge him in another.

Se â¢
Corone in Fitzherbert, 220 41. aÅ¿Å¿. p. 9. A man indicted in the Kings Bench of rape and robberie, pleaded acquitall at the Countie of Cornwall, at the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿es, and it was adi â¢ dged goodâª Stanford bids vs enquire where the Kings Bench was at the taking of the Indictment, and whether any other Indictment in Cornwall, of that matter, were remoued into the Kings Bench, becauÅ¿e the Booke Å¿aith, one indited in banke le Roy, &c.

YÃ©e muÅ¿t know, that if there were not Å¿ufficient matter of felony in the Indictment or Appeale, vpon which the acquitall was had, auter â¢ orts acquite is no plea, to Å¿tay a man indicted of new from new arraignment, for it fals out vpon the matter, that the parties life was neuer in ie â¢ pardie.

And Å¿o is it if a man be acquite in an erroneous Appeale, which acquitall is reuerÅ¿ed by errour; hee may bÃ©e arraigned at the Kings Å¿uit vpon Indictment; for by the reuerÅ¿all he is become as ne â¢ er acquited. But before re
â¢ erÅ¿all outer â¢ oi â¢ s acqui â¢ e is good plea, and if the errour were onely in the pro â¢ eÅ¿ â¢ e, it is not materiall, for appearance Å¿al â¢ es thoÅ¿e defects: And it Å¿Ã©e â¢â¢ eth alÅ¿o, that hÃ©e which was once acquited in appeale, Å¿hall not anÅ¿wer any more to the Appellant, though the acquitall be reuerÅ¿ed by â¢â¢â¢â¢ ur howÅ¿oeuer, for Å¿o the Court might be deliuered
ãââã
and the Defendants neuer be deliuered.

But if one bring an Appeale, which hath no cauÅ¿e or title to it, as perhaps one which is neither wife nor heire, &c. and the Defendant takes none aduantage of it, but pleads
ãâã , and is acquited, this will no â¢ Å¿erue to ãâã the right heire or wife in their appeale, or the King vpon arraigning him vpon Indictment, or vpon the new Appeale, if the wife or heire be at non Å¿uit therein.

And if one be arraigned vpon Indictment at the Kings Å¿uit and acquited, whereas by order of Common Law,
the King Å¿hould haue Å¿tayed, till the Appeale hanging had bÃ©ene determined. Yet this is no errour, for th â¢ plea of auterfoits acqui â¢ e Å¿hall Å¿erue the Defendant in Appeale well enough. And Auterfoits acqui â¢ e in Appeale is no plea againÅ¿t the King, in an Iindictment of the Å¿ame felony; if the acqui â¢ all were by battaile and not by InqueÅ¿t, 12. E. 2. Corone in Fitzherbert, â¢ 75. For battaile lieth not againÅ¿t the King, a â¢ d therefore that triall againÅ¿t another Å¿hall not binde. Quaere, Å¿aith Stam â¢ ord, for Bracton is contra. Si Ã pluribus appellatus, Å¿it de vno facto & vna pl â¢ ga, & verÅ¿us vnum Å¿e defend â¢ rit recedet quietus verÅ¿us omnes alios appellan â¢ es, & etiam de Å¿ecta regis, quia per hoc purgat innocentiam Å¿uam, &c. Before the Statute 3. H. 7. cap. 1. Whereby Auterfoits acqui â¢ e is become no plea in appeale of death, if a man were indicted of another mans death, the IuÅ¿tices would not arraigne him, (as appeares by recitall of the Statute) till the yeare and day were paÅ¿t. And in Corone Fitzhe â¢â¢ ert, 44. YÃ©e may â¢ ee that in 22. E. 4. the IuÅ¿tices of England aduiÅ¿ed, all men of Law to obÅ¿erue this order and courÅ¿e thorowout the Realme; yet before this time it appeares, 7. H. 4. fol. â¢ 0. & 21. H. 6. fol. 32. That where th â¢ re was no appeale hanging, if Å¿uggeÅ¿tion had beene made to the IuÅ¿tices, that the â¢ uidence was manifeÅ¿t and apparant againÅ¿t the party indicted, they would arraigne and try him vpon the Indictment, al â¢ hough it were within the yeare. LikewiÅ¿e if the Appellant were vnder age, the IuÅ¿tices did vÅ¿e to arraigne and try him that was indicted maintenan â¢ ! For otherwiÅ¿e the partie indicted might cauÅ¿e by Couin, that the Appeale Å¿hould be brought by an Infant vnder age, as perhaps thrÃ©e yeares old, and Å¿o periÅ¿h the Kings Å¿ â¢â¢ t for euer. But all this Å¿eemeth now to be remedied by the Statute, in Appeales which are of death, but other Appeales are left as they were before. The Common Law therefore vnchanged is, that if a man be indicted of robberie, whereof there is an Appeale hanging, and the â¢ ppeale is proceeded Å¿o farre, that the IuÅ¿tices may percei â¢â¢â¢
the felome is all one, they ought to Å¿urceaÅ¿e triall vpon the Indictment, as it is 1. 31. H. 6. fol. 3. For note that in Appeale of robberie when it is by Writ, the robberie cannot be certainly knowen before Declaration. OtherwiÅ¿e it is, if it be commenced by bill, or that the Appeale be of death of a man any.

div.head: SECT. XIII. Auterfoits attainted.
div.p:
THis is a Å¿ore Å¿aying, which Å¿ome men haue to plead for themÅ¿elues, viz. that they are already condemned to be hanged, and aÅ¿ke Iudgement, whether during the Attainder, they Å¿hould anÅ¿wer to the felony whereof they are condemned, or to any other: And this plea Å¿erueth, where the partie condemned hath already forfeited as much as he can forfeit, Å¿o that it is to no purpoÅ¿e to tra â¢â¢â¢â¢ him any further. But in Å¿ome Å¿peciall caÅ¿es, when there is Å¿ome end of it, a man already condemned may bÃ©e arr â¢ igned againe. As if a man attaint of felony, were guiltie of treaÅ¿on alÅ¿o, at the time of the felony committed, hÃ©e may now bee put to anÅ¿wer the treaÅ¿on; becauÅ¿e thereby the King Å¿hall haue the â¢ Å¿cheat of his land, of whomÅ¿oeuer it were holden, 1. H. 6. 5. OtherwiÅ¿e it is if the treaÅ¿on were committed after the felony; or at the leaÅ¿t, if it were after the attainder had of felony; for then the title veÅ¿ted in the Seigniors, before the Kings title, might not be deueÅ¿ted by matter accruing ex poÅ¿t facto. And if diuers men haue diuers Appeales of robberie againÅ¿t one, to the end that euerie man may haue againe his goods, whereof he was robbed, by making freÅ¿h Å¿uit, he Å¿hall bee attaint at euerie one of their Å¿uits. But note (Å¿aith Stamford) in caÅ¿es where the Defendant will diÅ¿charge himÅ¿elfe of anÅ¿wering, by attainder of any other felony, than that whereof he is arraigned; it may be replyed
either for the King or the partie, that Å¿ince the Attainder the King hath pard â¢ ned him the Å¿aid Felonie and Attainder, whereby he is now reÅ¿tored to the Law, and ought to anÅ¿wer to all other felonies, though they were perpetrated before the felony whereof he Å¿aith he was attainted. Titulo Coronae in Fitzherbert, 227. 10. H. 4. &c.

But to the felonie whereof a man is attainted hÃ©e Å¿hall anÅ¿wer no more after he hath his pardon of it. Thus far, Stamford. SÃ©e Brooke, Titulo Coronae, 11. Quaere. Whether a man attainted of felony, and pardoned, Å¿hall anÅ¿wer at the Kings Å¿uit, to other felonies before committed, and whereof he was not indicted at the tune of the Attainder, per aliquos videtur quod ita, as well as at the Å¿uit of the partie in Appeale; yet Å¿ome held otherwiÅ¿e, 10. H. 4. That a man can die but once at the Å¿uit of the King, and he that is pardoned is as a new man, all former Iudgements, as againÅ¿t the King, being determined: Quaere de Appeales, Cor il eÅ¿t â¢ foredure de maintainer Appeale in le caÅ¿e. For all Appeales were determined once by the Iudgement vpon Indictment.

Note that it was reÅ¿olued in Wrote; caÅ¿e, Sir Edw. Cokes 4. Rep. fol. 45. That Auterfoits conuict of manÅ¿laughter vpon an Inditement of murder, and Clergie allowed is a good plea in an Appeale of murder, and that although the conuiction was had hanging the Appeale. But it was alÅ¿o there reÅ¿olued, that if the Inditement vpon which the conuiction was had were inÅ¿ufficient, the offender may, notwithÅ¿tanding that conuiction, bÃ©e indited or appealed againe, for that his life in iudgement of Law was neuer in ieopardie: and Å¿o it was reÅ¿olued alÅ¿o in Vauxes caÅ¿e in the Å¿ame Report.

div.head: SECT. XIV. Clergie.
div.p: IF the Defendant in Appeale craue his Clergie, and the Plaintiffe Å¿ay that he is Bigamus; if he be Å¿o certified it is peremptorie, and he Å¿hall be hanged without pleading OuÅ¿ter to the felony. SÃ©e 11. H. 4. fol. 10. That Clergie is allowed in Appeale de morte viri. In the Booke of Entries, wherein Å¿cil. fol. 5. is the Kings writ to certifie, whether the partie appealed were Bigamus as E. which appealed him of the death of A. her huÅ¿band alleaged: But at this day Bigamus Å¿hall haue his Clergie, by the Statute of 1. Edw. 6.

div.head: SECT. XV. The Kings pardon.
div.p:
IF a woman which bringeth an Appeale de morte viri, let fall her Å¿uit, the Kings Å¿uit is not preiudiced thereby, and if the wife releaÅ¿e all Appeales, and afterward by verdict in Appeale brought by her, the releaÅ¿e is found, the entrie is, De appello praedict' quoad Å¿ectam praedictae Aliciae Å¿it quietus, & quod ipÅ¿e eat inde Å¿ine die, &c. Sed quoad Å¿ectaÌ Dom. Regis in hac parte inÅ¿tante allocutus eÅ¿t qualiter Å¿e velit acquietare, & dicit quod in nullo eÅ¿tinde culpabilis, &c. SÃ©e the Booke of Entries, fol. 47. b. So likewiÅ¿e in Appeale DÃ¨ morte patris, or De morte viri, the Kings pardon cannot take away execution, 13. H. 4. But it is a good plead againÅ¿t the King, when an Appeale is once determined. And if the Appeale be determined not by act of the Appellant, but by act of Law, the Kings pardon Å¿hall not be allowed without the Appellants priuitie. As if the Plaintiffe purÅ¿ue her appeale till the Defendant
be outlawed, by this Outlawrie the appeale is ended: and now if the King pardon the felonie, &c. this pardon Å¿hall not bÃ©e allowed without Scire facias againÅ¿t the partie, at whoÅ¿e Å¿uit the Felon was outlawed. And at the day of Scire facias returned, the partie may appeare, and pray execution, which is grantable, the pardon notwithÅ¿tanding. But if the Sheriffe returne, that hÃ©e warned her to appeare, and Å¿he make default, the pardon Å¿hall be allowed without more adoe. And this Scire facias, vpon pardon granted, may be required againÅ¿t the Appellant, though the AppellÃ©e neuer deÅ¿ire it, and though hee Å¿hew no releaÅ¿e or other matter in diÅ¿charge of the Appeale. For he Å¿hall come timely enough with that, when the other appeares vpon the Scire facias. AlÅ¿o the Scire facias is grantable, though the Charter of pardon haue not the clauÅ¿e. Ita quod Å¿tet rectus in curia.

Vide Fitzherbert. p. 17. titulo Charter, 11. R. 2. In appeale againÅ¿t Principall and AcceÅ¿Å¿arie, the Principall was purÅ¿ued till Outlawry, and Exigent went out againÅ¿t the AcceÅ¿Å¿arie, and at the day of the returne, the Plaintiffe was at non Å¿uit in his Appeale, and then came the Principall with his Charter of pardon, and prayed it might be allowed, becauÅ¿e the Plaintiffe was at non Å¿uit. GaÅ¿coyne made anÅ¿wer, That the non Å¿uit could not help him, for the Appeale had run his full courÅ¿e, and was determined as towards him, by the Outlawrie.

div.head: SECT. XVI. Dammages in Appeale.
div.p:
NOw to draw towards an end of this matter, though a woman cannot be put to triall by battaile in appeale, any more than the King may in his Å¿uits, yet Å¿hÃ©e proÅ¿ecutes appeales, not altogether without danger, as y â¢ e may perceiue by the entrie made in the Booke of Entries,
fol. 49. b. and by the CaÅ¿e 8. Hen. 4. fol. 18. likewiÅ¿e 41. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿. pl. 8. In appeale de morte viri in the Kings Bench, the Plaintiffe was at non Å¿uit after appearance, wherefore it was awarded, that Å¿hee Å¿hould bee taken to pay a fine, and Å¿he came and paid it, the AppellÃ©e was afterward diÅ¿charged, and inquiry made of dammages and abbettours, and two abbettours being found, dammages were taxed to a hundred pounds, and the appellant was not worth aboue a hundred Å¿hillings, yet it was awarded, that the Defendant Å¿hould recouer his dammages taxed at a 100. li. againÅ¿t the woman, and that hee Å¿hould Å¿ue againÅ¿t the abettours if hee would, but no Capias againÅ¿t the woman, becauÅ¿e Å¿he had fined before.

It is by the Common Law, Å¿aith IuÅ¿tire Stanford, that dammages in Appeales of folony are alwayes for the defendant, when hee is acquit, for common reaÅ¿on wils, when a man is put to vndergoe a triall, whereby his lands, goods, life and reputation are all put in hazard, without deÅ¿ert or matter of good foundation, by only the malicious accuÅ¿ation, of his aduerÅ¿ary, and he is found by due acquitall of Law, a loyall true man, that he haue amends againÅ¿t his falÅ¿e AccuÅ¿er, and (if the AccuÅ¿er be himÅ¿elfe inÅ¿ufficient) againÅ¿t them, which procured and abated the Plaintiffe to purÅ¿ue the Appeale, but for Å¿o much as dammages were not recouerable againÅ¿t Procurers and Abbettors, but by originall Writ of conÅ¿piracie, which was no Å¿uch Å¿pÃ©edy redreÅ¿Å¿e or Å¿atiÅ¿faction, as the great miÅ¿chieffouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e of the offence required, a Statute was made for a more quicke remedy.

div.head: SECT. XVII. WeÅ¿t. 2. ca. 1 â¢ .
div.p:
AS followeth. BecauÅ¿e many men of pure malice and purpoÅ¿e to grieue others, procure falÅ¿e appeales,
to bee brought of â¢â¢â¢â¢ cide and other felonies by Appellants, which are nothing worth, and therefore can n â¢ ither anÅ¿wer the King for their falÅ¿ety, nor yÃ©eld dammages to them whom they. Appeale. It is prouided, that if any man be appealed of felony, and acquite himÅ¿elfe in due manner in the Kings Court, at Å¿uit of either the King, or of the Appellour, the IuÅ¿tices before whom Å¿uch Appeale Å¿hall beheard and determined, Å¿hall puniÅ¿h the Appellour by one yeeres impriÅ¿onmentâª and neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿uch Appellours Å¿hall render dammages to the Appeales, according to the IuÅ¿tices diÅ¿cretion, hauing regard to the arreÅ¿t and impriÅ¿onment, which the Appeale hath Å¿uÅ¿tained, and to the Infamy, which by the impriÅ¿onment or otherwiÅ¿e, the AppellÃ© â¢â¢ haue incurred. And neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e they Å¿hall bee grieuouÅ¿ly fined towards the King. And if peraduenture Å¿uch Appellours haue not wherewith to make amends for the dammage aforeÅ¿aid, it Å¿hall bee inquired, by whoÅ¿e abatement the Appeale was malitiouÅ¿ly thus formed, if he which is appealed doe Å¿o require that. And if it bee found by the InguiÅ¿ition, that any man were an Abbettour by malice, he Å¿hall be diÅ¿trained by a Iudiciall Writ at the AppellÃ©es Å¿uit, to come before the IuÅ¿tices; And if he be in â¢â¢â¢ manner conui â¢ ted of abbetting by malice, he Å¿hall be puniÅ¿hed by impriÅ¿onment, and reÅ¿titution of dammages. Å¿icut de AppeÅ¿latore Å¿uperius dictum eÅ¿t. And from henceforth in appeale of death of a man, there Å¿hall lye no eÅ¿Å¿oine for the Appellour, in what Court Å¿oeuer the Appeale Å¿hall bee determined. The Statute is againÅ¿t Appeales by malice, &c. therefore if the Defendant were indicted of felony, before the Appeale Å¿ued (though he be acquit afterward,) he Å¿hall recouer no dammages, for it is to bee intended, that the inditement induced the appeale, and not maliceâª OtherwiÅ¿e it is, if hÃ©e were not indicted till after the appeale commenced, or if there be a variance betwixt the appeales and indictment, as the acquitall of him vpon the one, is no acquitall of him vpon the other, as if he be indited as a principall, and appeales
as an acceÅ¿Å¿ary, vel contra But if the variance be in things of no Å¿ubÅ¿tance, Å¿o that the acquitall in the one bÃ©e an acquitall in the other, there Å¿hall be no dammages. And though the word malice by the letter of the Statute doth Å¿Ã©eme to reach onely to the Appellours and Procurours, yet it is to bee vnderÅ¿tood by the bookes, that it reach as well to the Appellant as to them. And the word felony in the Statute Å¿tretcheth to feloni â¢ s, Å¿o made after this Statute, and ancient felonies made Å¿o before the Statute. Acquited in due manner is as well where the Defendant is acquit by battaile, as if it were by the Corntry, and he is intended acquit by battaile, when the Appellant acknowledgeth in the field his appeale to bee falÅ¿e (which is a kinde of vanquiÅ¿hment) for if the Appellant bee flaine in the field, the dammages are gone; Now there is as well an acquitall in Law, as an acquitall in fait. Therefore if two be appealed, one as principall, and the other as acceÅ¿Å¿ary: the acceÅ¿Å¿ary Å¿hall recouer dammages, vpon acquitall of the principall (if the enqueÅ¿t, which tried the principall, were charged with the acceÅ¿Å¿ary,) though they gaue no verdict of the acceÅ¿Å¿ary, for the acceÅ¿Å¿ary in Å¿uch caÅ¿e may haue by the Common Law his Writ of conÅ¿piracy, as appeares 33. Hen. 6. fol. 2. But if the principall bee acquited, the acceÅ¿Å¿ary neuer appearing, but hanging Å¿till in proceÅ¿Å¿e, he Å¿hall neither recouer dammages by this Statute, nor haue a Writ of ConÅ¿piracy by Common Law, till he come and be acquited by verdict, as appeare â¢
41. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿Å¿. p. 24. vn bone caÅ¿e. If the Defendant barre the Plaintiffe in appeale, hee Å¿hall not recouer dammages, except the barre did acquit him of the felonyâª Therefor â¢ if his plea were baÅ¿tardy in the Plaintiffe, or that he hath an elder brother, or ne vnques accouple in legall m â¢â¢â¢ imonie, and Å¿uch like pleas, although th â¢ Å¿e ple â¢â¢ may diÅ¿charge the appeale as well againÅ¿t the King, as againÅ¿t the party, yet notwithÅ¿tanding any Å¿uch plea in barre, he may be afterward indited, and attaint of the felony, and therefore hee is not to recouer dammages, for th â¢ Å¿e plea â¢â¢ ry
not his innocencie any more, than pleas which are onely in abatement of the Writ. So is it likewiÅ¿e, if the Plaintiffe bee barred vpon a demurrer in Law, and Å¿o, where it is found by verdict akilling Å¿e defendend â¢â¢ , or by miÅ¿aduenture, for this is none acquitall of the felony, in Å¿o much as the Defendant can neuer be clÃ©ered thereof without purchaÅ¿ing his pardon: So is it alÅ¿o, when the Defendant vpon arraignement takes him to his Clergy, and the Court takes an enqueÅ¿t of office, whereby hee is found riens culpable: this is none acquitall, whereby hÃ©e may recouer dammages; for claime of Clergy, is rather by implication, confeÅ¿Å¿ion of felony than otherwiÅ¿e: But hee that will waiue his Clergy, and put himÅ¿elfe in inqueÅ¿t, if he be a quit hee Å¿hall recouer dammages: So if the AppellÃ©e haue both the Kings pardon, and the Appellants releaÅ¿e, and yet he will waiue them, and plead riens culpable, hee Å¿hall recouer dammages, if the Country ac
â¢ uit him, yet hee hath done a matter of record, which by implication acknowledgeth the felony, quoe â¢ e: for if the pardon were by Parliament Å¿ans queÅ¿tion, hee might not waiue it. SÃ©e thereof 11. Hen. 4. fol. 40. He is not acquited debito modo, that is, acquited erroniouÅ¿ly, without dew proceÅ¿Å¿e, As 9. Hen. 5. fol. 2âª the Defendant c â¢ me in by exigent, vpon which the ViÅ¿count had returned ce â¢â¢ corpus, whereas he Å¿hould haue returned exigifeci and the Defendant appearing vpon the exigent, without taking aduantage of the proceÅ¿Å¿e, pleaded riens culpable, to the appeale, and Å¿o was found; but yet he could not get iudgement to recouer dammages, for the cauÅ¿e aforeÅ¿aid quaere. for 19. E. 3. Titulo Corone in Fitzherbert 444. is contra. that errour in the proceÅ¿Å¿e is not materiall, Å¿o long as there is no errour in the Writ of appeale, Declaration or pleadingâª for the Defendant is arraigned vpon the originall, and not vpon the meane proceÅ¿Å¿e.

The Statute Å¿peakes thus, vel ad Å¿ectam domini Regis, vel appellatoris. The Kings Å¿uit here is vnderÅ¿tood in appeale, when after arraignement of the Defendant,
the Appellant hauing declared, is at non Å¿uit, f â¢ r if the Defendant bÃ©e acquit at the Kings Å¿uit vpon an Indictment of the Å¿ame felony, he Å¿hall recouer no dammages.

And the manner of recouering dammages, when acquitall is at the Kings Å¿uit, differeth Å¿ome what â¢â¢ em recouery vpon Å¿uit of the party, &c. for in the firÅ¿t â¢ aÅ¿e hÃ©e which is acquited, Å¿hall recouer no dammages, till he haue Å¿uedâª Å¿cire fac. to bring the Plaintiffe into Court, which by non Å¿uit was become out of Court. But in the other caÅ¿e hee Å¿hall recouer dammages without other proceÅ¿Å¿eâª Titulo Dammages in Fitzherbert 7. 7. Whore the Ca â¢ e was, that the Appellant tooke a huÅ¿band after non Å¿uit, and yet Å¿cire facias was awarded againÅ¿t the woman onely. The Statute is further, that the IuÅ¿tices before whom, &c. Å¿hall puniÅ¿h the Appell â¢ ur, &c. this cannot bÃ©e vnderÅ¿tood by IuÅ¿tices of NiÅ¿i prius, though by the Stat â¢ te 14. Hen. 6. cap. 1. they haue power to giue Iudgement in treaÅ¿on and felony tried before them, and that â¢ s well where the Defendant is acquited, as where hee is attainted; But yet within this Statute they are not, ãâã the plea of the whole appeale is not heard before them, nor any more, Å¿aue only the triall, as you may â¢ Ã©e, 10. E. 4. â¢ o. 14. The Statute is further, that the dammages Å¿hall bee conÅ¿idered, hauing reÅ¿pect to the impriÅ¿o â¢â¢â¢ nt, &c. Therefore if appeale bee againÅ¿t diuers men, and they all are acquited, dammages Å¿hall be taxed to them Å¿euerally, becauÅ¿e perhaps one is more damni â¢ ied than another, for one may be appealed as principall, and an â¢ ther as acceÅ¿Å¿ary, and one may be a Gentleman, and another n â¢â¢â¢ , â¢ . Hen. 5. fol. 1. and 40. E. 3 titulo Dammages in Fitzherbert p. 77. But note that this recouery of dammages is not for euery one, for if an appeale â¢ ee againÅ¿t a Monke, â¢â¢ Feme couert, without the ioyning the Soueraigne or â¢â¢â¢
band, as it muÅ¿t bee, (except the Soueraigne with his Monke, or the Baron with his wife commit â¢â¢ the â¢â¢ l â¢
ny) the Monke or Feme couert Å¿hall recouer no dammages, though they bÃ©e acquit. Titulo Corone in Fitzherbert
276. 22. E. 3. The principall CaÅ¿e was an appeals againÅ¿t a Monke, and the IuÅ¿tices Å¿aid it was all one for Law, if it had boene a Feme couert. quaere. for if an appeale bee againÅ¿t Baron and Feme, which are acquited, dammages Å¿hall bee taxed, and recouery Å¿euerally, viz. The Baron Å¿ole Å¿hall recouer for his owne impriÅ¿onment, and the Baron and Feme ioyntly for the imp â¢â¢ Å¿onment of the wife. The Statute is moreouer, verÅ¿us Dominum regem grauiter redimantur. This fining to the King is neuer, but where the Defendant is to haue dammages alÅ¿o, for otherwiÅ¿e the Plaintiffe Å¿hall not fi â¢ e, but only beeamerced, as 9. Hen. 5. fol. 1. the appeale abated for miÅ¿ â¢ o â¢ mer, and the Plaintiffe was but only amerced. vide 41. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿. Corone 219. the appellant was at non Å¿uit after Declaration, and the Court preÅ¿ently awarded proceÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t the Appellant, to c â¢ me and make fine, agrÃ©eing that if the party were afterward acquit, at the Kings Å¿uit, Å¿o that hÃ©e recouered dammages againÅ¿t the Appellant, yet Å¿hÃ©e Å¿hould not pay a new fine. Put the ca â¢ e therefore, that at the Kings Å¿uit the Defendant had bÃ©ene found culpable of the felony, what remedy there might be, for the Plaintiffe to recouer his fine againe, which hee payd before noone, as it Å¿ â¢â¢
meth, for it Å¿Ã©emes the Plaintiffe which is at non Å¿uit in the appeale, Å¿hall pay a fine by the Common Law, and this was the cauÅ¿e why they awarded it to bÃ©e payd maintenant. Then for enquiry of Abbettours, &c. Cum appellatores non habeant vnde praedicta dam â¢ a reÅ¿titue â¢â¢ , inquiratur per quorum abettum. TheÅ¿e words imply, that if dammages be not by Law recouerable againÅ¿t the Appellours, there Å¿hall be none enquiry of Abbettours. And where the Statute is, that if the Appellants are not able to reÅ¿tore dammages, it is intendible all the dammages, for if the Appellant bee Å¿ufficient to render part, but n â¢ t all the dammages, enquiry Å¿hall be of the Abbettors, and they Å¿hall be charged. 8. E. 4. fol. 3. & 8. Hen. 5. & 219. â¢ itulo Corone in Fitzherbert. The Statute is, Å¿hoppellatus hoc petat. Of office only therefore, and without requeÅ¿t,
as it Å¿hould Å¿Ã©eme, the Court cannot enquire of Abbettors. And
â¢ 8. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿. 222. titulo Corone. where they â¢ ad enquired of Abbettors, at the deÅ¿ire of one Defendant, and they found none, and afterwards another of the Defendants, being acquited, prayed enquiry likewiÅ¿e, it might not bee obtained, becauÅ¿e it appeared by the firÅ¿t verdict, that there were none Abbettors, there rem ined therefore no more to be enquired o â¢ , but what dammages were Å¿uÅ¿teined. This Stamford affirmes to b â¢ e in appearance againÅ¿t Law, for Å¿aith hee, it is againÅ¿t the words of the Statute, and againÅ¿t reaÅ¿on, for what reaÅ¿on is it, that a man Å¿hould bee bound by an enqueÅ¿t, whereunto he is not priuy, and againÅ¿t which hÃ©e can haue no remedy, becauÅ¿e it was but an enqueÅ¿t of offi â¢ e, for albeit that commonly the enquiry of Abbettors, is by the Å¿ame enqueÅ¿t that acquited the Defendant, yet their enquiry in this point is but of office, for if they finde Abbettors, theÅ¿e Abbettors when they come may trauerÅ¿e all that is found in this point; As if it be found, that the Appellant is not Å¿ufficient, and A. and B. were Abbettors, A. and B. may come and Å¿ay by proteÅ¿tation, not knowing the felony for plea, that the Appellant is Å¿ufficient, or that they neuer abetted. 8. E. 4. fol. 3. and the words, S â¢ legitimo mod â¢ conuictus fuerit de huiuÅ¿ â¢ odi abbe â¢ to per ma â¢â¢â¢ iam, proue alÅ¿o that anÅ¿wer is allowed, to that which is found by the enqueÅ¿t. And note that it is a good anÅ¿wer for the Abbettor to Å¿hew matter, wherefore the Defendant ought not to haue dammages, or to Å¿hew that hee was acquited, not lawfully, bu â¢ erroniouÅ¿ly. But the Abbettors Å¿hall not take exception, againÅ¿t the InquiÅ¿ition, for that it is not found at what day, yeere, or place they abetted, for the Abe â¢ nent Å¿imply found Å¿atiÅ¿fieth the Statute, which willeth, v â¢ inquiratur per quorum abe â¢â¢ um. And when that it is once found, the Defendant may Å¿upply that which wanteth, adding to the inquiÅ¿ition, the yÃ©ere, day and pla â¢â¢ .
â¢ i â¢ ulo Corone in Fitzherbert 45. 22. E. 4. By the words, per br â¢ ue de iudicto ad Å¿ectam appellati diÅ¿tringantur all
veni â¢ ndum coram IuÅ¿ticiariis, &c. And the proceÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hould Å¿Ã©eme to bee diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e infinite. But Titulo Corone, 102. the Court awarded firÅ¿t a Venire facias, & then DiÅ¿ â¢ reÅ¿Å¿e, which courÅ¿e hath little authoritie for it, for all the other Bookes giue a D â¢ Å¿tring as for the firÅ¿t ProceÅ¿Å¿e, which is alwayes Å¿ued out by him which is acquited. And for his better Å¿pÃ©ed, he may purÅ¿ue this if he will, though the Appellant bÃ©e not in Court. As if the Appellant bÃ©e at non Å¿uit, and the Defendant arraigned at the Kings Å¿uit is acquited, his dammages taxed, and his Abbettors found, now he may haue ProceÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t the Abettors maintenant, though the Iudgement of dammages bÃ©e Å¿uÅ¿pended till Scire facias
â¢ e Å¿ued, and returned againÅ¿t the Appellant: and note if the Defendant which is acquited in an Appeale, be non Å¿uit in his ProceÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t the Abettors, this is not peremptorie, but he may commence proceÅ¿Å¿e againe of new, if he will, Corone, 386. And 3. E. 2. titulo Action Å¿ur le Statute, 28. An originall Writ brought for Abetment and Declaration againÅ¿t the Abettors, for greater dammages than were aÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed in the Appeale is awarded good. For of dammages taxed in Appeale, there lyeth no attaint, becauÅ¿e the EnqueÅ¿t, as to the dammages, is but of office, and the Defendant cannot compell the IuÅ¿tices to encreaÅ¿e dammages, therefore it is reaÅ¿on that he aid himÅ¿elfe by Action. So Å¿aith Stamford.

div.head: SECT. XVIII. Of the old Law.
div.p:
I Haue waded further into this vindicatiue Action than I thought to haue done, and yet not touched what the Princes warrant of a mans life may auaile him, againÅ¿t the inÅ¿tant appeale of a widdow. I know one or two that are thought to be buckled againÅ¿t Appellants, by a leaÅ¿e of their owne liues from the King; but how tr â¢â¢ it is, or
how contording with Law, I know not: HowÅ¿oeuer it be, I aduiÅ¿e a widdow, that is full of Å¿plÃ©ene for the Å¿laughter of her huÅ¿band, to read ouer mine inÅ¿tructions here, to a â¢â¢ a â¢ choller, and then if compoÅ¿ition be offered, not to refuÅ¿e it. For firÅ¿t I doe you to wÃ©et, that appeales d â¢ mor â¢ are but Å¿lipperie Actions. Be iudged by the caÅ¿e, 33. H. â¢ . Dyer â¢ ol. 50 Warnforo of the Temple was Å¿ued in an appeale of murder: the Writ was, Ad reÅ¿pondendum A. B. alias dictâª A. B. fra â¢â¢â¢ & haetedi, to him that was murdered, and the Defendant was diÅ¿charged, becauÅ¿e the Plaintiffe was not named brother and heire in the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Writ, but onely in the Alias dict â¢ , for it ought to haue b â¢â¢ ne, Ad reÅ¿pondendum A. B fratri & â¢â¢â¢â¢
âª redi, alias d â¢ ct â¢ , &c. This was the chiefe cauÅ¿e why the Defendant was diÅ¿charged. Then, I Å¿ay, it is a more ChriÅ¿tian thing to take fiue hundred po â¢ nds of a mankiller, for a releaÅ¿e, leauing him to agree with the King for his necke, as good cheape as he can, than to Å¿Ã©eke bloud and death (though of one which hath deÅ¿erued it) in anger, malice, and reuengefulneÅ¿Å¿e. LaÅ¿t of all I affirme, that it agrÃ©eth with the eldeÅ¿t cuÅ¿tome, and ancienteÅ¿t EngliÅ¿h Lawes. For that which learned M. Lamberd in one place Å¿peaketh but as coniecturall, is (me thinketh) true without all peraduenture. Id â¢ Å¿t, that this forme of procÃ©eding againÅ¿t an homicide giuen to the dead mans heire, or widdow, is a â¢ euengefull Action firÅ¿t giuen to appeaÅ¿e Å¿uch quarrels and capitall enmities of families and kindreds, as the Northerne men yet vÅ¿e and call F â¢ awds, which heretofore (but a long time Å¿ince) were generall, and ouerÅ¿pread the Realme. So that an Appeale du mort, is but an image of deadly Feawd. The inducements to thinke Å¿o are theÅ¿e. The action of Appeale is preferred before the Kings action: the offer of triall by the Appellant, by Bracton is, per corpus, &c. & Å¿i de eo male contigerit per corpus fratris, &c. And the ancient vÅ¿e was, when the AppellÃ©e condemned went to execution, that all they which were of bloud to him that was murdred, Å¿hould
draw the man-flayer to the gallowes, by a long rope, or cord, to Å¿hew loue to their kinÅ¿man, and deÅ¿ire of reuenge, per Bromley in Plowdens Commentarie, 306. And 11. H. 4. fol. 12. When T â¢ rwit had affirmed, that by the ancient Law in Appeales de mott, the dead manâª kindred and his wife Å¿hould draw the Felon to execution. GaÅ¿ â¢ olgne added, Hoc â¢ uit in diebus noÅ¿tris. By theÅ¿e dayes Appeales de mort Å¿hewed, by their outward face and phiÅ¿nomie, from whence they Å¿prung. But by the old Lawes of King Inas, King Edmun â¢ , and the reÅ¿t, yee Å¿hall plainly perceiue, that Feawd was their mother, and that money was the quencher of the quarrell, verie often, if not alwayes. See therefore in M. Lamberds Booke, DepriÅ¿cis legibus, the Law 7 â¢ . of Inas: If a bond man kill an EngliÅ¿hman, his Lord Å¿hall deliuer him into the hands of the Lord or kinÅ¿man of him which is Å¿laine, or redÃ©eme him at Å¿ixtie Å¿hillings: If the Lord will not pay the money, he Å¿hall at the leaÅ¿t emancipate his bondman, and the kinÅ¿man of the murderer Å¿o emancipate, may vndertake for him, to pay the price of him which is dead. If hÃ©e haue no kinÅ¿man that will doe Å¿o much for him, Metuat Å¿ibi malum ab aduerÅ¿ar â¢ is, Let him be at the hazard of his enemies. And I haue read an old Law which I cannot finde againe, Parentibus occiÅ¿i fiat emendatio, vel guerra eorum portetur. But in the Å¿ame booke, De priÅ¿cis Legibus, yÃ©e may finde that King Edmund, which reigned an hundred yeares and more before the ConqueÅ¿t by the aduice of Odo of Canterburie, and the ArchbiÅ¿hop WolÅ¿tan of Yorke, with many other of the Clergie and Laytie, made Lawes, amongÅ¿t which one hath this Preface; Etenim nos omnes harum taedet pugnarum quotidianarum: and therefore we ordaine as followeth.

div.head: SECT. XIX. King Edmunds Law.
div.p:
IF any man hereafter doe kill another man, hÃ©e alone Å¿hall take vpon him, and Å¿uÅ¿taine the deadly enmitie of the dead mans kindred, vnleÅ¿Å¿e he can by the helpe of his friends pay the whole price and eÅ¿timation of his head, whom he hath killed, (what condition Å¿oeuer he were of) and that within the Å¿pace of twelue monethsâª If his kindred forÅ¿ake him, and refuÅ¿e to pay any thing for him, hÃ©e alone Å¿hall beare the quarrell, and his kinÅ¿men Å¿hall not be reputed as enemies: But if they giue him Å¿uÅ¿tenance, or haue any peace and Å¿ocietie with him, he that doth Å¿o Å¿hall forfeit all that he hath to the King, and bÃ©e taken alÅ¿o as an enemie â¢ o the blood: But otherwiÅ¿e, if any man to reuenge his kinÅ¿mans death, purÅ¿ue and kill any one, but only the firÅ¿t murderer, he Å¿hall loÅ¿e all that he hath to the King, and be dÃ©emed an enemie to the King, and to all that loue him. This Statute abridges
â¢ eawds excepteth the Felon â¢ kindred, forbidding to kill in Withernam, and for money it Å¿Ã©emes the
â¢ eawd was Å¿tripped.

div.head: SECT. XX. Of Rape.
div.p:
CHu â¢â¢ now whether yÃ©e will imagine, that the widdow hath agrÃ©ed with him which was her huÅ¿band â¢ bane, or that Å¿he hath purÅ¿ued him to death: She remaineth from henceforth a widdow, giuing her Å¿elfe to almes and dÃ©eds of charitie, and of this good minde are many of our widdowes, which purpoÅ¿e conÅ¿tantly to liue out the reÅ¿idue of their dayes in a deuout remembrance of their
deare huÅ¿bands departed, to whom perhaps they made vowes neuer to marrie againe after their deaths. But to what purpoÅ¿e is it for women to make vowes, when men haue Å¿o many millions of wayes to make them break them? And when Å¿wÃ©et words, faire promiÅ¿es, tempting, Å¿lattering, Å¿wearing, lying will not Å¿erue to beg â¢ ile the poore Å¿oule: then with rough handling, violence, and plaine Å¿trength of a â¢ mes, they are, or haue bÃ©ene heretofore, rather made priÅ¿oners to luÅ¿ts thÃ©eues, than wiues and companions to faithfull honeÅ¿t louers: So drunken are men with their owne luÅ¿ts, and the poyÅ¿on of Ouids falÅ¿e precept,
div.q: Vim licet appellant, vis eÅ¿t ea grata puellis.
div.p: That if the rampier of Lawes were not betwixt women and their harmes, I verily thinke none of them, being aboue twelue yeares of age, and vnder an hundred, being either faire or rich, Å¿hould be able to eÅ¿cape rauiÅ¿hing.

This is therefore a matter concerning maids, wiues, widdowes, and women of all degrees and conditions, if either they be, or poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e any thing worth the hauing, and becauÅ¿e the ignorance of Law may here turne a mollifying heart to harme, I were to blame, if I left my Schollers without warning to take hÃ©ed.

div.head: SECT. XXI. RauiÅ¿hment i â¢ in two Å¿orts.
div.p:
THere are two kindes of Rape, of which though the â¢â¢â¢ be called by the com â¢â¢â¢ people, and by the Law it Å¿elfe, RauiÅ¿hment; yet in my conceit it borroweth the name from r â¢ pere, but vnproperly, for it is no more but Species Å¿tup â¢â¢ , a hideous hatefull kinde of whoredome in him which committeth it, when a wom â¢ n is enforced violently to Å¿uÅ¿taine the furie of brutiÅ¿h conc â¢ piÅ¿cence: but Å¿he is left where Å¿he is found, as in her owne houÅ¿e or
bed, as Lucrece was, and not hurried away, as Helen by Paris, or as the Sabine women were by the Romans, for that is both by nature of the word, and definition of the matter: The Å¿econd and right rauiÅ¿hment, Cum quis leoneÅ¿tae f â¢ mae Å¿oeminam, Å¿iue virgo, Å¿iue vidua, Å¿iue Å¿anctimonialis Å¿it inuitis illis in quorum eÅ¿t poteÅ¿tate, abducit. Neque refert, an quis (volente vel nolente rapta) id faciat, nam vis quae Parentibus vel Curatoribus fit, moxime Å¿pectat. It Å¿eemeth the firÅ¿t kinde of rape deÅ¿erued alwayes death by Gods Lawes, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the woman rauiÅ¿hed were vnbetrothed, Å¿o that the rauiÅ¿her might marrie her, as you may read Deuteronomy, chap. 22. verÅ¿. 23. and by the Ciuill Law. Raptores, in the Å¿econd kinde, Å¿ubjiciebantur poenae mortis rapta Å¿i fue â¢ t ingenua. How hainous they bÃ©e both, and haue a long time bÃ©ene, by the Lawes of England, yÃ©e Å¿hall now perceiue.

div.head: SECT. XXII. The old Law of libidinous Rape.
div.p:
BRacton in the eight and twentieth Chapter of his third Booke Å¿heweth, that by the antique Law of King AdelÅ¿tan, Hee that mÃ©eting a virgin Å¿ole, or with company, did but touch her vnhoneÅ¿tly, was guiltie of breaking the Kings Edict, Et emendabit Å¿ecundum iudicium comitat. If againÅ¿t her will hÃ©e threw her on the ground, hÃ©e loÅ¿t the Kings fauour; if he diÅ¿couered her, and caÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe vpon her, he loÅ¿t all his poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions; if he lay with her, he Å¿uffered iudgement of life and member: yea, if he were an horÅ¿e man, his horÅ¿e loÅ¿t his ta â¢ le and maine, (as Stamford citeth it to be, lib. 2.) and â¢ raine. And the virgin had in recompence all his land & money by the Kings warrant. This was in King AdelÅ¿tanes dayes, at leaÅ¿t an hundred and twentie yeares before the ConqueÅ¿t, when
â¢ o â¢ roprores v â¢ ig nitatis & caÅ¿ti â¢â¢ tis were hanged, and their fautors alÅ¿o. Before whom, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the offender aid himÅ¿elfe by exception, that the Appellant was Å¿till a virgin, (which was tried by inÅ¿pection of women) and if Å¿he were found a virgin, the Appellant was impriÅ¿oned for her Å¿lander, or that he held her before times as his Concubine, or that Å¿he conÅ¿ented to his imbracements, or Å¿ome other like plea, he l â¢ Å¿t his eyes and Å¿tones, for they calorem Å¿ â¢ up â¢â¢ induxerunt. Except the woman before iudgement giuen, demanded him for her huÅ¿band, for that was onely in the womans election, and not in the mans, becauÅ¿e of the inconuenience which otherwiÅ¿e might haue happened, if Å¿ome hardy Å¿trong Leacher had rauiÅ¿hed a Dame noble, or of great birth, he Å¿hould either goe away vnpuniÅ¿hed, or elÅ¿e by meanes of one pollution, perpetually deÅ¿ire her, to the diÅ¿grace of her whole Å¿tocke. Thus farre Bracton. And in the Booke, De priÅ¿cis l â¢ gibus, it is Å¿ â¢ t downe for a Law made by King William the Conquerour; Interdico ne quis occida â¢ ur vel Å¿uÅ¿pendatur pro aliquo culpa, Å¿ed eruantur oculi, &c abÅ¿e â¢ ndantur teÅ¿ticuli, vel pedes vel manus, ita vt truncus vivus remare â¢ t, in Å¿ignum proditionis vel nequitiae. I command that from henceforth no man bee hanged, or put to death for any tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion, but let the offenders eyes be pulled out, or his Å¿tones, fÃ©et, or hands cut away, that the trunke or mutilate body Å¿till left aliue, may remaine as a teÅ¿timony of
his prodition and lewdneÅ¿Å¿e. Now if this mangling Law of King William were Å¿till in force in Bractons time againÅ¿t rauiÅ¿hers, was it Mag. Chart. cap. 29. Or what was it that made the Law Å¿o mÃ©eke in Edward the firÅ¿t his timeâª that the firÅ¿t Statute againÅ¿t Rape, Å¿peaketh of it Å¿o mildly, as if it had bÃ©ene at Common Law a verie Å¿mall treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e.

div.head: SECT. XXIII. WeÅ¿t. 1. cap. 14. anno 3. E. 1.
div.p:
THe King commands, that no man rauiÅ¿h or take by force any damÅ¿ell within age, either with her conÅ¿ent or without. Nor any dame or damÅ¿ell (of Å¿ull age) or other mans wife, againÅ¿t her will. If any doe, the King will doe iuÅ¿tice and common right, at his or her Å¿uit, that Å¿hall Å¿ue within 40. dayes, if none commence Å¿uit within 40. dayes, the King Å¿hall haue the Å¿uit, they which are culpable Å¿hall bee impriÅ¿oned two yÃ©eres, and bee ranÅ¿omed at the Kings pleaÅ¿ure. And if they haue not to Å¿atiÅ¿fie the ranÅ¿ome, they Å¿hall Å¿uffer a longer impriÅ¿onment, as the treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hall require, a man may well Å¿uÅ¿pect that there was Å¿omething, which had allayed the rigour of former Law, before this Statute was made. div.head: SECT. XXIV. WeÅ¿t. 2. cap. â¢ 5.
div.p: THe mitigation of the old Law, one way or other, in a few yÃ©eres brought forth Å¿o many enormities, That at the next Parliament, which King Edw. held ten yÃ©eres after, it was ordeined as followeth.

div.head: SECT. XXV. 6. Richard. 2. cap. 6.
div.p:
A Man would haue thought, that this Statute Å¿hould haue repreÅ¿Å¿ed for euer, all violence towards the perÅ¿ons of women, but quantos motos Å¿cies, reclamante ratione, Priape: In the Å¿ixt yÃ©ere of King Richards reigne, and about the 16th. of his age, this villany of rape was

AgainÅ¿t rauiÅ¿hers of Ladies and daughters of Noble men, and other women in euery part of the Realme, now a dayes more violently offending, and oftener than was wont; It is ordained, that whereÅ¿oeuer, and whenÅ¿oeuer Å¿uch Ladies, daughters, or other women bee rauiÅ¿hed, and after rape doe conÅ¿ent â¢ o Å¿uch reuiÅ¿hers, that as well the rauiÅ¿hers, as they which be rauiÅ¿hed, bee from henceforth diÅ¿abled, to haue or challenge Heritage, Dower or Iointfeoffement after the death of their huÅ¿bands; and anceÅ¿tors. And that incontinently the ne â¢ t of the bloud of thoÅ¿e rauiÅ¿hers, or of t â¢ em that bÃ©e Å¿o rauiÅ¿hed, to whom Å¿uch Heritage, Dower or Iointfeoffement ought to reuert, remaine, or fall, after the death of the rauiÅ¿her, or of her that is Å¿o rauiÅ¿hed, Å¿hall haue title m â¢â¢ ntinently after the rape, to enter vpon the rauiÅ¿her, or her that is rauiÅ¿hed, and their AÅ¿Å¿ignes and lands, tenements, in the Å¿ame heritage, Dower, or Iointfeoffement, and the Å¿ame to hold in Å¿tate of Heritage.

This is a Å¿hrewd Statute. Till this time he that had rauiÅ¿hed a woman might hope for a clemencie, at the leaÅ¿t at her hands, becauÅ¿e he had ventured his life for her Å¿ake, but what Å¿hall luÅ¿ty leachers now doe? the more a woman is worthy to bee won, becauÅ¿e Å¿hee hath or Å¿hall haue
wherewith to kÃ©epe a man, the more danger it is to medle with her. She that perhaps might haue b â¢ ene perÅ¿waded, (had this Statute not ãâã ) to ãâã a matter of greater aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment, then ãâã bares not now be mercifull, leÅ¿t Å¿h â¢ e b â¢ e cruell to herÅ¿elfe. Therefore now men looke on faire Gentlewomen, heires, and widdowes, as the ea â¢â¢ looketh at a fiÅ¿h in the water, Å¿he would ãâã

THerefore in the 31. y â¢ ere of Hen. 6. was a Statute made, beginning with complaint, that in all parts of the Realme, diuers people of power, moued by ãââã couÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, againÅ¿t all right and gentleneÅ¿Å¿e, had ãâã new ãâã , to the danger, trouble, ãâââã of Ladies, Gentlewomen, and other women Å¿ole, hauing Å¿ubÅ¿tance of â¢â¢ nd, tenements, or moueable goods, ãâã then great innocency and Å¿implicity, wiÅ¿hing to take them by force, or otherwiÅ¿e come to them, Å¿eeming to be their great friends, promiÅ¿ing them the â¢ r faithfull loues, and to by great ãâã , they caught them into their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, co â¢â¢â¢ ying them into places where the Offenders were of power, not Å¿uffering them once gotten into their gouernance, to g â¢â¢ a â¢ liberty, till they h â¢ d bound them by Obligation or Statute merchant, and enforced them to marry againÅ¿t their owne liking, otherwiÅ¿e they would leuy the Å¿aid Å¿umme in the Å¿aid Obligation or Statutes, to preuent danger of forfeiture of the

The purueyance of this Statute, is but a Grant of a Writ, whereby to call before the Chancellor, or before the IuÅ¿tices of AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿es in the County, or before Å¿ome other noble perÅ¿ons, aÅ¿Å¿igned by the Chancellor of England, the perÅ¿ons offending, to make void the Obligation or Statute, if there be cauÅ¿e, with a Å¿euere penalty of 300. li to bee forfeited by the Sheriffe, if hee did not execute Å¿he Å¿ame Writ duly, according to the tenure thereof. This Statute was too mÃ©eke and gentle, Å¿omething like him that made it. H. 6.

div.head: SECT. XXVII. 3. H. 7. c. 2.
div.p: BVt 3. Hen 7. cap. 2. beginning with a better complaint againÅ¿t takers for lucre, of maids, widdowes, or wiues hauing Å¿ubÅ¿tance of lands or goods, or being heires apparant, which takers Å¿ometimes married them, and Å¿ometime deÅ¿ â¢ owred them, to the breach of Gods Law, and the Kings, the diÅ¿paragement of Å¿uch women, and vtter heauineÅ¿Å¿e and diÅ¿comfort of their friends, ordaineth, that whoÅ¿oeuer taketh againÅ¿t her will vnlawfully, any maid, widdow, or wife, Å¿hall together with the procurors, abbetters and receiuers of any Å¿uch women (knowing her to bee Å¿o taken againÅ¿t her will,) bee felous, and euery of them bÃ©ene reputed and iudged as felons principall. div.head: SECT. XXVIII. 4. & 5. Phi. & Mar. cap. 8.
div.p:
THerefore to Å¿upply what hitherto was wanting againÅ¿t takers, and alÅ¿o intiÅ¿ers, rauiÅ¿hing by allurements and flatterers, 4. & 5. Phil. & Mar. cap. 8. Å¿aith, that for want of Å¿ufficient Law, it remained Å¿till a faml â¢ ar and common miÅ¿chiefe in the Realme; That maidens and women children of Noble men, Gentlemen, and others, which were heires apparant, or had lands in great Å¿ubÅ¿tance left by their AnceÅ¿tors or friends, by flattery, trifling gifts, or faire promiÅ¿es of light perÅ¿ons, and alÅ¿o by Å¿ubtility of Å¿uch as bought and Å¿old them for reward, were many times allured to contract matrimony with vnthrifty perÅ¿ons, and thereupon oftentimes with Å¿leight or force were taken from their parents, friends or kinÅ¿ â¢ olke, to the high diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure of God, the diÅ¿paragement of the children, and perpetuall condolence of their friends; Therefore it is ordained, that it Å¿hall not bee lawfull to conuey any maid or woman child, vnmarried, or vnder the age of Å¿ixteene yÃ©eres, out of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and againÅ¿t the will of her father, or of Å¿uch perÅ¿on, to whom by his will or otherwiÅ¿e in his life time, he Å¿hall haue appointed the kÃ©eping, education and gouernance of her, except Å¿uch taking, as Å¿hall bee without fraud by the MaÅ¿ter or MiÅ¿tris, or Gardian in So â¢ age, or in Chiualry, of or to Å¿uch maid or woman child. And if any perÅ¿on that is aboue the age of fourtÃ©ene yÃ©eres, Å¿hall conuey, or cauÅ¿e to bee conueyed, any Å¿uch maid being within the age of Å¿ixtÃ©ene yÃ©eres, out of the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion, and againÅ¿t the will of the father or mother, or any other perÅ¿on which then Å¿hall haue by lawfull meanes, the order, keeping, education, or gouernance of her, the offender duly attainted or conuicted (other than Å¿uch, of whom Å¿hee Å¿hall hold by knights Å¿eruice,) Å¿hall Å¿uffer two yÃ©eres impriÅ¿onment, without
baile or mainpriÅ¿e, or par Å¿uch fine, as Å¿hall bee aÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿ed by the QuÃ©enes Councell in the Starchamber.

div.head: SECT. XXXVIII. The Statute 18. Eliz. cap. 7.
div.p:
I Am at the end of my voyage; but before I take Å¿hore I will â¢ hew you how our late moÅ¿t excellent Lawgiuer, renowned QuÃ©ene Elizabeth, (whoÅ¿e vigilant care hath alwayes bÃ©ene, that all her people might liue vnder her in peace, and without oppreÅ¿Å¿ion) hath giuen Å¿trength and perfection to the former functions of other Princes, to make them a firme bulwarke againÅ¿t all manner of iniurers that poÅ¿Å¿ibly might oppreÅ¿Å¿e women; and
